webTitle: Jeffers rejects Everton offer to double wages

fields.headline: Jeffers rejects Everton offer to double wages
fields.trailText: Everton are all but resigned to losing Francis Jeffers after the 20-year-old striker spurned the most lucrative contract ever offered to one of their players.
fields.body:
Everton are all but resigned to losing Francis Jeffers after the gifted, young striker spurned the most lucrative contract ever offered to one of their players. The England Under-21 international has rejected a five-year deal which would have netted him around £8m.

Had the 20-year-old agreed to stay at the club he has supported since childhood, his pay would immediately have doubled to £20,000 a week and eventually risen to £30,000 a week.

But Jeffers has twice rejected the offer, insisting that, for the time being at least, he wished to keep his options open.

Although the Everton board and team manager Walter Smith are desperate to ensure Jeffers remains at Goodison Park, it would now seem that the player is intent on leaving.

Tottenham's manager George Graham was in the Netherlands on Sunday to watch the £5m-rated striker Jan Vennegoor of Hesselink.

Graham saw the 22-year-old Twente Enschede player score his 13th goal of the season in a 5-1 defeat by Sparta Rotterdam and Vennegoor said: "Tottenham are a great club and I've always fancied the Premiership. But right now I really don't know yet where I will be playing next season."

Birmingham City have told the former Liverpool full-back David Burrows he is free to leave the club following a pre-Worthington Cup final disagreement with the manager Trevor Francis.

The 32-year-old Burrows was desperate to play against his former club because he wanted the chance to complete his set of winners' medals in domestic competitions. But after learning he was to play no part in the game at Cardiff's Millennium stadium he was involved in an angry confrontation with Francis.

webTitle: Smith rules out return to terraces

fields.headline: Smith rules out return to terraces
fields.trailText: The government yesterday ruled out the reintroduction of terracing at Premiership football grounds after an official report claimed it could lead to a return to widescale hooliganism, be too unsafe and too costly for clubs.
fields.body:
The government yesterday ruled out the reintroduction of terracing at Premiership football grounds after an official report claimed it could lead to a return to widescale hooliganism, be too unsafe and too costly for clubs.

The report by the Football Licensing Authority, the government-appointed body that supervises the safety of English football grounds, was commissioned by the sports minister Kate Hoey, who provoked controversy after she called for a return to standing areas.

Hoey made her comments, which contradicted government policy, just before Christmas, angering football officials, fellow politicians and relatives of those killed in the Hillsborough disaster. She suggested copying technology in use in Germany.

Chris Smith, the secretary of state for media, culture and sport, to whom Hoey reports, said in a statement last night: "The team of experts concluded that the accommodation arrangements at Hamburg would not be appropriate in UK conditions, and that it is doubtful that existing UK stadia could be converted to accommodate German practice without compromising safety standards.

"The government does not think that German stadia are unsafe. However, for good historical reasons, UK grounds have the highest standards of spectator safety in the world.

"Having considered the authority's expert advice, the government has concluded that safety must remain the primary consideration, and remains convinced that the current arrangements are the best. The government will, of course, continue to keep abreast of the latest in stadium technology."

FLA officials visited Hamburg's Volkspark stadium last month, where large standing areas can be converted to seating. Football fans stand during German league games but have to sit during European matches, according to Uefa guidelines in what are known as "kombi" seats.

The report claims that similar standing areas would prove to be too unsafe in England and that during the visit to Hamburg it found serious congestion with fans standing three-to-four deep in gangways.

Crucially, the report found a completely different fan culture in Germany compared to England which minimised risks in standing areas. In Germany, notes the report, there was no last-minute rush close to kick-off by supporters attempting to gain entry and rival fans mixed together with no hostile chanting, segregation or drunken behaviour. The report points out that this is not the case in England.

Convertible standing areas would also be costly. The report states that kombi seating in Germany costs £90 per seat to buy and install compared to £21 for seats in England.

The report notes: "The Hamburg kombi seat system could not be physically installed in any existing Premiership or Football League ground, primarily because of the 900mm row depth required [English and Welsh row depths are normally between 700mm and 760mm]."

webTitle: Harte is a diver, says Ferguson

fields.headline: Harte is a diver, says Ferguson
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson last night hit back at criticism of Fabien Barthez and accused Leeds left-back Ian Harte of having a reputation for diving.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson last night hit back at criticism of Fabien Barthez following the French goalkeeper's controversial clash with Ian Harte at Elland Road on Saturday, accusing the Leeds left-back of having a reputation for diving and prompting David O'Leary to leap to his defender's defence.

"I think that what Fabien did was a silly thing to do. It was unnecessary. But Harte made a meal of it," Ferguson said. "In the context of the situation, given that the player involved had a record in the game of diving, you've got to say that he didn't deserve to get a player sent off."

Many observers felt Barthez, who was only booked, had been fortunate to stay on the pitch after aiming a kick at Harte to give away a penalty which he then saved. Later Lucas Radebe, the Leeds captain, claimed that officials were intimidated by Manchester United's big name.

When asked what he thought the Football Association's video panel might make of the incident Ferguson felt that "it may consider Harte's action for the dive and really look hard at that situation".

But O'Leary, in Madrid for Leeds's game against Real this evening, said: "Maybe the great man [Ferguson], at 59, his memory is going, but he did say on Saturday Barthez should have been sent off.

"This smells of some sort of smokescreen, although I couldn't tell you what it's for. But who am I to compete with the great man, as I'm still only young and learning my trade?"

Ferguson flew here yesterday with his Manchester United team to prepare for tomorrow night's Champions League encounter with Panathinaikos. Ryan Giggs, who stayed in Manchester to continue treatment on his injured hamstring, is the only doubt for a game which, if won, would ensure the English champions of a place in the quarter-finals for the fifth successive season.

 The former Manchester United defender Steve Bruce is planning to take legal action against Barry Rubery, the chairman and owner of Huddersfield Town. In his programme notes for Saturday's game against Norwich, Rubery criticised his former manager for "wasting" £3m, saying the money would have been "spent more wisely by a more experienced manager without an ego to feed".

fields.headline: Arsenal look to talismanic captain to steady ship
fields.trailText: Arsenal still have it all to do and must win tonight if they are to stand a chance of reaching the last eight before next Wednesday's game at Bayern Munich.
fields.body:
Tony Adams admits he "rattled cages" after Arsenal's 4-1 capitulation at Spartak Moscow in November, and it is safe to assume the captain will ensure his voice is heard before the crucial return tonight.

The meek manner of defeat in Moscow hurt Adams and he will hardly need reminding that Arsenal must win to stand a chance of reaching the last eight before next Wednesday's game at Bayern Munich.

Victory will suffice if Lyon fail to beat the German champions in France this evening, and Adams - like his fellow thirty-somethings David Seaman and Lee Dixon - is well aware his chance to leave a mark on the Champions League is fast running out.

"They certainly feel like that," acknowledged the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger. "I don't think they believe it is their last year but it is an opportunity they have to take because of time getting shorter."

Although Dixon and Adams sat out training yesterday, Wenger is confident both will start against a Spartak side who can still reach the quarter-finals despite sitting bottom of the group. The value of Adams, in particular, is plain from the statistics.

Whereas Arsenal have won 17 of the 24 games he has played this season, keeping 15 clean sheets, they have been victorious in only six of the 19 matches he has missed, managing three shut-outs.

Assuming Arsenal maintain their record of scoring in every Champions League game at Highbury, the challenge will be to prevent the slips which have seen them throw away the lead in three of their four games in this group.

As well as falling apart from 1-0 up in Moscow, they conceded a last-minute goal to hand Lyon a 1-1 draw at Highbury a fortnight ago and allowed Bayern back from 2-0 down to earn a point. "A strong team," Wenger reminded his players, "shows its strength in the decisive games."

The skill of Egor Titov and the power and finishing of the Brazilian strikers Marcao and Robson made life hard for Arsenal in Moscow, but Spartak are poor travellers and should be beaten. They have not played a league match for almost four months and have lost twice to Bayern since the Champions League resumed.

Thierry Henry's speed unsettled their defence at the Luzhniki Stadium and Wenger must decide whether to partner him with Dennis Bergkamp or the more pacy Sylvain Wiltord, who scored a hat-trick against West Ham on Saturday.

Ray Parlour and Martin Keown are injured but Ashley Cole has recovered from an ankle problem and will play because Silvinho is on international duty.

Asked whether Arsenal could win the Champions League, Wenger was non-committal. "We have to show we are good enough," he said. "We have to accept the challenge." Expect similar words from Adams in the dressing room tonight.

Arsenal (4-4-2, possible): Seaman; Dixon, Adams, Grimandi, Cole; Pires, Lauren, Vieira, Ljungberg; Henry, Wiltord.

fields.headline: Arsenal 1 - 0 Spartak Moscow
fields.trailText: Team
fields.body:
Team

Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon, Adams, Grimandi, Cole, Ljungberg, Vieira, Lauren, Pires, Bergkamp, Henry. Subs: Manninger, Wiltord, Edu, Malz, Luzhny, Vivas, Kanu.

Spartak Moscow: Filimonov, Kovtun, Tchuisse, Baranov, Bulatov, Irismetov, Kalynychenko, Parfenov, Mitreski, Robson, Titov. Subs: Levytsky, Khizaneishvili, Marcao, Pisarev, Bougakov.

1 Spartak kick-off with both teams needing a win if they are to keep alive hopes of qualification for the quarter-finals. With a bit of luck elsewhere of course. Arsenal's first corner; Pires takes and Spartak clear.
3 Second corner for Arsenal. Cole takes from the right and Spartak clear again.
4 Lauren puts Pires away into space on the right and suddenly the way to goal opens up for the Frenchman. But, with Henry waiting on the edge of the six-yard box, Pires slices his shot across the face of goal.
7 Lots of good movement by Arsenal; Spartak being pinned back in their own half.
9 Parfenov and Bulatov knock the ball around the centre circle before trying to release Robson; Adams equal to it. Spartak starting to push out in an attempt to bring their midfield into action.
12 Arsenal over-commit and Spartak have their first meaningful attack on goal; Arsenal snuff out the threat and reply with a Ljungberg break down the left, but the move breaks down when Pires is unable to reach Ljungberg's ball to the by-line.
15 Lauren does well to intercept a pass 25 yards out from the Arsenal area and immediately releases Bergkamp on the right. The Dutchman plays a great ball to the corner of the six-yard box but there is no one there to meet it.
17 Bergkamp turns and shoots from six yards but finds only the side netting.
19 Arsenal free-kick 25 yards out to the left. Henry takes and fails to find Grimandi behind the wall. Cleared for a corner, Filimonov claims after some flapping.
21 Arsenal's fourth corner; Pires takes and Spartak clear. All Arsenal at the moment.
23 Great tackle by Vieira in the centre of the park, but his pass finds Bergkamp offside. Spartak struggling with Arsenal's pace.
25 Bulatov fires in a right-foot shot from 20 yards - straight at Seaman.
26 Two Arsenal corners in succession on the left. Pires takes both: the first is put out after an attempted flick-on by Grimandi; the second goes for a goal-kick after Filimonov comes for the ball and misses.
29 Pires gets away from Kovtun on the right, but Filimonov restores confidence when he claims easily. A quick clearance allows a break down the left for Spartak but Arsenal kill-off the move.
31 Spartak's first corner with Kalynychenko; finally cleared for a second corner, which is played short to Baranov before Arsenal intercepet his pass and break. The ball comes to Bergkamp just outside the Spartak area, but his volley flies wide of the left-hand upright.
34 Dixon down injured after a collision with Kovtun.
37 Filimonov nearly blows it for Spartak when he is asked to clear with his left foot - could not have looked more uneasy.
38 Yet another corner to Arsenal. You guessed it, Pires again takes and again it comes to nothing as he predictably aims it at the near post. And another corner. What do you know, Pires plays it deeper to the far post, but Adams is unable to capitalise.
43 Spartak break with men over in the Arsenal half. Kalynychenko crosses from the left but there is no one to meet it. Arsenal break from the clearance. Bergkamp's shot from the edge of the Spartak area takes a touch from Filimonov as it clears the bar.
45 Bergkamp gets another chance from the corner and curls the ball just wide of the far post. Half-time. Arsenal totally dominant in midfield but unable to make things count in the final third. Spartak admirably open in their play, if overwhelmed.

46 Arsenal get the second 45 underway as the heavens open at Highbury.
47 Spartak have the first meaningful move of the half when Bulatov and Titov combine to find Robson in the Arsenal area, but he can't make it count.
49 Quiet start to the half, with neither side showing much urgency.
51 Titov breaks through the middle but his pass finds Irismetov offside. Great chance for Adams when Kovtun clears his header off the line.
52 Followed by three corners in succession as Arsenal pressure the Spartak goal. Cole takes the last one from the right and Adams gets up to head straight at Filimonov.
54 Substitution Pisarev on for Titov.
57 Vieira asks a lot of Henry when he tries to release him down the left; Filimonov comes charging out to clear.
58 Henry gets into a good position wide on the left but his cross towards Bergkamp is poor.
61 Ljungberg does well to hold of Baranov; he cuts inside and passes to Henry 20 yards out. Henry finds Bergkamp just inside the area the Dutchman's shot is deflected for a corner. Pires takes and Grimadi flicks it out to Bergkamp, who in turn passes for Henry to flick the ball into the hands of Filimonov.
64 A great chance for Arsenal as Henry guides his shot just wide of the right-hand upright from Ljungberg's through-ball.
70 Still nothing coming off for Arsenal; Arsene Wenger starting to look increasingly anxious on the bench.
71 Substitutions Kanu and Wiltord on for Bergkamp and Pires.
73 Frustration starting to get the better of Arsenal as they give away free-kicks in their own half and get caught offside too often.
77 Poor pass by Vieira from the centre circle just about sums things up for Arsenal as the minutes tick away.
78 Kanu and Cole work around the left of the area before the ball goes out to the right. Spartak clear and break with Tchuisse; he goes all the way, but Seaman is spared by a timely intervention on the the six-yard line. Corner comes to nothing.
80 Wiltord comes close under pressure from Kovtun when he crews his shot across goal and fractionally wide. Baranov replies with a run at Cole and a shot straight at Seaman.
82 GOAL: Arsenal 1 - 0 Spartak Moscow The breakthrough for Arsenal. Henry gets up from Cole's corner to head down and back across goal into the corner of the net. Can Arsenal hang on to their lead?
87 Arsenal doing a good job of keeping the ball in the Spartak half.
90 Two minutes of stoppage time to play. Substitution Vivas on for Henry. Arsenal give the ball away in their own half and Seaman has to come out to punch clear for his first real test of this half. Full-time.
Arsenal 1 - 0 Spartak Moscow Arsenal will ahve to wait until next week to see if they have qualified for the quarter-finals after Lyon defeated Bayern Munich 3-0.

fields.headline: Prescott talks in tongues
fields.trailText: Politicians throughout the world stand accused of obfuscation instead of straightforward answers to questions.
fields.body:
Politicians throughout the world stand accused of obfuscation instead of straightforward answers to questions.

Luckily, in Britain, our politicians are a bit more rooted in reality and as such, are renowned for their straight-talking, no nonsense answers to questions asked by pesky journalists who then twist everything they say.

We don't condone this practice so here is our list - straight from the horses mouth - of the expressions favoured by our deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

Prescott on

...Tony Blair
"no deputy could have a better leader to help him"

...the Tories
"I just can't wait to get stuck into those Tories"
"14 pints Billy Fizz drunk in charge of a bandwagon"

...policies
"People want to hear about real policies"

...education
"We had a belief that comprehensive education was indeed that there was a new building and most people built the new buildings and they looked wonderful"

...straight-talk
"Promise made, promise kept"
"You have to make a balanced judgement"
"you're on a powerful point"
"we came in and we made that clear"
"There's a lot more to do, a lot done"

...not so straight-talk
"we believe every person is of equal worth"
"We believe in opportunity for all"
"This Government's mission is to deliver opportunity and security in a world of change"
"that's a very important fact for us"
"I never said that it would be across the place"
"I'm not going to give you comments on these things"

...the electorate
"We need to retain the trust of the electorate by showing that we deliver as promised"

...government
"We were elected to govern for the whole country, and that is what we are doing"
"We have achieved a lot. But there is still a lot to do"
"We are a human government"
"This Labour government has delivered"
"We still haven't gone far enough"

...the election
"Now when I go to the election, as we will go in shortly, I don't know when it's going to come, but I'll be arguing one of delivery"

...Prescott
"I've spent years developing this image"

...the Lib-Lab coalition
"Put it in a boat and send it away"

...the Dome
"Well it's clearly cost a lot more than it was actually promised to do, largely because the figures that were then thought to be possible were not achieved and therefore we end up with this kind of deficit"
"I think it's a wonder architectural structure"
"I don't accept it was a flop"

The best of the rest
Blair catches foot and mouth
Hague's common sense revolution
Kennedy plays word association
Prescott talks in tongues
Brown remains tight-lipped
Portillo stays quiet

Send your best examples of "straight-talk" to redbox@guardianunlimited.co.uk
The best one wins a straight answer - maybe.

fields.headline: Copying maps costs AA £20m
fields.standfirst: 'Fingerprints' in Ordnance Survey sources used as proof
fields.trailText: Ordnance Survey has won a £20m payout from the Automobile Association, after using sophisticated "fingerprinting" techniques to catch the motoring organisation copying its maps.
fields.body:
Ordnance Survey has won a £20m payout from the Automobile Association, after using sophisticated “fingerprinting” techniques to catch the motoring organisation copying its maps.

The payment was agreed hours before a courtroom showdown was due to begin yesterday, ending a dispute over more than 500 different AA atlases, town plans and fold-out maps.

A team of Ordnance Survey experts identified unique “fingerprints” in these publications which proved that the AA was using its maps as a source.

These included stylistic features and proportions - such as the width of roads in each drawing.

Ordnance Survey’s chief executive, Vanessa Lawrence, said: “There are design elements in the way we show things which are not obvious to either the user or the copier. When we see the two versions side by side, we can spot clues.”

The row between the two organisations dates back to December 1996, and concerns AA maps created as early as 1990. The AA, previously a non-profit body, was bought by the gas distribution firm Centrica two years ago.

Centrica insisted the motoring club had “genuinely sought” to draw its own maps. However, Centrica’s director of information services, Matthew Thompson, said: “It is clear from our investigations that the AA’s processes were not as robust as they should have been. Centrica is very concerned that such a situation could have arisen and is now confident that it could not happen in the future.”

Yesterday’s settlement followed talks between Ms Lawrence and board-level executives from Centrica. Ms Lawrence said: “We spent a day together looking at various different sheets containing lots of different examples.”

She stressed that Ordnance Survey’s “fingerprints” did not extend to putting misleading features in maps: “There are some publishers who put deliberate mistakes in their maps. We don’t do that - it would mislead our customers. For us, it’s more about the style we use.”

Ordnance Survey has a small team of copyright experts who are charged with scrutinising rival publications. The government agency has won several smaller cases in the past. In 1995, it won damages from two Norfolk publishers of tourist maps, Streetwise and Color Maps International. However, a spokesman said: “There’s never been anything in any shape or form of anything like this magnitude.”

Ordnance Survey typically charges map-making organisations a few pence for each copy of any map printed using its information as source material. This can mean substantial bills for large publishers - the AA printed more than 300m copies of the maps and atlases in dispute.

Companies which do not make money from publishing maps, but which want to use Ordnance Survey maps on advertising material, are charged a fee of £45 a year.

Established in the 18th century, Ordnance Survey was originally intended to provide the army with reliable maps to help put down rebellion and invasion. The organisation is still wholly owned by the government but it was recently granted “trading fund” status, which allows it to keep any profits for reinvestment in the business. It made profits of £12.7m last year, on sales of £99.6m.

Ms Lawrence said: “We are the master mapper of Britain. I would always wish to settle disputes like this in a businesslike way - we have to protect the intellectual property of both ourselves and our licensed partners.”

webTitle: Jeanette Winterson: Women can solve the farming crisis

fields.headline: Purse power
fields.standfirst:
Why women hold the key to solving the farming crisis

What's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: I have bought organic food since the days when you had to call a New Age hippy from a phone box and haggle over a cabbage. Before that, I was vegetarian because I hate factory farming, its treatment of animals and its effect on the land.
fields.body:
I have bought organic food since the days when you had to call a New Age hippy from a phone box and haggle over a cabbage. Before that, I was vegetarian because I hate factory farming, its treatment of animals and its effect on the land.

I am used to hearing the usual blather about how expensive organic food is and how it can never be more than a niche market for cranks. The fact is, I spend less on food than my "sensible" friends, because I buy only raw materials and I cook.

Now, I'm not claiming to be Marguerite Patten and this is not an essay on how to whip up a nutritious meal for six using only a tin of Spam and an elastic band. What I am claiming is that most people's shopping habits cost them more than food farmed sustainably would, if our shopping habits could be changed.

Try this experiment - junk all the ready meals and snack foods, decide to eat meat only two or three times a week, and buy the best of everything. You will save a fortune. One of the most fascinating things about Channel 4's 1940s House was what happened to Mrs Hymer after the series ended. She did not go back to supermarket shopping and she no longer bought convenience foods. The result was a saving of £70 a week for a family of five.

The fact is that women are mostly still in charge of shopping and cooking. This gives us huge power. We can change food production in Britain faster than governments or legislation. What we demand will determine what supermarkets buy.

Something has to happen - and soon. On the back of BSE comes foot and mouth. Not long ago it was E coli and salmonella. Farming is not a business in which costs can be cut indefinitely. The real price of cheap food is a sickly, obese population and a chemically maintained countryside where disease flourishes, while habitat and species diversity is destroyed. The bucket-loads of antibiotics fed to animals have not proved protection against the unnatural way they are farmed.

Nick Brown says he wants to look again at the effects of intensive farming. The big issue is going to be cheap food. Ask yourself this: why will you pay 50p for a chocolate bar and expect six eggs for the same price? Food has become something we seem to feel should not cost money. To keep prices low and margins high, supermarkets import half of what we eat. I live in the Cotswolds, next door Hereford produces wonderful beef. My local Tesco only sells organic beef from Argentina. How does that help British farmers? How does that support a rural economy?

It is true that beef ranched abroad can be produced more cheaply than anything we can manage in Britain - or so it seems. Earth scientist James Lovelock has worked out the true cost of a rainforest hamburger. He arrived at this figure by ruling out all the economically invisible benefits rainforests provide - habitat, livelihood for indigenous people, etc - and focused on the fact that rainforests act as giant cooling systems for the whole planet. He then calculated the cost of providing this service technologically. He divided that cost per hectare of forest, averaged the number of cattle ranched on each cleared hectare, then worked out how many hamburgers could be got from each animal. So next time you pay 99p, remember the $65 the planet has paid for you.

The implications of the way we eat will be problems our children will have to solve. Seventy-five per cent of the earth's fertile land is farmed. I do not believe more chemicals, drugs and GM crops are the answer. The answer starts with a quiet revolution - what we are going to eat and how we are going to pay for it. We will have to pay, if not out of our pockets, then out of our bodies. We will pay with our health and with the health of the planet.

Purse power is not just a middle-class solution, but as the middle classes are better paid and better informed, they are in a strong position to drive the changes in shopping habits that are the only thing that will force supermarkets to alter their destructive buying policies. When Tony Blair accused supermarkets of holding farmers in an "armlock", he was right. The supermarkets in turn blame the consumer - forgetting the 1960s advertising adage: "The consumer is not a moron, she is your wife."

Now she has her own bank account. Go shop.

 This column will appear fortnightly. www.jeanettewinterson.com

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Corina
fields.trailText: I'd suggest a trip to Kununurra. Stay at the Kununurra Adventure Backpackers (tel 8 9169 1998) - they are so lovely there - they seem to make a point of knowing everyone's name. From there, you can visit the Bungle Bungles or go on a canoe safari in crocodile infested waters! It was one of the highlights of my trip. If you do end up there, please say hello to the tour guide Darren for me!
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

I'm enjoying reading your updates - I got back from travelling a few months ago and I really miss it! About Australia - I'd highly recommend heading west from Darwin. The west coast is far less touristy and just as beautiful as the east. At the very least, I'd suggest a trip to Kununurra which is just inside the WA border. If you do end up there, please say hello to the tour guide Darren for me!

Carry on enjoying yourself and take care.

webTitle: Unions give postal votes pledge to boost Labour

fields.headline: Unions give postal votes pledge to boost Labour
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Trades union leaders have promised Tony Blair they will deliver 500,000 postal votes at the election to counter fears that a low turnout will cost Labour seats on polling day.
fields.body:
Trades union leaders have promised Tony Blair they will deliver 500,000 postal votes at the election to counter fears that a low turnout will cost Labour seats on polling day.

Full-time officials and shop stewards will tour workplaces handing out forms and chasing up workers in an unprecedented union drive to bolster support for the government.

The plan to exploit new laws on postal voting was reached at a recent meeting of senior union and party figures on the Labour party's trade unions liaison committee, after a private presentation from No 10's private pollster, Philip Gould.

Five of the biggest unions affiliated to the Labour party - Unison, AEEU, TGWU, MSF, and GMB - have undertaken to sign up between 65,000 and 80,000 postal voters. Smaller unions will provide the remainder of the votes.

If successful, the strategy would give Mr Blair half a million votes before the ballot booths open on election day, and it could prove crucial in marginal constituencies, particularly in the West Midlands and north-west England.

The initiative echoes the tactics of US unions, which delivered huge numbers of votes for Bill Clinton and Al Gore, and comes after Mr Gould discovered a big swing to Labour among union members.

The unions' more central role in Labour's campaign compares with four years ago when Mr Blair wanted them kept in the background to reassure big business and blunt Tory attempts to revive memories of the winter of discontent.

Prominent leaders, such as the AEEU's Sir Ken Jackson and the TGWU's Bill Morris, will be deployed to counter cynicism over the govern ment's record, and persuade traditional Labour supporters to back Mr Blair.

The unions intend to set up phone banks to contact members and send them copies of an in-house journal listing Labour's achievements, including anti-crime and pro-family measures as well as the minimum wage and employment rights.

"The party hierarchy is completely relaxed about union involvement because scare stories will carry little or no weight," said an influential union official close to Millbank. "We have a network still of 7m people _ most will vote Labour if only we get them to vote."

With spending by political parties expected to be capped at under £15m, non-financial contributions by organisations such as trade unions will be increasingly significant in election campaigns. Unions are likely to donate about £8m to Labour and will provide extensive back-up with staff, offices and cars.

The balloting drive follows a Home Office experiment during last spring's council elections which found that the most successful way to boost turnout was to ease restrictions on postal voting.

Under the Political Parties Act electors will for the first time be able to demand a postal vote from their local council or returning officer without proving they are ill, on holiday or away working.

With Mr Blair warning that the party might lose 60 seats if one in six of the 1997 Labour voters this time stay at home, Millbank believes the union initiative will help Labour's position. Key Labour figures have for months voiced concern that cynicism among the electorate and apathy among party activists could undermine Mr Blair.

webTitle: Major left fuming after Thatcher reopens old wounds

fields.headline: Major left fuming after Thatcher reopens old wounds
fields.trailText: Margaret Thatcher and John Major, who are barely on speaking terms at the best of times, have had another spectacular falling out.
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher and John Major, who are barely on speaking terms at the best of times, have had another spectacular falling out.

Mr Major is said by friends to be "seething" after Lady Thatcher unceremoniously upstaged him at last week's 10th anniversary celebrations marking the liberation of Kuwait. Lady Thatcher, who makes no attempt to hide her contempt for the man she backed as her successor, swung the proverbial handbag in Mr Major's direction when she lamented the failure of Britain and the US to wipe out Saddam Hussein at the end of the Gulf war.

Standing within yards of Mr Major in the garden of the British embassy in Kuwait, she declared: "I only wish that I had stayed on to finish the job properly. Perhaps then we wouldn't be where we are today with this cruel and terrible man securely in power."

Mr Major, who defended the allies' decision not to march on Baghdad within moments of her outburst, flew home in a rage. One friend said: "John is seething with Margaret. He feels that once again she has shown no grasp of the finer details of policy."

Friends said Mr Major was particularly enraged because he has been widely praised, along with George Bush snr, for his deft handling of the war. One friend said: "To suggest that the allies could have stormed up to Baghdad and take out Saddam after the liberation of Kuwait is ludicrous, not least because there was no UN mandate to do so."

Lady Thatcher ensured she received top billing at last week's celebrations in Kuwait even though she resigned in November 1990, before the launch of Operation Desert Storm in January 1991. The former prime minister believes she deserves credit for the success of the war after she famously stiffened the resolve of Mr Bush when he prevaricated after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.

The latest row shows there is little hope of a reconciliation between Lady Thatcher and Mr Major. Relations, which soured within months of Mr Major taking office, are so bad that Lady Thatcher is now said to be on comparatively better terms with Sir Edward Heath, despite his 26 year-long sulk after she deposed him as Tory leader in 1975.

The latest row shows there is little hope of a reconciliation between Lady Thatcher and Mr Major. Relations, which soured within months of Mr Major taking office, are so bad that Lady Thatcher is now said to be on comparatively better terms with Sir Edward Heath, despite his 26 year-long sulk after she deposed him as Tory leader in 1975.

webTitle: Rise in low pay to woo voters

fields.headline: Rise in low pay to woo voters
fields.standfirst:
Labour targets 1.5m workers in heartlands

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government fuelled expectations of an imminent general election yesterday when it announced an inflation-busting increase of almost 11% in the national minimum wage, designed to shore up support among its disgruntled core voters.
fields.body:
The government fuelled expectations of an imminent general election yesterday when it announced an inflation-busting increase of almost 11% in the national minimum wage, designed to shore up support among its disgruntled core voters.

With Labour concerned that voter apathy could still deny it a second term, the 10.8% increase from £3.70 an hour to £4.10 will boost the pay of between 1.3 and 1.5m low-paid workers, mostly in the party's heartlands.

Women, who have cooled in their support for the government, represent 70% of the beneficiaries of the new low pay floor, which will come into force on October 1.

This year's increase was recommended by the independent Low Pay Commission after consultations with unions and employers. It was quickly rubber stamped by the trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers.

It will mean that workers on the lowest earnings will have enjoyed the same percentage boost to their pay as the rest of the workforce since the minimum wage was introduced in April 1999.

A further 10p rise to £4.20 an hour has been accepted in principle by the government for next year, although Mr Byers said this would depend on the economic conditions.

Coming on the eve of tomorrow's budget, which will include more help for families on low incomes, the announcement added to the pre-election mood at Westminster.

Mr Byers denied the announcement was designed to soften up voters ahead of a spring general election. He said the Low Pay Commission had chosen to publish its unanimous recommendation, and the government to accept it now, as a result of pressure from employers who had asked for plenty of time to adjust their payrolls.

However, the Tories questioned the timing of the move which, they said, would add to the regulatory burden on business already costing billions of pounds a year.

David Heathcote-Amory, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, said: "Last October, the national minimum wage was uprated by 10 pence an hour, before that the secretary of state made no oral statement to the House.

"But today, the secretary of state announced here that there will be a 40 pence uprating in the minimum wage. Is the difference in the announcement and the way that it was announced, anything to do whatever with the fact that there will shortly be a general election?"

Digby Jones, director general of the CBI, said: "The government has gone as far as it can without moving to a point where the damage outweighs the benefits."

Government sources said the employers' organisation had been persuaded to back the increase by the argument that all workers should share the fruits of economic growth.

But Chris Humphries, director general of the British Chamber of Commerce, which tends to represent smaller companies, predicted job losses in some sectors. "In the social care sector in particular, where margins are extremely tight, only the leanest companies will be in a position to absorb an 11% pay increase, and their reaction, under pressure from government to meet budget targets, will be to cut jobs.

"We are also fearful that such a rise will put pressure on pay settlements over the next few months for those firms directly affected and for those in related sectors, as employees earning above the minimum wage look for comparative increases."

Bharti Patel, director of the Low Pay Unit, which is campaigning for a minimum wage of £5.11, said the announcement was welcome, but overdue. "To begin to close the gap between highest and lowest paid, and with it the gender pay gap, would require a more substantial increase," she said.

TUC general secretary John Monks, said: "This is clearly another significant step towards a decent minimum wage _

"In the longer term, we will continue to press for the adult rate to be extended to over 18-year-olds and for the minimum wage to do even more to secure justice for the low paid. We look forward to the Low Pay Commission taking further steps towards a fair settlement for Britain's lowest paid workers."

Announcing the move in the Commons, Mr Byers said the introduction of the national minimum wage was one of the greatest achievements of the government, disproportionately benefiting women and workers in poor regions without harming jobs or the economy.

The commission plans to deliver its recommendations on the age range of the separate youth rate, covering 18 to 21-year-olds, in May.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Lib Dems and the pink vote

fields.headline: Gay cafe life draws would-be camp followers
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The election is in the wind, like sleet or the foot and mouth virus. In the Commons, Stephen Byers was announcing a rise in the minimum wage. Tomorrow, Gordon Brown will produce a tax-cutting budget. On Friday we can expect the Tooth Fairy (Increased Emoluments) Order, by which children will all get a £10 note, discount pizza  coupons and stock options in the privatised air traffic control system.
fields.body:
The election is in the wind, like sleet or the foot and mouth virus. In the Commons, Stephen Byers was announcing a rise in the minimum wage. Tomorrow, Gordon Brown will produce a tax-cutting budget. On Friday we can expect the Tooth Fairy (Increased Emoluments) Order, by which children will all get a £10 note, discount pizza coupons and stock options in the privatised air traffic control system.

And at a gay cafe in London, Charles Kennedy was working the homosexual vote. Some poll the Lib Dems have produced suggests that gays are so disillusioned with the Labour party that instead of voting Labour two-to-one, as they did in 1997, a majority will pick the Lib Dems this time. (The poor old Tories score only 7% of gays, possibly a smaller proportion than they have in the parliamentary party.)

The launch of the new Lib Dem policy document was at the First Out cafe, which opened in 1986 and was the first admittedly gay restaurant in the capital. Gay friends tell me that these days it is thought staid, being somewhat less louche than the Garrick Club.

As it is, there were just a few chaps sitting around with coffees, glancing at the journals which are essential reading in the gay community: the Pink Paper, Boyz magazine and the Guardian.

We were early, and as I and my colleagues leafed through these publications, I was struck by how gays write about each other in a way which would be furiously denounced as homophobic if it appeared elsewhere, eg in the Guardian. For instance, dna magazine seems to consist largely of attacks on other gay men, such as Peter Mandelson and Elton John, and even angrier assaults on the rest of the gay press.

The Pink Paper includes a sprinkling of political comment, some of it about Stephen Twigg, who beat Michael Portillo in 1997. Apparently when Mr Twigg won the seat, "he rolled his eyes in mock surprise".

The Pink Paper is puzzled by this news. "And we just thought sexy Stephen was as camp as tits!" their columnist reflects.

The wine correspondent of Boyz recommends Rude Boy wine, with a "temperature-sensitive label which causes the rude boy's gleaming white boxers to be removed once the bottle's chilled, revealing a sexy red thong". It concludes, and this is absolutely true, with the words "Bottoms Up!"

Mr Kennedy arrived. Luckily the camera crews were late, so they didn't get a shot of him sitting under a photo of a naked man in a leather cap.

The Lib Dem leader was rather good. He wants gay marriage legalised, gays to be able to adopt children, and a new offence dealing with homophobic hate crimes. He also wants to remove discrimination against "trans-gender people".

This was not, he said, just to win votes. "It's not for reasons of headcounting. It's for reasons of principle, because it's the right thing to do."

What would he say to party members who disagreed with him? "I would say, look in the mirror and ask yourself, 'why do I call myself a Liberal Democrat?' " As for him, he would defend the party line on gays on radio, TV, and "to any journalist who you care to put in front of me!" When you're running third, you have no need to fake sincerity.

As I left I picked up a copy of TS/TV News, "for transsexuals and transvestites". A man called Rosemary complains that the Gloucester branch of Debenhams made him go into the men's department to be fitted for a new bra.

There seem to be fresh examples of discrimination everywhere. I expect the Lib Dems will have a position paper out on this scandal in time for their conference.

webTitle: BBC warns staff of sensitivity on Europe

fields.headline: BBC warns staff of sensitivity on Europe
fields.trailText: The BBC has warned its reporters and programme-makers to be extra-sensitive over the issue of Europe during the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
The BBC has warned its reporters and programme-makers to be extra-sensitive over the issue of Europe during the run-up to the general election.

In guidelines issued yesterday, the corporation said that issues such as Europe caused divisions within parties as well as between them, and all views should be fairly represented.

The BBC has come under fire from all sides of the debate over its coverage of Europe. The Today programme on Radio 4, which has attempted to cover the issue in depth, has taken much of the flak.

The guidelines take account for the first time of the problems posed by the internet. Since the last election, the BBC's online news service has undergone a huge expansion.

Online staff are warned to be aware of concerted email campaigns conducted by political activists, and talk forums must be monitored to ensure that they reflect a fair debate. Devolution also features strongly in the guidelines: network programmes must give time to Plaid Cymru and the SNP. Individual programmes do not have to be artificially balanced, but must give the different parties a fair hearing over the course of a week.

The guidelines highlight the sensitivity of certain issues. "Particular care should be taken over high-profile issues like Europe where there is a multi-faceted debate within and between the parties to ensure that a balance of views is maintained," the guidelines warn.

Producers and editors are also warned over the dangers of opinion polls. The results of an opinion poll should never lead a news bulletin on their own, and the interpretation given to the results by the publication or organisation that commissioned it should not be relied upon.

Great care must be taken with the language used to report political surveys: "Polls 'suggest' but never 'prove' or even 'show'," the guidelines say.

The BBC said that the guidelines, developed by the corporation's editorial policy department, would "help ensure balance and fairness during the campaign".

webTitle: And on the seventh day, thou shalt continue to spin

fields.headline: And on the seventh day, thou shalt continue to spin
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Even God had the seventh day for rest. Not so for the foot soldiers of Alastair Campbell who have been ordered to run press launches of government initiatives at weekends. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Even God had the seventh day for rest. Not so for the foot soldiers of Alastair Campbell who have been ordered to break with tradition and begin running press launches of government initiatives at weekends.

In a sure sign that a general election is looming, the government is preparing for a barrage of good news, seven days a week.

A confidential memorandum from the strategic communications unit at No 10 refers to "the prime minister's strong view that the government should make more use of weekends for substantive business".

It is critical of the conventional method of simply issuing a press notice through the central office of information on Saturdays and Sundays and says many "good stories" are being thrown away at weekends because they are not given the same "impact and effort" as a weekday launch.

The memo suggests that events and initiatives during the week are being crowded out by the sheer weight of announcements.

If government departments do not begin to schedule full press conferences on Saturdays and Sundays, then they will be allocated slots by No 10.

The memo was sent by Paul Brown at the communications unit to the various government departments on February 13.

It reads: "The prime minister is determined to make this shift for business which does not require an announcement to parliament, not least to avoid the situation where weekdays are overcrowded with government events and initiatives competing for attention.

"If we cannot develop a good weekend forward programme quickly, decisions will have to be made here about what pieces of business might be suitable.

"The weekend media are keen to report news stories and we can get good value by using them.

"This depends on the story being handled properly, with proper detailed briefing and a minister up and about on the day available for interviews, visits, etc."

A government source said the move was a matter of common sense. "With the advent of 24 hour news, seven days a week, the government is under ever growing pressure to meet the demands of the media," he said. "There is an endless desire for fresh news and stories and it makes sense to try to meet that demand."

Making the most of the government's good news has not made everyone happy, however. A press officer in one government department said the memo had met with a furious reception.

"This has upset quite a lot of people who want their weekends off," he said. "People are already working long hours and this is quite an extra burden. And you have to ask, do the electorate at large want this stuff rammed down their throats at weekends as well?"

fields.headline: 'Quick op' redress scheme by NHS
fields.trailText: A trial scheme to provide express treatment for NHS patients whose operations are cancelled at the last minute was launched by the government yesterday as ministers acknowledged that hospital waiting lists lengthened in January.
fields.body:
A trial scheme to provide express treatment for NHS patients whose operations are cancelled at the last minute was launched by the government yesterday as ministers acknowledged that hospital waiting lists lengthened in January.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said patients in nine areas would benefit from a guarantee of treatment within 28 days if their operation was cancelled on the appointed day for surgery.

If the local NHS trust could not do the operation within that time, it would have to pay for treatment at the time and hospital of the patients' choice. The patients would be free to choose a private hospital and the NHS would have to pay.

The nine pilot schemes will include three NHS trusts having problems with cancelled operations: Isle of Wight healthcare, North Middlesex University hospital and University of Coventry and Warwick

Others chosen because they have made progress in reducing the rate of cancelled operations are: Leeds teaching hospital, Royal Devon and Exeter, Princess Alexandria, Southern Derbyshire acute hospitals, North Manchester healthcare, and West Cumbria healthcare.

The number waiting for in-patient treatment in England rose by 4,500 in January to 1,039,000. This compared with an increase of 11,000 during the same month last year.

The number waiting more than a year for in-patient treatment fell by 1,310 to 47,100 in January. Two people had waited longer than the government's promised maximum of 18 months.

But 1,880 more operations were cancelled during the last quarter of 2000, as hospitals scrapped routine surgery to deal with emergency cases.

Mr Milburn said: "Waiting lists rose as we expected during January but by a much smaller amount than we had thought. The fundamental reason is that the NHS has more beds and more staff and prepared better than ever before this winter.

"As a result, many patients whose operations would not have gone ahead in previous years, got the treatment they needed but far too many had their operation cancelled. We are tackling waiting lists. Now we need to tackle cancelled operations head-on."

The January figures helped the government to maintain its key manifesto pledge to reduce the number waiting for NHS in-patient treatment to 100,000 below the 1,158,000 inherited from the Conservatives.

But the number of operations cancelled on the day of surgery for non-clinical reasons rose from 16,965 (0.73% of all admissions) in the third quarter of 2000, to 18,844 (0.79%) in the fourth quarter.

If the trials were successful, the guarantee of treatment within 28 days for such cases would be extended nationwide.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said: "When will the health service accept that the prime minister's waiting list initiative is causing widespread fear and anger, and scrap it in favour of a system that treats patients according to clinical need?"

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation representing health authorities and managers, said: "We were lucky in that there haven't been the epidemics of things like flu that we have seen in other years and that has certainly helped. But we also planned as well as we could and had much money to spend and that has obviously made a real difference."

webTitle: Tube sell-off plan runs into buffers over safety rules

fields.headline: Tube sell-off plan runs into buffers over safety rules
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Transport in the UK
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The plans of John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, for partial privatisation of London Underground suffered a severe setback last night with official revelations that the present system is unsafe to hand over to the government's private-public partnership.
fields.body:
The plans of John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, for partial privatisation of London Underground suffered a severe setback last night with official revelations that the present system is unsafe to hand over to the government's private-public partnership.

An outstanding list of 69 key safety issues on overcrowding and emergency evacuation from trains have been discovered by the health and safety executive (HSE), according to official papers leaked last night.

The HSE papers sent to LU on February 16, and confirmed by the HSE to the Guardian, say there are 69 "significant" issues which have not been resolved to the satisfaction of safety inspectors.

The issues have to be resolved by LU before it can officially hand over the system to the private-public partnership. HSE sources suggested that the LU had no chance of getting its safety case right before the deal is due to be completed by the middle of the month.

The rejection of LU's safety case by the HSE would in effect make any legal action by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, to challenge the government's private-public partnership through the courts irrelevant. It would mean that the government's plan would have to be abandoned. This would make a nonsense of almost four years of work, but the government could not ignore such a condemnation of the underground by a statutory body, particularly as safety is such a sensitive issue.

Government sources said yesterday that ministers had gone as far as they could go in negotiating with Mr Livingstone. They indicated that there could be slight room for manoeuvre, but the government had no intention of abandoning the private-public partnership.

Official sources also stressed that if they changed the partnership any more, they could be challenged under European law by the bidders and would have to go through the tendering process again.

The HSE is critical of LU in several areas and says that LU has provided "insufficient detail to prevent risks from overcrowding at stations" or for emergency evacuation at stations.

It is also concerned that LU appears to have little or no information on evacuation of trains. The criticism is so wide-ranging that it presents LU with the task of sorting out the network's safety problems in time for the handover.

The HSE has been warning the industry for several months that it is deeply unhappy at LU's safety case and that it will be forced to reject the plan if significant improvements are not made.
fields.bodyText: The plans of John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, for partial privatisation of London Underground suffered a severe setback last night with official revelations that the present system is unsafe to hand over to the government's private-public partnership. An outstanding list of 69 key safety issues on overcrowding and emergency evacuation from trains have been discovered by the health and safety executive (HSE), according to official papers leaked last night. The HSE papers sent to LU on February 16, and confirmed by the HSE to the Guardian, say there are 69 "significant" issues which have not been resolved to the satisfaction of safety inspectors. The issues have to be resolved by LU before it can officially hand over the system to the private-public partnership. HSE sources suggested that the LU had no chance of getting its safety case right before the deal is due to be completed by the middle of the month. The rejection of LU's safety case by the HSE would in effect make any legal action by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, to challenge the government's private-public partnership through the courts irrelevant. It would mean that the government's plan would have to be abandoned. This would make a nonsense of almost four years of work, but the government could not ignore such a condemnation of the underground by a statutory body, particularly as safety is such a sensitive issue. Government sources said yesterday that ministers had gone as far as they could go in negotiating with Mr Livingstone. They indicated that there could be slight room for manoeuvre, but the government had no intention of abandoning the private-public partnership. Official sources also stressed that if they changed the partnership any more, they could be challenged under European law by the bidders and would have to go through the tendering process again. The HSE is critical of LU in several areas and says that LU has provided "insufficient detail to prevent risks from overcrowding at stations" or for emergency evacuation at stations. It is also concerned that LU appears to have little or no information on evacuation of trains. The HSE has been warning the industry for several months that it is deeply unhappy at LU's safety case and that it will be forced to reject the plan if significant improvements are not made.

fields.headline: Criminals' cash in Straw's sights
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A new law to use civil powers to confiscate ill-gotten fortunes worth £220m from 39 big gangsters who have so far escaped criminal conviction was unveiled yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
A new law to use civil powers to confiscate ill-gotten fortunes worth £220m from 39 big gangsters who have so far escaped criminal conviction was unveiled yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Mr Straw's draft proceeds of crime bill has attracted criticism from civil liberties groups.

The bill, to be introduced later this year, would set up a criminal assets recovery agency charged with the task of hunting down cash, houses, cars and other wealth accumulated through criminal activity.

It is estimated that up to £650m a year might be generated through criminal activity in Britain, while only £44m was seized last year under current powers.

The 335 clause draft bill published yesterday confirmed that the courts would be able to issue confiscation orders using a lower standard of proof - the balance of probabilities - rather than the criminal test of "proving beyond reasonable doubt" that the assets concerned are the profits of criminal activity.

But the legislation does not go as far as was originally feared by civil liberties groups and reverse the burden of proof so that the accused would have to prove that their wealth was legitimately acquired.

Mr Straw said that £54m would be spent on setting up the criminal assets recovery agency, which could be in business as early as next year.

"There are individuals and families who are well known to the police as people who are organisers of large-scale criminal rackets.

"They may have begun their criminal activity many years ago but by one means or another have managed to detach themselves from the commission of offences. They have therefore made proceedings against them very difficult and yet they have large houses and cars and live in a wealthy way but give no reasonable explanation as to how they came by their assets," said Mr Straw.

The draft law would give the new agency the power to seize property at the start of a criminal investigation instead of waiting until a charge is brought.

The agency would also have the power to tax individuals and require financial institutions to identify any accounts held by a person under investigation and full transaction details. The offence of failing to report knowledge or suspicion of drug money laundering, which carries a sentence of up to five years, is to be extended to all types of money laundering.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, warned however that if a civil procedure is to be introduced it should only be allowed once all criminal options have been pursued.

"Civil forfeiture cannot be used to side step normal criminal procedure," he said.

webTitle: Lords order inquiry into Chinook crash

fields.headline: Lords order inquiry into Chinook crash
fields.trailText: The RAF's worst peacetime accident is to be independently investigated for the first time in five years after the government last night conceded to peers' demands for a select committee into the crash.
fields.body:
The RAF's worst peacetime accident is to be independently investigated for the first time in five years after the government last night conceded to peers' demands for a select committee into the crash.

The official verdict at the time was that the loss of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre on June 4 1994 was caused by "gross negligence" on the part of the pilots.

In a development which campaigners hope may lead to the overturning of that verdict, the defence minister, Lady Symons, said she would not ask the government's supporters in the Lords to vote against a move by Lord Chalfont to set up a special inquiry.

The unusual Lords select committee comes after a long campaign for justice by the families of the two special forces pilots, Flight Lieutenants Johnathan Tapper and Rick Cook, who died in the crash along with two other air crew and 25 senior MI5, army and RUC intelligence officers from Northern Ireland.

RAF rules at the time stated that only in cases where there was absolutely no doubt could deceased aircrew be blamed for crashes. The air force's own board of inquiry said a major technical malfunction could not be ruled out, but two air marshals overruled the board and blamed the pilots.

The last full investigation into the crash was a Scottish fatal accident inquiry under Sheriff Sir Stephen Young which ruled in 1996 that there was no evidence to suggest that Flt. Lts Capper and Cook were to blame. But the terms of the inquiry prevented it challenging the gross negligence verdict. The MoD has refused to consider reviewing the verdict, despite the emergence of a catalogue of evidence of serious technical malfunctions in the newly upgraded Chinook fleet.

Some of the evidence - including an accident in the US involving a MoD Chinook, was known at the time. Some emerged later after repeated allegations by MPs that they had been mislead by successive defence ministers.

The campaign to overturn the verdict has been driven by Tony Collins, executive editor of Computer Weekly, who has unearthed a stream of internal MoD documents pointing to serious problems with the computerised engine control system, known as Fadec, which was installed in the Chinook fleet before the crash.

Last week the Guardian and Computer Weekly revealed that two leaked internal documents showed that the RAF was aware that technical problems experienced in the Chinooks could have endangered the safety of an aircraft.

Yesterday the paper and the magazine produced evidence that ministers had misled MP's and the public by claiming erroneously that a 1998 defence select committee report endorsed the official version of events.

The Lords committee which is backed by a number of peers, including two former law lords, comes amid a growing clamour for a new inquiry into the loss of Chinook ZD576. In November the Commons public accounts committee threw its weight behind the campaign. It accused the MoD of "unwarrantable arrogance", employing "flawed logic" and adopting "incredible" and "shocking" test procedures when it brought the new Chinooks into service in 1994 against the advice of its test pilots.

Lord Chalfont, a former Labour foreign affairs minister, and his fellow campaigners believe the Lords inquiry will offer ministers a way of saving face on an issue on which it has had to rely on the advice of MoD officials and serving military officers.

Lord Chalfont told the Lords last night: "A number of distinguished and experienced people, including judges, aviation and computer experts, former ministers and politicians of all parties, have the gravest doubts. Only two air marshals and their colleagues in the MoD apparently have no doubt at all."

He added: "It is on their subjective judgment that two outstanding special forces pilots have been found guilty of making a joint decision to risk their own lives and those of the passengers."

Since the crash the RAF has changed the rules and will no longer blame dead pilots.

Mike Tapper, the father of Jonathan Tapper, said he looked forward to evidence being heard in public over his son's death.

"It offers families a chance to have this matter fully aired in public. It also gives us the chance to hear from the two air marshals and how it was they came to their findings."

fields.headline: Over here and over-paid?
fields.trailText: The announcement that US nurse Beverly Malone has finally agreed to join the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) as general secretary, six weeks after the job was offered to her, will come as a huge relief to the college.
fields.body:
The announcement that US nurse Beverly Malone has finally agreed to join the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) as general secretary, six weeks after the job was offered to her, will come as a huge relief to the college.

The prospect that she might turn down the post, after the RCN had announced, highly publicly, that she was the preferred candidate, must have been the stuff of nightmares for the college's leaders, who had gone out on a limb to hire her.

The RCN had disappointed many of its grassroots members by choosing a non-UK nurse, effectively snubbed several of its own most senior officials who had applied for the job, and caused one of its senior fellows, David Rye, to resign in high dudgeon.

But even though the charismatic former adviser to ex-US president Bill Clinton has put pen to contract after keeping the RCN hanging on for so long, it unlikely the controversy surrounding her appointment is likely to disappear fast.

Ms Malone's salary alone is guaranteed to raise a few eyebrows. The RCN will only say the job sits - assuming a proposed 3.7% pay rise for RCN staff is confirmed - within a pay band of £88,514 to £97,151.

Few observers expect Ms Malone to be on less than the top rate, not least because of the strength of her negotiating position. She can expect a London weighting of £3,000 (a payment meant to help recompense RCN staff for the additional costs of living in London) pushing her salary to more than £100,000, plus pension contributions.

This will make her one of the UK's top-earning trade union leaders when she joins the RCN in April 2002.

The RCN has also arranged a relocation package for Ms Malone - about which it has refused to comment - but speculation suggests it includes the use of an appropriately salubrious rented apartment in central London. This could cost the RCN between £20,000 and £30,000 a year.

It is also reported that the college spent between £30,000 and £50,000 on a firm of headhunters to advise on the recruitment process.

The timing could be better; the college is facing industrial action over pay after staff unions accused it of tearing up a previously agreed pay formula that would have given them a 5.7% rise instead of the 3.7 % on offer.

But regardless of how well what was always going to be a contentious appointment was handled - and the signs are it was hardly the smoothest of processes - the RCN has got who it wanted - the best person, in its view, for the job.

It's easy to see how the appointment might attract obvious, kneejerk outrage and suspicion. But it is more difficult, given Ms Malone's track record, to see it as an genuinely controversial move.

It's worth putting the salary into context. At £100,000 her package is hardly outrageous. Indeed it is dwarfed by NHS trust chief executives in the big teaching hospitals and it only just outstrips the £95,000 earned by the director of personnel at the Leeds Teaching Hospitals trust.

It is also worth sweeping aside the vaguely jingoistic outrage about an American taking over the top job.

Walk into any ward in the NHS and you will find nurses from all over the globe; nursing operates in a truly global market, and the RCN is no different.

The real issue, as ever, is low nurse pay, low morale and professional development - the roots of the crisis in the profession.

The college and Ms Malone have a key role in tackling this. If they fail, then is the time for outrage and controversy.

webTitle: Lecturers asked to fill teacher shortage

fields.headline: Lecturers asked to fill teacher shortage
fields.trailText: Lecturers are being asked to fill vacancies in short-staffed UK schools thanks to a little known clause in the department of education's guidelines.
fields.body:
Lecturers are being asked to fill vacancies in short-staffed UK schools thanks to a little known clause in the department of education's guidelines. The clause says that a 'person with special qualifications or experience' may be employed when no suitable qualified teacher is available.

UK supply agency Teaching Personnel are interpreting this as a green light to invite HE and FE lecturers to make up their recruitment shortfall, although the DfEE itself does not endorse the practice.

"We did it on our own initiative," says Gavin Donnelley, director of Teaching Personnel. "We turn down over 6,000 placements a week because there simply are not enough teachers to go around. We try and do everything we can to avoid letting schools down, and we came up with idea of recruiting lecturers. We organised a mail shot last week and the phone lines started buzzing today."

Donnelley admits that the 'buzz' of the phone lines was not all positive. "Some of the calls were made to say 'What makes you think lecturers have any spare time?' but a lot of them were saying 'Great, when do I start?"

A DfEE spokesperson said: "We don't endorse what this agency are doing. We really don't want them recruiting from one sector only to deplete another. Lecterers may be able to teach in schools, but we are not supporting it."

However, it seems that it is not only part-time academic staff who feel they could use the extra income. Donnelley says he has had a positive reaction from many full-time lecturers as well. "Schools and universities often have differing term-times, so after they break up, lecturers may be available for temporary teaching posts. Also, a lot of academics only lecture three or four days a week."

Dr Simon Cohn, lecturer at Goldsmiths College, University of London said that the days when he doesn't lecture are not 'spare time'. He said would greet the letter with mixed feelings. "There's a real tension between needing the money and needing every hour you've got to conduct research.

"Some junior lecturers may well have a lower income than supply teachers. It's a matter of weighing up a short-term need for money against a long-term need to fulfil RAE requirements. Lecturers may be endangering their long term career prospects by taking on work as supply teachers."

But he added: "I have to admit, I'd consider it. If I did it though, I wouldn't tell my colleges. They would assume I wasn't serious about my research."

University and college lecturers' union NATFHE say they urge lecturers to throw the recruitment letters in the bin. They said "Recruitment agencies are exploiting loopholes and are doing no one any favours. If lecturers were being paid a decent wage they wouldn't be tempted by this kind of thing. Besides which, the vast majority of lecturers have workloads which are far too great for them to be able to take anything else on."

fields.headline: Michael Jackson nurtures Oxford Union
fields.standfirst: Recent Oxford Union debates
fields.trailText: Pop star Michael Jackson will tell members of the Oxford Union of the need for 'nurturing relationships' tonight when he delivers a lecture on child welfare to students.
fields.body:
Pop star Michael Jackson will tell members of the Oxford Union of the need for 'nurturing relationships' tonight when he delivers a lecture on child welfare to students.

A Union spokesperson says that Jackson could expect a warm welcome on the campus. "Students here are very much looking forward to a lecture from Michael Jackson. He has done a great deal of valuable work within children's charities, and everyone recognises that he is a committed worker in that field."

Having established a reputation for attracting top speakers - in 1992 Ronald Reagan told students: "I am delighted to be here. At my age I am delighted to be anywhere" - and as a training ground for politicians, Oxford Union came under attack in the mid-Nineties for 'dumbing down'. While the society had previously provided a stage for the likes of Gladstone and Macmillian, the Union began to welcome speakers such as Eddie the Eagle and Kermit the Frog.

Former prime minister Sir Edward Heath was one of the alumni who spoke out against the union's shift in direction. In 1995 he told the Times that the Union "did not require change." "It was not intended to be a venue for pop concerts or excessive drinking," he added. "The job of the union is provide a debating society." A union official at the time responded: "The kids just don't want intellectual debate anymore."

Stephane Grey, the Union's current vice president, agreed. "This is not dumbing down, it's giving members exactly what they want. I understand that 2,500 people tried to get tickets to this. I am going myself and am very much looking forward to it."

Speaking as chair for the 'Heal The Kids' foundation, Jackson and his colleague Rabbi Shmuley will talk of the need for 'nurturing relationships' between parents and their children.

Organisers of the lecture will admit an audience of 500 into the lecture chamber and a further 400 into the building to watch via television link-ups.

fields.headline: Universities watchdog defends record
fields.trailText: The UK is leading Europe in setting out clear standards for graduates, John Randall, chief executive of the Quality Assurance Agency, said today.
fields.body:
The UK is leading Europe in setting out clear standards for graduates, John Randall, chief executive of the Quality Assurance Agency, said today.

The head of the standards watchdog body said developing national frameworks for higher education qualifications had been a major achievement for the agency. "This will have real benefits for UK higher education in competitive global business."

The agency, which cost £10.3m to run last year, carried out more than 350 subject reviews in England and Northern Ireland last year, according to its annual report. These inspections have been bitterly criticised by many academics for generating huge amounts of paperwork.

Mr Randall has promised a lighter touch regime in the future. But the chief executive, who earned £97,636 last year, insisted the review process lead to improvements. The agency's code of practice prompted universities to think about their own practices. "By using self-evaluation as a starting point our reviews are able to act as a stimulus to enhancement."

The frameworks describe what can be expected to students who hold the main higher education qualifications in terms of intellectual skills, mastery of knowledge and conceptual understanding. In the Bologna Declarationn of 1999, European ministers are seeking to establish a common currency in honours and masters degrees.
