webTitle: Low enrolment means cutbacks for some universities

fields.headline: Bread but no honey
fields.standfirst: Disappointing enrolments mean some of the new universities face cutbacks, says  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Disappointing enrolments mean some of the new universities face cutbacks, says Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
A growing divide between the haves and have-nots in higher education emerges from the annual shareout of government funds for the coming year.

Announcing the distribution of £4.76bn for teaching and research, Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, said it was a "good year" for universities and colleges.

The money available per student was going up "for the first time in living memory". "British higher education is in a healthy state."

But a number of new universities will suffer a cut in funding after failing to recruit enough students, and the settlement has done nothing to shake the vice-chancellors' conviction that the sector is £900m short of what it needs to do its job properly.

Meeting in Newcastle, Universities UK, which represents the heads of institutions, insisted on Friday that top-up fees were still an option - despite being ruled out by David Blunkett, the education secretary, and all the opposition political parties.

Paying the penalty for missing their recruitment targets are the universities of East London, Lincolnshire and Humberside, Luton, Nottingham Trent, South Bank, Sunderland and De Montfort.

The funding council has tried to cushion the blow by moderating the amount the worst-hit institutions lose under the formula for student numbers. Luton has been subsidised to the tune of more than £5m over the past two years. But universities are expected to take serious action to bring their finances back into balance. Luton is axing nearly 100 academic and administrative staff jobs. Lincolnshire and Humberside is to abandon its Hull campus and become the University of Lincoln. De Montfort is closing the Milton Keynes campus.

Among the biggest winners in this year's funding stakes are old-established Nottingham, which gets an extra £3.4m to teach additional students, Southampton (£2.5m), Leeds (£3.2m), Birmingham (£2.3m). Bristol, Durham, Essex, Exeter, Liverpool, Newcastle, Sheffield, Queen Mary and Westfield College London and Warwick which all receive more than £1m additional funding for increased numbers. These are the beneficiaries of the government's drive to expand numbers and the funding council's decision last year to relax the restrictions on how many students institutions were allowed to recruit. There were many more 18-year-olds on the market to take up places.

It is not all gloom for new universities, however. Teesside is awarded a rise of more than £2m for additional students, while Leeds Metropolitan and Plymouth also gain substantially.

Sir Brian said some universities and colleges were having to work hard to fill their places, but overall demand was rising. It was inevitable that some universities would be doing better than others in recruitment: "We have an increasingly well informed student population who are careful about where they go."

The picture is complicated by the continued unpopularity of science and engineering among school and college leavers, which appears to have hit both old and new universities. Prestigious Imperial College London suffered a £1.8m holdback this year because it failed to meet its recruitment targets. Professor Rees Rawlings, pro-rector, blamed the shortfall on the 5% decline in students taking maths and physics at A-level.

Some of the biggest gainers are not conventional universities. A massive 9% increase (nearly £8m) goes to the Open University, and further education colleges get a 6.5% rise in funding for higher education, against an average 4% rise for all institutions.

The lion's share of the new foundation degrees announced by Blunkett are due to be delivered in further education colleges (collaborating with universities). These grants also reflect the government's goal of promoting part-time degrees as a way of increasing participation to its goal of 50% of young people under 30.

Part-time courses are not proving as attractive as predicted. More than 14,000 new part-time places funded by the council in England last year remained unfilled (most on sub-degree courses like Higher National Diplomas). Sir Brian predicts that the government's targets will be met by a greater proportion of full-time students than in the original targets.

Scotland has already passed the Blair target: by 1999/2000 58% of 17-30-year-olds were in higher education or had participated.

Over the next 10 years the number of 18- to 20-year-olds in England is set to rise by 10% (see graph), compelling the funding council to find more places even if the government were not committed to increasing the proportion of young people in higher education. On past trends, school and college leavers are looking for full-time courses - which will reinforce the advantage of the old universities. Numbers in the older age group (25-29) who have been more interested in part-time courses will drop rapidly.

 For students applying to start de gree courses in September this year, the funding announcement is good news. Universities and colleges in England are being funded to take an extra 20,400 full-time and 32,300 part-time places, though there were more than 5,000 full-time places left unfilled last September. Of course there are more 18 to 20-year olds around in the population (see graph) but on balance institutions are looking for candidates and will be more likely to negotiate if your grades do not quite match your offers. There should also be places available through clearing.

webTitle: Pay differences for part-time university staff

fields.headline: Budget brains
fields.standfirst: Thousands of part-time university staff are paid arbitary, and often grossly unfair, wages.  Tony Mooney  reads a disturbing new report
fields.trailText: Thousands of part-time university staff are paid arbitary, and often grossly unfair, wages. Tony Mooney reads a disturbing new report
fields.body:
Annie Abbott is in the second year of her research into polymer chemistry at Sheffield University. With an annual bursary of £6,800, the 24-year-old has to have another job to supplement her income - a familiar story - and so she does laboratory supervision with undergraduate chemistry students. At £9 an hour, she is one of the new army of part-time teaching staff which has been drafted in to cope as student numbers soar and university budgets are squeezed.

Down the road, at Sheffield Hallam University, Jillian Newton is doing the same as she works towards a PhD in analytical chemistry. She, on the other hand, is paid £20 an hour.

The wide and apparently arbitrary differences in pay and conditions for part-time staff are revealed in a survey by Christopher Husbands of the London School of Economics and Annette Davies of the Cardiff Business School. Rates for demonstrators - who help lecturers with practical experiments - varied from £3.65 to £23.89 an hour. More worrying were the ways in which an unregulated system leaves part-time staff open to exploitation, putting them under pressure to work long hours in the hope of gaining an academic post.

Husbands and Davies surveyed the academic personnel officers of 22 universities to obtain information about the numbers of particular types of part-timer at each university and the terms and conditions of their employment. The findings make disturbing reading.

Abbott says demonstration work is not part of her contract but there is a "culture of expectation" within her faculty that postgraduates will take it on: "If the postgraduates did not do the demonstrations there would be nobody to look after the students, and presumably some of practical classes would not take place." A quick three-hour course was all that was deemed necessary to train her to become a demonstrator. She now does 71 hours of laboratory demonstration each semester, about eight hours a week.

But Abbott's £9 an hour cannot be taken at face value because of the preparation and marking time involved. At first the preparation used to take two hours a week but now, as she becomes more used to her role, it takes only 30 minutes. It is the marking of student laboratory scripts that eats into her hourly rate. She is paid £40 a semester for this marking, which takes about five hours a week. This is an improvement - it used to be eight hours a week, but after complaints by the demonstrators the workload was spread out and the time spent on it reduced.

Given the extra hours involved, then, Abbott's hourly rate comes in somewhere between £5-6 an hour. She's not grumbling. "It is better than working in a pub and I don't mind helping the university. I have pride in my university and I want it to do well."

She might not be so accommodating if she were to look at the rates of pay for demonstrators at Sheffield Hallam. Jillian Newton, 35, also needs to supplement her £6,500 bursarybut is paid more than twice as much as Abbott. She did only eight hours of demonstration work last semester and has an allocation of 18 hours for the present one. The training was more extensive at Sheffield Hallam: Newton had to attend a course one day a week for four weeks before she was allowed to supervise students.

"If the work is there you just do it, because somebody has to," she says. "I am responsible for 20 students and the hard part of the job is marking the formal laboratory reports and question books which take about three hours a week.

"Preparation work takes me a couple of nights, about three to six hours reading around the topic and discussing with the lecturers. I receive no extra pay for this, so I suppose the rate of pay is less than £20 per hour."

Roger Allum, the head of Sheffield University's public relations department, says that the postgraduate demonstrators in their chemistry laboratories are paid on a standard inter-university scale: "Annie Abbott will be being paid at the bottom point of the Research and Analogous 1B scale which gives her a rate of pay of £9.30 an hour. This is a common scale used by most universities. But if your findings hold up, I imagine our demon strators will be knocking on our doors asking for a pay rise."

Laura Mark of Sheffield Hallam's publicity and marketing department says: "Demonstrators are paid on a scale used for associate lecturers and that ranges between about £17 and £27. Where they fit in on that scale is determined by the school that they are working for and depends on the type of work they are carrying out and the level of involvement."

The problems seem to stem from the fact that there are no agreed pay scales for part-time teachers in universities. The survey points out that on such issues as pay there is a lack of uniformity "that seems never to have received any legal challenge, even though it might, in certain circumstances, be actionable from an equal opportunities perspective." Hourly rates of pay for demonstrators in 1997 varied between institutions from £3.65 to £23.80, while the rate for small group teaching ranged from £7.65 to £23.89. The differences in rates for formal lecturing were even more marked, ranging from £13.80 to £70 an hour.

Marking and setting exam scripts is another area in which postgraduate part-timers were getting a raw deal - 64% of the reporting institutions made no extra payments for setting examinations over and above the hourly teaching rate, and 50% said that the marking of scripts was included within that rate. In three-quarters of the universities, postgraduates were not paid for marking coursework. In only 7% was additional payment made for preparation time for the teaching undertaken.

Even in those institutions that seemed to be paying a reasonable hourly rate, the reality was different when all the unpaid work was taken into account. Some part-timers are expected to hold up to three "office" hours a week, times when they must be available to answer problems and questions from students.

What's more, the appointment of part-time teachers does not appear to adhere to any consistent selection criteria. The survey points out that "despite legislative guidelines attempting to reduce arbitrariness in such forms of employment, [the selection] is in the gift of more powerful academics, who may . . . favour their own supervisees".

Some universities use an indenture model of employment. Postgraduate students doing a higher degree receive full or partial coverage of tuition fees. In return the student must teach undergraduates. These duties are supposed to be for a fixed number of hours a week, but extra teaching may be difficult to resist, says the report, because of "the power differential between the teacher and the senior academic enforcing the extra allocation".

The news is not uniformly gloomy. The survey also showed up the differences in the treatment of part-time teachers by new and old universities. Older universities are more likely to have better provision for improving the teaching abilities of their part-timers, although this is patchy and taken up on a voluntary basis. On the other hand, the new universities are more likely to offer contracts and letters of appointment as well as to carry out formal gender and ethnicity monitoring. Husbands and Davies believe that the new universities have "adopted a more professional approach to the terms and conditions aspects of part-time teachers."

The plight of part-time university teachers has not escaped attention in the past. The Higher Education Quality Council noted the problem in two audit reports in the mid-1990s: "In several institutions, part-time staff were playing a significant role. However, they were often at a disadvantage in respect of access to development and training opportunities compared to full-time colleagues. Also, their administrative and tutorial roles were not always properly acknowledged."

Little has changed.

The report by CT Husbands & A Davies on The teaching roles, institutional locations and terms and conditions of employment of part-time teachers in UK higher education, is in the Journal of Further and Higher Education 24(3)

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

 Research into near-death experiences has been given a new lease of life at Southampton University by an overwhelming response from the public. Dr Sam Parnia has been studying patients who have been declared clinically dead and have then revived. They have recalled a range of feelings and images - implying the mind continues to exist after the brain stops functioning, or an afterlife, he believes. His appeal for more subjects has deluged the university with calls.

 Claims about life on Mars tend to come when a space agency needs funding or publicity, says sceptical Dr Andrew Coates, of University College London. "If life did exist, it was a very long time ago, and it was a very primitive life-form." But maybe he will be more enthusiastic after Boxing Day 2003 when a Beagle lander is due to touch down carrying a special camera he is building.

 However disappointed vice-chancellors might be with their funding from HEFCE's chunky chief executive Sir Brian Fender, no one would call him a Phantom Menace. But he is due to star opposite Star Wars and Trainspotting actor Ewan McGregor at Ulster University's next honorary degree ceremony.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News

Top-up fees still an option

Vice-chancellors insist that top-up fees must remain on the agenda to meet a shortfall of £900m in university funding by 2004. After gathering in Newcastle last week they agreed their funding options report and decided it perhaps had not gone far enough in calling for extra cash.

The president elect of Universities UK, Roderick Floud, said the capital investment for teaching in lecture halls, libraries and computers had been under estimated and more work would be done. They would also investigate the real costs of recruiting and retaining disadvantaged students.

The four options of more money from the taxpayer, market fees, graduate contributions and the Tory's endowment scheme should remain on the table, the group decided. But they are also looking at the possible savings that greater collaboration between institutions might bring.

Research news

Blank cheque

The Scottish executive promised more freedom to academic researchers as it announced it would provide £90m to help universities develop new pharmaceutical drugs and advanced technologies. Universities due to benefit include Edinburgh which will gain £19.49m; Glasgow £14.56m; and Strathclyde £6.7m. Other projects include new astronomy facilities at Glasgow.

Eating people is old

Bristol archaeologists have uncovered evidence of cannibalism among 2,000-year-old bones in a cave in Gloucestershire - just about the time the Romans were arriving. One adult femur was split and the marrow scraped out; one victim had been murdered by a blow to the head.

Universe

Rude cookies

The president of Pennsylvania State University was grilled for three hours by state legislators about a sex education fair that featured anatomically correct gingerbread cookies. Republican representative John Lawless tried to cut off state funds to the university and complained that student emails were not being monitored by the authorities. He is getting rude ones apparently.

Albania is not so bad Forty-six per cent of Albanian academics would take a manual job in the West rather than stay in Albania, according to a survey conducted by Albania's Centre for Economic and Social Studies. This a big improvement over three years ago, when 63% of academics said they would leave.

This a big improvement over three years ago, when 63% of academics said they would leave.

webTitle: The marriage of two teachers' unions

fields.headline: But will they get on?
fields.standfirst: Many dreams rest on the marriage of two teachers' unions, says  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Many dreams rest on the marriage of two teachers' unions, says Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
Lecturers' and teachers' leaders will today announce a "lifelong learning alliance" in a deal which could signal sweeping changes in the profession. The "marriage" brings together the Association of University Teachers, with 40,000 members in the old universities, and the Association of Teachers and Lecturers with 160,000 teachers from pre-schools to secondary schools and further education colleges. Together they form the largest grouping among the education unions.

For years teaching unions have engaged in constant feuding - to the despair of many staffroom members. But the general secretaries of the three largest unions are within sight of retirement, and senior union figures make no secret of their hopes for greater cooperation and the chance to present a united front to the government and the public.

The unions had far too often bickered among themselves instead of present coherent policies, said Peter Smith, general secretary of ATL. "This initiative will set a new tone and a new agenda, and lead within the TUC and beyond to a realignment of the teacher unions." He said this kind of alliance was much more likely than formal mergers.

David Triesman, AUT general secretary, said: "The alliance will add to our mutual influence because it will be clearly seen as an attempt to break new ground and add to the policy debate in a modern and pro-active way."

But the marriage has not been welcomed by the other lecturers' union, Natfhe, which has been jilted in the process. Its higher education "confederation" with the AUT has been put into abeyance after moves towards closer links broke down, and it has been irritated by the ATL's efforts to recruit in further education colleges, where it had been the sole academic union.

Tom Wilson, Natfhe's higher education secretary, called the new alliance "irrelevant". The two higher education bodies were already working with the Educational Institute of Scotland on a joint pay claim for all academics. "There is so much more they could do with us," he said.

Teacher education will be a priority for the new alliance. Triesman said they aimed to create research teams of practising teachers and academics: "There has been an arid debate largely about the amount of on-the-job 'training' and the need to get teaching students away from the influence of what Chris Woodhead saw as dangerous academics. The result has been that there is almost no new thinking about what is needed of the teachers of the coming generation, what new social responsibilities need to accompany their subject and other specialisms. We will create a new view of the teaching profession.

"The unions feel they will be in a position to find new ways of encouraging the flow of pupils from sixth form colleges into higher education. We will work on the standards of numeracy needed to create a superb science base in the UK, an area where we lag the best of the OECD."

He said the new union would help the professional development of teachers at all levels "by sharing and disseminating good practice (and criticising bad)".

The coalition would mean far more than a mutually self-interested trading partnership, said Smith. "The real joint prize will be if we succeed in presenting a powerful and persuasive professional analysis of what the education service needs if it really is to be world class rather than an insular, cut price operation. We also have high on both our agendas the quality of education and training future generations of teachers will receive - and that is a shared schools and higher education agenda."

webTitle: Britain's plans to introduce US-style university entrance tests

fields.headline: Tricky choice
fields.standfirst: Just as Britain is considering introducing US-style university entrance tests, a top American academic has spoken out against them.  Joe Plomin reports
fields.trailText: Just as Britain is considering introducing US-style university entrance tests, a top American academic has spoken out against them. Joe Plomin reports
fields.body:
In his drive to attract more talented inner city children into the best universities, education secretary David Blunkett is considering the introduction of American-style aptitude tests for sixth-formers. Since Laura Spence ended up at Harvard after being rejected by Oxford last year, arguments over access have generated considerable heat. The latest attempt to shed more light on the issue came last week with a pilot study financed by Peter Lampl, a millionaire philanthropist who has been immensely influential in setting the Blair government's agenda on access.

Lampl believes the study shows that at least some children attending poorly performing schools would stand a better chance of being considered on the basis of aptitude tests than they would on A-level results.

But ironically this enthusiasm comes at a time when American universities are voicing concerns that Scholastic Aptitude Tests have the opposite effect - giving well-off students at good schools an unfair advantage.

On this side of the Atlantic, vice-chancellors are deeply divided about how useful aptitude tests would be.

The study, commissioned by Lampl's Sutton Trust, tested 1,300 students at high-achieving and low-achieving schools from around the UK and compared their A-level results. Potentially, bright students from low-achieving schools could be helped into university, the report by the National Foundation for Educational Research concludes. "For low attaining schools [aptitude tests] would lead to an extra 25 pupils from the sample being considered [for university], increasing the percentage of pupils considered from the schools from 4% to 8% (a 100% increase)."

However, the report does not argue that tests would automatically eradicate social disadvantages. Children with parents in professional and managerial occupations did best at both aptitude tests and A-levels. Also, boys tended to do better in the tests than girls.

Meanwhile, the president of the University of California, Richard Atkinson, sparked debate in the US when he announced last month that he wanted his university to stop using SATs, the standard American university entrance exam.

Atkinson believes the aptitude test is "distorting educational priorities". American schools devote time specifically to studying for the aptitude test and anxious parents spend money on extracurricular coaching. Students facing the test memorise long tables of synonyms and practise algebraic questions. Despite evidence that it does not help exam performance, this relentless mugging-up continues.

Although last-ditch swotting might not help, Atkinson clearly believes that better schools get better SATs when he suggests that a broader record of scholastic achievement would allow more children from disadvantaged schools to make it to university.

Because he represents one of the largest US institutions (with 170,000 students), Atkinson's decision rocked American parents and high schools, where "the test" has come to dominate. Although he avoids calling his plans affirmative action to help disadvantaged children, the implication is clear. He thinks that a greater diversity of children will make it to the University of California as a result of the change.

There have been fierce arguments about whether dropping SATs could directly help ethnic minority students in the United States gain equal access to universities. On average, black students score 198 points less than white applicants.

The UK pilot scheme found no evidence that candidates' test scores varied according to their race; but the Laura Spence debate means that universities are taking the idea of aptitude testing seriously.

Warwick University, for instance, which has stiff competition for places, investigated the American example but is now extremely dubious about aptitude testing. Dr Katherine Lloyd Clark, the assistant registrar, made two visits to the US and spoke to eight leading universities about the SATs. She was told that fewer than 20% of entrance decisions are based on test results. The prospect of yet more testing in schools also helped put her off the idea: "We are not convinced aptitude tests are the best idea. We need something that gives us a rounded view of a student. Also, at the moment it's just testing, testing, testing. These kids have been tested all the way down the line. It isn't in their best interest."

Clark believes the money it would cost to set up aptitude tests could be better spent by Warwick University on developing other means of selecting candidates. "There is much more work in the UK to be done benchmarking candidates against other students in the same school, rather than just looking at their grades. We're thinking about building up a database of information about schools and students, particularly in the Midlands."

Other universities share that con cern about introducing more testing. Sussex University's vice-chancellor, Professor Alasdair Smith, says: "While more tests might provide a better overall picture of the abilities of potential students, we have to be very careful about the proliferation of exams and tests. Students in secondary education are already over-tested."

For most courses where competition is not intense, the attempt to introduce a standardised and competitive selection process could be counterproductive, according to Professor Roderick Floud, provost of London Guildhall University and president elect of Universities UK, which represents 122 executive heads of UK higher education institutions. "You can't have standardised admissions processes if you don't have a standardised course system," says Floud.

He argues that where competition is intense, universities need to use every available means, including potentially the right sort of aptitude test, to differentiate between candidates. But, for most courses, the question is irrelevant. "In most cases, we're not talking about the selection of a few candidates for a few places, we're talking about matching many students to many courses. There it's a two-way process where the university has a responsibility to make information about themselves public. Both sides discover whether they suit each other. It's like courtship and marriage," says Prof Floud.

Professor Rick Trainor, the US-educated vice-chancellor of Greenwich University, believes aptitude tests could be useful in the UK: "While I suspect that there's no test that just measures ability without including educational achievement, my bet is that an aptitude test for the UK context could be developed. There is room for empirical research."

What Trainor finds particularly galling is the idea that such tests should be reserved for elite institutions or courses. "An unfortunate aspect of the discussion of access to universities is that it's only been about 'leading' universities. If aptitude tests make sense for leading universities in a complementary way to A-levels then they are going to be useful for all universities. Any university would like as much relevant information as possible."

Edinburgh University's principal agrees that aptitude tests have the potential to help children from low-achieving schools. Professor Sir Stewart Sutherland thinks they could ensure that students who could benefit most from university actually got in: "We have to devise ways of testing potential students who haven't come through ordinary routes. I am convinced there is talent out there not being accessed. Aptitude testing has to be taken very seriously indeed, but we would have to be convinced that the methods work."

In Sutherland's view, arguments about selection obscure the real argument in university entrance. Something prevents some bright children from becoming high-achieving students, and it is that "something" which has to be removed, regardless of the selection process.

"None of this should distract from finding out what prevents students at the starting blocks from making it to us. What is it that is happening down the track that is disadvantaging potential students?"

A Pilot of Aptitude Testing for University Entrance from the National Foundation for Educational Research costs £11 and can be obtained from www.suttontrust.com or 020-8788 3223

A recruit...diminish

B entertain...utilize

C expel...include

D eliminate...replace

E include...discourage

A. about 69%

B. exactly 12%

C. between 1% and 2%

D. exactly 1%

E. less than 1%

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Robot Kit
fields.trailText: Robot Kit
fields.body:
(TTS, www.tts-group.co.uk tel: 0800 318686)

Price: £58.69 inc vat & £3.95 p&p

Age/ability range: 10-11 yrs

The manufacturer says: "A pack of ready-drilled and cut pieces of wood plus syringes, tubing and valves. This kit comes complete with instructions to build a robot as a demonstration of the use of hydraulics."

Jill Cameron, P6-7 teacher, Condorrat primary school, Cumbernauld, Scotland, says: "The children thought the kit was fantastic! It's operated by three cylinders with a turning base unit and elevating arms, and works with air or water, demonstrating both pneumatics and hydraulics. The instructions were good, but didn't include a glossary so assumed a level of technical competence. I felt very daunted when I first saw the kit, but once we got stuck in I saw that it could be done. The class of 10- and 11-year-olds carried out the experiments suggested and constructed the kit from the diagrams provided. The children needed constant supervision as they needed saws and hammers to build the robot. They've gone wild with it since, undertaking more investigations into how much weight the arms can take and which materials it can pick up! It's been very successful and is perfect for DT curriculum work. I haven't used anything like it before."

Curriculum links

webTitle: Action zones do not make much impact, says Ofsted

fields.headline: Action zones do not make much impact, says Ofsted
fields.standfirst:
Flagship initiative fails to raise standards, watchdog warns

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday warned by its schools watchdog that Education Action Zones, one of its flagship initiatives, have not been sufficiently innovative and have failed to make any significant impact on raising standards in secondary schools.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday warned by its schools watchdog that Education Action Zones, one of its flagship initiatives, have not been sufficiently innovative and have failed to make any significant impact on raising standards in secondary schools.

Inspection by the office for standards in education (Ofsted) of six of the longest-established zones, set up by the government to raise standards in disadvantaged areas through local partnerships, found "a mixed picture" overall, with too much variability in effectiveness and impact.

The warning came as the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, promised to increase schools' freedom as part of new-style partnerships between central government and local education authorities.

In an article in the Guardian today, he writes: "The fundamental premise, as made clear in 1997, has always been 'intervention in inverse proportion to success'. Now that we have much greater success and a more positive culture we can develop ... a new sense of partnership. The foundations are in place for the next stage of reform."

He calls for a "new partnership" between government and local authorities and pledges to "enhance autonomy" for successful schools.

A commentary by Ofsted on the inspections of zones in Blackburn, Halifax, Birmingham, Southwark, Salford and Weston-super-Mare, published yesterday, found they had a greater impact in primary schools than secondary. Apart from small-scale activities reducing pupils' disaffection, the zones have had "no significant impact" on standards in secondary schools. The inspectors add that they have not been "test-beds for genuinely innovative action".

The zones allow local partnerships to develop new approaches to raising standards, involving schools, local education authorities, parents, business and other representatives from the community. Each zone typically includes two or three secondary schools with supporting primaries. Private sector cash is then met by government funding.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said: "These inspections show Education Action Zones are helping to drive up standards. I want to thank zones for the good work they are doing, particularly in primary schools. I know some took time to get going, but Ofsted now believes they are making useful contributions to raising standards."

In a speech to the Adam Smith Insitute tonight, Mr Blunkett will refer to a Mori poll of head teachers, commissioned by the government, which appears to show little popularity for Tory plans to abolish LEAs. Asked "What do you think should be the future role of LEAs?", 5% of head teachers said they should be abolished. Some 24% said they should remain as they are. But 27% said they should "improve with greater delegation" and 44% said they should "improve generally".

Mr Blunkett will call for a "new relationship" between the state and the individual. "Government should be there to support and encourage people to help themselves but not to attempt to do everything for them."

Meanwhile, government plans to turn nearly half of all England's comprehensives into specialist schools was given a boost by research showing their pupils got better grades. David Jesson of York University analysed GCSE results at specialist schools last year and found that, on average, 53% of pupils got five A* to C-grade passes. By contrast, ordinary comprehensives saw an average of 43% get five such passes.

 Two of the largest teaching unions will today announce a new alliance. The Association of University Teachers, representing 40,000 members, and the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, representing 160,000, will work jointly on education policy, responses to government policy and services for members.

fields.trailText: Number Shark | Let's Go With Katie
fields.body:
Number Shark

(White Space, £58.97 inc vat, 020-8748 5927)

Age: KS3

This program is particularly useful for supporting KS3 pupils who need to practise their numeracy skills. It enables pupils to engage in the four rules of number using a "small steps" approach. The addition section begins with practice in adding with answers between one and five, and concludes with answers up to 1,000. Subtractions are similarly introduced and developed. Multiplication and division begin with the 2x table and progress to five and 10 before tackling the others. With some spoken calculations, 30 games and an easy interface, this program has much to offer pupils who need variety when reinforcing their number work.

Let's Go With Katie

(Learning and Teaching Scotland, 0141-337 5000, /www.scet.com £35.24 inc vat)

Age: KS2

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at Start with a Song by Mavis de Mierre, and Shylock's Daughter, by Mirjam Pressler
fields.body:
Start with a Song, by Mavis de Mierre

(Brilliant Publications, tel: 01525 222844, sales@brilliantpublications.co.uk, £15.95)

Age: 3-6 yrs

The creator of this collection of 70 songs put it together because she discovered a serious lack of suitable resources to encourage young children to sing. The result is a hefty, utilitarian, spiral-bound volume of simple lyrics, accessible music and sensible supporting ideas. Ideal for non-specialists, music teachers will also find it invaluable when integrating music with the varied demands of the curriculum. A CD is planned later this year but, meanwhile, the book is worth the investment, particularly for early years but also for pupils less familiar with English.

Shylock's Daughter, by Mirjam Pressler, translated by Brian Murdoch

(Macmillan, £4.99)

Age: 12-18 yrs

Pressler's Shylock character is based on Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice, and he's every bit as uncomfortable a character in this novel. The daughter is Jessica, who appeared as a small but incendiary part in the play. The author stays true to the original, but her tale glaringly illuminates some of the more troubling elements of that great drama. Shylock's faith is unshakeable, terrifyingly so. Temporary rebellion is not enough for his daughter. She must escape, but she knows that she is escaping to somebody much less principled than her father, and much less substantial. Despite being set in 1568, this shouldn't be written off as a historical novel.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: We have recently moved to London from Scandinavia. Do I have an alternative to either a state school (huge class sizes, no discipline) or an independent school (too strict and academic) for my five- and 10-year-olds? We want a school where children can think for themselves and where they feel free to be a child, albeit a well-behaved one. Are we asking too much?
fields.trailText: Leading experts answer your problems
fields.body:
The short answer to your question is no: in Britain schools are either state-run (and therefore lacking certain freedoms) or they are independent (and therefore fee-paying). However, there is a "third way". Promoters of a more human-scale approach to education, similar to the one you describe and to that which is widely available in Scandinavia, have set up alternative schools. They tend to describe themselves as the "reluctant private sector" - they are fee-paying because they have to be, but some take only voluntary contributions from parents. We can provide a full list of what is available throughout the country.

You are not asking too much. The majority of parents want an environment like this for their children, and many heads in the state sector are trying to provide it. But the constraints of the national curriculum don't leave space for anything that's not prescribed. The government wants an increase in academic standards, with the emphasis on testing, and the curriculum is geared towards that; children and teachers are under stress even at primary school.

We believe that learning actively by doing is much more effective for a young child than being talked at. Class size is all-important, too; smaller classes allow the teacher to respond to each child as an individual. You should also look for a school with a commitment to drama, arts, nature trips - something wider than a desk-based approach. So look around locally, but remember: you could get together with other like-minded parents and set up your own school or learning centre; we have a workshop on this in London on June 16 this year.

Fiona Carnie
Co-ordinator of the educational charity Human Scale Education

There is a wide variety of schools within the independent sector. Some are so academic that they are totally selective even at four, others are totally mixed-ability and operate on a first-come, first-served basis. So don't give up on the private sector just yet.

If you don't want hot-housing, you should look at schools with a mixed-ability intake. And be aware of how the school operates later on: some split classes in the final two years into a scholarship stream and those who will be making straightforward applications to secondary school.

The problem you may have is that most independent schools in London are very over-subscribed. Also, you won't want your young children to have a long journey, so your choices are further limited by what's available locally. When it comes to behaviour, discipline at home should be the starting point.

Valerie Parr
The Independent Schools Information Service

Steiner education recognises the child as a spiritual being. This informs the respect Steiner teachers have for the children; the child won't notice any difference, but he or she goes to school happily, and it's a very conducive environment to learning. Each child has a teacher who moves up with the class for a daily two-hour lesson, which gives the child a feeling of security. Yes means yes, and no means no: children look up to their teacher for a moral example.

Our schools have mixed-ability classes. They are not just for children with special needs, nor for gifted children; admission is for any child, by interview. In the UK, pupils follow exam curricula. Our results don't appear in the league tables, but they are in fact double the national average. Our curriculum is broad, but we don't believe in introducing things like computers too early, so there is something to look forward to; this means pupils retain the enthusiasm for learning that is the essence of lifelong learning.

Christiana Bryan
Spokeswoman for the Steiner Waldorf Schools Fellowship

Coming next

I have two children aged nine and 11. The trouble is that they tend to take up activities with great enthusiasm, then drop them again as soon as any real effort is required. How can I gently encourage them to persevere?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020 7239 9933 or email to education.letters@theguardian.com

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: Famous artists | The Victorian novel
fields.trailText: Famous artists | The Victorian novel
fields.body:
Famous artists

Web Museum

www.oir.ucf.edu/wm/paint.auth/

Suitable for: KS1/2 teachers & pupils

This brilliant site lists hundreds of well known artists. Click on any of the names for a clear, illustrated biography with useful links and the option to click on any of the given photographs for a much larger, good quality photograph of the art work.

Art History Network

www.arthistory.net/artist.html

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

Like the previous site, this lists famous artists, although it is not as comprehensive. The biographies are difficult for children to read but they will enjoy the high quality reproductions.

Art History

www.arthistory.about.com/arts/arthistory/index.htm

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils, KS1 teachers

This extensive site offers a wide chronological choice. You can also select individual artists. Biographies are fairly easy to read, although the page is rather cluttered. Few illustrations.

Picasso's Guernica

www.grnica.swinternet.co.uk/index.htm

Suitable for: KS2 teachers

A detailed study of this famous work. Well illustrated, the site provokes considerable thought from both artistic and historical perspectives.

Getty

www.artsednet.getty.edu/

Suitable for: KS1/2 teachers

Lesson plans can be sorted by age group and offer more helpful links for a series of lessons around one theme, such as Space Art. A useful US site.

Art.Com

www.art.com

Suitable for: KS1/2 teachers

This is a commercial site selling reproductions of works of art. But it does list a number of famous artists and by selecting one, a number of images of their works appear. There isn't much information but it is a good way to see great works well displayed.

Compiled by Jim Merrett

The Victorian Novel

The Victorian Web

landow.stg.brown.edu/victorian/victov.html

Suitable for: KS4/5 pupils & teachers

The place for research into Victorian science, religion, manners and art. The picture gallery is especially strong, and is recommended as the first port of call in a study of Victorian idealisations of women.

Novel Guide

www.novelguide.com

Suitable for: KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

Aims to guide a student through main ideas, characters and images in a novel. The list of novels included is impressive (Brontë, Dickens and Eliot figure), as is the attempt to provide a plot synopsis for each one. User-friendly.

Voice of the Shuttle

vos.ucsb.edu/shuttle/ eng-vict.html

Suitable for: teachers & KS5 students

The most scholarly and literary site available on the subject, hosted by the University of California. As well as a range of reliable e-texts and links to some good author specific sites, Voice of the Shuttle boasts sections on Victorian sensation writing and Gaskell's Life of Charlotte Brontë.

Key terms in Literature

courses.nus.edu.sg/course/ellibst/lsl01-tm.html

Suitable for: KS4/5 pupils & teachers

Links to sites giving workable definitions of rhetorical and literary terms. Very user-friendly, and a good deal more accessible than some books on the subject.

Victoria Research Web

www.indiana.edu/~victoria/teaching.html

Suitable for: teachers & KS5 pupils

An unusual site carrying a list of (mostly university) courses dealing with Victorian literature. Interesting to see how other teachers have laid out their syllabuses, especially if you are proposing to teach a Victorian novel as part of a synoptic A-level unit. The site also takes you to some very interesting US university sites which can be used as part of a research or coursework project.

Compiled by Lyndsey Turner

fields.headline: 'We  are winning'
fields.standfirst: Poor old  David Blunkett. First the teachers vote for industrial action, then Chris Woodhead launches his broadside in the Telegraph. Here, the education secretary defends himself
fields.trailText: Poor old David Blunkett. First the teachers vote for industrial action, then Chris Woodhead launches his broadside in the Telegraph. Here, the education secretary defends himself
fields.body:
There is widespread recognition that the government's education reforms have been successful. Standards in literacy and numeracy at primary level have risen dramatically. GCSE and A-level results are up. School failure and local education authority underperformance have been firmly tackled. Of course there is still much to do. We need to see through the changes at primary level and build on them at secondary level to modernise the comprehensive system and deliver higher standards. But perhaps the most important changes of all are in the culture of the education service. The old despair that characterised the education service before 1997 is being replaced by a can-do culture. As a result of the remarkable progress at primary level, there is a new belief that rapid, fundamental reform can be achieved.

In bringing about these changes I have sought to strike the right balance between driving change from the centre and decentralising decision-making to schools. Getting this right is a difficult issue of public policy not just in education. It is also the case that the balance can be changed over time. In education, for example, what we inherited in 1997 cried out for a clear vision. Leadership was required at national, as well as at education authority and school level. Now that the culture has changed significantly, the same clear vision and sense of direction can be pursued through a new partnership with schools and local education authorities.

Let me illustrate. I make no apologies for the prescription in the literacy and numeracy strategies. We had to deal with the failure of teacher training over decades. Primary teachers wanted to teach mental arithmetic, to embrace phonics and to ensure high standards of grammar and spelling but there had been no attempt to enable them to do so. Our strategies have put that right and as a result of teachers' efforts primary schools have been transformed.

Similarly, we had to deal with the challenge of failing schools. In 1997 I was appalled at the way so many failing schools had been neglected. The life chances of thousands of children were at stake. Now, as a result of our tough central prescription and the efforts of local authorities, 667 schools have been successfully turned round, another 123 have been closed and a small number given a Fresh Start. We have taken an equally robust approach to failing local authorities with similar success. Ofsted reported recently that "there were considerable signs of improvement this year across a wide range of functions . . ."

The results of these three central interventions speak for themselves. Without them we would not have made nearly as much progress but I have never taken the view that central direction was the only way.

In fact, while these centrally driven policies have been working through, I have simultaneously been devolving more power, funding and responsibility to schools. We now delegate 84% of the education budget to schools, up from 79% in 1997. Heads welcome the opportunity this gives them to make decisions at school level.

The dilemma for many on the right is that they want intervention where they regard it as important but in the same breath proclaim the virtues of "free schools". The real world is rather more complex and demands a balance of the sort that we are achieving.

The fundamental premise, as made clear in 1997, has always been "intervention in inverse proportion to success". Now that we have much greater success and a more positive culture, we can develop, as we put it in the green paper published on February 12, a new sense of partnership. The foundations are in place for the next stage of reform.

We will enhance autonomy for successful schools. The new light-touch inspection approach should become the norm for those that demonstrate continuous success. We want a more diverse system too, with each secondary school developing its own ethos and mission and many becoming specialist or Beacon Schools.

Schools are increasingly determined to seek best practice and innovative ideas from each other. Central government will continue to intervene on behalf of pupils if necessary but, increasingly, its central tasks will be to create a climate in which everyone works together to achieve world-class performance.

fields.headline: Chips all round
fields.standfirst: The farm at the centre of the foot and mouth outbreak fed its pigs leftover school dinners, it was reported last week. So, what do children eat at school, and is it only fit for pigs?  John Crace and  Children's Express report
fields.trailText: The farm at the centre of the foot and mouth outbreak fed its pigs leftover school dinners, it was reported last week. So, what do children eat at school, and is it only fit for pigs? John Crace and Children's Express report
fields.body:
Amid the more widespread concerns for British farming, many parents will have permitted themselves a wry smile at reports that the farm at the centre of the foot and mouth outbreak had fed its pigs on leftover school dinners. After all, what better confection to turn the little piggies into proper porkers than that which has transformed the nation's children into Europe's newly crowned top chubsters?

If you check out the average school canteen, it doesn't take long to work out how Britain achieved its pre-eminence in the obesity stakes. The queues for the burgers, chips and pizza stretch round the block, while the one for the better-value "healthy option", which may even include the odd vegetable, is eerily empty. And if you do come across someone choosing the healthy option, the chances are it is only because the pizza has run out. In the battle for the hearts and tums of our children, the multibillion-pound fast food industry is winning hands down.

It's not all bad news, though. Most food experts believe that standards have risen, albeit slowly, in the aftermath of the BSE crisis and from the beginning of next month the deregulation of school dinners will come to an end. From April 1, headteachers will be held to account for the service they provide and the school meals must meet minimum nutritional standards and offer pupils balance, variety and choice.

"To be honest," says Joe Harvey, director of the Health Education Trust, "the minimum standards won't trouble most caterers. Where they will have an impact is on those authorities that only provide packed lunches as it will be hard to providevariety and choice without costing a great deal more."

Eating well is not just about physical well-being; a balanced healthy diet has been proven to have knock-on benefits, such as improved concentration, and there are indications that additives can contribute to behavioural difficulties. So how come schools don't just sling all the junk off the menu? The answer is money. Remove burgers and pizzas and the kids will bunk off to McDonald's, and no caterer is going to pitch for a contract to serve just a handful of kids.

Moreover, with free meals pegged to a budget of £1.25, there is a limit to just how exotic a school dinner can be. So rather than tasty M&S bangers, you tend to get sausages filled with a slurry of pig and chicken bones, aka mechanically recovered meat (MRM).

There are links between low-income families and obesity, and many kids certainly have their poor eating habits reinforced at home, but few school children are so dim they don't know the difference between healthy and unhealthy eating. The point is they don't care; they are still young enough to believe themselves immortal. So how do you get children to recognise the long-term benefits and opt for the pasta and salad instead of a wedge of super-saturated pizza?

"One shouldn't automatically assume that pizza is an unhealthy option," counters Luci Daniels, the independent state-registered dietician who sat on the committee that advised the government on the new school meals standards, and who monitored the food diaries of our five guinea-pigs (right). Phoebe Saunders, 10
Hugh Myddelton Junior Infants School, north London.

Breakfast: Sugarpuffs with milk.

School dinner: Two fishfingers, chips and baked beans; water. Plain doughnut and custard.

Dinner: Chicken in breadcrumbs, chips and peas; a beaker of Ribena. "Fab" ice lolly.

Phoebe says: "When the school makes custard they leave the skin on the top, ugh, totally disgusting. It would be nice if we had bigger portions and there isn't enough healthy food on the menu. We have chips, pizzas, fishfingers and sausages at least once or twice a week. I'd rather have packed lunch in the summer than school dinners so I can eat it outside in the sunshine."

Luci Daniels says: "Kids shouldn't have sugar-coated cereals. Her lunch isn't bad, but she's had chips twice in the day - she should switch one of the portions for another starchy but non-fried food, like pasta or rice or a jacket potato. James Fletcher, 12
Holloway School, north London.

Breakfast: Kellogg's Honey Nut Cornflakes with semi-skimmed milk.

Pre-school snack: Apple turnover and packet of Polos.

School dinner: Southern fried chicken and chips with ketchup and added salt; blueberry-flavoured soft drink.

Pre-dinner snack: Rhubarb-flavoured lollipop.

Dinner: Lamb chops, mashed potatoes and carrots. Lemon curd tart and a piece of Mr Kipling's Battenburg cake.

James says: "The dinners are nice but the portions are stingy. I've never seen salad on the menu. Fruit is available, but I don't eat it because my favourite - chicken and chips - takes up all of my £1.25. Most days I eat pizza, a packet of crisps and a currant bun."

Henrietta Barnett School in Hampstead, north London.

Breakfast: Frosties with milk.

School dinner: Chicken burger, bottle of water.

Afternoon snack: Fruit smoothie.

Pre-dinner snack: One banana and two biscuits with blueberry jam.

Dinner: Burger, chips and beans. Pink grapefruit juice. One tangerine.

Depending on the size of it, it's probably around 300 calories. A school meal should be providing at least double that quantity. She should have a jacket potato and some salad and vegetables, maybe even some dessert. She could pad out breakfast with some fruit. What she's had as a pre-dinner snack is fine. Hugh Myddelton Junior Infants School, north London.

Breakfast: Two slices toast (white) and butter; one glass orange juice.

School dinner: Chicken curry and rice; brown and white bread; glass of water. Apple crumble and custard.

Dinner: Cheese and tomato pizza and mixed salad; orange juice; lemonade.

Cindy says: "School dinners are tasty. My favourite is burger, chips and beans or pizza, chips and beans. I drink water every day at school because they don't provide anything else. Luci Daniels says: "Cindy's lunch is pretty good. On the face of it, it might look like a big lunch, but I'd hazard a guess that the chicken curry probably isn't that high in fat. She's having a glass of water, which is pretty good and the apple crumble and custard will pad out the calorie content, which she needs. The custard will provide calcium, which growing girls need for their bones. It would be nice if the meal contained some vegetables. For her fruit, she's relying quite heavily on juice in the morning; she should eat more fruit over the rest of the day."

Zak Garner-Purkis, 13
Acland Burghley School in north London.

Breakfast: Bowl of Granola with semi-skimmed milk; pint of water.

School dinner: Baked potato with a side serving of rice and some bread. Can of Diet Pepsi. Chocolate-chip muffin.

Pre-dinner snack: Two slices of toast with margarine.

Dinner: Chicken in sauce with brown rice and broccoli; pint of water. Pancakes with lemon and sugar; water.

Zak says: "There are salads but most of the hot food is junk. It's greasy and there's not much healthy food. The fruit juices are sickly sweet. Most of my friends tend to eat pizza or chips or both, washed down with a can of Coke. Normally I have water but it's very expensive to buy at the canteen and you have to save your money for an affordable meal. I usually take in my own water as people spit in the fountain."

Luci Daniels says: "For a young man of 13, his daily calorie requirements are about 2,200. He's not eating enough. One bowl of Granola isn't enough for breakfast. For lunch, he's having three starches - potato, rice and bread - and nothing with it. He's not chosen well from what's on offer. The only dairy he's getting is in the morning. The new school meal nutritional requirements say children should have a starch, a meat equivalent and a fruit, veg and a dairy on offer. He's not having any of these groups other than starch. It is a low-fat meal, but it does not have a range of nutrients. "

webTitle: Teachers refusing to cover for vacancies

fields.headline: Are you ready?
fields.standfirst: It's not just Doncaster and London - teachers all over the country are refusing to cover for vacancies, and your child could be the next to be sent home.  Martin Wainwright and  Claire Phipps  ask, how long will parents' sympathy for teachers last?
fields.trailText: It's not just Doncaster and London - teachers all over the country are refusing to cover for vacancies, and your child could be the next to be sent home. Martin Wainwright and Claire Phipps ask, how long will parents' sympathy for teachers last?
fields.body:
Jade Jobes crumpled her mitten in a goodbye wave to her mum, Dawn, at a Doncaster school gate yesterday, in a gesture which up to half-a-million school students may soon be making only four days a week.

Back at home in the suburb of Scawthorpe, a former mining community where the word "strike" has many resonances, the eight-year-old's bedtime reading now includes the Doncaster Star, with its bulletins on the local teachers' vote in favour of working to contract.

Last week, members of the two largest school teaching unions, the National Union of Teachers and National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, voted overwhelmingly - 93% in favour - to stop covering unfilled vacancies and staff absences of more than three days.

The action starts a week tomorrow in Doncaster and the 32 LEAs of Greater London. Ballots in Manchester, Nottingham, Kent, Portsmouth, Southampton, Leicester, Middlesbrough and Reading close next week, with the results expected to go the same way.

And at the end of last week, the NUT announced plans to ballot its members in Hertfordshire, Sandwell, Hartlepool, Ipswich, Liverpool, Barnsley, the Medway Towns and Rochdale. The disruption, when it comes, will be the first to hit classrooms in England since the mid-1980s, when teachers took action over extra workload triggered by Sats.

Aware of potentially negative reactions to empty classrooms and enforced childcare crises, the unions are keen to win the support of parents for these measures. "Parents probably don't know what's happening in schools," argues Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT. "Surely it is better for children to have four days of good-quality education than five days of second-rate education?"

In the sunshine and snow of a Scawthorpe morning, the "quality not quantity" argument has plenty of support, as Don Valley high school pupils mingle with parents, buggies and the lollipop lady outside Castle Hills primary.

"Yes, I'm worried," admits Dawn Jobes. "I don't want to see Jade or any other kiddies sent home from school. But I certainly don't want teachers having to double-up classes and take other shortcuts with the kids' education. You've got to see the whole picture."

It's a view echoed in London, where teacher shortages are most severe and four-day weeks a more immediate threat. Jane Martin, whose son attends a primary school in south London, last week contacted the school's head for reassurance. "She said that at the moment they were OK, but the slightest thing could mean they'd have to go on a four-day week - sickness or maternity leave could be enough.

"The thought of children being sent home fills me with dread. I don't know what I'd do - work from home? But I completely support what the teachers are doing, even though it puts me in a difficult situation."

Mark Stanley, a supermarket warehouseman in Doncaster, shares the same tug of contradictory feelings, as he hands his seven-year-old daughter Samantha her Tigger bag, dangling its long black and orange tail. He sympathises with teachers, but wouldn't have patience for long if Sam and her brother Aron were sent home.

"The teachers say they're going to put the children's education first, and so they should," he said. "We're all trying our best to give them a good start. We definitely don't want them missing school."

Castle Hills' head, Graham Sewell, says that he and his staff take the same view. Teachers have agreed to abandon long-arranged days away for courses if the result would be no cover and children sent home.

Action by the NUT and the NASUWT will kick in immediately on such pre-arranged absences. Pat Maguire in the NUT's regional office in Doncaster says that everyone is waiting to see where the over-stretched supply system will crack first. A Roman Catholic primary is one front-runner in Doncaster; a high school with an obdurate "hard-to-fill" vacancy is another.

Stephen Fletcher, head of Sherwood Park primary in Bexley, Kent, is keeping a close eye on the situation following the Greater London ballot. "We're not thinking about a four-day week at the moment, because we've got no vacancies or missing staff, but I know we're extremely lucky," he says. Neighbouring schools are not so fortunate. "Secondary schools in Bexley are already discussing the possibility of a four-day week. I can see it happening. Holes will appear all over the place."

Other heads are optimistic that short-term gaps can be plugged. But the pressures underlying the unions' decision to ballot point to classroom shutdowns before the end of March.

"To try to keep continuity for the children, we book supply teachers months ahead from a pool of people we know," says Sewell. "But there are only so many, and the demand can be huge. You might get a course which takes a teacher - in some cases two - from each of Doncaster's 130 schools. Just that means 200 supply teachers in one go."

The town's director of education, Matthew Simpson, has taken the first step in a limited emergency plan by writing to every recently retired teacher - several thousand of them - still living reasonably nearby to ask for supply stints. The problem is exacerbated, he says, by the fact that Inland Revenue rules allow recently retired teachers only so many days' work per year, and many of the regulars have used up their quota so close to the end of the tax year.

Some may simply not wish to return to the classroom. John Coe, of the National Association of Primary Education, runs a returners' course for former teachers. "The trained teachers are out there, but most of them won't come back," he says. "Stressed teachers are not the best thing for children. And stress means that occasional absences mount and the need for supply teachers is even greater."

Maguire predicts that "challenging schools" - in socially and economically deprived areas or with difficult pupils - will be among the first to have send-homes, as supply colleagues opt for easier billets. It's a view shared by Alan Carter, a parent and school governor in north London. "What worries me is that it is the most disadvantaged schools in the most de prived areas which will be the worst affected, when they are the ones least able to cope. They are the schools that are finding it hard to fill vacancies, so the impact will be worse."

Mike Townsend and his colleague Bob Johnson, whose high schools at Balby Carr and Don Valley both have "demanding" pupils on their 1,450-strong rolls, are taking measures common across the affected LEAs. But the first and most obvious one, of prioritising exam-year pupils, is a stark illustration of the pressures which the unions blame for the current crisis.

"We'll protect year nine because they're coming up to Sats," says Johnson. "Then there's year 11 doing GCSEs this summer and year 13 doing A-levels." Townsend chips in: "And year 12 doing AS-levels," leaving both computing briefly just how many years are not priority cases now.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, is concerned that the action could add to the strains that schools are already suffering: "This will make life more difficult because it introduces tensions between heads and their staff."

"The head has to tread very carefully," agrees Fletcher. "The child's education must not suffer. But you need to work with your teachers and be able to explain the situation to them. Morale is still very low."

Many heads are optimistic about avoiding send-homes, but Maguire believes that schools will be gradually boxed into a corner. The NUT's 1,000-odd members in Doncaster will follow the contract action, he says, and cover is bound to fail somewhere, when supply arrangements falter and health and safety implications of unsupervised children arise.

Parents meanwhile are starting to consider the prospect of how they would cope if children came back home for an extra day or at odd hours.

"It's not inconceivable that you'd have children off school on different days," says Anne Armstrong. She supports the action but, with two young children at school in Hackney and a teacher husband still on a five-day week, is weighing up the short-term inconveniences. "I'd have to take on the childcare myself. I could hire extra help, but most people can't."

Kate Green of the National Council for One Parent Families is especially concerned. "Lone parents are very vulnerable," she says. "Employers are not necessarily sympathetic and lone parents in particular cannot afford to lose income. We are worried about how they would cope."

Karen Hinds and Lynne Shephard, dropping off their children Niall and Nicole at Castle Hills, confirm that, although the four-day week is not an immediate threat to them, worries are starting to spread.

"It's bad for the kids but it'd be an added worry for anyone who'd got to think about making arrangements to have someone to collect at odd times or be there for them at home," says Hinds.

The unions remain convinced that parents will understand their reasons for the action. They certainly need the support of those most affected - and that, in reality, means parents, as few children will be complaining about an extra day away from their desks. Certainly those dropping sons and daughters off at the school gates appreciate that something has to be done to force a resolution to the current crisis. But a general sympathy for the teachers doesn't necessarily translate into an enthusiasm for regular days away from the classroom. Fletcher can see problems ahead: "Most parents do understand the pressures, but if it starts to affect their children directly, I think that this goodwill would be lost very quickly."

Some names have been changed. Additional reporting by Rebecca Smithers.

Maguire predicts that "challenging schools" - in socially and economically deprived areas or with difficult pupils - will be among the first to have send-homes, as supply colleagues opt for easier billets. It's a view shared by Alan Carter, a parent and school governor in north London. "What worries me is that it is the most disadvantaged schools in the most de prived areas which will be the worst affected, when they are the ones least able to cope. They are the schools that are finding it hard to fill vacancies, so the impact will be worse." Mike Townsend and his colleague Bob Johnson, whose high schools at Balby Carr and Don Valley both have "demanding" pupils on their 1,450-strong rolls, are taking measures common across the affected LEAs. But the first and most obvious one, of prioritising exam-year pupils, is a stark illustration of the pressures which the unions blame for the current crisis. "We'll protect year nine because they're coming up to Sats," says Johnson. "Then there's year 11 doing GCSEs this summer and year 13 doing A-levels." Townsend chips in: "And year 12 doing AS-levels," leaving both computing briefly just how many years are not priority cases now. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, is concerned that the action could add to the strains that schools are already suffering: "This will make life more difficult because it introduces tensions between heads and their staff." "The head has to tread very carefully," agrees Fletcher. "The child's education must not suffer. But you need to work with your teachers and be able to explain the situation to them. Morale is still very low." Many heads are optimistic about avoiding send-homes, but Maguire believes that schools will be gradually boxed into a corner. The NUT's 1,000-odd members in Doncaster will follow the contract action, he says, and cover is bound to fail somewhere, when supply arrangements falter and health and safety implications of unsupervised children arise. Parents meanwhile are starting to consider the prospect of how they would cope if children came back home for an extra day or at odd hours. "It's not inconceivable that you'd have children off school on different days," says Anne Armstrong. She supports the action but, with two young children at school in Hackney and a teacher husband still on a five-day week, is weighing up the short-term inconveniences. "I'd have to take on the childcare myself. I could hire extra help, but most people can't." Kate Green of the National Council for One Parent Families is especially concerned. "Lone parents are very vulnerable," she says. "Employers are not necessarily sympathetic and lone parents in particular cannot afford to lose income. We are worried about how they would cope." Karen Hinds and Lynne Shephard, dropping off their children Niall and Nicole at Castle Hills, confirm that, although the four-day week is not an immediate threat to them, worries are starting to spread. "It's bad for the kids but it'd be an added worry for anyone who'd got to think about making arrangements to have someone to collect at odd times or be there for them at home," says Hinds. The unions remain convinced that parents will understand their reasons for the action. They certainly need the support of those most affected - and that, in reality, means parents, as few children will be complaining about an extra day away from their desks. Certainly those dropping sons and daughters off at the school gates appreciate that something has to be done to force a resolution to the current crisis. But a general sympathy for the teachers doesn't necessarily translate into an enthusiasm for regular days away from the classroom. Fletcher can see problems ahead: "Most parents do understand the pressures, but if it starts to affect their children directly, I think that this goodwill would be lost very quickly." Some names have been changed. Additional reporting by Rebecca Smithers.
