fields.headline: Back out in the outback
fields.standfirst: Eager to see more of the Australian outback after  Frazer Island, Sam heads for Uluru and finds an ingenious way to combat the heat
fields.trailText: Week 13, Sydney to Uluru Eager to see more of the Australian outback after Frazer Island, Sam heads for Uluru and finds an ingenious way to combat the heat
fields.body:
Getting off the plane at Alice Springs was like stepping into a furnace. The sun was beating down out of a clear blue sky, but the surrounding landscape was a scorched ochre. The temperature was over 40C. It was like a wall of heat. I sweated my way to the relief of the air-conditioned terminal.

I had come to the centre of Australia to go on a three-day outback camping tour, taking in some of the highlights of the Northern Territory, including Uluru (Ayers Rock), the Olgas and Kings Canyon.

Alice Springs has grown up around the tourist trade, and there were plenty of hotels lining the road from the airport. As soon as I got to my hostel I dived into the shade and stayed there until the sun dropped and the temperature became slightly more normal.

The next morning, I was up at 6am to meet my bus. I was travelling with Sahara Tours. There were 19 in our group and Dave, an Englishman who had emigrated to Australia 12 years ago, was our guide.

Australia is vast and it takes a really long time to get anywhere. We had to drive for 400 kilometres to reach Uluru: it took most of the day. We passed camel farms and stopped at isolated roadhouses to stock up on cold drinks. We saw Aboriginal ranchers herding cattle along the highway. At one point, a dust devil made up of whirling red sand and tumbleweed swept across the road in front of us.

Arriving in the Ayers Rock resort, we sorted ourselves out in the campsite and then went to have a look round the Aboriginal Culture Centre. Uluru is of immense religious significance to the Aboriginal community; they believe that such features were formed during the Dreamtime - or creation - when their ancient god-like ancestors moved through the landscape. There are numerous stories about Uluru and the battles and incidents that formed it - many of which are known only to the local people (look at Sam's photos).

The displays in the centre explained that the Aboriginals regard Uluru as a spiritual place: it is part of them, and as such they would prefer people to respect their ancestors and not climb it. This caused some debate among our group as we drove out to the sunset viewing area. Tomorrow we would have the opportunity to see the rock up close, and climb it if we wished.

Sunset was impressive, but still a bit of an anti-climax for me. Everyone has seen Uluru on television or in magazines and inevitably, the reality does not live up to your expectations (particularly when you have to share the experience with busloads of other tourists).

The next morning we were up at 4.30am, and it was still dark as we made our way to the start of the path up Uluru. On seeing the sheer face and the flimsy rail that ran up the steep incline, I was more than happy to respect the Aboriginals' wishes and stick to the walk round the base. There was no one else about. As I gradually made my way around, the rock changed from grey to a deep, vibrant red. In the early morning light and the strange stillness that envelops Uluru, I began to understand its significance to the Aboriginals.

Back on the bus we were headed for the Olgas when I suddenly realised that I had dropped my hat. This was not good news. It would be madness to go out in the sun without some sort of protection. Clearly I would have to improvise.

A little later, tourists getting off the other buses were treated to the sight of an odd-looking character coming down from the hills. Was it Yasser Arafat on holiday? Laurence of Arabia, perhaps? No, it was me with a tea towel round my head. It actually worked quite well: I could put my head under the tap and soak the cloth to keep myself cool.

This was the first time I had encountered the sort of heat that could kill you. There were plenty of stories about people expiring among the rocks because they hadn't taken enough water with them. Dave made sure we were all carrying plenty - at least a couple of litres each - when we ventured out. Back at the campsite, I slept out under the stars - partly for the experience and partly to get away from the extremely poisonous redback spider that was sharing my tent.

Next day began with another early morning rise in order to get to Kings Canyon before the heat made walking unbearable. The canyon turned out to be another ancient rock feature with a beautiful green oasis and a deep, dark pool sandwiched between the steep rock sides. We dived in to cool off - it was lovely.

Then it was back to the bus for the long, hot drive to Alice Springs. In the evening the group all met up for the traditional goodbye meal in a local bar. I tried kangaroo steak (if you are interested, it tastes like a slightly tougher version of veal).

And the following day, with not a little trepidation, I caught the plane to Perth for my connecting flight into Africa. Until next week...

fields.headline: Tender loving care
fields.standfirst: Competition: The school I'd like The entries are flooding in. In this week's preview, Donna, 15, dreams of better schools for those in care. Plus how to enter
fields.trailText: Competition: The school I'd like The entries are flooding in. In this week's preview, Donna, 15, dreams of better schools for those in care. Plus how to enter
fields.body:
This is my 18th residential care placement. I've been to so many schools I can't even remember how many - from primary to primary, although I've only had two secondary schools.

"I've been at this school now for four years and I'm in my first year of GCSEs. It's very hard, but I'm hanging in there.

"I don't think my school will change: it's too old. My ideal school would be less time - starting at half nine and finishing at three.

"The one subject that shouldn't be there is RE. Most of us are not religious, so I don't see the point. And there's no proof, is there? We should be able to choose what subjects we do, like sixth-formers. And you have to have time for sports and be encouraged to do it. There should be mixed football, but that's down to the FA.

"Schools should be more flexible about uniform. We're not allowed certain jackets, and have to wear cotton trousers when it's really cold. We're not allowed to wear short skirts, or certain heels. It's so the teachers can pick you out and identify what school you're from.

"I'm involved in a project for young people in care because I'm basically a good example of how to cope with education, going through so many placements. It has been difficult, but I think I've handled it quite well. People have helped me to get through problems, and to catch up and work harder.

"It's important to be treated equally, as normal students. My teachers don't care where we're from. Most kids in care do get a lot of questions. But I don't mind.

"After my GCSEs, hopefully I'll go to college. I'll still get social services help with money for education. But it's really appalling that some people in care don't get a good education. Just because you live in care doesn't mean you've done something wrong."

It's not too late to enter the competition to describe "The School I'd Like". The closing date for entries is Friday, March 30, so there's still time to put together your plan for the school of your dreams. Do you agree with Donna's views? Or do you have ideas about how classrooms should be designed, what teachers should know before they step in front of the blackboard, or what rights pupils should have?

Your entry can take any form you like. We have had entries ranging from powerpoint presentations to poems, and even a single sentence with one wish. All your ideas will count - they will be part of a new archive of what children really think about education. Watch this space for details of a conference to discuss the inspirational ideas that you come up with.

To enter the competition: Email education@theguardian.com or write to Education Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER for an entry form. Please include a postal address. See theguardian.com/ education for more details. The prizes: the winner in each of the three categories (primary; years 7-9; years 10-13) will receive £10,000 of Toshiba ICT equipment and Microsoft software for their school.

Thanks to the National Children's Bureau www.ncb.org.uk

fields.headline: Spreading the word
fields.standfirst: This is the government which will finally solve the adult illiteracy problem, says  Malcolm Wicks
fields.trailText: This is the government which will finally solve the adult illiteracy problem, says Malcolm Wicks
fields.body:
How can you tell a bedtime story to your four-year-old if you cannot read? What do you do if you have a splitting headache but can't understand the instructions on the paracetemol bottle? What do you do next if you are sacked by the boss when he finds out you are illiterate?

These dilemmas face people every day. It is shocking that up to seven million adults in England cannot read and write as well as we expect our 11-year-olds to and even more have problems with numbers. Some simply cannot read at all.

The cost to the country could be £10bn a year; to the individual it is incalculable. People with low basic skills earn on average £50,000 less over their working lives, are more likely to have health problems and be excluded from society in many ways. The statistics show that they are more likely to turn to crime.

I want to see this change. Our crusade is to improve the chances of these people so they can gain the skills they need for the twenty-first century. If we do not, then millions risk being cut off from the advantages of a society increasingly linked through information and technology.

Our target, set out in our strategy Skills for Life, is that 750,000 adults will improve their literacy and numeracy by 2004. In the longer term we want to make sure that the country has one of the best adult literacy and numeracy rates in the world. Ultimately we want to eliminate the problem altogether.

Across government we will spend £1.5bn in the next three years to achieve this. We will give a lead as an employer from the Army to the NHS, but this is not just about government. Business has a vital role to play along with voluntary organisations, local community groups and trades unions.

With the hard work and commitment of teachers we are already tackling under-achievement in schools. Today children are reading, writing and using numbers better than at any time in the past.

I am determined that adults should have the same chances to make progress. To date, much of what has been provided has been ineffective at improving literacy and numeracy skills with many not progressing beyond where they started. I find this unacceptable.

There are some shining exceptions however. People like Sue Torr who returned to learning aged 38 after years of struggling with practical difficulties and the stigma associated with poor basic skills. She tackled her problem. Sue and her "Shout it Out" team now tour schools, colleges, prisons and community centres encouraging others to take the first step.

To succeed we need co-ordina tion. The new Adult Basic Skills Strategy Unit will be based at DfEE. They will ensure that the planning and delivery of literacy and numeracy skills provision is co-ordinated between government and is coherent across all national and local policies and provision.

We have identified a series of target groups, including the unemployed and prisoners, and we have set up nine Pathfinder projects in areas which will try innovative new approaches to basic skills teaching.

One of the main difficulties is reaching and convincing people they need help, but anyone who needs training can find out more by calling learndirect on 0800-100900.

Education and training opportunities will be entirely free no matter where it is provided or who provides it. Some will want to learn in the classroom, others at work and others at home. Some will want to learn literacy and numeracy as part of their other studies. We plan to provide two million flexible learning opportunities over the next three years to meet demand.

I do not deny that the challenge of reducing poor adult literacy and numeracy levels is a great one. It is something that has eluded us in the past. It is now something we cannot fail to beat and it will benefit all in our community.

To find out more and get involved contact our website on: www.dfee.gov.uk/readwriteplus. Malcolm Wicks is the minister for lifelong learning.

fields.headline: Snap happy
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock finds he has no place in the new college brochure
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock finds he has no place in the new college brochure
fields.body:
I have long got used to the fact that students do not seem to notice me when I am trying to get their attention in class, but to be completely wiped from the pages of history is difficult to accept.

Let me explain. Excuse me, I said let me explain. I should have known better than to get involved with the planning of the new college prospectus. No one at the meetings seemed to listen to my objections to calling the publication a brochure.

I said that a brochure sounds like something you consult for a holiday, and therefore the name would suggest that college is little more than a holiday camp. No one, it seems, heard me passionately defending the traditional-sounding "prospectus" against such new names as directory, style guide and menu.

The planning of the new prospectus, sorry brochure, was marked by disagreement. We could not agree on our brand identity. I said I thought we were thinking of running a variation on our usual smiley student faces on every other page. Patty, our head of corporate communications, said that we should be selling an attitude.

It came as a surprise to discover that one of my lessons was chosen for a photo shoot. Well, I was the only one surprised when the door opened and in walked a troupe of people with lights, tripods and plenty of attitude.

"I didn't know you were coming in today."

"Change of plan," said Patty into her Dictaphone. "Beauty therapists on work experience. Substitute . . . what's this subject?" she asked one of my students.

"Old dead male poets," replied Roxanne.

Tables were moved, books hidden and my posters of Germaine Greer and David Lodge replaced with assorted members of Big Brother, series one. Students were grouped into small huddles and I was told to visit each one and stand over them. Shutters clicked and flashguns went off.

"Hand on chin and elbow up a bit," snapped Patty. Give it some attitude," she advised. I tried not to smile.

After the photographers had departed the students were star-struck and refused to settle down.

"What was all that for?" asked Roxanne.

"The college brochure," I mumbled as I busied myself trying to repair a rip across Germaine's forehead.

I stopped going to the prospectus planning meetings as a sign of protest over the way the project was being managed. I took no further part in its creation. So it was with a sense of apathy that I approached the brochure upon its publication.

I noticed some of my students flipping between its bright orange and green covers, looking for pictures of themselves. In fact, everyone seemed to have a copy. I accosted my mate Colin from maths and asked to have the one he was about to toss into a wastepaper bin.

There on the front cover of the new brochure is my class. And there is Roxanne, who appears to be leading an animated discussion. No one is smiling, but they are all displaying a certain kind of attitude. But where am I? I am missing, replaced by a slightly out-of-focus Nasty Nick.

I am not sure I like this. But who am I to say anything?

Nice food. Ya.

Lots of booze. Ya.

So, what's your line of work then? Investment analyst.

Oh, the rag trade. Pardon?

Vestments. Not vestments. Investment.

Ah, I see. You analyse investment. Correct.

Keeps you busy? Ah, I think my wife wants a word?

Hang on. What does that entail, then? What?

Your job? An investment analyst tries to predict the long- and short-term performance of securities and decide what will be a good buy for investors, both within the UK and foreign markets. They also deal in commodities, futures and options.

Um, right. We study financial and performance data of securities and incorporate this with knowledge gained from companies' annual reports, government statistics, regulations and legislation, and then make forecasts and representations to clients.

I think my wife's calling me now. You wanted to know. We work in two fields, as a stockbroker's investment analyst or as institutional investment analysts.

That's fascinating. Anyway . . . A stockbrokers' investment analyst tends to specialise in a particular field, say utilities. and regularly meets with their organisation's clients to advise them on how to raise money through shares issues or investing in portfolios.

Gripping. But my wife . . . In large firms an analyst will probably work in a team producing regular reports. In small companies they may be in charge of their own client and be expected to complete reports individually.

Nice talking to . . . Institutional investment analysts work closely with fund managers and decide what to buy and sell and make presentations to representatives of the funds they manage.

Er, that it? I expect you want to know how to become a trainee investment analyst.

Oh, is that the toilet? Well, you'll need a degree or professional qualification, and many applicants have both. The most useful are in economics, statistics or accounting.

I think I heard the doorbell. The Institute of Investment Management Certificate (IMC) is the mandatory test of competence in this field. Candidates must have six months experience in the financial services industry before they attempt the exam. After the IMC you may take a further two-part exam to become an Associate member. Competition for vacancies is fierce and tend to be concentrated in the south-east of England, Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester and Edinburgh.

I'm feeling a bit faint. That will never do. Investment analysts need to be outgoing and be able to sell their skills and knowledge to clients, and have a capacity to work well in a team environment. Clients often demand information at short notice, so an ability to work under pressure and be able to cope with high levels of stress is paramount. Numerical fluency and an understanding of statistical and financial data are important. And it goes without saying that computer, communication and written skills are needed.

webTitle: The role of business studies in the curriculum

fields.headline: Serious money
fields.standfirst: We must give business studies more status, says  Jenny Wales
fields.trailText: We must give business studies more status, says Jenny Wales
fields.body:
Will the UK ever return to its entrepreneurial heyday? We once led the world in innovation and trade but now lag behind badly in the business start-up stakes. Governments constantly plead for people to set up in business but what has been done to develop the nation's enterprise instincts? The simple answer is - very little.

Some inroads are being made, but slowly. There is, at last, some recognition that business as a subject exists but activity is generally aimed at schools rather than colleges. Here it does not receive, however, the same status as geography and history even though, for 14- to 16-year-olds, busi ness studies has an equal place in the curriculum.

What makes it stranger is that Tony Blair has been talking about business studies in recent weeks. His statements about education included plans to set up specialist schools for business and enterprise. In further education there has been no such progress. A student of A-level psychology brings more money to a college than one taking business studies. Does the former really cost more than the latter? Most lecturers would doubt it.

Business is the biggest area for GNVQ and vocational A-levels. It has provided a successful route to higher education and employment for many students. Turning GNVQ Foundation and Intermediate into a vocational GCSE leaves many students with no route forward from school. Half the population achieves less than C grades at GCSE and they really don't want to go to college to resit.

Young people want something new. If they have achieved a foundation pass at school, they could move to intermediate at college. Will these students really want to start a GCSE, with its school-based image, which they will "fail", as a C grade is probably beyond their expectations? Foundation GNVQ motivated many because they could receive a positive outcome. Why take it away?

There is a shortage of business teachers. Adverts for business lecturers elicit few responses in the college sector. Graduates see enthusiastic employers who offer tempting packages in return for their skills. Maths teachers, among others, will get their student loans paid off and be given golden hellos but business teachers are never included in these deals.

Business students and lecturers in colleges do not get a fair crack of the whip. There is a mismatch between the perception that business education is economically important and the reality of the lack of support for it. We must all shout louder.

Jenny Wales chairs the Economics and Business Education Association, which holds its annual conference in Leeds this weekend. Tel 01273-846033 or email ebeah@pavillion.co.uk

webTitle: The decline of core agricultural training courses

fields.headline: The Dimmock factor
fields.standfirst: Agricultural colleges are booming, but not with courses that farming needs, reports  Joe Plomin
fields.trailText: Agricultural colleges are booming, but not with courses that farming needs, reports Joe Plomin
fields.body:
Foot and mouth disease will surely drive another nail into farming as a career option for young people. But a more powerful factor behind the decline of traditional agricultural training courses might be more to do with telly gardening and vet programmes than with the years of crisis.

The latest figures from agricultural colleges show that the numbers of students on mainstream courses are dropping while applications for other land-related courses continue to soar. Fewer people want to grow food while more want to grow horses or golf courses.

But even as the core agricultural student body declines there are too many people being trained with inadequate skills.

A report published this week by Lantra, the agricultural sector's national training organisation, highlights a worrying skills gap. It estimates that 50,000 more unskilled people than needed are working in crop production. But there are at least 38,000 too few people with skills at an owner/manager or degree level.

Meanwhile other courses developed by agricultural colleges over the past seven years are continuing to bloom.

"People want to be involved with anything that's on television between six and nine pm," says Richard Winterton, Lantra's director of development services.

"I call it the Dimmock factor.

"There are too many would-be Charlie Dimmocks or Rolf Harrises compared to those who can fix a combine harvester."

Final figures are still unavailable, but Winterton says the total of students on land-based courses in the UK last year would show a downturn from the 103,487 in 1998-9.

"The industry is in crisis, prices are depressed, and that is clearly having an impact."

The upshot will be a probable glut of people trained to care for small animals, says Howard Petch, secretary of the National Association of Principal Agricultural Education Officers.

"You might question whether the small animal industry can absorb that number of people," he said.

"In horticulture, there is the opposite situation, particularly in amenity horticulture like garden centres or house plant growing or in landscape gardening. They're crying out for enough people per se, as well as for skilled people."

Colleges must clearly try to address the gap problems. However, student demand is hard to oppose, and the demand is clearly for the newer courses developed as colleges diversified to survive.

The most important changes might need to be made at the stage before young people choose their college courses. Perhaps some careers advisors and teachers need to change their ideas about agricultural training, if one student's experience is typical.

In July, Emma Mifkimmon, 19, finished a three-year national diploma in agriculture at Moulton College in Northampton. This was just the sort of solid farming course which Richard Winterton wants to encourage.

But when Mifkimmon was leaving school, career's tutors tried to steer her away from agricultural training.

"They wanted me to go into small animal management," she said. "But I was brought up on a farm and that's what I decided to go into."

She did a general agricultural course that covered everything, she said. "We had arable and animal management. We had an hour and a half management and technical training a week and the same for machinery."

She's now a month into her second job, responsible for milking 90 cows on a farm near Cambridge. "It's going really well. I was working on another dairy farm with 180 cows, but I just had less responsibility, so moved."

She is, she said, a modern herdswoman, not interested in Charlie Dimmock. The question is whether Winterton and Petch can encourage more like her.

webTitle: Goverment's package to solve colleges' pay dispute

fields.headline: Last-ditch effort on pay
fields.standfirst: Government wades in to settle dispute before the election, reports  Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Government wades in to settle dispute before the election, reports Francis Beckett
fields.body:
Education ministers, desperate to resolve the colleges' pay dispute before the election, have come up with a package - including a proposal to write off new lecturers' student loans - which they hope will settle it. Until now they have publicly insisted that colleges, as employers, must find a way - acceptable to lecturers - of divvying up the £50m the government allocated for pay this year, and the £100m for next year.

But as time runs out and no agreement looks imminent, the government plans to intervene. The package will also include a "substantial" pay rise which, whenever it comes into effect, will be backdated to April this year. Ministers are "mindful" that lecturers get at least 10% less than schoolteachers.

Part-time lecturers will no longer be paid only for contact hours. There will be an element for other work, such as helping students outside class time, marking work, preparing, and attending meetings. But it may not match the formula put forward by the lecturers' union, Natfhe. For every contact hour, Natfhe wants part-time lecturers to be paid for an hour and a half.

There will also be measures to enhance part-time lecturers' status, which are likely to include giving them access to training and professional development opportunities.

There will be a new senior grade of classroom teacher, perhaps called "principal lecturer". The aim will be to ensure that good lecturers can stay in the classroom, instead of having to take on administrative posts in order to increase their salaries. Lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks has always been concerned that the top people in colleges are not teachers, but finance and marketing people.

But the government will not drop its insistence on the one proposal which has so far blocked an agreement with the unions: performance- related pay. The scheme it will propose is closely modelled on the one in operation at Derby Wilmorton College.

There, the lecturer wishing to become a "learning director" is interviewed by a panel consisting of the deputy principal, the relevant line manager and a student. But promo tion to learning director is automatic unless there is what the college calls a "competence dispute". And in that case, an action plan is drawn up so that they do advance next time.

Principal David Croll says: "The first question is: what can we do to bring them up to the level? But if they lack the skill to be a good teacher, that does not mean there is no role in the organisation for them. The key is that someone who spends his or her working life teaching should earn as much as someone who spends his or her working life managing."

The lecturers' union Natfhe, which opposes performance pay, may just be able to swallow this.

"Many elements of the Derby Wilmorton scheme we are happy to work with," says general secretary Paul Mackney cautiously. "We have been arguing for better promotion prospects for experienced teachers who don't want to become managers."

The key to ministers' thinking is said to be "more pay and status for college lecturers". It wants to see an end to the concentration on raw A-level results, in which sixth-form colleges and school sixth forms do better than colleges, and a move to a system where added value counts.

"Any extra money is very welcome." says Mr Mackney. "But no one should be under any illusion that it resolves the pay crisis in colleges. The money in the pot is just 2% of the lecturers' pay bill, while 8% went into a similar scheme for schoolteachers."

webTitle: In brief: Brad Pitt to play computer villain in Internet thriller

fields.headline: Brad Pitt to play computer villain in Internet thriller
fields.standfirst: Plus: Benjamin Bratt latest name to be linked to Basic Instinct 2; Ang Lee plans Houdini biopic; Sylvester Stallone accused of attempted rape
fields.trailText: Plus: Benjamin Bratt latest name to be linked to Basic Instinct 2; Ang Lee plans Houdini biopic; Sylvester Stallone accused of attempted rape
fields.body:
 Brad Pitt is set to star as a computer bad-guy in an Internet thriller called Silicon Alley. Although little is know of the project, Pitt's ruthless, mega-rich character is allegedly based on Microsoft boss, Bill Gates.

 Julia Roberts' boyfriend Benjamin Bratt is the latest name to be associated with the much-maligned Basic Instinct sequel. The on-again-off-again movie looks set to be saved by Bratt, who will play a married analyst who treats Sharon Stone's sociopath Catherine Trammel. Michael Douglas, who starred opposite Stone in the 1992 original, turned the role down, as did Kurt Russell, and now it seems Thirteen Days star Bruce Greenwood has also pulled out of the project. Stone apparently met with Bratt last week after stipulating that she has final approval over her co-star. The decision is expected later this week

 Ang Lee has revealed that he plans to direct a film about the infamous escape artist Harry Houdini. The director, who is nominated for an Academy Award for his critically acclaimed Chinese-language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, also admitted last month that he would like to direct a film version of the cult TV series The Incredible Hulk. However, he is not expected to begin work on either film before the summer as he told USA Today that he will be unable to start work before the proposed actor and writer strikes.

 Sylvester Stallone has been accused of attempted rape and sexual assault by a stripper, according to reports this afternoon. Margie Carr is seeking damages for emotional distress, suffering, pain and "oppressive and malicious actions" after the 55-year-old actor allegedly trapped her in a gym and tried to force himself on her. The muscle man, who has been married to model Jennifer Flavin since 1997, denies the charges claiming Ms Carr is a "totally unreliable woman."

fields.headline: Whip hand?
fields.standfirst: How long will it be before computers replace lecturers entirely - if ever, asks  Stephen Hoare
fields.trailText: How long will it be before computers replace lecturers entirely - if ever, asks Stephen Hoare
fields.body:
Given their weakness for any jargon, it's not surprising that further education folk have taken the word e-learning to their hearts. But how much of it is really taking place in colleges? How much is now piped to students via computers and will these ever displace human teachers?

The kit is certainly coming in. Colleges are putting £100m a year into information communication technology and they've got an additional £74m from the Further Education Funding Council. This is to set up the National Learning Network.

Flagship schemes like Reading College and School of Art and Design's £2.5m Digital Academy and New College Nottingham's online distance learning programme appeal to a new constituency of time-poor adults who would rather download lessons from the internet than attend class.

The government has been helping to kick-start e-learning through Ufi, the former University for Industry, which aims to help people brush up skills online at work. Many colleges have successfully bid to set up the Ufi's so-called "hubs" and "learndirect" centres in a range of premises which people are likely to find congenial studying places.

E-learning looks a beguiling solution to waning college attendance and employers' moans that material needs to reflect current industry practice. Some reckon that information put on the internet can be updated far more readily than a lecturer's notes and it will reach a far wider audience.

But has the technology lived up to its promises? Will all the bells, whistles and engaging interactivity ever replace honest to goodness classroom teaching?

E-enthusiasts point to smart technical solutions and speed of delivery. The use of e-mail, discussion groups, online assignments, reading lists and chat rooms patrolled by lecturer/facilitators means students, in theory at least, need less time in the classroom. In addition, learning management systems that accompany e-learning packages track student performance, providing a safety net for weak students.

All in all there are some impressive benefits. At its most whizzy, e-learning is like an interactive computer game. You could picture disaffected students happily playing for hours on some piece of educational software such as Knowledge = Power's interactive Crazy College World, a multi-media learning environment boasting video clips and animation flash files. It can be tweaked to deliver a wide range of course material and Weymouth College uses it, for example, to train students on New Deal programmes.

But according to the boffins who create e-learning software, technology can never replace the classroom teacher.

Jan Hagen, head of solutions for the e-learning company Wide Learning, has worked with colleges and business schools on developing online courses and says that e-learning can only ever be part of the broader picture.

"Lots of colleges spend money on developing a sexy web campus but fall down because they think they can convert existing course material to a web format. It doesn't work and all they end up with is a factually dry content which no amount of computer animation can disguise."

Hagen adds that while the computer game format may be an acceptable way of delivering lists of hard facts and references it is a poor substitute for the teacher most of the time. "If you remove the teacher you take out the key component of a classroom course. Video and animation are never going to be as good as a teacher jumping up and down telling jokes, bringing a subject to life."

So what are the gains and the pitfalls for colleges using e-learning? Ever since introducing e-learning three years ago, Derby College Wilmorton has certainly been able to reach the parts other colleges haven't. It has gained hundreds of extra distance learning students who are part of its wider community. Derby College is a Ufi "hub" and runs online courses as part of the government's learndirect initiative. And last year the college also ran two European-funded "Adapt" e-learning projects to provide online training to local small businesses. Vice principal Gordon Stewart says: "We reached about fifty small businesses through the Adapt scheme and we now provide 450-500 courses and online tutorials through learndirect."

To help it achieve an e-learning revolution Derby College Wilmorton is having to retrain lecturers in the art and etiquette of managing online learning - adding the role of "facilitator" to their many other talents. So far only 20 out of 250 staff have signed up to train for e-learning, putting a brake on expansion of e-courses. Stewart sees problems in trying to move too fast too soon. "Training your staff is one issue but colleges also have to look carefully at the quality of the materials. We design our own courses rather than buy material off the shelf because our students are not highly motivated businessmen trying to get through their professional exams. Our third concern is that there are not many students who would want to learn solely online."

Wide Learning's Jan Hagen agrees: "I don't think you can expect anybody to do more than three hours a week learning online."

But sooner or later everything boils down to cost. E-learning is a cost-effective way of reaching a large number of students and getting them to a certain standard. In the private sector companies are slashing training budgets by switching to e-learning. In 1999 Ernst & Young reported that e-learning had created a 35% reduction in costs and a dramatic improvement in consistency.

In spite of the fact that e-learning materials are hugely expensive to produce and require a great deal of re search and development, there is considerable expertise available now both from e-learning solutions providers and colleges themselves. fields.headline: Cockpit lights may replace marshals
fields.trailText: Cockpit warning lights informing drivers of incidents ahead may be introduced to formula one cars next season, in an effort to reduce the number of trackside officials at each event following the death of a marshal during Sunday's Australian grand prix.
fields.body:
Cockpit warning lights informing drivers of incidents ahead may be introduced to formula one cars next season, in an effort to reduce the number of trackside officials at each event following the death of a marshal during Sunday's Australian grand prix.

Fifty-two-year-old Graham Beveridge, from Queensland, suffered chest and abdominal injuries when he was struck by a loose wheel after Jacques Villeneuve's BAR-Honda collided with Ralf Schumacher's Williams-BMW at 160mph. Though Villeneuve walked away from the accident, one of his wheels sped through a gap in the perimeter wall in what the race director Ron Walker called a "one in a billion accident". The gap was necessary to allow marshals quick access to the track, for example if a car was in flames.

Police yesterday interviewed Villeneuve and Ralf Schumacher about the fifth-lap accident, and Villeneuve's car was impounded by the Victoria state coroner Graeme Johnston as part of his investigation. Race stewards investigating the crash decided it was a "race incident" and that action would not be pursued against either driver.

The sport's governing body, the FIA, yesterday launched its own inquiry into the incident, in which 13 spectators were also injured. Its president, Max Mosley, is expected to hurry along the introduction of the cockpit lights technology, which has been in development for the past two years. This would drastically reduce the number of officials required at each grand prix next season, by removing the need for volunteer officials to wave the sport's traditional warning flags.

Beveridge was the second marshal to die at a grand prix in six months, after an identical fatality during the Italian event at Monza last year. Paolo Ghislimberti, 33, was killed by a flying wheel after a five-car crash.

In Melbourne, seven spectators suffered minor injuries from flying debris and were treated at a first aid centre at the track. Six more were treated at the scene.

"The first thing we knew there was a loud bang and then a cloud of white dust," said one spectator, Andrew Maggiore. "Villeneuve's car disintegrated and bits of carbon fibre sprayed through the wire in the fence. It was like being showered by shrapnel."

Responding to the accident, the FIA's director of communications, Francesco Longanesi, revealed that the governing body "has already put forward to the World Motorsport Council, for the session on March 21, the proposal from the circuit and safety commission to raise all the fencing at all the formula one world championships by one metre. This would not have saved the poor marshal in this instance, because the height of the fencing had nothing to do with it, but it shows how not only car safety but also trackside safety is subject to constant study."

Longanesi added: "The fact that the marshals have a certain degree of exposure is due to their function, because they are there to signal and to help. If you put a fire marshal completely far away from where an accident may happen, and he's in the position where his possible intervention would not be quick enough, it is not worth having him there."

Workers dismantling the temporary Albert Park street circuit yesterday laid a large wreath at the spot where Beveridge died. Walker said the dead man's family would be looked after, regardless of what the insurance cover was.

"We'll be asking the teams to donate their uniforms and helmets to be auctioned, so we'll be doing everything we can to assist the family," he said.

Meanwhile, according to the BMW-Williams team's technical director Patrick Head, Ralf Schumacher's telemetry has revealed the German did not brake any earlier when Villeneuve ran into the back of him than on the three previous laps.

The Canadian briefly went to hospital on Sunday night for a check-up, complaining his back and neck had started to seize up. He left after just a routine check.

webTitle: Smooth start for the blue-eyed boy of formula one

fields.headline: Smooth start for the blue-eyed boy of formula one
fields.standfirst: Kimi Raikkonen is something special, says Richard Williams
fields.trailText: He is 21, but looks no more than 16. His complexion is as pale as his arctic-blue eyes. Sunday's Australian grand prix was the first time he had raced a formula one car, and only the 24th car race of his short life. But after he had finished sixth, scoring his first world championship point, Kimi Raikkonen seemed no more impressed than if he had spent the preceding hour and a half playing outside on his skateboard.
fields.body:
He is 21, but looks no more than 16. His complexion is as pale as his arctic-blue eyes. Sunday's Australian grand prix was the first time he had raced a formula one car, and only the 24th car race of his short life. But after he had finished sixth, scoring his first world championship point, Kimi Raikkonen seemed no more impressed than if he had spent the preceding hour and a half playing outside on his skateboard.

No, the race in Albert Park had held no real surprises. Even though none of the young Finn's previous races, in much smaller cars, had lasted more than half an hour, the experience of a full-length grand prix in a 750-horsepower machine, pulling goodness knows how much G-force in the corners, had not left him exhausted, either physically or mentally. In fact he felt like he could have got straight back into his Sauber and done it all again.

"It felt much shorter," he said, giving the barest hint of his new perspective on life, "than it does if you're looking from outside."

This may have been the most impressive grand prix debut since Jacques Villeneuve arrived from the United States and finished second on the same track five years ago. And yet Raikkonen is effectively on probation, his FIA "superlicence" - the document permitting him to compete in formula one - issued on the understanding that it will be reviewed after the fourth race of the season.

As with the case of Jenson Button a year ago, there has been no shortage of greybeards keen to express reservations about letting such an inexperienced young man loose on the grand prix grid, including Max Mosley, the president of the FIA and a member of the superlicence committee, who cast his vote against letting Raikkonen race.

The sceptics were wrong. Raikkonen qualified 13th for Sunday's race - the same grid position, someone recollected, as his compatriot Mika Hakkinen, the double world champion, in his first grand prix 10 years to the month earlier - and after making a bit of a mess of the start, recovered to pick up places not just by benefiting from retirements but through finding a way past some of his better known rivals. "It was nice to do some overtaking," he said. "I got past Fisichella, Jenson, and Alesi."

Perhaps passing the two underpowered Benettons did not count for much. "There wasn't a fight," Button remembered. "He was behind me, and then he was in front of me, and that was it." But the third scalp clearly pleased Raikkonen's team boss, Peter Sauber, with whom Jean Alesi spent two disappointing seasons before leaving to join Alain Prost's team.

Sauber was clearly elated by the performance of both his young drivers, the 23-year-old German Nick Heidfeld finishing fourth. "I'm very, very proud of them," he said. "Nick has more experience than people think. But it was a risk to take Kimi. You know, we finished eighth in the championship last year, we needed to go forward, and to do that you have to get good drivers. I tried very hard to get Heinz-Harald Frentzen, but it was not possible. So I had to take a risk. And I'm really happy, because Kimi's race was beautiful."

And not just his race, either. "What's remarkable about him," his race engineer, Jacky Eeckelaert, said, "is that with so little experience he can act at a grand prix weekend just like a normal racing driver. He's quite amazing. In those three days he didn't put a foot wrong - not one single spin, no gravel trap, not even a flat spot on a tyre. Nothing. He drove a perfect three days, like a driver who's been doing it for 10 years."

Eeckelaert had told him to take the weekend steadily. "We pushed him to be very careful, because people had been critical. For instance, Michael Schumacher rolled his car on Friday. Not his fault. Jacques Villeneuve and Ralf Schumacher had a big accident in the race, and a marshal was killed. I don't know whose fault that was. But if Kimi had been involved, and perhaps someone had been killed, can you imagine what would people have said?"

But if Eeckelaert was pleased by his sensible behaviour, he was delighted by his speed. "He was fast and consistent. You can be slow and make no mistakes, but he's fast with no mistakes. So it means that his potential is even bigger than he's shown this weekend."

Raikkonen is from Espoo, a small town a few miles outside Helsinki. His background is modest. His father, Matti, drives a machine that flattens gravel roads. His mother, Paula, works in the state pensions office. He has an older brother, Rami, who is a rally driver and is currently leading the national under-25 championship.

When Kimi was three or four, his father gave the boys a pair of mini motorbikes to ride around the back yard. Sliding around in the rain and snow they made such a mess that it was thought prudent to move their hobby outside the home, and at the age of eight Kimi got his first home-built go-kart.

Ten years of successful competition in national and international kart races led him to England and Formula Ford in 1999. Last year he graduated to Formula Renault, winning all four races in the winter series, seven out of the 10 rounds of the British championship, and two of the three races comprising the European series. Of his total of 23 races before Sunday, he had won 13.

He has been managed since 1999 by Steve Robertson, a former Indycar driver who is the son of David Robertson, one of Jenson Button's co-managers. Raikkonen has been living with Robertson in Chigwell, Essex, but will soon move to Switzerland to be close to the Sauber factory. He is also an expert snowboarder and ice hockey player.

Just as some have misjudged Raikkonen's maturity at the wheel, others will probably assume from his quiet manner that he has nothing to say. But after a few minutes of parrying post-race questions, trying not to give answers that might betray naivety, his reserve began to melt. A grin broke through when he was asked how he had felt about finishing on the same lap as the leader.

"That was really nice," he said. "I was looking in my mirrors towards the end, but nobody was coming."

Kimi Raikkonen is probably not destined to spend his life looking in his mirrors. Pretty soon, you would have to guess, everybody else will be looking out for him.

webTitle: Launch of new higher education website

fields.headline: Hero for college hopefuls?
fields.standfirst: Whether you're seeking courses or verifying research, a new catch-all website launched today may help. Report by  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Whether you're seeking courses or verifying research, a new catch-all website launched today may help. Report by Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
Universities, courses and degrees are multiplying on the internet - but how does a would-be student know if they're any good? Today's launch of the Hero website is an attempt to inject quality control into the exuberant growth of online information and e-learning. Higher Education and Research Opportunities aims to be a shop window for British higher education - a first port of call for students in the UK and overseas, for academics, and for companies seeking to link up with researchers. The sector plans to have spent £1.5m on the project by next year.

The site is broad-based to reflect the diversity of universities and colleges, full-time and part-time courses, and research interests. But it does not connect to everything in higher education, says director Christopher Harris. "We are only linking to sites where we feel they are giving validated, authentic material. If you go through Hero you will be getting a credible site."

For international students the problem of what Tim O'Shea, the chairman of Hero calls "the University of Dalkey accredited by the Tara Awards Agency" is acute. It sounds good but it is genuine? The problem is compounded by commercial outfits increasingly using site names that sound like universities or colleges - "brand piracy" in the jargon.

Professor O'Shea, Master of Birkbeck College London, says the venture has produced some "encouraging surprises" in getting UK universities to cooperate. Providing full and accurate information on courses and research at all UK universities would help with their international marketing. "It will aid access for first generation UK students who will be able to relate university course choices to their financial situation and to their career aspirations."

Backing Hero are all four national higher education funding councils, the scientific research councils and the Arts and Humanities Research Board, the Universities & Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS), the Teacher Training Agency and the Careers Service Unit.

Prof O'Shea believes the project could not have succeeded a couple of years ago. "Universities, especially the older ones and, in particular, their librarians, are thought to be very cautious and conservative but they have swiftly adapted to the oddities of the internet and anarchic web."

Hero users are future and former students, staff who work in the sector and those who use the products of UK research. The website will be successful to the extent that it supports "time travel", says Prof O'Shea. "A prospective student will wish to know how much their studies will cost, what the pattern of study will be, whether they could break for a year, and what job they might be holding after three years. Business will want to know who generated a research result, how old it is, whether related work is in progress, when the next result is likely to be announced, and who owns what aspect of it."

The site's six zones cover studying, research, business, staff, culture and the institutions. The latest news on the higher education sector comes via a link to the Guardian's education website (see opposite).

Prof O'Shea believes it will boost the chances of the e-University being set up by the funding councils. "Potential overseas students will be able to make sense of the courses offered by the e-University by inspecting them electronically in the context of all the other UK university and college courses."

Security, authentication and privacy, he adds, are key issues for the all providers and users of information on websites, and this is especially critical for educational institutions.

The most important challenge for both Hero and for the e-University is the advent of mobile wireless computing, the profesor predicts. "Students will be freed from the constraints of place and time associated with the traditional lecture theatre and library. If we can take proper advantage of ubiquitous computing in step with current and future students, then UK higher education will be well placed to enrol very many more overseas students and provide much better access for domestic learners."

The sector plans to have spent £1.5m on the project by next year. The site is broad-based to reflect the diversity of universities and colleges, full-time and part-time courses, and research interests. But it does not connect to everything in higher education, says director Christopher Harris. "We are only linking to sites where we feel they are giving validated, authentic material. If you go through Hero you will be getting a credible site." For international students the problem of what Tim O'Shea, the chairman of Hero calls "the University of Dalkey accredited by the Tara Awards Agency" is acute. It sounds good but it is genuine? The problem is compounded by commercial outfits increasingly using site names that sound like universities or colleges - "brand piracy" in the jargon. Professor O'Shea, Master of Birkbeck College London, says the venture has produced some "encouraging surprises" in getting UK universities to cooperate. Providing full and accurate information on courses and research at all UK universities would help with their international marketing. "It will aid access for first generation UK students who will be able to relate university course choices to their financial situation and to their career aspirations." Backing Hero are all four national higher education funding councils, the scientific research councils and the Arts and Humanities Research Board, the Universities & Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS), the Teacher Training Agency and the Careers Service Unit. Prof O'Shea believes the project could not have succeeded a couple of years ago. "Universities, especially the older ones and, in particular, their librarians, are thought to be very cautious and conservative but they have swiftly adapted to the oddities of the internet and anarchic web." Hero users are future and former students, staff who work in the sector and those who use the products of UK research. The website will be successful to the extent that it supports "time travel", says Prof O'Shea. "A prospective student will wish to know how much their studies will cost, what the pattern of study will be, whether they could break for a year, and what job they might be holding after three years. Business will want to know who generated a research result, how old it is, whether related work is in progress, when the next result is likely to be announced, and who owns what aspect of it." The site's six zones cover studying, research, business, staff, culture and the institutions. The latest news on the higher education sector comes via a link to the Guardian's education website (see opposite). Prof O'Shea believes it will boost the chances of the e-University being set up by the funding councils. "Potential overseas students will be able to make sense of the courses offered by the e-University by inspecting them electronically in the context of all the other UK university and college courses." Security, authentication and privacy, he adds, are key issues for the all providers and users of information on websites, and this is especially critical for educational institutions. The most important challenge for both Hero and for the e-University is the advent of mobile wireless computing, the profesor predicts. "Students will be freed from the constraints of place and time associated with the traditional lecture theatre and library. If we can take proper advantage of ubiquitous computing in step with current and future students, then UK higher education will be well placed to enrol very many more overseas students and provide much better access for domestic learners." www.hero.ac.uk

webTitle: What's wrong with men working in childcare?

fields.headline: Gender 'apartheid' of childcare
fields.standfirst: There are women serving on warships - so what's wrong with men working in childcare?
fields.trailText: There are women serving on warships - so what's wrong with men working in childcare?
fields.body:
In the film Meet the Parents, much is made (by the parents) of the fact that Greg, played by Ben Stiller, is a male nurse. He faces the usual jokes and innuendo. But what is most striking is that the term "male nurse" is still in use at all. True, there are very few men in nursing. But I can't recall someone being described as a female doctor, lawyer, engineer - or even "female soldier". It's a sign of how men in caring professions continue to be viewed as slightly weird. They are lucky if people simply assume they are gay; if unlucky, that they have darker motives for choosing a caring role.

Men who choose a career caring for children are the ones who face the highest obstacles. At a nursery attended by my oldest son, the good news was that there was a male member of staff. The bad news was that many parents were put off by this. Many insisted that their children's nappies were not changed by him. Think that through just for a moment, and imagine how it made him feel. He has moved on to other things now.

Just one in a hundred nursery nurses are male. Early schooling is also - increasingly - a female- dominated zone: just 3% of nursery teachers and 17% of primary school teachers are men, with the lower years even more skewed along gender lines.

The only two men on an infant school course at a central London college say they have been openly accused of being gay ("even by my mum's friends," says one), "perverts" and/or not up to a "proper" job.

Does it matter? Isn't childcare women's work anyway? Yes and no. The gender gap in care matters hugely. It blocks men from a growing part of the labour market. And it almost certainly holds wages down in the caring professions. But the real price will be paid in years to come, because the apartheid of the childcare professions is based on outdated, self-fulfilling assumptions about gender roles. It risks condemning another generation to a life of gender inequality. We lament the fact that men do not do their fair share of unpaid work, then put our sons into institutions which, being female-staffed, ram home the message that caring is women's work.

Why is an 18-year-old woman with no children seen, intrinsically, as a better carer than a man who has raised three? We have progressively and successfully abolished the myths that barred women from certain professions, including the military. Women are now on warships and in the cockpits of fighter planes. It is time to drop the similarly short-sighted prejudices about men's ability to care, to cuddle, to teach, to play. We've had GI Jane; it's time for Barbie Bill.

What, then, is to be done? The national childcare commission, which produced its excellent report recently, records gender disparities but has little to offer in terms of remedies. A few symbolic gestures from the government would help (how about a Male Carer of the Year award?). The training bodies for caring professions need to adopt a more proactive approach to attracting men - or at the very least, to not repelling them. And individual institutions need to put in place strict non-discrimination policies.

But it may be that, given the size of the mountain, more drastic action is required. We know that men are put off by the low salaries and that many are unable to take the time to undergo training courses, because they are more likely to be the primary breadwinner in their household. Perhaps we should offer men who want to train as childcarers an additional financial incentive. We offer science and maths teacher trainees £1,000 bursaries. Why not male childcare trainees? Of course, it should not be necessary. But in the real world, right now, it might be the key to kick-starting the process of getting more men in the nursery, in the same way that women-only shortlists kick-started the process of getting more women into parliament.

Above all, though, a broader shift in attitudes is required if men are to feel comfortable choosing a caring job. One of the infant school trainees, after recounting endless tales of stereotyping and innuendo, said: "It is incredibly upsetting. You just try not to think about it and get on with the job. Because I think it is the most important job in the world."

fields.headline: Jackson bans cameras from Oxford address
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Michael Jackson's public address at Oxford University will not be shown on TV tonight, writes Julia Day.
Feb 22: Jacko bans TV from Oxford address
fields.body:
The British public will be denied the spectacle of Michael Jackson's public address at the Oxford University union tonight.

Jackson's speech, which focuses on his children's charity Heal the Kids, will not be broadcast on TV news bulletins tonight.

The BBC, ITN and Sky News cameras have been banned from the union's debating chamber.

Like all popstars, Jackson is sensitive about his image. And to control exactly what footage is released, he has hired a TV company to film the proceedings.

However, the film will remain his property with less than five minutes of "hellos and goodbyes" released to broadcasters.

So the broadcasters will have to make do with filming the spectacle surrounding Jackson's unprecedented appearance.

Jackson will be surrounded by his own security entourage, and police presence has been stepped up in the city.

Fans sporting Michael Jackson T-shirts are already gathering to try and catch a glimpse.

Around 40 journalists will have seats inside the chambers, while a similiar amount will watch the address from an ante-room via a live feed.

Many more press photographers are expected outside the St Michael Street building.

Oxford University Union has put its most stringent ever security measures in place for tonight's address.

There will be 40 security guards inside the students' union building and 40 police outside.

The security arrangements are even tighter than those deployed when Salman Rushdie addressed the union during the peak of the death threats against him.

But the university guards will jostle for space with Jackson's own team of minders

"These are not the usual security arrangments. Michael Jackson is not a usual speaker," said Daniel Johnson, spokesman for the students' union.

"We are more interested in crowd control than security threats," he said.

By 4pm 250 fans had gathered outside the union, but thousands more are expected to converge on the city centre to try to catch a glimpse of the world's most eccentric popstar.

The union has been deluged with applications from students wanting tickets for the event with 3,000 applications.

"There will only be 500 people in the chamber tonight," said Mr Johnson.

"Jerry Springer and OJ Simpson are the only other celebrities who have generated as much demand for tickets."

webTitle: Housing association found guilty of mismanagement

fields.headline: Housing association found guilty of mismanagement
fields.trailText: A charitable housing association that planned to pay its chief executive £837,000 in a severance package has been found guilty of mismanagement in a regulation report that will add to the fat-cat image of the sector. Matt Weaver reports
fields.body:
A charitable housing association that planned to pay its chief executive £837,000 in a severance package has been found guilty of mismanagement in a regulation report that will add to the fat-cat image of the sector.

Liverpool-based Liver housing association proposed to pay Elaine Price-Taylor what would have been by far the highest pay-off in the sector, as part of a £1.7m package to three of the association's directors. The package was drawn up as part of plans for a merger with Grosvenor housing association, which has now been postponed.

A statutory report into affair by solicitor Nicholas Bohm for the Housing Corporation, published this week, found that the payments would have been "ultra vires and incompatible with Liver's charitable status and would injure the reputation of the housing association sector".

The report revealed that the association had been warned against the sums involved but still proceeded with the plan. It also criticised Ms Price-Taylor for failing to withdraw from discussions about her proposed pay off.

The report concluded that the association's whole board were responsible for mismanagement, but said the responsibility of the association's chairman at the time, Bryon Clarke, who remains on the board, was larger than others.

It added: "The scale of the proposed payments was far beyond what would have been reasonable or appropriate." However the report clears Liver of misconduct.

The association remains under supervision by the Housing Corporation which this week made three statutory appointments to Liver's board.

This is the first report of its kind to be made public by the Housing Corporation. It comes amid growing concern about high pay and severance packages in the sector.

A statement from Liver welcomed the fact that it had been cleared of misconduct and stressed that the payments had not been made.

The corporation's chief executive Dr Norman Perry said: 'This inquiry has underlined the importance of good corporate governance. There are lessons for us all - for associations and for the corporation.

"Looking to the future, I hope the three new appointments we have announced today in order to strengthen Liver's board will allow the association to resolve satisfactorily the outstanding issues so that the proposed merger with Grosvenor housing association can come before the corporation's registration and supervision committee at an early opportunity."

webTitle: Q&A: pay offs in the housing sector

fields.headline: Q&A: pay offs in the housing sector
fields.trailText: Q&A: pay offs in the housing sector
fields.body:
Are huge pay offs in the housing association sector common?
If Liver housing association had paid its group chief executive Elaine Price-Taylor £837,000 this would have been by far the highest severance package in the sector. But it is just the latest in a number of high profile pension and pay off scandals. In 1998, Riverside housing association agreed to top up its chief executive's pension by more £200,000, in a move the Housing Corporation said it would have blocked if had the power. Last year the director of Flagship housing group received £290,00 compensation for loss of office.

Is there anything to stop housing associations paying such sums?
Yes and no. The Housing Corporation closely regulates the sector and it has a number of sanctions if it is concerned about issues such as excessive pay within an association. But housing associations are independent organisations and their boards can pay staff what they like within reason for not-for-profit organisations.

What did the Housing Corporation do in this case?
If the corporation is concerned that there may have been misconduct or mismanagement in an association it can launch an inquiry. In this case it appointed a solicitor to conduct the inquiry and for the first time it has made the result of the inquiry public.

What did the inquiry find?
There was concern that association had entered into merger talks with Grovesnor housing association in an attempt to provide executives with financially beneficial severance terms. But the inquiry found that the initiation of the merger "does not call for criticism". But it did criticise the association's board for mismanagement.

What about the level of the pay offs?
The solicitor's inquiry said the money was "so large I think some error of principle must lie at its root". He concluded "the board must have convinced itself that it should buy out the rest of the executive's prospective period of service".

What would have been a reasonable pay-off?
The solicitor claimed that given Mrs Price-Taylor's contract at the association, she should get £257,476 if she is forced to leave because of a proposed merger with Grosvenor housing association. But he said even this was "at the limit of what is reasonable and appropriate".

Why was the report made public?
The corporation said publication was part of its commitment to greater openness and accountability. But the publication will also be seen as a way of issuing a warning to other associations. It is concerned to prevent large pay-offs in future mergers. Associations are being encouraged to merge if they are threatened by government proposals to restructure social housing rents.

What will Housing Corporation do Liver housing association now?
A statement from corporation said it was "initially minded" to force the association to sack five of its board members but because no misconduct was found it opted instead to use its statutory power to strengthen the association's board by recommending three new board members.

Is that unusual?
This is a typical response by the corporation to an association in trouble. It tends to favour focussing on governance to help the associations work their own problems out for themselves. The number of new appointees usually reflects the scale of the problems involved.

How much do housing association chief executives get paid?
It depends on the size and turn over of the housing associations. Several chief executives now earn more than £100,000 a year. John Belcher, chief executive Anchor Trust, topped the pay league last year with a salary and benefits worth £155,000. Last year Mrs Price-Taylor earned £98,900 for running an organisation with a £15.4m turnover.

How does chief executive pay compare to others in the sector?
Local authority housing directors are usually paid less than their opposite numbers in housing association, even though they are typically responsible for more homes. Birmingham's director of housing for example, England's biggest social landlord, gets £88,410 a year.

Is the high pay justified?
Housing associations bosses claim they are worth it because they are running complex social business, some with an annual turnover of more than £100m. Critics, however, point to the fact housing association are set up as charities or not-for-profit companies and that their main source of income comes from housing benefit via tenants' rents.

fields.headline: Second generation rail crash victim
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The last four victims of the Selby rail disaster were named yesterday, including a rail company manager whose father was killed in a trackside accident 20 years ago.
fields.body:
The last four victims of the Selby rail disaster were named yesterday, including a rail company manager whose father was killed in a trackside accident 20 years ago.

The cruel coincidence emerged as the last major pieces of wreckage were lifted from the East Coast mainline at Great Heck, where police have now set the final death toll at 10, with 30 serious injuries and 40 passengers suffering cuts, bruises and shock.

Clive Vidgen, 39, who lived with his mother Joyce in Bishopthorpe, near York, died on his way to a meeting in Swindon. He had worked for the railways for 22 years, following in the footsteps of his father, a rail linesman, who was killed by a train near York in December 1969 while repairing track.

It was also confirmed yesterday that another of the fatalities was Steve Baldwin of Teesside University, whose work on alternatives to Ritalin, the controversial children's drug, attracted international attention. Professor Baldwin lived in York and had caught the GNER express to London where he was due to give a speech to a seminar at the Institute of Psychiatry.

He was noted for his dedication to tackling teenage problems, in his academic work in Britain and Australia, but also on the ground. Using a Comic Relief grant of £434,000, he helped to set up an innovative advisory service on young people's drugs and drink problems based in Manchester.

The vice-chancellor of Teesside University, Derek Fraser, said: "The whole university community is in shock. We have lost an immensely valued and talented colleague. Our thoughts are with all of those who will miss him so much."

The two other victims named yesterday were Alan Ensor, 44, a civil engineering project manager of York, and Barry Needham, 40, a freight logistics coordinator, also of York.

Mr Ensor leaves his wife Wendy and two sons, aged 11 and 13. Neighbours in the village of Dunnington said that he had been a devoted family man and that everyone who knew him was distraught.

Friends and relatives of Mr Needham, who lived with his wife Marguritta, were too upset to comment.

A Coventry man, Ian Farndon, 27, was remanded in custody yesterday, accused of wasting police time by falsely claiming that a relative of his had been on the wrecked train and was missing. He was also charged with possessing cannabis.

fields.headline: ITN revamps new media arm
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: ITN has restructured its new media department after the resignation of MD Garron Baines, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
ITN has been forced to restructure its new media department following the resignation of Garron Baines, its managing director of ITN New Media.

Rather than replace him, ITN has split Mr Baines's role and tied reporting lines directly into key personnel at ITN.

Sue Inglish, editor of ITN New Media, and executive producer Mark Gawlinski will now run the division, reporting directly to ITN editor-in-chief Richard Tait.

Commercial director Philippa Edward will also take on some of the responsibility, and will report to ITN finance director Andy Whitaker.

Mr Baines, who has spent 24 years at ITN - four years as boss of ITN New Media - is joining IBM as managing principal for media and entertainment.

A spokeswoman for ITN New Media said his departure was a personal decision for Mr Baines and that he would be leaving ITN "sooner rather than later".

"Garron has made ITN New Media a force to be reckoned with. After a distinguished career as a programme-maker, Garron effectively reinvented himself as a new media executive and made a great success of it," said Stuart Purvis, chief executive of ITN.

ITN New Media's flagship product is itn.co.uk, which claims 11m page impressions per month.

The department's main focus at present is extending its content onto other digital platforms such as PDA and Wap.
