webTitle: Pugnacious Mugabe still firmly in control

fields.headline: Pugnacious Mugabe still firmly in control
fields.standfirst: The Zimbabwean president has neutralised or compromised every challenge to his power and is now being feted in Paris and Brussels, writes Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean president has neutralised or compromised every challenge to his power and is now being feted in Paris and Brussels, writes Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
Just six months ago, the question on Zimbabwean lips was not whether their widely loathed president would be brought down but when, and the exact manner of his departure after 21 years in charge.

Would Robert Mugabe finally confront reality at the ballot box? Or would he have to be pushed by a popular uprising?

After the opposition surged to take almost half the seats in last June's parliamentary election - and it might well have won a majority had it not been for vote rigging and intimidation - Mr Mugabe's enemies anticipated his imminent downfall.

"He will be out by Christmas!" predicted the Movement for Democratic Change leader, Morgan Tsvangirai.

But today Zimbabwe's president looks as secure as ever, and it is his opponents who are wondering if they have a future.

Mr Mugabe has neutralised or compromised just about every challenge to his power. The police and army were brought into line a long time ago. Dissent within his Zanu-PF party has been marginalised if not crushed.

Some heavyweights, most notably former politburo and cabinet member Edison Zvogbo, are still prepared to denounce the government's misrule and to face a barrage of invective from Mugabe loyalists as a result. But for now, at least, they are in a minority.

The latest target for attack - the judiciary - has already begun to buckle. Last week, the government forced out Zimbabwe's white chief justice, Anthony Gubbay. It plans to replace him with a loyal judge who will open the way for a purge of the judiciary.

Mr Mugabe is particularly keen to settle a score with judges who struck down his land redistribution programme as illegal, and ordered the police to remove the "war veterans" who occupy hundreds of white-owned farms.

But there is another motive. The government wants the judiciary neutralised before the next presidential election, which must be held within the next year or so. A plan is under way to bar Mr Tsvangirai from running for the presidency by putting him on trial for inciting violence. But the ruling party is keen to ensure the supreme court will uphold the ban, and so it has set about replacing all of the judges on the court with threats of violence and plans for disciplinary tribunals.

Mr Mugabe is also moving against the Commercial Farmers' Union, the organisation that represents the white farmers whose land has been occupied by "war veterans".

First the government said it would no longer deal with the CFU because it has taken a position on land reform and is therefore an "unregistered political party". Then Zanu-PF persuaded a small group of white sympathisers inside the farmers' union to challenge its existing leadership for control with the implicit message to the membership that they should cooperate or be destroyed. The battle is still on.

The bigger loser is the Movement for Democratic Change, which did so well in last year's parliamentary election. But it is also part of the problem.

Mr Tsvangirai's promise that Robert Mugabe would be gone by Christmas was backed by threats to take hundreds of thousands of people onto the streets in protests, and to shut the country down with strikes. But sympathetic officials in the military and the sinister Central Intelligence Organisation warned the MDC leadership that if it did that it would play right into Mr Mugabe's hands.

He would kill the protesters, declare a state of emergency and round up the opposition leadership, they said. So Mr Tsvangirai backed off. He said he did not want to sacrifice lives, but it has left the MDC adrift with no real means of pressuring Mr Mugabe other than by hurling insults in parliament.

The last truly vigorous critic of Mr Mugabe is Zimbabwe's fearless press. But he has plans for it too. The government is on the brink of introducing new regulations governing journalists. It has already expelled two foreign correspondents - one for the BBC, the other for the Mail and Guardian in Johannesburg. The remaining overseas reporters fear they may also be forced to leave before long.

But the real question is what the government will do with the domestic press. It has tried intimidation with the arrest and torture of two journalists on the Standard newspaper, and blowing up the printing press of the Daily News, which is the country's best selling paper and a furious critic of Mr Mugabe.

Now it may be about to use the law with new forms of accreditation aimed at curbing criticism by effectively banning journalists.

All of this might make Mr Mugabe an international pariah. Britain is certainly scathing. But this week he is being feted in Brussels and Paris because, to the Belgian and French governments, there are more important issues than rights of Zimbabweans.

Mr Mugabe is a key player in the Democratic Republic of Congo's interminable war and both European countries are keen to woo him to a new peace deal. The Zimbabwean president knows this only too well, and will be making clear that his cooperation comes at a price: no European Union sanctions even if he does steal the presidential election.

webTitle: Young people missing out on entitled support

fields.headline: Young people missing out on entitled support
fields.trailText: Leading children's charities have called for better advocacy services for children in need to inform them of their rights after a report found few young people realised what help and support they were entitled to.
fields.body:
Leading children's charities have called for better advocacy services for children in need to inform them of their rights after a report found few young people realised what help and support they were entitled to.

The survey of 108 young people across the UK by charity Save the Children called for child rights officers to work alongside existing support staff as teenage mothers, care leavers, young carers and other young people with "adult" responsibilities said social workers did not appreciate their problems.

But the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) said children would be more empowered if they were given the resources to find the solutions to their problems.

The report, Challenging transitions: young people's views and experiences of growing up, for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, found that many young people felt social workers discriminated against them because of their age.

Interviewees said this meant they had lacked adequate information and support for independent living, especially in relation to housing benefits, social services and education. They were also not informed about their rights so lacked the knowledge and confidence to get the support, training and opportunities needed to take on their "adult" responsibilities.

Save the Children recommended that local authorities appoint a "young people's worker" or children's rights officer to complement the work of youth and social workers. It said professionals could benefit from further training to help them meet young people's emotional and practical needs.

Paula Rodgers, policy and research manager of Save the Children in Northern Ireland said: "We would like to see young people involved in social work training so staff can gain a better understanding of their needs and aspirations."

Neil Hunt, director of child protection at the NSPCC, said advocacy schemes needed to be formalised, so at least children in care had access to a child right's officer.

However, he added: "We would prefer to see advocacy services available to all children in need, and have been developing standards for them in the Advocacy Consortium, along with the Children's Society, Barnardo's and NCH [formerly National Childrens' Homes]."

Mr Hunt said advocacy was important for young people, as they often found it difficult to express their needs when they were under stress.

But he acknowledged that research suggested young people were most likely to seek support from their peers, rather than from an adult professional.

Peter Kemp, children's rights and participation lead on ADSS children's and families committee, welcomed the idea of involving young people in social work training.

Mr Kemp, who is also the director of Durham social services said: "In Durham, we've asked children in care what they think about their social workers and compared this with social workers' self-assessments. This feeds back into staff training."

But he was not convinced that child rights officers would help youngsters with a wide range of needs. "They're more appropriate for helping children at risk."

It would be more empowering to enable children to find their own solutions to their problems, argued Mr Kemp. "We've set up an investing in children programme to ensure young people's needs are met.

"This has enabled them to do research on subjects that concern them before they put their views to service providers. For example, they were unhappy about the lack of subsidised public transport, which left many feeling isolated so we paid for them to gather information on schemes in Cumbria and the Netherlands."

webTitle: Report hits out at education of looked-after children

fields.headline: Report hits out at education of looked-after children
fields.trailText: Scottish local authorities have been given six months to come up with plans for improving the education of looked-after children after a damning report found they were being failed by the schools system. David Mitchell reports
fields.body:
Scottish local authorities have been given six months to come up with plans for improving the education of looked-after children after a damning report found they were being failed by the schools system.

Education minister Jack McConnell has written to council leaders after voicing "serious concern" over the joint report - the first of its kind by HM inspectors of schools and the social work services inspectorate - which showed looked-after children leave school with fewer qualifications and are more at risk of exclusion.

Mr McConnell said: "This report shows that some of our most vulnerable young people are not being supported by the formal education system. It is unacceptable if that by being in care children get a poorer start in life - indeed for many, their circumstances should mean the opposite. It is time for action to tackle these failures."

The inspectors looked at a sample of five local authorities throughout Scotland - Aberdeen City, South Lanarkshire, Stirling, Highland and West Dunbartonshire.

They found that up to 75% of looked-after children leave school without any qualifications. While looked-after children make up only 1% of the school population, they account for 13% of all exclusions from school.

Although care plans have been a statutory requirement since 1997, they were in place for only a minority of children in two of the authorities inspected.

The report says: "It is clear that the education of looked-after children is not as good as it should be. In particular, there are too many instances where local authorities have failed to carry out their duties to ensure that all children looked after away from home have care plans and placement agreements.

"Where there were care plans, they did not usually address educational needs and goals in any detail, and schools were not normally supplied with a copy of the care plan."

Angus Skinner, chief inspector of social work, said he was disappointed, but not surprised, by the findings. "There is some good work to build on but it is patchy and overall the performance is not good enough. Too often local authorities are not looking after children well and are not providing for their education. Being looked after ought to be a plus in their lives, not a negative," he said.

The charity Children in Scotland claimed national policy was not being implemented properly and local authorities were not fulfilling their duties to young people.

"It is symptomatic of the breakdown between social work and education. Very often they don't know what the needs of young people are and they are not taken into account in schools. There should also be greater communication between local authority departments, recognising that these children have particular needs," said policy officer Douglas Hamilton.

Deirdre Watson, director of Who Cares? Scotland, which represents young people in care, said: "We welcome anything which focuses on outcomes for young people and improves the situation. The education of children in care is frequently interrupted and not given the same kind of priority by those looking after them as parents would give to young people living at home."

The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) said it accepted the findings but claimed councils were already addressing the problems.

"We need to firm up our multidisciplinary work, communication between social work and education, and look at individual education plans. We have to learn lessons from this and will work positively to correct some of these findings," said education and children spokesman Danny McCafferty.

webTitle: Pillow talk, Angry talk, and Money talk

fields.headline: Pillow talk, Angry talk, and Money talk
fields.trailText: HAND OF SQUAD
fields.body:
HAND OF SQUAD

[A phone rings in the top secret MOD barracks, somewhere in the Home Counties.]

"Who the dashed bally heck is that disturbing Squadron Leader Fiver in the middle of the night? Get the phone will you Janice? Yes, just pass it to Angela. Thank you, darling.

"Hallo, Squaddy here, what's the problem? The agreement on the future of the transfer system concocted by the EU, Fifa and Uefa in Brussels yesterday is already submerged under a bladderful of controversy? You don't say. Tell me more.

"Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, eh? Been going on national radio to criticise the scheme, which sets contracts at a minimum of one year and a maximum of five and proposes compensation in the event of them being unilaterally broken, has he? Told the Beeb that "what we don't want to see is players leaving at the drop of a wallet. The problem for the club is that they could be faced with the choice after one year of either renegotiating his existing contract or losing his services", did he? Mmmm.

"And what about those FifPro johnnies? I take it Gordon Taylor's staying quiet after that "incident" with the boa constrictor? You what? They've found another spokesman, who described the deal as "a very black day for European sport and footballers"? Who is this ponce? Laurent Denis? And he reckons that "a new category of workers has been created at a European level - footballers who will not benefit like others from the same social protection"? Consider his card marked, sir.

"Have you had any word from the PM sir? Ah. "This is very encouraging news." Well, it's always nice to be appreciated, sir. I'll get on to it straight away. Over and out.

"Angela? You couldn't pass me the cattle prod, could you, sweetest? Yes, the one under the pillow. I've got to go out for a couple of hours."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A QUICK GAME OF SQUABBLE

Sadly for the manufacturers of imaginary chess, when people say "mind games" they usually mean one thing: the Imperial Lord Ferg having a whine. Over the years, the great red one has vanquished many a competitor with a well-timed barb aimed in their direction. Well, he upset Kelvin Koogan anyway. But it is the Fiver's sad duty to report that whatever heights the psychological ploys may once have reached, standards are slipping faster than a sandal-clad safety inspector in a soap factory.

"People who live in glasshouses should not throw stones," was Ferg's succinct rebuttal of Lucas Radebe's suggestion that referees have one law for United and "one for the rest of us". As far as the Ferg is concerned, there was only one culprit when Fabien Barthez upended Ian Harte on Saturday. "Harte's record of diving is well known," he said today, before delivering the coup de grace. "Everyone knows that for us to get a penalty we need a certificate from the Pope and a personal letter from the Queen." Of course they do, of course.

The FA appear to agree with Ferg on the reffing issue, having decided not to punish Barthez further for his indiscretion. But, sadly, that wasn't the end of it as David O'Leary O'Leeds could not resist chucking his handbag at the windbag. "Regarding Ian Harte," O'Leary told the press before tonight's Big Cup match against Real Madrid, "Maybe the great man - at 59 - is losing his memory, but he did say Barthez should have been sent off on Saturday. I don't know, maybe he has had a bad weekend." Children, please.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I've been playing well. What can I do? All I can do is keep hammering on that door. I think I'll buy a crane and get one of those big steel balls and start smashing it on the manager's door" - Steve Guppy bemoans his lack of Foxy first-team action.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TWO TEAMS, ONE CAUSE

As anyone who has ever watched Scotsport knows, everyone north of the border supports either Celtic or Rangers. So the Fiver is sure the in-no-way-myopic STV digest will soon be reporting joyous dancing on the streets of towns as diverse as Raith, St Mirren and Hearts, after the news that both of Scotland's clubs are interested in nicking Claudio Caniggia from small amateur upstarts Dundee.

"Caniggia is a very good player, definitely," stumpy little Dick Advocaat mumbled miserably today from beneath his bowler hat. "I don't know if he wants to move but I like him very much as a player with his pace and his all-round quality", he went on. This, by the way, is the same Dick who earlier in the season preferred to waste his time at the "low-risk" top end of the market while visionary Dens Park manager Ivano Bonetti gambled on the ageing (ie: 34) and controversial (ie: mates with Diego and Charlie) Argentine striker.

As Celtic are also reportedly interested in Agathe-ing another decent player away from one of these tiny no-mark clubs, it wasn't long before Dundee circled their wagons. "As far as Bonetti is concerned," club co-ordinator Dario Magri said, "he would be suicidal if we sold Caniggia. If Claudio was 25 and someone wanted to give us £12m he'd think about it, but at this stage in his career unless Celtic or Rangers came forward with crazy money it wouldn't be sensible to sell." Get the phone will you Janice? Yes, just pass it to Angela. Thank you, darling. "Hallo, Squaddy here, what's the problem? "Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, eh? webTitle: Comment: America's love affair with guns

fields.headline: I grew up with guns
fields.standfirst:
As another fatal school shooting hits the headlines, Sarah Left recalls a US childhood in which shooting was another sport just like softball

Special report: US gun violence
fields.trailText:
As another fatal school shooting hits the headlines, Sarah Left recalls a US childhood in which shooting was another sport just like softball.
Special report: US gun violence
fields.body:
Yesterday's murder of two more teenagers in a school shooting - this time in San Diego, California - shows America, if it needed to be shown again, what can happen when you mix children with easy-access weaponry. Seven shotguns were discovered in the home of the 15-year-old suspect.

The recent spate of school shootings reached a grisly height in 1999 when two teenagers shot dead 11 classmates and a teacher at Columbine high school near Denver. Other shootings before and since have forced schools to install metal detectors to keep guns out of classrooms.

But the idea of having guns around - at home, at summer camp, at the neighbour's place down the road - is one with which most Americans are completely comfortable.

I grew up in a middle class suburb of Los Angeles, a city synonymous with gun violence. On my 12th birthday, my father gave me a shiny .22 rifle, all wrapped up in pink ribbon and promises of afternoons spent together blowing up clay pigeons.

To me, receiving the gun was no different from receiving a softball glove and bat - I thought of shooting as just another sport I could play. It certainly never occurred to me to shoot the family pets, my brother (no matter how tempting) or my classmates. The gun lived unloaded in cupboard full of tennis rackets and roller skates.

Being a responsible parent, Dad sent me for shooting lessons with an ex-Marine at an expensive summer camp. When he was not looking, we kids would string up some unsuspecting frog by its hind legs and fire away. We also took great delight in loading ants into the bullet chamber of the single-shot rifles, popping in a bullet and watching the curl of smoke that used to be an insect.

Kids are like that, of course. And today I am the only leftwing vegetarian I know with a string of target shooting awards from the National Rifle Association, a group better known for its well organised intolerance to any law that restricts gun ownership.

Unfortunately, as yesterday's shooting illustrates, some kids go tragically further. And it seems that the last people to realise which children are suspect are their parents.

Let's get one thing straight: my father is not a gun nut. He is not a member of the NRA and he understands the need for waiting periods and background checks. He is a reasonable man and by any standard a good parent.

But he also kept a small collection of handguns and rifles scattered on the top shelves of cupboards around the house while my brother and I were growing up. To this day he keeps one loaded and stored in the bedside table. This was not and is not considered abnormal. No one in may family - not my mother, cousins, godparents, anyone - ever said a negative word about the guns.

My brother and I never touched any of them, save a pellet airgun we all considered harmless, because we were simply not interested in shooting as a sport.

This is, after all, not a new problem: in 1984, James Huberty gunned down 21 children and adults in a McDonalds restaurant in San Ysidro, just miles from the site of yesterday's shooting. It was one of the worst mass murders in US history.

Huberty - who was shot dead by the police at the scene of his crime - did have previous shooting incident to his name. When he was a child, he had been accused of shooting a neighbour's dog with an airgun.

I'm sure we would all have agreed that was no more than a malicious prank. I doubt Huberty's father would have melted down all his guns as a result of the incident. Nor, I suspect, would mine.

There is something about gun ownership embedded deep within the idea of being an American. For a variety of reasons that range from racism to unfounded optimism, the vast majority of gun owners honestly do not associate themselves with the shootings that make the news every week in major metropolitan areas.

Yesterday's tragedy will spark more outcries against America's indelible gun culture. Once again, there will be no legislation that makes a difference, particularly not in George W Bush's America. This is the man, remember, who in 1995 made it legal to carry a concealed weapon in his home state of Texas.

He does support legislation that would raise the age at which it is legal to own a gun from 18 to 21. I doubt that counts parental gifts.

fields.headline: Banking on helping the homeless
fields.standfirst: A new scheme launched by the Big Issue in Scotland and the Bank of Scotland will give the homeless in Glasgow access to bank accounts. Tricia Hughes explains why the initiative is vital in helping to get the homeless off the streets
fields.trailText: Comment: A new scheme launched by the Big Issue in Scotland and the Bank of Scotland will give the homeless in Glasgow access to bank accounts. Tricia Hughes explains why the initiative is vital in helping to get the homeless off the streets.
fields.body:
After a long period of being down on your luck you're finally offered a job. However, your elation turns to bitterness when they tell you your wages will be paid directly into your bank - but you don't have a bank account.

You want to save money and put down a deposit on a flat of your own, but you don't have a bank account. Will you carry your growing pile of money about with you at all times and risk being mugged, or will you leave it under the bed in your hostel and risk it being stolen - or will you give up and stop trying to save money?

You could try to open a bank account, but you might be like the millions of people in Britain today who are refused because of bad credit history, a lack of a driving license or passport to prove your identity or, at the extreme end of social exclusion, a lack of an address.

As we increasingly move towards a "cashless" society, those without bank accounts are left on the outside. Despite government pressure, there are still three million "unbanked" people in Britain today. Not surprisingly, homeless people are almost entirely excluded from banking services, yet they are among the most at risk of assault and robbery living as they do on the streets or in dangerous hostels.

The Big Issue recognises the need for homeless people to access banking facilities. Thanks to Bank of Scotland, this is now happening. The amount of red tape and financial regulation involved in setting up a bank account is huge, but the Bank of Scotland has found ways to cut through the red tape and take risks.

Six years ago, the bank agreed to accept Big Issue vendor badges as proof of identity to open a bank account. The bank enabled Big Issue vendors and other homeless people to use its easy cash, no-frills accounts.

But homeless people weren't making full use of the services. As one Big Issue vendor explained, they were embarrassed to go into "posh" bank branches; embarrassed to be depositing small amounts of money - £1 or £2 at a time - in such places.

So once again Bank of Scotland and the Big Issue in Scotland put our heads together, this time with the full support of Glasgow city council, which was keen to explore ways of offering financial services to homeless people.

The result was Grand Central Savings - a "branch" of Bank of Scotland for the exclusive use of homeless people, based in the Big Issue in Scotland's Glasgow headquarters. In its first two weeks of operation nearly 60 homeless people have opened bank accounts, and we're confident that this will be 200 by the end of the year. Some are saving for deposits on flats. Some are just saving for Christmas, hoping to avoid the trap of catalogue debt this year. Some just use the bank to keep their takings from selling the Big Issue safe overnight. Just like anyone else, each Grand Central Savings customer has his or her own way of managing money.

At the public launch of Grand Central Savings in Glasgow yesterday, one Big Issue vendor was explaining to Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland, how pleased she was to finally have access to a bank. Peter Burt joked that the next time he saw her he hoped it was when she came to the bank to arrange a mortgage. The vendor laughed, but she didn't rule out the possibility.

 Tricia Hughes is group managing director of the Big Issue in Scotland.

webTitle: Who out there will bang the drum for England?

fields.headline: Who out there will bang the drum for England?
fields.trailText: One thing was clear during England's victory over Spain - supporting the national team is a dull affair compared to the luminaries that follow other countries.
fields.body:
For some while during the late 80s it was common for conversations on the inadequacies of the England football team to centre on the lack of a defensively solid-yet-attack-minded winger. Traditionally this discussion was brought to a conclusion with mass exclamation of the words, "We've never really replaced Steve Coppell".

I imagine that these days something similar must be heard coming from the lips of television outside-broadcast crews as they feverishly scan the crowd at England's matches. They are looking for a conspicuous, talented fan with the ability to conjure something a little bit special for the people at home during moments when the ball has gone out of play. Someone they can use to say "England" to the viewers in the same way US movie directors use a still of Big Ben and a snatch of The British Grenadiers.

Sadly, as was obvious during last week's match at Villa Park, despite the face paint and the wacky headgear we just don't have the individuals any more.

Because, when it comes to a ubiquitous and easily recognisable supporter of the national team, it has to be said that we've never really replaced the red-white-and-blue-wearing Ken Bailey. The diminutive, tail-coated Bailey was a fixture of England matches, a target-man for the cameras. Since his death nobody has been found to fill his top hat and other nations have overtaken us.

Colombia, for example, have unexpectedly come from nowhere with their spectacular birdman. Clad from head to toe in yellow and blue feathers, this wunderkind of modern fandom has shot right to the top during the past decade.

His greatest moment came during a match at USA 94 when his fellow countrymen lowered him from an upper tier on a wire so that he could flap in attention-grabbing style over the heads of the crowd. That at least is my interpretation of it. It's possible, of course, that they were actually attempting to lynch him for bringing shame on the motherland with his irritating aviform antics.

The Dutch on the other hand have come up with a typical dashing solution to the problem facing TV directors and produced a whole roster of fans who are comfortable on camera. The trio who most encapsulate this style of total supporterhood are the Orange Pope, a spectacular if somewhat paradoxical figure in beard and mitre, and an elderly couple from the polder country who since the 1988 Holland v West Germany clash have been attending games in matching tangerine togas and wigs made entirely from carrots.

If English fans are ever to match this sort of thing they have to watch and learn. Luckily, for the past three weeks they have had a chance to see how it should be done. At international and European level we have seen a master at work in therotund shape of the Spain and Valencia fan Manolo, whose drum-beating on behalf of club and country down the years has made him a favourite of TV directors the world over.

It has to be said that Manolo's clumping rhythms are not to everyone's taste. The big man may wear a bebop-style beret but when it comes to drumming technique he is more max volume than Max Roach. His style is simple but brutally effective: he bangs that skin as hard as he can. And since he has forearms that look like a couple of Serrano hams, that is very hard indeed.

When you are sitting 20 yards away from him, as I was in St Etienne in 1998, you can feel the beat thudding up through your feet, rumbling along your thighs and landing in your stomach with the kind of jolt that will stir evocative memories in anyone who has ever grabbed hold of an electric cattle fence to settle a dare. I don't know what Manolo does for the rest of the week but if my experience is anything to go on he could certainly make a tidy profit hiring himself out as an alternative remedy for anyone seeking relief from the discomfort of trapped wind.

Hopefully, watching the big man in action will have inspired young fans of Manchester United and England to get out there and practise. Meanwhile the country awaits the new Ken Bailey. What we need is an elfin, bald and slightly lost-looking figure who will wave the union flag at every public opportunity. Yes, I know what you are thinking. But I reckon we should leave William Hague out of this.

webTitle: Learning the lessons of a 'freak' accident

fields.headline: Learning the lessons of a 'freak' accident
fields.standfirst:
It would be foolish to dismiss the Selby train crash as a one-off, warns northern editor Martin Wainwright

Full text of HSE interim report
fields.trailText: It would be foolish to dismiss the Selby train crash as a one-off, warns northern editor Martin Wainwright.
fields.body:
You could hear the professional engineer's amazement in Vic Coleman's voice - and see it in his face - as he presented his interim report on the Great Heck train disaster this morning in a York hotel.

He cupped his hands and arched his eyebrows as he spoke of the "energy creation" and "energy absorption" in the world's highest closing-speed railway collision (the combined speed of the two trains was 140mph on impact) - and the way that 20-year-old steel rolling stock had survived it.

Reassurance might seem an incongruous word in the context of 10 deaths and 70 injuries - 30 of them serious - on a humdrum journey across the countryside of northern England.

But any traveller by train, even ones like myself who have spent hours at Great Heck within yards of the wreckage, must wonder at the skill and engineering expertise which saw these "survival capsules" - as Mr Coleman called them - survive a joint speed impact at 140mph.

That wonderment doesn't extend, however, to the remains of the Driving Van Trailer (DVT), the relatively lightweight "false engine" at the front of the train, whose completely flattened remains were the most horrific image of the crash.

Mr Coleman, the chief inspector of railways for the health and safety executive, has concluded provisionally that running the DVT at the front, with the much heavier locomotive pushing at the back, was not a factor.

But any lay person looking at the interim report will want more than that.

Rail unions have expressed concern about the practice, known as "push-pull". It sees GNER expresses (and other big trains) run north with the locomotive pulling from the front and south with it pushing from behind.

The practice saves uncoupling and turning the trains, whose fixed procession of heavy carriages is a proven help to safety in derailments. But it may increase the risk of disaster when in "pushing" mode.

At Great Heck, the DVT first had to swipe Gary Hart's Land Rover aside - something made harder, as Mr Coleman said, by the vehicle's trailer being stuck in a solid embankment and creating a wedge, which helped knock the express off the rails.

The train survived this and carried on upright and inline, with only the front wheels on the ballast. But then it hit a small set of points which serve the sidings of a cement factory.

The interim report suggests that these jerked the DVT - followed by the rest of the Newcastle-London flyer - just enough to the right to smash into the freight train coming the other way. Would the heavier locomotive have ridden the points and missed the 1,700-tonne procession of coal wagons?

It is certainly something the HSE must exhaustively test.

The unions will insist on it. Not in the spirit of blame which has soured railway culture, by falsely suggesting that privatisation means unsafe trains (the statistics show the opposite) - but because it is dangerous to label any accident as a "freak" which requires no further action. That tendency was encouraged today by the headline-grabbing revelation that the freight train was 20 minutes early and so "should not have been there".

In fact, its earliness was known, entirely within operating rules and had no connection with safety. But it unavoidably adds to the eerie feeling that some malevolent spirit governed all the timings of this crash.

Eerie feelings, however, are not in the vocabulary of engineers. Like the police, who are taking apart the Land Rover to check for faults (the road surface and bridge barriers were exonerated this morning), safety professionals must inevitably want a re-examination of "push-pull".

webTitle: First report on Selby train crash

fields.headline: First report on Selby train crash
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Selby crash
Read the report
fields.trailText:
An interim report into last week's Selby rail crash, which claimed 10 lives and injured 70 others, has been published today by the health and safety executive.
Special report: Selby crash
fields.body:
An interim report into last week's Selby rail crash, which claimed 10 lives and injured 70 others, has been published today by the health and safety executive.

Running to just 10 pages, the report details the initial investigation into the "unaviodable" disaster by the HSE's railway inspectorate, and focuses on a factual account of the crash, which was sparked by a trailer-towing Land Rover.

The vehicle, driven by Gary Hart, 36, from Strubby, Lincolnshire, careered off the M62 near the village of Great Heck, North Yorkshire.

It ran down an embankment and ended up on the UK's fastest rail line - the London to Scotland east coast route - and was struck by a King's Cross-bound GNER 225 express train travelling at 125mph.

The train, the 4.45am from Newcastle, was derailed but continued down the track in an upright position before colliding almost head on with a coal-carrying Freightliner goods train travelling from Immingham, Humberside, to Ferrybridge, west Yorkshire.

"The immediate cause of the collision is quite clear - the Land Rover fouled the track. The circumstances that led to the Land Rover ending up on the railway track and the subsequent catastrophic events were not easily foreseeable," it says.

"HSE considers, on the basis of the evidence to date, that there was nothing that the railway industry could reasonably have done to prevent the collisions."

The report says that the freight train was running 20 minutes early but adds that its early departure was within the rules. The driver had no chance of avoiding the collision with the London-bound GNER train.

The document's release follows the disclosure last night that the father of one of the victims of the disaster died in a train accident more than 30 years ago.

Clive Vidgen, 39, of Bishopthorpe, near York, was on his way to a business meeting in Swindon, Wiltshire, when the crash happened last Wednesday.

His father, a railway worker, was killed by a train while working next to a line in December 1969.

A spokesman for North Yorkshire police said: "Clive's death is the second tragic incident to hit the family and they are obviously devastated."

Another victim named yesterday by police was professor Steve Baldwin, a pioneering psychologist from York, who had been travelling to London to give a keynote seminar speech at the Institute of Psychiatry.

Colleagues at Teesside University paid tribute to him. Vice chancellor professor Derek Fraser said: "The whole university community is in shock. We have lost an immensely valued and talented colleague."

GNER train driver John Weddle, from Throckley, near Newcastle, buffet car chef Paul Taylor, 42, from Newcastle and one of the two drivers of the goods train - Stephen Dunn, 39, from Brayton, Selby - were among those killed in the crash.

The other men named yesterday were Alan Frederick Ensor, 44, a civil engineering project manager from Dunnington, near York, and Barry Needham, 40, a freight logistics coordinator of Willow Bank, New Earswick, York.

Investigations are continuing into the road's design and conditions on it at the time of the accident. A separate report form the Highways Agency found the crash barriers at the accident scene would have had to be more than double their length if they were to have prevented the Land Rover from leaving the motorway.

fields.headline: Bloody foreigners
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Westminster is the political hub of Britain. This is where young William Hague barks across the dispatch box at Tony Blair, who, he tells us, wants to turn this country into a "foreign land". A what? Hasn't Britain always been a bit foreign?
fields.body:
Having, by means of pontoons and German troops who excelled at swimming, seized what later generations of invaders would call Thorney Island, and the British having withdrawn generally Essexwards, Aulus Plautius established his base camp on the Thames. The year was AD43. Plautius was the Roman general charged by Claudius with the invasion of Britain. The island his troops used as a stepping stone across the Thames we call Westminster.

Today, Westminster is the political hub of Britain. This is where young William Hague barks across the dispatch box at Tony Blair, who, he tells us, wants to turn this country into a "foreign land". A what? Hasn't Britain always been a bit foreign? It wasn't anything like a unified territory until the Claudian invasion, and even crack Roman legions couldn't subdue the Picts (some of whom later became Irish). London didn't exist before the Romans. The Belgae, the most recent invaders, had made their capital near St Albans.

As for the British, who had arrived here in coracles, quite illegally, some six or seven hundred years before (no Eurostar trains to hide under then), they came from continental Europe. Perhaps they didn't like mixing with all those foreigners. They certainly didn't think much of Londinium, with its fancy Italian ways. In AD60 Boadicea, a British queen, and her army of 250,000 East Anglian warriors, torched London, burning and crucifying its first citizens.

Rebuilt after Suetonius had defeated Boadicea, London quickly became one of the principal cities of the Roman Empire, with a population of about 100,000. For 400 years, London was a Roman city, as cosmopolitan in its more intimate way as Rome was then and London is now.

Those British who accepted the Pax Romana were soon enough sporting togas and speaking and writing Latin. The most successful among them rode around in covered chariots (the Ferraris of their day) and bought centrally heated villas in the home counties. They were mortified when Roman troops left for good from 410 as the empire came under attack by assorted Goths and Huns.

Perhaps there was a moment when some conservative Roman politician, desperately wooing Middle Italy at a spring conference, said: "Thank Jupiter for that. We've invested time and energy in Britain and what have these woad-wearers ever done for us?"

Centuries before the withdrawal of the legions, the poet Juvenal was having a go at the latest Roman fads. The fashionistas were flaunting around imperial markets carrying chunky "ethnic" handbags woven of reeds by the Brits. They called them "bascauda", which was British for basket. These insolent puellae were even polluting the Latin language with foreign words.

Foreigners and their undermining ways, eh? Not to mention their suspicious sounding names. Caratacus. Cleopatra. But, how about William Hague? William sounds a bit Norman, and you couldn't trust the Normans with your Anglo-Saxon kingdom, could you? As for Hague, is that Dutch, or what? Got to watch Johnny Dutch. One moment he's flogging you a nice bit of Delft china, the next he's sailing men-o'-war up the Thames and taking potshots at London. Three cheers for the good old English, eh? Yes, but the English - 14-pints-a-day Vikings - arrived long after the British, who became the Welsh (and thus foreigners like the Scots and the Irish) when they weren't seeking asylum in France, which is very foreign.

Isn't France where the Normans came from? They conquered England and their court in London spoke French before it spoke English, which was, of course, old German with a twist. Somewhere other confusing foreigners fit into this Dark Ages tapestry before the crown became Welsh (Tudors), Scottish (Stuarts), Dutch (William of Orange) and German (George I, and ever since). Now add into this regal weave the colourful common threads of later immigrants. Huguenots. Irish. Jews. More Italians. Poles, West Indians, Cypriots, Indians, Turks, Africans, Romanians, Chinese..

Britain's genius, and London's in particular, has been to absorb and ultimately nurture in its rough and ready way, foreigners of every creed, culture and colour. We live on a mixed-race island governed largely from a capital founded by Italians, who brought with them a system of government divided into two assemblies with a separate judiciary wrapped around with a central treasury and ministries run by secretaries of state and based on and around Thorney Island. All very familiar to William Hague, you'd have thought. All terribly foreign.

fields.headline: The Guardian Graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: The Guardian Graduate jobs email
fields.body:
The Guardian Graduate jobs email

In a week when it was reported that those living in Birmingham enjoy a better quality of life than those in Milan or Rome, here is this week's Brummy email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

As usual, we take a look at the best graduate jobs offered by Jobs Unlimited - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies. We also review last Saturday's Rise and get a look at next week's issue. In addition we've included a link to a past article featured in Rise that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold.

If you spent most of last Saturday dreaming of the Bullring, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 3 March)

Sarah Richardson posed the question: "Are blue chip companies as black as they are sometimes painted?" and asked whether those with a conscience can realistically take the corporate shilling.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,445665,00.html?bnr=grad.email

It also looked at some of the companies that were dreamt up by students attending MBA coursesnone were in Birmingham, incidentally.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,445664,00.html?bnr=grad.email

And we got a hint of what CVs are going to look like in the future. Forget sending it, get ready to beam the mother
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,445668,00.html?bnr=grad.email

NEXT WEEK'S RISE looks at some of the counselling services on offer to students who get into difficulties for whatever reason.

This week's RISE GOLD is some advice on how to survive on that starting salary. While pay levels have never been higher, students are leaving college with average debts of £4,500. Hilary Freeman does the sums.
http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3967500,00.html?bnr=grad.email

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP
Don't get hung up on going to London after graduating - Birmingham and other cities have got lots going for them. Your salary will go further and getting onto the property ladder won't involve selling your sister to the Devil.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS
If you've always wanted to be involved in the building world, Ian Ritchie Architects is looking for an administrator. They want a resourceful graduate who is willing to learn, act with initiative and take on responsibilities.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888106906,00.html?bnr=grad.email

Media buying and planning agency Carat is looking for seven grads to train up to work with some of Europe's biggest advertisers - more positions to follow in the summer.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888106465,00.html?bnr=grad.email

Leading music publisher Boosey & Hawkes is looking for two people who know the difference between their Brahms and their Bach for two jobs at its London HQ.

fields.headline: Email petition makes history
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Tony Blair today received his first e-petition, from people protesting against stamp duty on shares. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
True to his word of embracing all things electronic, Tony Blair today received his first e-petition.

A total of 2,000 signatures, collected over the internet in the past fortnight, have been emailed to Downing Street to protest about stamp duty on stocks or shares.

A tax of 0.5% is currently levied on UK investors when they buy shares in UK-listed companies.

Internet stockbrokers who signed the history-making e-petition called for the abolition of stamp duty on share transactions.

The e-petition is set to change the way Downing Street is lobbied by members of the public. Long-gone are the days when protesters had to march from all corners of the UK to present signed petitions to prime ministers.

The only drawback could be that their quiet nature may mean e-petitions might not be taken as seriously as the boisterous parades on Downing Street.

Downing Street is expected to send a formal reply confirming the petition has been received, also by email.

"Now that Downing Street sees this as a valid way of generating a petition we can see it growing and growing. It's a much more effective than standing on a street corner or knocking on doors," said e-petition organiser Brian Mairs from the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers.

fields.headline: Sharon: 'I have formed a government'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister elect, Ariel Sharon, today told the country's parliament that he is ready to take power tomorrow after successfully forming a government of national unity.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister elect, Ariel Sharon, today told the country's parliament that he is ready to take power tomorrow after successfully forming a government of national unity.

After several weeks of negotiations, Mr Sharon has lined up a broad-based ruling coalition including at least 70 members of the 120-seat parliament, or Knesset. He needs a majority of 61 votes when he presents his government for formal approval tomorrow.

Mr Sharon has built the eight party coalition with the aim of giving his government a more moderate image and making it less susceptible to collapse in the fractious parliament. However, Palestinian militants have threatened to welcome Mr Sharon with an onslaught of bombings. On Sunday a Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in the Israeli town of Netanya, killing three people and injuring 60 more.

The coalition includes rightwing religious parties as well as the centre-left Labour party, which has led the drive for a peace deal with the Palestinians. Labour's elder statesman, Shimon Peres, will serve as foreign minister in Mr Sharon's government.

The unwieldy collection is necessary to provide Israel with stability and a unified government during a time of crisis, Mr Sharon said. But the factions have widely divergent views on fundamental issues, such as how to deal with the Palestinians.

While Mr Sharon faces the urgent task of halting the violence, he must also win approval for this year's budget before the end of the month, or his government will be dissolved, forcing new elections.

The peace talks with the Palestinians broke off shortly before the February 6 ballot, and Mr Sharon has said negotiations will not resume until the violence comes to an end. He opposes the far-reaching compromises proposed by the former prime minister, Ehud Barak, and there appears little chance for a quick resumption of talks at present.

The fighting, which broke out after Mr Sharon visited Jerusalem's most hotly disputed religious site last September, has claimed 423 lives, including 347 Palestinians, 57 Israeli Jews and 19 others.

Mr Sharon has promised to restore security to Israel, but has not detailed how he plans to achieve this in the month since he won a landslide victory over Mr Barak.

"We will make every effort to achieve (peace), but the reality around us reminds us that the struggle for the land of Israel is not over," Mr Sharon said during a visit to northern Israel today. "Our neighbours have recognised our military might, but have not yet recognised our right to the country."

webTitle: Report calls for radical pension reform

fields.headline: Report calls for radical pension reform
fields.standfirst: Highly paid City investment managers who control £800bn in pension funds often do little more than follow the herd and copy other funds, according to a treasury-commissioned report published today
fields.trailText: Highly paid City investment managers who control £800bn in pension funds often do little more than follow the herd and copy other funds, according to a treasury-commissioned report published today.
fields.body:
The report calls for radical reform in the way that pension funds are managed, and warned that legislation may be needed if their behaviour does not change.

In a damning assessment of the City fund management, the report's author, Paul Myners, said that investment decisions were often skewed towards preventing underperformance in respect to their peers rather than obtaining the best returns for pensioners over the long term. For example, a fund which has dropped 10% is considered a top performer if other funds have fallen 11%.

Mr Myners, chairman of the Gartmore fund management group and also chairman of the Guardian Media Group, said: "The review finds that savers' money is too often being invested in ways that do not maximise their interests."

Decisions about who looks after pension money is at the crux of the problem, said Mr Myners. Under current practice, employers appoint pension fund trustees from their staff, who are then asked to take crucial investment decisions. "Yet many lack resources and expertise, are often unsupported by in house staff and are rarely paid," said Mr Myners.

The trustees in turn have to rely on a small group of investment consulting firms, which are largely unscrutinised but wield immense power in the City. These consulting firms set the objectives and benchmarks for performance, which create "unnecessary and artificial incentives" for fund managers to follow the herd, said Mr Myners.

The decision making process is also partly responsible for the lack of money going into startup business in the UK compared to the USA, says Mr Myners. The publication of the Myners report comes at the end of a nine month inquiry instigated by chancellor Gordon Brown into why such a small proportion of pension fund assets - which make up around one third of the entire stockmarket - are invested in startups.

"Decision makers should consider a full range of investment opportunities across all major asset classes, including private equity," recommended Mr Myners.

His other recommendations are that pension fund trustees should be paid, and that they should set overall investment objectives for the fund, relating directly to the circumstances of the fund rather than the relative performance of other funds.

He also endorsed calls for the Minimum Fund Requirement - a solvency test on pensions introduced in the wake of the Maxwell pensions scandal - to be abolished, and replaced by a regime requiring pension funds to report each year to regulators on their current financial state.

fields.headline: Tesco.com moots Seoul sales
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Grocery e-tailer Tesco.com might soon be delivering shopping to doorsteps in Seoul, chief executive officer John Browett told a retail conference yesterday.
fields.body:
Grocery e-tailer Tesco.com might soon be delivering shopping to doorsteps in Seoul, chief executive officer John Browett told a retail conference yesterday.

The group already has hypermarkets in Malaysia, Thailand, Taiwan and South Korea, but online operations only in Britain and Ireland.

"Clearly we want to take the model international. We have already taken it to Ireland," Mr Browett told the conference. He added that Korea and even the US might be next.

Tesco.com, which took its first order in December 1996, is now the third-largest retail portal in the UK, beaten only by Amazon.co.uk and Amazon.com, according to the Nielsen ratings quoted by Tesco. Mr Browett estimated last year's sales at about £250m - up from £125m in 1999.

He attributed Tesco.com's success to its ability to draw supplies from the parent company's national network of supermarkets, reducing costs and raising efficiency.

A report last month showed that online's share of the overall grocery market remains small. In Britain, internet grocery shopping accounts for only 0.4% of the market.

In the US, the rate is 0.33%, and in Germany and Italy 0.1% and 0.02%. Web food shopping is forecast to grow rapidly. According to Datamonitor, the online grocery market is worth $3.5bn, and is set to become the biggest business-to-consumer sector.
Reuters

fields.headline: Failing social services 'face ministerial intervention'
fields.trailText: The Welsh assembly is seeking new powers to crack down on poorly performing social services departments in the wake of a high profile series of damning reports.
fields.body:
The Welsh assembly is seeking new powers to crack down on poorly performing social services departments in the wake of a high profile series of damning reports.

The assembly has launched a draft consultation document setting out where and when ministers will intervene in the case of serious failings in social services.

Underperforming, failing to protect vulnerable clients and unfairness would all be potential reasons for intervention, according to the document sent to unitary authorities for discussion.

The document comes in the wake of the damning Waterhouse report on the abuse of children in care in north Wales and several critical joint reviews that have highlighted concerns about some social services departments in the principality.

It sets out in detail the protocol whereby the assembly would intervene, but says intervention powers will only be used "where there is clear evidence that an authority is failing either to discharge its functions adequately or failing to meet its statutory obligations".

Social services managers said they supported the move. Chairman of the Association of Directors of Social Services in Wales, Hugh Gardner, said: "We welcome the protocol because we support good practice and we do not want to have to defend the indefensible."

"If an authority is failing then clearly it is a priority for the community and for the staff working in the service that it is brought up to speed as soon as possible."

It is expected that most concerns will be resolved by the social services inspectorate in Wales. But it says that when serious problems do arise, intervention will hinge on how effectively the authority concerned responds to the criticisms.

Action by the assembly would probably involve a minister meeting with the council leader to discuss the issues. An agreed action plan would then be drawn up and its implementation by the authority would be monitored.

Serious concerns could involve problems in several areas including practice; staffing and management; policy; and external relations.

The triggers for intervention are likely to involve serious failures to meet a range of statutory requirements, or a failure to follow guidance without justification.

Examples of what could invoke intervention include:

 A failure to protect vulnerable people from actual or potential harm;
 Significant unfairness in dealing with individuals who are entitled to service;
 Persistent underperformance on key indicators.

fields.headline: IPC to launch Web User magazine
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: IPC's first foray into the technology market will make its debut on March 22, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC has announced its new technology magazine is to be called Web User.

The magazine, which is IPC's first foray into the technology market, will launch on March 22.

Web User will be housed in IPC's Country and Leisure Media division.

It is designed to be IPC's first "media neutral" product launch - a website will appear at the same time as the magazine.

Editor Jim Lennox said Web User would "show users the best websites, help them get the best deals, make sure they don't get ripped off and give practical advice about using web software".

The technology publishing sector has been buffeted by dot.com casualties and a series of profit warnings from computer manufacturers such as Dell and Gateway.

However, IPC has said it believed it can make a success of the magazine despite tough market conditions.

fields.headline: BBC's Hunt moves from One to Six
fields.trailText: 8.30am Jay Hunt is expected to be confirmed as the new editor of the Six O'Clock News, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC One O'Clock News editor Jay Hunt is expected to be confirmed as the new editor of the Six O'Clock News, taking over from Mark Popescu who is joining the Ten O'Clock News.

The appointment of Mr Popescu, a former ITN News at Ten editor, has led to jockeying for position among senior BBC editors.

It is believed BBC news bosses, under new head of news Richard Sambrook, believe that Ms Hunt, who has recently returned from maternity leave, is the best candidate for the job.

Other contenders for the job were believed to include Newsnight editor Sian Kevill and Chris Rybczynski, who is in charge of the BBC's weekend coverage.

Insiders say news bosses believe Ms Rybczynski is likely to be offered the editorship of the One O'Clock News.

"This is all speculation," said Roger Mosey, the BBC's head of television news.

"We're carrying out interviews for a number of jobs in the next couple of weeks and will make an announcement of our new line-up of editors in due course."

Mr Popescu will not take over as editor of the 10 O'Clock News until after the general election.

The appointment of the editors of the Six O'Clock and One O'Clock News will cement a new era under Mr Sambrook, who replaces outgoing boss Tony Hall in April.

Mr Hall is taking up the position of chief executive of the Royal Opera House.

Relevant story Dec 22: Popescu to edit BBC Ten O'Clock News

fields.headline: Double jeopardy
fields.standfirst: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has asked the Law Commission to review the ancient law of double jeopardy, under which no one who has been convicted or acquitted of an offence can be retried on the same facts
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has asked the Law Commission to review the ancient law of double jeopardy, under which no one who has been convicted or acquitted of an offence can be retried on the same facts
fields.body:
What is double jeopardy?
Double jeopardy is an ancient English law that states no one who has been convicted or acquitted of an offence can be tried a second time on the same facts.

Why is it in the news?
The Law Commission, the official law reform body for England and Wales, has recommended that the law be changed with regard to murder. It says that a fresh trial should be possible if "compelling" new evidence emerges after the defendant is found not guilty. It is likely to become law if the government is re-elected.

Does that mean the suspected Stephen Lawrence killers could be retried?
Yes - the law commission has recommended that the change should be retrospective, which would allow a fresh trial if compelling new evidence emerged. Neil Acourt, Luke Knight and Gary Dobson were acquitted of the murder in 1996 when a judge ruled that identification evidence was unreliable.

Who else could it affect?
The Home Office has calculated there are currently 35 murder cases where defendants who were acquitted could be reinvestigated and new charges brought if the law is changed retrospectively.

One of these is Billy Dunlop, who murdered pizza delivery girl Julie Hogg. He was acquitted of the crime in 1991 but confessed to the killing in a perjury trial last year and jailed for six years. Another would be former East End gangster Freddie Foreman, who admitted on television to committing two murders for the Kray twins that a court acquitted him for in the 1960s.

Who supports a change in the law?
The law commission, the government and victim's relatives such as Ann Ming, Julie Hogg's mother, and Doreen Lawrence, Stephen's mother. Mrs Lawrence said today that she wanted her son's alleged killers to stand trial again. "The jury in the case never had a chance to hear any of the evidence and they were acquitted by the judge," she said.

What are the problems
Michael Napier, president of the Law Society which represents 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales, said they were not fundamentally opposed to a change in the law but questioned how a fair trial could be guaranteed.

So who outright opposes it?
Civil liberties groups and lawyers such as defence barrister Geoffrey Robertson QC and Imran Khan, who brought a private prosecution against Neil Acourt, Gary Dobson and Luke Knight on behalf of the Lawrence family. Mr Khan said today that scrapping double jeopardy in murder cases would end the principal of innocent until proven guilty.

"Imagine a jury sitting in the trial who know a High Court judge has looked at the evidence and said it is compelling and should lead to a conviction," he told the BBC.

Any other objections? Ending double jeopardy could tempt sloppy investigations from the police since they would know that should things go wrong they could always attempt the prosecution again. The police may also continue to investigate a former suspect who had been acquitted of murder to justify their original decision to prosecute.

Will double jeopardy be scrapped for all crimes?
Mr Robertson, though he does not support a change in the law, says it is irrational to scrap double jeopardy for murder but not other violent crimes such as armed robbery. However, the law commission is unlikely to agree. Instead it says that double jeopardy is of "fundamental importance" and should be put on a statutory basis for all other offences.

What happens in other countries?
In Scotland, the high court is able to order a new trial on appeal for the same crime after a conviction has been quashed. Double jeopardy exists in the United States although in rare instances a person may be tried for a different crime based on some of the same facts used in a trial that resulted in acquittal.

webTitle: Transfer deal draws up instant controversy

fields.headline: Transfer deal draws up instant controversy
fields.trailText: The agreement on the future on the transfer system has already divided the world of football.
fields.body:
The agreement on the future on the transfer system has already divided the world of football.

The compromise deal, finally agreed in Brussels on Monday by world governing body Fifa, Uefa and the EU, was ratified without the agreement of FIFPro, the international players' union, who have threatened to pursue the matter in court.

But the deal has also been criticised by club owners like Arsenal's David Dein who believes the new system will allow players to change clubs "at the drop of a wallet".

In an interview with BBC Radio this morning, Dein explained his disappointment with the compromise. "What we don't want to see is players leaving at the drop of a wallet. The problem for the club the player is currently playing for is that they could be faced with the choice after one year of him signing a long contract or either renegotiating his existing contract or losing his services."

Meanwhile, the players' representatives are unhappy because they feel that players will not get the same rights as other European workers - which was the reason the whole transfer situation was examined in the first place.

FifPro spokesman Laurent Denis said today: "It's a very black day for European sport and footballers. It creates a new category of workers at a European level - footballers who will not benefit like others from the same social protection."

The football authorities and the EU are happy. While recognising the absence of FIFPro from the agreement, Fifa president Sepp Blatter said: "Without the players there is no football but without professional clubs there is no job in football as well. We have to strike the right balance."

While much of the "new deal" had been agreed two weeks ago, including, for the first time, two international transfer windows a year, the crucial issues of "contract stability" and compensation to smaller clubs was agreed only after a five-hour meeting on Monday.

The main new elements include agreement that any player breaking his contract within the first two years of a three-year "protected period" of a five-year contract could be banned for playing for his new club for up to four months in the next season.

One immediate development is that transfer fees are likely to come down as contracts can be protected only for a maximum of three years. The money not spent on the "transfer fee", or "compensation fee" as it more accurately becomes, will probably go to the players in salaries. Much talking is still expected to take place between the disputing parties, but yesterday's meeting means the new deal will go before Fifa's Congress in Buenos Aires on July 7 and will be in force in time for next season.

fields.headline: Granada/Boots health venture sets launch date
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Granada and Boots are preparing to launch their Wellbeing health and beauty website and TV channel next Wednesday, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Granada and Boots are preparing to launch their Wellbeing health and beauty website and TV channel next Wednesday.

The Wellbeing Network will be screened as an interactive TV channel on Sky Digital ONdigital and tied into a website, wellbeing.com.

It is the first major broadband development from Granada since it committed last year to the eponymous new division, Granada Broadband.

Wellbeing will eventually be made available across all digital platforms, such as cable, PDA and mobile devices, and customers will be able to book doctor's appointments via the website.

The TV channel, which will be broadcast from 9am-9pm every day, will feature interactive programming about health, fitness and nutrition.

The selling point of Wellbeing is that it taps into Boots-sanctioned health and beauty "experts", including doctors and pharmacists, and allows consumers to buy Boots products with their TV remote controls.

Granada Media has a 40% stake in Wellbeing, with Boots accounting for the remaining 60%.

fields.headline: Benson takes BBC factual post
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Glenwyn Benson has been named BBC joint director of factual and learning overseeing Watchdog and Top Gear, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Glenwyn Benson has been appointed as BBC joint director of factual and learning, overseeing shows including Watchdog, Top Gear, Tomorrow's World and Antiques Roadshow.

Ms Benson has been acting in the role since Lorraine Heggessey was promoted to become BBC1 controller at the end of last year.

She will become a member of the BBC executive committee alongside the other joint director of factual and learning Michael Stevenson.

Controller of documentaries Jeremy Gibson and controller of leisure and factual entertainment Anne Morrison will both report to Ms Benson.

"Although Glenwyn did not originally apply for the job, she is absolutely the right person for it and I'm delighted we have been able to persuade her to take on the role permanently," said BBC director general Greg Dyke.

Ms Benson, currently controller of specialist factual, is a former editor of Panorama and On the Record editor.

She began her broadcasting career at LWT, where she rose to become deputy editor of Weekend World.

fields.headline: Case study: Age Concern England
fields.trailText: Age Concern England is launching a new training and development programme this month to grow its own senior managers as part of a wider reform of management development in recent years.
fields.body:
Age Concern England is launching a new training and development programme this month to grow its own senior managers as part of a wider reform of management development in recent years.

The "moving into management" programme will take 12 home-grown staff, who have recently taken on supervisory responsibilities but are not yet managers, and train them in a variety of management skills over the coming six months.

"Age Concern has grown a lot in recent years and we've realised we need to invest more in growing our own managers," says learning and development manager Colleen Nicholson.

The charity has some 450 staff, of which about 10% are managers, but became increasingly aware of gaps in management skills following research carried out with a consultant three years ago. The study revealed significant skills shortages in working at a senior level of the strategic direction of the charity.

Other areas the charity decided to focus on were change management skills and the development of quality standards within Age Concern.

The skills gap research led to the introduction of a management development initiative. This involved the development of a series of in-house courses on topics such as finance, people management and influencing skills.

"We also developed coaching, especially for the top team and senior managers, because it's often difficult for them to get away from their jobs to do courses," says Ms Nicholson.

One initiative involved trying to enlist staff from the finance department as coaches. This meant that if a manager was not following the proper financial procedures, instead of simply sending that manager a form to fill in someone from finance would coach the manager in understanding the procedures better.

"It's a good idea but has only been partially successful because we've had a lot of turnover in the finance department," says Ms Nicholson.

The learning and development unit, where Ms Nicholson is based, has been renamed this month the organisation development unit. The rename is part of an attempt to focus on how training and development should be linked to the organisation's goals rather than just sending people on courses.

Quality standards are one of the drivers for improving management. Quality standards are becoming increasingly common in the relationship between statutory funders and charities and within voluntary organisations themselves.

"Quality standards mean how good the services are and cover issues like user involvement and change management," says Ms Nicholson, adding that it is increasingly important for managers to be able to understand and put into practice quality standard frameworks.

Other methods of delivering training and development at Age Concern include "action learning sets", in which staff are brought together to share experiences, and a growing focus on projects that involve managers from different divisions. The charity also now has a small resource library with videos, books and cassettes on training and development topics.

"People used to see the voluntary sector as rather sleepy when it came to management but that's not true anymore and we're catching up with other sectors," says Ms Nicholson.

webTitle: Cattle moves to abattoirs despite new cases

fields.headline: Cattle moves to abattoirs despite new cases
fields.standfirst:
• Livestock moves to slaughterhouses
  • Seven new cases
  • 76 farms hit; two near Dartmoor
  • Farmers clamour for licences

    Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
• Livestock moves to slaughterhouses
  • Seven new cases
  • 76 farms hit; two near Dartmoor
  • Farmers clamour for licences The discovery of new cases by officials from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food has brought the total number of affected farms across the United Kingdom to 74.
fields.body:
Livestock was beginning to move to British slaughterhouses today, even as more farms were declared unsafe as five new cases of foot and mouth disease were reported in England and Scotland.

The discovery of new cases by officials from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food has brought the total number of affected farms across the United Kingdom to 76.

The most significant discoveries of the disease were at two farms bordering Dartmoor national park in Devon, where 50,000 cattle graze on common land.

An outbreak was confirmed at Dunna Bridge Farm, Two Bridges on Saturday and fears were increased today with a second case confirmed at a nearby farm at Widecombe in the Moor.

The potential for the disease to have spread to the cattle leading to an enforced mass slaughter operation was described as "nightmare scenario" by the south west regional National Farmers' Union director, Anthony Gibson.

While the disease continued to take hold in some areas, the government said unaffected farms could begin to transport their animals to slaughterhouses under close supervision and under licenses.

Farmers - whose livestock has plummeted in value over the last 11 days of enforced immobility - have been clamouring to apply for licenses. In Aberdeenshire alone, 71 licenses have been applied for.

The British Horseracing Board and Jockey Club today announced that racing in unaffected areas would resume tomorrow - the first time since a ban was introduced last week.

However, music magazine NME warned that some outdoor summer festivals might be cancelled due to the disease.

There are hopes that the crisis may soon be under control as all but one of the confirmed outbreaks in Britain were conclusively linked to diseased animals elsewhere.

Five new cases yesterday - at farms in Bishop Auckland, County Durham; Hatherleigh, Devon; Highampton, Devon; St Weonards, Herefordshire; and near Beattock, Dumfries and Galloway - were also believed to linked to previous cases.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said measures were already in place to start moving unaffected cattle, sheep and pigs to abattoirs, while slaughtering was already under way in parts of Scotland.

Hundreds of special licences have been given to farmers in such areas and one supermarket promised shoppers fresh supplies of British pork as early as today.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said 14,092 animals had been slaughtered so far while another 60,000 would also be culled.

In France, all movement of sheep, pigs, goats and horses has been stopped for two weeks, although officials at the EU maintain the crisis has not yet reached epidemic proportions.

Meanwhile, banned spinal cord has been found at an abattoir in Blackpool in a consignment of imported beef from Holland.

Spinal cord is included in the list of specified risk material (SRM) which is thought to be at greatest risk of carrying BSE infectivity. Under EU rules, it must be removed when the animal is slaughtered.

Europe's veterinary experts will today consider authorising the use of vaccine to counter the spread of foot and mouth disease. But the policy is still seen as a last resort, and too costly, and is likely to be rejected.
