fields.headline: Attic auction set to attract big names
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Attic Futura's sale is likely to attract bids from big consumer publishers including NatMags, Emap and IPC. By Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 2: Oz-owned publisher up for sale
fields.body:
The "For Sale" sign going up at Attic Futura is likely to attract bids in the coming weeks from big consumer publishers including NatMags, Emap and IPC.

Parent company PMP is reported to be seeking around £60m for the company, which publishes Sugar, Shine, B, Inside Soap and TV Hits.

Meanwhile, Attic Futura has confirmed it has carried out an asset swap with the other PMP subsidiary North South.

The move should disentangle some of the complicated joint ownership relationships involving magazines including B and Sugar.

Having secured full ownership of these titles is likely to make them more attractive to potential buyers.

Attic Futura's magazines offer synergy with IPC, Emap and NatMags' magazine portfolios.

Natmags deputy managing director Duncan Edwards has made it clear in the past that he is interested in acquiring more companies.

The Attic magazines would make a good fit with the Emap and IPC portfolios, but both companies have significant debts which hinder them making a bid.

Nevertheless, moves by Emap to sell one or more of its publishing arms - either its US business (formerly Petersen) or Emap Business Media - could speed up a purchase.

fields.headline: Growing your own staff
fields.trailText: There is growing pressure on voluntary organisations to develop their own managers and not rely on bringing people in from outside, writes Patrick McCurry
fields.body:
A few years ago it was common for charities to hire retired generals or civil servants as chief executives, and look to the private sector for many senior managers.

But there is growing pressure on voluntary organisations to develop their own managers and future chief executives and not rely on bringing people in from outside.

Research last year by the voluntary sector national training organisation (NTO) found that management skills were the biggest challenge for the sector.

NTO head Ben Kernighan says: "In the past it was easier to recruit good managers from outside but now charities need to look carefully at their own training and development."

Another reason for developing the potential of existing staff is the growing complexity and commercial activities of the sector. But that "business" approach still needs to be aligned with the traditional values of charities, which can make it difficult for a private sector manager to quickly adapt to working for a voluntary organisation.

"It can take a long time for managers from outside to come in and understand the culture of the sector so if charities can develop their own people they don't need to worry about that learning curve," says Mr Kernighan.

That "culture" includes issues such as consensus-based management, the ability to manage volunteers and knowing how to deal with boards of trustees.

Paul Streets, chief executive at Diabetes UK, says: "Some people from the commercial sector think they can walk into a charity and start running it and some charities are seduced by that.

"But the sector needs to grow its own staff more. There are a lot more people in their 30s and 40s, who have worked in the voluntary sector all their lives and who want to be chief executives, and they need to be trained and developed."

Stephen Bubb, head of the charity chief executives association Acevo, says he wants to encourage more development of potential future leaders within the sector.

"We are bringing in a new category of membership of Acevo for senior people in charities who are hoping to become chief executives."

He praises the civil service system of identifying talented managers and developing them. The voluntary sector has never been very good at developing management potential, says Mr Bubb, but he hopes Acevo initiatives, such as a "leadership academy", will help to change things.

One of the main barriers to management development in the sector has been lack of funds. Mr Bubb says: "It's hard for a charity to fundraise for things like professional development of staff because people prefer to donate to charitable projects."

Despite the lack of resources in many small and medium-sized charities, Mr Kernighan argues that even very small charities can have a training and development programme.

"It doesn't need to be anything ambitious but can be informal. For example, a small charity can approach a larger organisation in the same field to find mentors."

Mr Kernighan is keen to stress that training and development does not necessarily mean "shoving people on to two-day courses". In fact, that can be counterproductive if the information learned is not effectively translated back into the organisation.

He wants to see charities adopt a multi-faceted approach, which brings in mentoring, shadowing colleagues and bringing together staff from different departments to share experiences and work on common projects.

Acevo's Mr Bubb agrees that mangers can learn a lot from simply talking to others in similar positions: "We try and offer networking opportunities because senior people can always learn a lot from their peers.

webTitle: Meetings could hold key to democracy

fields.headline: Meetings could hold key to democracy
fields.standfirst: China's National People's Congress event, while not as political as it once was, is becoming more interesting every year, says John Gittings
fields.trailText: China's National People's Congress event, while not as political as it once was, is becoming more interesting every year, says John Gittings
fields.body:
Beijing used to be festooned with banners hailing the event when the National People's Congress convened its annual meetings in the Great Hall of the People.

This week, the slogans - whether hung over shopping centres or chalked on neighbourhood blackboards - are still about the city's Olympic bid. In these less compulsorily political times, the Congress is the source of traffic jams for most Beijingers and nothing else.

Yet the event is becoming more interesting year by year, and harder for foreign media to write off as a "rubber stamp" affair. (In fact, such expressions are more likely now to be used by cynical Chinese).

For the third year in succession, premier Zhu Rongji has opened the Congress with a report which, while making the right obeisance to Marxism and the correct policies of the Communist party, spells out many of China's problems with remarkable frankness.

Chinese journalists are permitted a certain amount of doorstopping as the nearly 3,000 Congress delegates climb the steps to the Great Hall. The leaders, of course, still enter in privacy from their tinted glass saloon cars by another door.

A few outspoken provincial delegates will stop and speak critically of issues such as corruption, waste and incompetent planning. Others will seize the chance to advertise the attractions of their region. Those dressed in national minority costume just pose for the cameras.

A word of explanation is needed on the complex structure of the Congress and of another organisation which meets at the same time. (The whole event is officially known as the "liang hui" or Two Meetings).

Most of the Congress delegates are elected by provincial congresses whose members in turn are chosen by congresses at a lower level. Though it is a non-party body, the choice is approved, if not dictated, by local communist officials. Some delegates are chosen specially by the armed forces - and they are banned from talking to the media.

With these limitations, it brings together an assembly of fairly diverse people from across a diverse country. On several occasions the Congress has indicated popular concern over issues, such as corruption and the environment, when a significant number have abstained or even voted against key proposals.

The Congress only meets annually, but its standing committee convenes during the year to approve legislation and other government business - subject to party initiative and direction. Nine special committees also look at subjects ranging from law to rural affairs.

The second organisation goes by a name of such baffling length that western journalists despair when they write it. It is, in full, the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference or CPPCC for short.

Very roughly, this body brings together representatives from professional and business interests, from the cultural establishment and from the small rump parties, which survived the 1949 communist victory. It also, confusingly, includes some delegates from the Communist party.

If the Congress is a talking shop, the Conference can be called a sounding board. Both bodies split into small groups, either based on provinces or on interest groups, which meet at intervals over the next week.

Some media access is now allowed to these groups - though wary guards may be reluctant to permit it. The old habits of security die hard. The groups live for the entire period in assigned hotels, which are sealed off from the general public. As a great concession, this year some delegates who live in Beijing have been allowed to go home each night.

If Congress or Conference members visit a restaurant outside, the manager is supposed to inform the police so that they can send a guard. Conditions are even tighter this year because of fears that members may be accosted by the banned Falun Gong sect.

The small groups put forward resolutions or queries which are forwarded to "the relevant authorities". Sensitive issues like the plan to develop China's far western provinces, or to shift water from the Yangtze to the Yellow River, may attract quite a few resolutions.

Answers tend to come back slowly. "We have to nag the 'relevant authorities'," says one Conference delegate, "but in the end we may learn something useful."

Groups may reconvene later in the year to discuss the information they gain. Occasionally this leads to the publication of books and articles, or even new legislation.

Membership of the two organisations at the national or lower levels carries less prestige than before. The easier access it once provided for scarce commodities, like soft class train tickets, is also less important as living and transport conditions improve.

Yet on paper the Congress is still "the highest organ of power": there have been calls in the past - notably in the student movement of 1989 - for this to become reality. If China is ever going to move towards a more democratic government, then (bar an unlikely revolution) the Two Meetings could still offer the best route.

webTitle: Scoop, poop and videotape at Madonna christening

fields.headline: Scoop, poop and videotape at Madonna christening
fields.trailText: Robert Podesta, who hid in the organ of the cathedral where Madonna and Guy Ritchie were married, admits conducting himself in a disorderly manner likely to cause concern by filming the private ceremony
fields.body:
It would have been the celebrity scoop of the decade and Robert Podesta almost pulled it off.

As the fabulous and famous settled into the pews of Dornoch cathedral for the christening of Madonna's baby son, Rocco, the part-time security adviser, hidden in the massive cathedral organ, switched his video camera to record. He got it all: the proud parents, the tearful stars, Sting's rendition of Ave Maria, the kisses and congratulations.

Almost an hour after the last guest had gone he climbed out of his hiding place, which he had stacked with food and drink, and black binliners to use as a toilet. But he was spotted by Madonna's security guards on a final check of the 13th century cathedral, and the 24-minute film was found.

Yesterday at Dornoch sheriff court, Podesta, 51, from Garway, in Herefordshire, admitted conducting himself in a disorderly manner likely to cause concern by filming the private ceremony on December 21 last year. His not guilty plea to a charge of trespassing in the cathedral was accepted.

His co-accused James Bufton, 33, of Usk, Monmouthshire, who had faced three charges in connection with the christening, had his not guilty pleas accepted by the crown. He had been charged with trespassing in the cathedral, breaching the peace by videoing the service, and attempting to defeat the end of justice by giving a false name to police.

The court heard how Podesta had become involved in a plot to film the event in the Scottish Highlands, lured by the prospect of big money from the sale of the video.

His solicitor, Craig Wood, said Podesta and Bufton, a reporter, met a week before the ceremony and looked inside the cathedral. It fell to Podesta, a part-time security adviser, to carry out the filming, he said, and he was promised a share of the proceeds from the sale of the film.

Procurator fiscal Alistair Macdonald said Podesta hid behind the cathedral organ 24 hours before the christening, with food and drink, and black binliners to use as a makeshift toilet.

Mr Macdonald said the ceremony had taken place between 6.30pm and 7pm and around half an hour later security personnel checking the cathedral heard a noise and came across Podesta carrying a rucksack.

"He agreed to his rucksack being searched and inside was found a camcorder," said Mr Macdonald. "The black binliners were found to contain his excrement and other refuse ."

When questioned, Podesta confessed to having filmed the christening from behind the cathedral's organ. Mr Macdonald told the court there was no film in the camcorder and Podesta said he had dropped it down an organ pipe. The organ was searched and a film retrieved, which was blank, but meanwhile Podesta was spotted trying to hide a videocassette under a pew cushion. Mr Macdonald said this was a 24-minute recording of the ceremony.

He also told the court that rubbish found behind the organ suggested Podesta had been there for around 24 hours before the service.

"Obviously his intention was to sell this video recording which it is believed would have some relatively considerable commercial value."

Mr Wood said Podesta, who was not in court, earned around £4,000 as a security adviser and £6,000 from a pension. "My instructions are that he got involved because he saw it as a bit of fun and excitement, but he now realises that he has been a fool and he regrets it," he said.

"There was no particular sum of money mentioned to him. It was a speculative venture. The film would have been passed on to other parties and he would have got a slice of the proceeds."

Sheriff Ian Cameron ordered the destruction of the video and called for Podesta to appear in person on March 29 to give a full picture of his financial circumstances before sentencing.

fields.headline: Terminated
fields.standfirst: Big, flash and rolling in cash, Arnold Schwarzenegger was the epitome of the Hollywood action hero. But then came a run of bad movies - and now a string of sordid allegations. Danny Leigh on the humbling of an icon
fields.trailText: Big, flash and rolling in cash, Arnold Schwarzenegger was the epitome of the Hollywood action hero. But then came a run of bad movies - and now a string of sordid allegations.
fields.body:
In the glossy US magazine Movieline, there was once a column called Guess Who Don't Sue, devoted to the drug habits and sexual peccadillos of film industry notables. The gimmick (and safety valve) of the slot was that the magazine never let slip the identity of that month's victim. Hints, of course, were dropped; but hints were all. Such, outside the scandal-mongering of the super- market tabloids, is Hollywood's way.

There were, for example, unsubstantiated rumours in Los Angeles about a much-loved action superstar with a bad attitude towards women and a self-induced heart condition. That's all the public would ever know: vague whispers about a nameless celebrity. Until, that is, the latest issue of Movieline's rival monthly Premiere appeared, in which journalist John Connolly finally named a name: Arnold Schwarzenegger.

The article began with the star's alleged harassment of TV presenter Anna Richardson during a trip to London to promote his recent film The Sixth Day. It got worse. Connolly detailed allegations of female colleagues groped, a male crew member bullied, a wife victim of infidelities, and a steroid-popping past as a bodybuilder bequeathing Schwarzenegger heart problems.

The article has drawn a response of sorts from the star's publicist, Jill Eisenstadt. "Arnold's not going to bother dignifying this," she said. "We're moving on." Schwarzenegger's doctor, meanwhile, has informed Premiere that "100% of what's written in the article" is untrue. Some commentators suspect a political motive behind the attack, given the star's vocal Republicanism.

All of which has left the movie business in shock - not least because Schwarzenegger is not known for sparing the lawyers. American newspaper the Globe, for instance, found itself embroiled in a $50m defamation suit in 1998 after describing him as a "timebomb" following heart surgery. It later printed a retraction. Dr Willi Heepe, the Berlin cardiologist unwise enough to raise the subject again on German radio, was ordered to pay Schwarzenegger $10,000 in damages.

Then there's Premiere itself, which received a cautionary letter from Schwarzenegger's attorney Martin Singer the moment his camp got wind of Connolly's investigations. But, despite a pre-emptive campaign to discredit it (featuring outraged letters to Premiere from, among others, director James Cameron), the magazine stuck with its story. And guess who didn't sue?

Apart from the lack of a lawsuit, however, there is another remarkable aspect to the story: that, amid the bloodless hype of movie journalism, it was even commissioned in the first place. After all, within the film press breaking ranks like this simply isn't done - and not just out of deference to publicists and lawyers. Rather, the flaws and foibles of movie stars stay out of the papers because their fame provides a livelihood for the studio system's ranks of worker bees, journalists included.

And that, quite apart from the grotesque nature of some of the allegations, is perhaps the story's most damaging implication for its subject. Increasingly unsuccessful at the box office, Schwarzenegger has apparently been deemed disposable by his own community.

It is a neat coincidence, therefore, that British audiences will this month be able to revisit the former Mr Universe in his cinematic pomp, with a reissue of his 1984 movie The Terminator. Back when the film was released, its leading man was fast becoming a pectoral-rippling emblem of his times: the champion bodybuilder from a remote Austrian mountain village who, like the equally cumbersome Swedish wrestler Tor Johnson in the 1940s, had come to the US with high hopes of movie stardom.

Except, while Johnson wound up entangled with Z-list auteur Ed Wood, Schwarzenegger was decidedly more successful. He was a walking (sort of), talking (occasionally) melange of carefully scripted one- liners and terrifying firepower. The 1980s belonged to him, just as they were the Reaganite Republicans' - whose politics he espoused. As well he might. Schwarzenegger was nothing if not a free-market phenomenon, a self-made man, marrying his Nietzschean on-screen persona with the cuddly, catchphrase-spouting "Arnie" of popular imagination. The adulation, and the dollars, rolled in.

Seventeen years later, however - even with a Bush in the White House, the party appears to be dragging to a standstill. The 1990s, complete with their Democratic president, were not kind to Schwarzenegger. After his career highpoint, 1991's Terminator 2, it was a downhill ride. Granted, the failure of Last Action Hero (1993) was followed by triumph with the bad-guy-go-boom action of 1994's True Lies. Yet, as the decade wore on, that film's success came to look less like the rule and more like the exception. Movie violence, as employed by bold young turks such as Quentin Tarantino, was suddenly becoming hip - and Arnie, with his limited array of heavily accented bon mots, was anything but hip.

Not that there's a newer, younger model in town. In fact, that's half the problem - rather than Schwarze- negger being usurped by the competition, the entire sub-genre in which he flourished has withered on the vine. With his natural constituency having been seduced away from the cinema by Playstation and the World Wrestling Federation, and the action movie revolutionised by the likes of John Woo and The Matrix, Schwarzenegger looks as appealing as the troubled Planet Hollywood restaurant chain he finally bailed out of in January last year.

Hence his potential vulnerability to rumour and revelations. For the 53-year-old Schwarzenegger, without a hit in seven years and now nicknamed Arnold the Barbarian, the future looks bleak. He has talked of wanting to make more "intellectual" movies; of working with Woody Allen (who has so far failed to reciprocate); of turning his back on violence altogether; and, whenever he's appeared in danger of slipping out of the limelight for too long, of running for political office. Whether the Republicans will be quite so keen on the candidacy of a family man whose alleged personal conduct - according to Premiere - would appear to be contrary to his wholesome public image remains to be seen. Meanwhile, although the star has expressed his distaste for sequels and the "low-foreheaded" studio executives behind them, his next significant movie project will see him pulling on the leathers one more time for a second follow-up to The Terminator. In de facto control of the project, he is reportedly already on to his third script revision in an effort to keep the budget down.

But perhaps he's wasting his time. Mud has a habit of sticking. One wonders whether it is not Tor Johnson to whom Schwarzenegger should be compared, but Fatty Arbuckle - the 1920s comic whose career foundered on disproved allegations of immorality while the business changed around him. And, if the response from the man himself would surely be a rictus grin and an "I'll be back", the world could be forgiven for thinking that this time, it really is hasta la vista .

fields.bodyText: In the glossy US magazine Movieline, there was once a column called Guess Who Don't Sue, devoted to the drug habits and sexual peccadillos of film industry notables. The gimmick (and safety valve) of the slot was that the magazine never let slip the identity of that month's victim. Hints, of course, were dropped; but hints were all. Such, outside the scandal-mongering of the super- market tabloids, is Hollywood's way. There were, for example, unsubstantiated rumours in Los Angeles about a much-loved action superstar with a bad attitude towards women and a self-induced heart condition. That's all the public would ever know: vague whispers about a nameless celebrity. webTitle: First bank for the homeless praised by charities

fields.headline: First bank for the homeless praised by charities
fields.trailText: Charities have welcomed the launch of the first bank for homeless people, and predicted that the initiative will help cut violent crime against rough sleepers.
fields.body:
Charities have welcomed the launch of the first bank for homeless people, and predicted that the initiative will help cut violent crime against rough sleepers.

The bank, a joint initiative by the Big Issue in Scotland and the Bank of Scotland, already has 56 homeless customers and is expected to have 200 by the end of the year.

Grand Central Savings based at the Big Issue's Glasgow office, offers homeless people the chance to deposit and withdraw money from as little as £1.

A spokeswoman for Shelter Scotland said: "Anything that helps the normalisation of life for homeless people is to be welcomed wholeheartedly, the Bank of Scotland is to be congratulated for taking the initiative."

She added: "Homeless people's access to financial services has been a problem for some time. If they carry money on them it makes them at risk of attack, so from that point alone it is going to increase their personal safety."

Tricia Hughes, managing director of the Big Issue in Scotland, said: "The Big Issue believes that work is the solution to homelessness for many people.

"However, if people can't get a bank account, then they can't save for the future. Grand Central Savings is a practical way for homeless people to help themselves, and to learn to manage their money."

But the spokeswoman for Shelter Scotland was cautious about the suggestion that the new bank would help homeless people find work. She said: "Homeless people don't need encouragement to take up jobs, they the need jobs to be available."

Tam Hendry general manager of Edinburgh Street Work Project said: "Getting a bank account has long been a major hurdle for those who are trying to rebuild their life and get into work. We can't wait to see a similar services her in Edinburgh and other Scottish cities.

The Bank of Scotland have opened their doors to homeless people, what are the other banks waiting for?"

fields.headline: Bookshops are closing. Hurrah
fields.standfirst:
Those that can't provide the service deserve to go to the wall

March 5: 10% of small bookshops forced out of business
fields.trailText: A report in the Guardian yesterday headed "One in 10 small bookshops forced under" noted that the number of independent book retailers in Britain had fallen from 1,894 to 1,699 since 1995. The amazing fact is not that 10% have closed, but that 90% have stayed open.
fields.body:
There was a report in the Guardian yesterday headed "One in 10 small bookshops forced under". This noted that the number of independent book retailers in Britain had fallen from 1,894 to 1,699 since 1995, the year the Net Book Agreement collapsed. There were appropriate woe-is-us quotes by way of illustration. These figures seemed to me staggering, but not in the way some people might think. The amazing fact is not that 10% have closed, but that 90% have stayed open.

Hardly anyone now remembers the great battle fought in the early 1960s over retail price maintenance, when Edward Heath, as the relevant minister in the Macmillan government, pushed through - against massive opposition - legislation abolishing the price controls that used to be imposed on just about everything.

I have a dim memory of the old Marmite jars with the prices stamped on the lid by the manufacturers: one shilling and sixpence for a small jar; two and ninepence for the next size up; four and sixpence for a large one (that's 7.5p, 14p and 22.5p to the under-40s). Heaven help a shop that sold them for a penny less. All was swept away - an essential precursor to the growth of supermarkets - except in the book trade, where change took another three decades.

It was held off because people in the industry were terrified that small booksellers would be decimated and this was said to be A Bad Thing. Indeed, they have been decimated, but only in the old-fashioned literal sense of the word: the loss of 10%. As Tim Godfray of the Booksellers Association agrees: "Armageddon didn't occur."

The resilience of the British book industry is quite astonishing: 110,155 books published last year, more than in the US, China or anywhere; a million books in print; 35,000 publishers from the Murdochian to the minute. The total number of shops has actually declined far less than 10% - more like 4% and, because they are bigger, more space is devoted to bookselling than ever before. Of those 110,155, a reasonably assiduous reader might get round to reading 0.02% of them.

Round our way we used to have one bookshop: independent all right, but tiny, tucked away and with an owner who was a bit of a grump. He closed down not because price control disappeared but because Waterstone's was moving in to pole position, opposite McDonald's.

They sold a few books cheaply, but that was a detail. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable, the shop opened late, it supported local authors, and it was about 10 times more likely that something would actually be in stock.

This column is quite capable of getting maudlin about the closure of any local institution, from a cattle market to a pub. But this change seems all gain to me and I haven't heard any of the local literati complaining either, though one or two have fantasised about the idea of a branch of Borders, which also sells magazines, CDs and cups of coffee.

There are lovely independent booksellers and I hope they all survive and thrive. But they do have to provide a service that the chains can't or won't, either by finding a specialist niche (like Sportspages or Politico's), setting up in places where the big boys would never go, or providing a brilliant service or ambience.

Still there seems nowhere in Britain to match the City Lights in San Francisco, a place so cool and enticing that no warm-blooded and literate human could emerge without buying at least one work on something like The Influence of Logical Posi tivism on Film Noir in Anatolia, which you will read assiduously until at least page four.

Quite clearly, though, 90% of British shops have done this well enough over the past five years to get through the end of price control, the expansion of the chains and the arrival of the internet. You used to wait six months if you wanted something just published in the US; now you can do it from your desk in about a fortnight.

The shops have also survived a new attitude among publishers. Book-lovers are like animal-lovers, venerating the objects of their affection which must never be defiled. I swear I know people who not merely would never dream of writing in a book but are reluctant to spoil one by actually reading it. Publishers, in contrast, have become increasingly like farmers. Books are units of production, to be dispatched if necessary to the pulping abattoir or the remainder-shop knacker's yard if the milk yield is unsatisfactory.

So I grieve for most of the 10% of shops that have gone. But we were told that the book was about to disappear, not just the shops. Nothing of the kind. Just for once, there may be more to celebrate than to mourn.

matthewengel@ndirect

webTitle: In brief: Clooney turns safecracker in new comedy

fields.headline: Clooney turns safecracker in new comedy
fields.standfirst: Plus: School shootings delay O's release again; Paul Whitehouse in Fast Show film fantasy; Philip Seymour Hoffman and Minnie Driver team up; Erika Christensen joins Hawn and Sarandon in groupie comedy
fields.trailText: Plus: School shootings delay O's release again; Paul Whitehouse in Fast Show film fantasy; Philip Seymour Hoffman and Minnie Driver team up; Erika Christensen joins Hawn and Sarandon in groupie comedy
fields.body:
 George Clooney will appear in the comedy Welcome to Collinwood, a Full Monty-type comedy in which he will play a safecracker involved in a pawn shop robbery. Clooney and Steven Soderbergh, who has directed him in Out of Sight and the forthcoming Ocean's Eleven, will produce Collinwood through their own company.

 Yesterday's high school shootings in San Diego, California, may further postpone the release of the blighted Othello adaptation, O, directed by Tim Blake Nelson, and starring Josh Hartnett and Martin Sheen. The film, completed in summer 1999, transfers Shakespeare's original play to a college setting, and ends in bloody tragedy. Its release was first delayed by the Columbine shootings in 1999 and a year later, producers pulled the film when US presidential candidates targeted movie violence. Miramax and Dimension Films latest release date, April 27, now looks equally threatened. Says Dimension publicist Elizabeth Clark: "We are not commenting on the release of the film, given the unfortunate incident that occurred [yesterday] in San Diego. What happened there is a very serious issue. The release of our movie is minor in comparison."

 Fast Show creator Paul Whitehouse says he would like to make a film involving the sketch show's characters. "I quite miss the Fast Show characters," he is quoted on ananova. "I know it sounds very poncy, but we regarded them with a lot of affection. It would be nice to make a film for the joy of doing it. Whether it's a Fast Show film or it involves any of the Fast Show characters, I don't know, but I'd like to use some of the actors." Whitehouse's former collaborator, Harry Enfield, recently made the leap to the big screen with Kevin and Perry Go Large, which was released in cinemas last year.

 Minnie Driver will star with Philip Seymour Hoffman in Owning Molony. The film, about a bank manager addicted to gambling who is given access to a $20m (£13.65m) account, is the first feature from British director Richard Kwietniowski since 1997's Love and Death on Long Island.

 Erika Christensen, Michael Douglas' drug-addicted daughter in Traffic, will take a lead role in Fox's The Banger Sisters. Susan Sarandon and Goldie Hawn co-star as former 1970s rock 'n' roll groupies who meet up thirty years later to discover that one (Hawn) remains wild and the other has gone square.

fields.headline: Joshua picks up Handbag
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Women's portal Handbag.com has chosen advertising agency Joshua after a three-way pitch, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Handbag.com, the women's portal owned by Boots and The Telegraph's new media arm, has chosen advertising agency Joshua after a three-way pitch.

Joshua, a subsidiary of Grey Communications, will create new advertising for the brand, which launched at the end of 1999.

The company, which has an advertising budget of around £1.5m, last year ran a multimillion pound national TV campaign through J Walter Thompson.

"Handbag.com already has a high level of awareness and was looking for a dynamic agency that would maintain this, help develop strong customer relationships and create integrated campaigns to attract new handbag.com users," said Alicen Stenner, marketing director of Handbag.com.

"We were impressed with Joshua's experience of through-the-line advertising and planning skills. We are looking forward to working with Joshua and building on handbag.com's success."

Handbag.com was the first major women's portal to launch in the UK, but the market has since become highly competitive.

Rivals include Associated Newspapers' Femail.co.uk, Beme.com and iVillage.co.uk, a joint venture between Tesco and the US's iVillage.com.

Ivan Palmer, executive partner at Joshua, will run the strategic planning and the account team will be headed by Michael Miley.

fields.headline: Gordon Brown profiled
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: The budget 2001
fields.trailText: Known as the "iron chancellor", Gordon Brown possesses the evangelical sincerity of a Scottish puritan and at times resembles a latter-day John Knox.  He became notorious during Labour's first two years in office for sticking to Conservative spending plans. Since then he has opened the government's purse strings a little while developing vast budget surpluses and spreading a little joy.
fields.body:
Known as the "iron chancellor", Gordon Brown possesses the evangelical sincerity of a Scottish puritan and at times resembles a latter-day John Knox. He became notorious during Labour's first two years in office for sticking to Conservative spending plans. Since then he has opened the government's purse strings a little while developing vast budget surpluses and spreading a little joy.

He has retained his gloomy, brooding dominance, stomping about the Treasury while shaping the nation's finances, planning his party's election strategy and plotting - perhaps - his eventual acquisition of the highest political job of all.

Mr Brown learned his oratorical mixture of Presbyterian doom and self-satisfied righteousness at the feet of his Labour-voting father, a Church of Scotland minister, who descended from Dunfermline farm labourers. At the age of 12 he volunteered to canvas against Sir Alec Douglas-Home at the 1963 Kinross and West Perthshire byelection.

His ambition was evident from the time he reached Edinburgh University, where he chaired its Labour club and became only the second student to win election as rector of its student court. By 1977, at 26, he was elected to Labour's Scottish executive and in 1983 he was elected to super-safe Dunfermline East. In the Commons he came of age in 1988 when, in the absence of John Smith, he made mincemeat of the then chancellor, Nigel Lawson.

His increasing commitment to politics suppressed his other interests, including rugby. As a schoolboy he lost the use of his left eye during a game - blighting his hope of becoming a professional footballer.

Until his 2000 marriage to public relations executive Sarah Jane Macaulay, his workaholic tendencies had hindered romance although his previous girlfriends included Sheena Macdonald, Marion Calder and Princess Margarita, the eldest daughter of exiled King Michael of Romania. She said: "It was a very solid and romantic story. I never stopped loving him but one day it didn't seem right any more, it was politics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing."

At Labour's Brighton conference in September 2000 it became clear he is a scrooge-Santa, one who can only be "generous" in a way he dictates. Only the poorest and next-poorest pensioners can benefit from increases, says Mr Brown. Pensions cannot be linked to national income because he dislikes giving to the one-sixth of pensioners already receiving more than £20,000 annually.

His unbending belief in his own judgement has been placed under enormous pressure - as in September 2000 when he was publicly attacked by Barbara Castle MP, John Edmonds from the GMB and Rodney Bickerstaffe of Unison after he defied the wishes of the majority of Britain's 11m pensioners.

But Mr Brown's frugality has also helped him gain a praetorian guard of admirers, led by close adviser Ed Balls. These, plus the fine-tuned treasury machine, keep him in touch with complex world financial movements, helping him to avoid blunders like that of August 1992. Then, in opposition, he resisted all efforts by Labour colleagues to advocate lowering the alignment of sterling in the ERM, only to see Britain ignominiously expelled.

He can win favour as the "red chancellor" with brilliant, tongue-chewing, Tory-baiting speeches that, more often than not, manage to hit opponents in the solar plexus while also amusing his own side.

His classic hit in 1991 was sneering at the Tory finances as dependent on "a Greek millionaire moving his money out of [Greek] colonels into Majors". John Major was so upset by this baiting that he tagged him "a specialist in personal abuse."

For his career to move up another notch he must manoeuvre successfully to win allies among the rival fiefdoms which make up the Labour cabinet. He was very accomplished in building such links until Tony Blair slowly twigged that he was surrounded by Brownite allies and neutered Nick Brown, one of the chancellor's major supporters, by moving him from chief whip to agriculture minister in the 1998 reshuffle.

But Mr Brown still has Alistair Darling at social security, Clare Short at international development and Andrew Smith backing him up as chief secretary.

The biggest longterm battle that he faces concerns the euro. Although at heart a pro-European, Mr Brown was the first disciple to become ultra-cautious about the timing of joining the euro. This has since been justified by the currency's tumbling value and its rejection by the Danes. He imposed his caution on the Blair government through a typically devious manoeuvre, spelled out in Andrew Rawnsley's book, "Servants of the People."

In October 1997 Mr Brown encouraged Philip Webster, political editor of the Times, to run a story which said he did not want to enter the euro for the lifetime of the 1997 parliament, having only discussed it cursorily with the PM for five minutes. This stunt, foghorned by his spokesman Charlie Whelan down a mobile phone in a pub, was designed to outflank Mr Blair, Peter Mandelson, and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary - are all advocates of entering the euro.

Mr Brown reserves special hatred for Mr Mandelson, who switched horses from Brown to Blair in the 1994 Labour leadership campaign, following John Smith's death. Mr Mandelson, quite accurately, judged Mr Blair was more likely to radically change the party. Faced with this betrayal, Mr Brown reluctantly agreed to give Mr Blair a free run for leader, provided he was offered shadow chancellor and chancellor.

But his ambition for the top job has never waned. With Mr Mandelson now in exile on the backbenches, Mr Brown has the opportunity to gain more allies by running a good election campaign. He will use this as a platform to build a warmer relationship with the public and party staff. If he is able to secure support for his longterm succession in the country and in Millbank then he will be on his way to capturing the job he wants.

Then he'll be able to move from No 11 Downing Street to his dream house - No 10.

fields.headline: Crossroads opens doors to 2m
fields.trailText:
11.45am TV ratings: Crossroads was one of the most talked about comebacks in TV history, but just 2m viewers were there to witness it. By Jason Deans.
Mar 6: Crossroads in steamy comeback
fields.body:
It was one of the most talked about comebacks in television history. But in the end just 2m viewers were there to witness the return of Crossroads.

According to overnight ratings, the show nevertheless was watched by one in three viewers who had switched on the TV yesterday lunchtime.

But it could be some time until it is indelibly etched into the nation's consciousness.

While ITV declared the ratings a success - it was the best audience for its slot in the year so far- the continuing crisis over foot and mouth and teenage angst in Australia was still more interesting to viewers.

The BBC1 regional news had 3.2m and Neighbours notched up 2.6m, according to unofficial overnights.

Crossroads made its comeback at 1.30pm yesterday, against the 15-minute BBC1 regional news bulletin and the first quarter-hour of the Aussie soap.

The 5.05pm repeat pulled in a bigger audience, but a lower share of viewing at that time. It took 3m and a 22% share.

At 1.30pm ITV has averaged 1.4m and a 19% share so far in 2001; while in the early evening slot - where ratings flop Public Property has played for six weeks - the average is 1.9m and a 14% share.

Crossroads was brought back to replace Home and Away, which was poached by Channel 5 last year.

The final ITV episode of the Aussie soap last June had 2m at lunchtime and 4.3m for its teatime repeat.

ITV director of programmes David Liddiment controversially pulled Home and Away early from the schedules to prevent Channel 5 inheriting ITV's audience for the show.

fields.headline: Election coverage overhaul shelved
fields.trailText: 11.45am: TV news chiefs have decided not to follow up plans to change the rules on election coverage, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC and ITV news chiefs have decided not to follow up tentative plans to overhaul the rules on election coverage.

The changes were mooted in response to the American TV networks' disastrous coverage of the US election.

Calls for UK broadcasters to pool exit poll operations - or to abandon the use of exit polls altogether - were issued after last year's Newsworld conference in Barcelona.

But the calls have been largely ignored in new producer guidelines issued by the BBC.

After the conference, Peter Horrocks, head of BBC current affairs, and Steve Anderson, ITV controller of news and current affairs, agreed to discuss new strategies to minimise the risk of inaccurate poll results.

Mr Horrocks told journalists a pooled operation would be the best strategy, while Mr Anderson opted for abandoning exit polls altogether.

But new BBC guidelines do not require any change to the way BBC journalists and producers use opinion polls.

"The feeling is producer guidelines are sufficiently well-designed not to need changing," said a BBC spokesman.

The guidelines advise journalists to be careful when using polls, pointing out that they "can be wrong".

They suggest journalists avoid using language that gives polls "greater credibility than they deserve".

But the guidelines have not been overhauled since the last general election.

They do, however, offer producers new advice on devolution and the use of the internet in elections.

Network programmes are asked to give "a fair proportion" of items to stories affecting the Scottish Nationalist party and Plaid Cymru, if they have "distinctive" policies.

fields.headline: United Ireland or bust
fields.standfirst:
Republican violence will always be with us, says Henry McDonald, Ireland editor, the Observer

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Republican violence will always be with us, says Henry McDonald, Ireland editor, the Observer.
fields.body:
The argument that says if politics works in Northern Ireland, that if the Good Friday Agreement is fully implemented and if the power-sharing Executive in Belfast is fully functioning, freed from the unionist demands for IRA decommissioning, then there will be no constituency for Real and Continuity IRA terrorism to thrive, is absolute nonsense.

Let us assume the benign scenario where the Agreement operates in all its forms, David Trimble has lifted his ban on Sinn Fein ministers attending cross-border ministerial meetings, the Ulster Unionists have dropped their decommissioning demands and there is sweetness and light around the cabinet table at Stormont.

Of course everyone who supports historic compromise in Northern Ireland believes this scenario to be the only way forward, but there are some people in the Province and across the border in the Republic who don't. The simple truth about violent republicanism is this: if the Stormont deal was working fully this would be even more reason for the CIRA and RIRA to wreck it.

A small core of young nationalists brought up on a diet of anti-British and anti-Unionist mythology, who were perhaps barely in their teens during the first Drumcree disturbances when they probably got their first taste of street violence, are hardly likely to care about North/South ministerial councils or the atmosphere between Martin McGuinness and David Trimble in cabinet.

People join organisations like the CIRA and RIRA solely and simply because they want a United Ireland or something even more unattainable, a unitary democratic socialist state.

Take for example the four young men who attempted to place firebombs in the west end of London three years ago. All of them came from south of the border, had no direct experience of security force harassment or past unionist discrimination. These third level students, many of who had bright career prospects in the Celtic Tiger economy, didn't join up because "politics wasn't working", they volunteered because they believed passionately in a United Ireland.

As Conservatives used to say about the poor, the recalcitrant core of violent republicans will always be with us, probably even beyond the day Ireland is united North and South through the slow, painful fusion of economics, culture and demography.

Just as the full implementation of the Oslo peace accord would never have satisfied maximalist terror groups like Hamas or Islamic Jihad, so the Belfast Agreement will never blunt the desire among a violent but growing minority for Brits out and a United Ireland or nothing.

To argue otherwise is to be deliberately naive and ignore centuries of republican opposition to Britain's presence in Ireland.

Conversely, the notion that decommissioning is irrelevant is equally absurd, more so in the Irish Republic than Northern Ireland. The clamour for decommissioning will become louder south of the border if and when Sinn Fein holds the balance of power in the Dail.

Both the Irish police, the gardai and the Irish Defence Forces, have made it clear it could not serve a coalition government in which one of the minority partners swore allegiances to two different opposing "armies of Ireland".

Sinn Fein, like Fianna Fail before them, will have to make a choice between recognising the sole legitimacy of the IDF or continuing to believe the IRA is the army of the republic. To those who say decommissioning doesn't matter keep an eye on Dublin and see what happens.

fields.headline: Rebels flee Macedonian flashpoint
fields.standfirst:
Peacekeepers monitoring clashes say ethnic Albanian fighters have left border village

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanian gunmen who clashed with Macedonian soldiers for a second day running yesterday appear to have withdrawn from a flashpoint border village in northern Macedonia.
fields.body:
Ethnic Albanian gunmen who clashed with Macedonian soldiers for a second day running yesterday appear to have withdrawn from a flashpoint border village in northern Macedonia.

US peacekeepers monitoring the clashes said the gunmen were seen leaving the village of Tanusevci, dumping their uniforms and weapons as they left, after exchanging fire with Macedonian troops.

The gunmen headed towards the border with Kosovo but stopped short of the US peacekeeping troops there who have reinforced their positions and say they will detain anyone who tries to cross.

Jim Marshal, spokesman for the US-led contingent of peacekeepers based in Kosovo, a division of K-For, said there had been between 70 and 150 gunmen in the village, but he could not say how many remained. He said the rebels had been armed with machine guns and grenade launchers, and possibly had a weapons cache inside Kosovo.

On Sunday, three Macedon ian soldiers were killed during fighting that flared in the mountain-top village. One was killed by a sniper, the others died when their vehicle hit a landmine.

Macedonia insists it has limited the fighting to a handful of villages surrounding Tanusevci, 20 miles north of the capital, Skopje. Fears remain, however, that the fighting could spread to other parts of the country. As a precaution, the government has fully mobilised its reserve police forces and partially mobilised those serving as reserves in the army.

A government police spokesman said that the rebel Albanian gunmen were operating throughout a wider area than just Tanusevci.

"Yes, there are some terrorists operating in the forests around Tanusevci," the spokesman said. "We cannot rule out the possibility that other attacks may happen in that area."

Macedonian army chiefs were in talks overnight with Nato on how to flush out the gunmen.

Western officials had earlier urged Macedonia not to use force to end the crisis, but on Sunday they abruptly changed their tune, saying they would now understand if it did so.

The Macedonian prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, has been scornful of what officials from his country say is the failure of Nato-led peacekeepers in Kosovo to control the ethnic Albanian guerrillas.

"They are too scared that some of their soldiers might get killed," Mr Georgievski said recently.

The Albanian militants near the border, the self-styled "National Liberation Army" (NLA), have yet to officially state their demands, or the reason for their rebellion.

Ethnic Albanians in Macedonia, however, have demanded on several occasions since the former Yugoslav republic gained independence peacefully in 1991 that they be granted more rights.

The NLA is also believed to have ties with ethnic Albanian rebels fighting against Yugoslav forces in the Presevo valley of southern Serbia, about seven miles to the north-east.

Rising tension in both areas have raised the prospect of another major crisis in Kosovo less than two years after Nato and the UN moved in to police the province.

Both rebel movements are thought to be receiving continual aid from Kosovo Albanians. In Skopje, the foreign minister, Srdjan Kerim, yesterday urged Kosovo's ethnic Albanian leaders to meet him for "talks on how to overcome the crisis in a way acceptable to all".

fields.headline: Guerrillas threaten Balkan stability
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato, the EU and Balkan states are engaged in an intense round of diplomatic activity to prevent fighting between ethnic Albanians and Macedonian troops developing into a serious crisis that could threaten the entire region.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and  Ian Traynor  in Moscow
fields.body:
Nato, the EU and Balkan states are engaged in an intense round of diplomatic activity to prevent fighting between ethnic Albanians and Macedonian troops developing into a serious crisis that could threaten the entire region.

In Britain and other EU countries, diplomats said they had delivered tough warnings to Albanian leaders in Kosovo, as well as to Pristina itself, about the consequences of continuing attacks by ethnic Albanian insurgents in Macedonia and southern Serbia.

The diplomatic moves came as Macedonian troops clashed with ethnic Albanian rebels for the second day running in mountains close to the Kosovo border. US peacekeepers sent in reinforcements to the border village of Debelde, and two US Apache helicopters and a spy plane tracked the fighting.

The aims of the militant Albanian fighters in Macedonia remain unclear. The country's ethnic Albanian community makes up about a quarter of its 2m population.

The Macedonian prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, yesterday held talks with his Bulgarian, Greek and Albanian counterparts and then criticised Nato troops in Kosovo for their "indolent treatment of the crisis".

Bulgaria said it saw no immediate need to send troops to help defend neighbouring Macedonia, despite a suggestion from Bulgaria's president, Petar Stoyanov, that such a move would be considered.

"Stoyanov declared moral and political support for the Macedonian government but this should not be interpreted as an official proposal for sending troops to Macedonia," the Bulgarian defence minister, Boiko Noev, said.

In Moscow, President Vladimir Putin called Kosovo a hotbed of terrorists and said Nato-led peacekeepers were helpless to prevent ethnic Albanian extremists exploiting a power vacuum.

Nato has sent a joint military and political mission to Skopje, the Macedonian capital, but Nato-led K-For peacekeeping troops in Kosovo have no mandate in Macedonia.

However, after calls from the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, to the Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson, the organisation said it was stepping up patrols on the Kosovo side of the border. "We want a political solution and not resort to military means," a Nato spokeswoman said.

The Kremlin blamed the west for the worsening situation. "We warned that this would happen," Mr Putin declared, following a telephone conversation with the Macedonian president.

Mr Putin said Albanian extremists were flourishing in the Nato-patrolled buffer zone between Serbia and Kosovo because the Yugoslav army had been compelled to withdraw from the area.

A Greek foreign ministry spokesman said yesterday that the spread of ethnic Albanian unrest to Macedonia stems from the "selective implementation" of UN-mandated pledges to disarm separatists.

Macedonia has asked for an urgent meeting of the UN security council to approve a three-mile buffer zone inside Kosovo on the Macedonian border in which K-For would strictly control any movement of people and supplies.

Nato, meanwhile, is engaged in talks with Belgrade over preventing Albanian insurgents entering the buffer zone between Kosovo and southern Serbia, where there is a significant Albanian population.

The insurgents have been active in particular in the Presevo valley region, where the situation is further aggravated by arguments over who should protect the border.

France has suggested that unarmed EU observers in the valley should be protected by EU rather than K-For troops - a move that could be interpreted as a first test for the proposed new EU rapid reaction force.

fields.headline: Bomber 'involved in road rage incident'
fields.standfirst:
Police appeal for witnesses as terror hunt intensifies

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The terrorist who drove a car bomb to the BBC on Saturday night may have been involved in a "road rage" incident shortly before he abandoned the vehicle.
fields.body:
The terrorist who drove a car bomb to the BBC on Saturday night may have been involved in a "road rage" incident shortly before he abandoned the vehicle.

Deputy assistant commissioner Alan Fry, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, said yestereday a witness had come forward to describe a row he had had with the driver of a red and black cab in Scrubs Lane, Shepherd's Bush, close to the BBC television centre in west London.

"The witness was cut up by a red cab. It is relevant because it was just before the cab was parked up in Wood Lane."

Police believe the cab which contained the bomb was bought by a man with an Irish accent at 9.30am on Saturday. It was sold by Alan Flockhart outside a breaker's yard in Edmonton, north London.

"Mr Flockhart was not a regular second-hand car dealer," said Mr Fry. "It was by chance that he put a for sale notice in the window of the cab."

Mr Fry appealed for owners of lock-ups or garages who may have rented them or returned to find unusual debris to contact police.

"We have a gap of 13 to 14 hours from when the cab was bought to when the bomb exploded in which the cab was clearly loaded with explosives."

Amid growing fears that the impasse in the peace process will not be resolved before the general election, Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, are to chair round-table talks in Belfast later this week.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, said the talks, which will involve the pro-agreement parties, were pencilled in long before the attack on the BBC by dissident Real IRA bombers.

He said Mr Blair had been concerned by the deadlock in the peace proces and added: "The prime minister has always felt the peace process doesn't stand still, it moves forwards or backwards. We have to find the momentum to get it moving forward again."

The talks in Belfast will concentrate on the three areas which are stalling the peace process - reform of the police, IRA disarmament, and the scaling down of security measures in the province.

There is speculation that the political process may have to be placed into a formal review, which would allow the power-sharing executive to remain in place, in the hope of engineering a soft landing.

Mr Campbell said Mr Blair believed Northern Ireland's political leaders had reached the "point where you have to make people face up to the realities". He added: "The prime minister is taking the view the peace process is in a difficult state and the leadership has to be found to try to move forward."

fields.headline: Mugabe men beat up Tatchell
fields.standfirst:
Second attempt at 'citizen's arrest' ends in assault at hotel

Audio: Andrew Osborn in Brussels
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The gay and human rights campaigner Peter Tatchell was savagely beaten by bodyguards protecting President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe as he tried to make a citizen's arrest yesterday of the African leader during an official visit to meet a senior European Union commissioner.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and  Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
The gay and human rights campaigner Peter Tatchell was savagely beaten by bodyguards protecting President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe as he tried to make a citizen's arrest yesterday of the African leader during an official visit to meet a senior European Union commissioner.

As Mr Tatchell attempted his citizen's arrest he was repulsed forcefully and left lying semi-conscious in the gutter after receiving at least three blows to the head.

In the lobby of the Hilton hotel in Brussels, Mr Tatchell managed to push past several of Mr Mugabe's burly minders and demanded that the African leader be arrested under the 1984 UN Convention against torture but was swiftly bundled into a corner.

After the attack, a dazed Mr Tatchell, who attempted a similar citizen's arrest of Mr Mugabe in London in October 1999, claimed that one of the bodyguards had issued him with a death threat saying: "We will find you and kill you."

"People who I believe were President Mugabe's agents attacked me and punched me around the face even though I was no physical threat to Mr Mugabe," said Mr Tatchell, his nose bloodied and his face bruised.

"The Belgian police allowed the Zimbabwean agents to have a free go and to beat me with impunity and yet President Mugabe is complicit in the use of torture which is a crime under international and Belgian law."

Mr Tatchell suspects Mr Mugabe ordered the torture of two Zimbabwean journalists.

Moments before the attack Mr Mugabe had finished off a lunch of smoked salmon and chicken with wild mushrooms in the company of the EU's development commissioner, Poul Nielson, who has been severely criticised by Zimbabwe's democratic opposition for agreeing to meet Mr Mugabe at all.

For one bizarre moment Mr Mugabe and his large en tourage were trapped in the revolving door of the Hilton as they hastened to beat a retreat from Mr Tatchell's approach, allowing him to exit the hotel by a different door and attempt a second "arrest".

But the campaigner was viciously beaten by a man who refused to identify himself but who later got into one of Mr Mugabe's limousines and left Mr Tatchell lying in the gutter almost under the wheels of one of the waiting BMWs.

Mr Mugabe laughed and joked with one of his minders in the back of his limousine as Mr Tatchell was beaten.

Mr Nielson later claimed he was unaware of the incident but said he was unrepentant about lunching with Mr Mugabe, who stands accused of orchestrating a campaign of violence and intimidation against the Zimbabwean media, judiciary and white farmers. "I think it's a big mistake not to listen to what he has to say. It's not a government we are relating to, it's a nation," Mr Nielson argued, adding that Mr Mugabe had agreed to enter into a critical dialogue with the EU.

He later told the European Parliament, however, that if Mr Mugabe did not act soon the EU would consider suspending its £6m a year aid programme to Harare.

Tory MEP Nirj Deva was one of several deputies to subject Mr Nielson to hostile questioning. "He (Mugabe) has to be told there is a line in the sand across which he cannot walk. Would you have discussed matters with Stalin and Hitler?" he asked the Dane.

Morgan Tsvangirai, the main opposition leader in Zimbabwe, also condemned the meeting. "I think it is a slap in the face for Zimbabweans," he told BBC Radio 4. "To me and the majority of Zimbabweans that is endorsing and condoning his actions."

Mr Mugabe later held talks with Belgium's prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, discussing the nascent peace process in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a former Belgian colony, where Zimbabwean troops are stationed.

Mr Mugabe is due in France today where he will meet President Jacques Chirac.

webTitle: Calls for change in housing design

fields.headline: Calls for change in housing design
fields.trailText: Charity Age Concern has called on councils and housing associations to design homes that meet the cultural needs of older people from ethnic minorities to stop them being isolated from their families and communities.
fields.body:
Charity Age Concern has called on councils and housing associations to design homes that meet the cultural needs of older people from ethnic minorities to stop them being isolated from their families and communities.

The recommendation followed a housing survey by the charity that found many older people from ethnic minorities wanted to live with their extended families. As a result, many lived in overcrowded accommodation - designed for white people who preferred to live near relatives rather with them.

The survey of more than 300 older people in 35 local authorities across England found that 74% of Bangladeshi and 66% of Pakistani householders said they preferred to live with their family compared with 11% of white and Irish respondents.

It also found that 78% of Bangladeshi households had between eight and 10 people living in 2-3 bedrooms, while 55% of Pakistani respondents lived with at least five other people. This was the main group of people who were unhappy about poor heating and lacked information about housing support.

The survey, When a house is not a home - older people and their housing, recommended that housing providers should consult with ethnic minorities when planning the development of new homes or upgrading existing stock.

The report said housing providers needed to recognise the religious backgrounds of ethnic groups, as many respondents wanted to live near a place of worship. For example, 96% of Bangladeshis, 76% of Pakistanis and 86% of black Caribbeans said they wanted to live near a church or mosque. However, many interviewees lived far from their community and said this increased their feelings of isolation and depression.

Stephen Boyo, national housing policy officer for Age Concern, said that culturally sensitive housing was only available through a few specialist agencies.

"All local housing strategies need to ensure that ethnic minorities are consulted about the design of their accommodation, so they can provide 'multi-generational homes' to those who want to live with their families," he said.

But Harris Beider, executive director of the Federation of Black Housing Organisation said housing provision should not be based entirely around the traditional stereotype of extended families caring for older people.

"Black and ethnic minority communities have become fractured," he explained. "Specialist sheltered housing should be developed for those who want it but the emphasis should be on ensuring that older people are not placed next to the racists who confronted them when they first came to this country.

"Housing associations need to educate and challenge elderly white people, while staff in sheltered housing schemes must have an awareness of race and cultural issues in line with the Macpherson report."

Hornsey housing trust in north London has set up a 27-bed multi-cultural residential scheme called Abyssinia for older people, which caters for each ethnic groups' dietary needs and celebrates their different faiths.

Housing manager Tammy Jakachira said: "The scheme managers ensure that residents are respectful of each other's backgrounds. We also have a prayer room with a corner for Catholics, a corner for Muslims, and so on. We celebrate all the major religious festivals and also visit community centres and restaurants. This has broken down barriers between the ethnic groups."

Emily Herman, elderly services manager of Ujima, a black and ethnic minority housing association in London, said ethnic minorities had been in the UK too long to start segregating them now.

She said: "Planners need to focus on the aspirations of black and ethnic minority people coming up to retirement age to meet future housing needs."

It also found that 78% of Bangladeshi households had between eight and 10 people living in 2-3 bedrooms, while 55% of Pakistani respondents lived with at least five other people. This was the main group of people who were unhappy about poor heating and lacked information about housing support. The survey, When a house is not a home - older people and their housing, recommended that housing providers should consult with ethnic minorities when planning the development of new homes or upgrading existing stock. The report said housing providers needed to recognise the religious backgrounds of ethnic groups, as many respondents wanted to live near a place of worship. For example, 96% of Bangladeshis, 76% of Pakistanis and 86% of black Caribbeans said they wanted to live near a church or mosque. However, many interviewees lived far from their community and said this increased their feelings of isolation and depression. Stephen Boyo, national housing policy officer for Age Concern, said that culturally sensitive housing was only available through a few specialist agencies. "All local housing strategies need to ensure that ethnic minorities are consulted about the design of their accommodation, so they can provide 'multi-generational homes' to those who want to live with their families," he said. But Harris Beider, executive director of the Federation of Black Housing Organisation said housing provision should not be based entirely around the traditional stereotype of extended families caring for older people. "Black and ethnic minority communities have become fractured," he explained. "Specialist sheltered housing should be developed for those who want it but the emphasis should be on ensuring that older people are not placed next to the racists who confronted them when they first came to this country. "Housing associations need to educate and challenge elderly white people, while staff in sheltered housing schemes must have an awareness of race and cultural issues in line with the Macpherson report." Hornsey housing trust in north London has set up a 27-bed multi-cultural residential scheme called Abyssinia for older people, which caters for each ethnic groups' dietary needs and celebrates their different faiths. Housing manager Tammy Jakachira said: "The scheme managers ensure that residents are respectful of each other's backgrounds. We also have a prayer room with a corner for Catholics, a corner for Muslims, and so on. We celebrate all the major religious festivals and also visit community centres and restaurants. This has broken down barriers between the ethnic groups." Emily Herman, elderly services manager of Ujima, a black and ethnic minority housing association in London, said ethnic minorities had been in the UK too long to start segregating them now. She said: "Planners need to focus on the aspirations of black and ethnic minority people coming up to retirement age to meet future housing needs."

webTitle: China's PM gives startling report to parliament

fields.headline: China's PM gives startling report to parliament
fields.standfirst: Zhu Rongji outlines '15 widespread problems' in annual speech to delegates in Beijing
fields.trailText: China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, yesterday gave a devastating account of what is still wrong with the country, in a report to the opening session of the annual two-week session of the national people's congress, the parliament.
fields.body:
China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, yesterday gave a devastating account of what is still wrong with the country, in a report to the opening session of the annual two-week session of the national people's congress, the parliament.

He listed 15 widespread problems ranging from the "low overall quality of the national economy" to "an increasing income gap" between rich and poor.

Other problems included growing unemployment, serious corruption, a shortage of water and environmental deterioration.

Mr Zhu said that China's vast countryside was critical to the success of the new five-year plan, promising to tackle farmers' grievances concerning illegal taxes and land-grabbing by local officials.

He warned that China's forthcoming entry to the World Trade Organisation - a goal which he has championed and one for which he has been criticised - would bring new problems at a time when "[economic] reform is in a very difficult period".

"[The report] follows a trend of franker and franker presentation," a European diplomatic observer said afterwards. "Mr Zhu has identified all the problems that he can see. It is really quite startling reading - much franker than many western politicians can be."

Mr Zhu paid dutiful tribute to the "correct" policies of the party and President Jiang Zemin, and to the achievements of the past five years. But he quickly went on to pay his "highest respects" to the people who had made them possible.

"This is the first time that the prime minister has thanked the people," one delegate said. "In the past, the people were supposed to thank the government."

In keeping with a recent Beijing security initiative, Mr Zhu also said there was a need to "expose and condemn" the controversial Falun Gong sect, which has been banned. But the delegates failed to applaud this less-than emphatic statement, perhaps reflecting the mixed feelings about the extreme lengths to which the "anti-cult" campaign has gone.

In an intriguing passage on rural reform, Mr Zhu hinted that a new way must be found to convince peasants that their land will not be confiscated.

He suggested the need to explore a new "land operations rights-transfer system". Land in China is farmed through long-term contracts which can, in practice, be torn up by local officials.

Mr Zhu also emphasised the need to expand employment to cope with the demands of an increasing workforce and the rising number of jobless created by the reform of industries formerly subsidised by the state. He said the social security system, which has failed in many cases to provide a safety net for old age and unemployment, must improve.

With a touch of historical irony, Mr Zhu called for the establishment of a minimum-wage to help the growing number of urban workers who are poorly paid. Wages used to be guaranteed under the grade system of the Mao Zedong era, which is now said to have been too "egalitarian".

In a shift which Chinese economists will welcome, Mr Zhu said that the new five-year plan will contain fewer specific targets and focus more on "key development areas and solving major problems". He did, however, set the annual growth target at "around 7%", and said that the plan should pave the way to double China's GDP by the end of the decade.

The outspoken Mr Zhu has learned during the past three years to single out the areas where he can exert pressure, while steering clear of issues where his hands are tied by vested Communist party interests.

In contrast to last year's report, Mr Zhu did not denounce official corruption at length - only listing it as one of many problems. He also adopted a low-key approach to democratic reform.

webTitle: Walt Disney secures rights to Winnie the Pooh

fields.headline: Walt Disney secures rights to Winnie the Pooh
fields.trailText: The Hollywood studio has paid $350m to secure lasting rights to AA Milne's classic character Winnie the Pooh
fields.body:
A deal believed to be the biggest in British literary history has seen Walt Disney secure lasting rights to AA Milne's classic character Winnie the Pooh. The cartoon makers have spent $350m (£239m) to buy the honey-guzzling bear. Since they first bought the rights to the character in the 1960s, Disney has been paying twice-yearly royalties for the privilege. The new lump sum replaces that obligation, buying Disney rights to Pooh until copyright expires on the bear in 2026.

The profits from the sale will primarily benefit the Royal Literary Fund, which should receive about £90m, while the Garrick Club and Westminster School will gain about £60m each. The descendants of EH Shepard, the books' illustrator, will receive a smaller sum.

However, the widow of Christopher Robin Milne, son of the author and hero of Pooh's original adventures, will not profit by the deal. Before his death five years ago, Lesley Milne and her husband sold half their share in the royalties to the Literary Fund for £150,000, using the other half to set up a trust fund for their daughter. "Christopher was very anti-Disney," Lesley Milne told the Sunday Times this weekend. "He hated what they had done with the books and the characters. Christopher just wasn't interested in money either."

Sales of Pooh products, according to reports, have doubled over the past five years, outstripping the merchandising success even of Disney's home grown favourites, Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck. One Disney spokesperson says: "The bear is even mightier than the mouse."

 More about Winnie the Pooh.
