fields.headline: Pocket rocket
fields.standfirst: The restyled Lotus Elise is fast, noisy and so low-slung that you almost rupture your hamstrings when you get in
fields.trailText: The restyled Lotus Elise is fast, noisy and so low-slung that you almost rupture your hamstrings when you get in
fields.body:
The Lotus Elise is a two-seater sports car for purists. It offers speed, noise and goose- pimpled thrills in a rigorously carpet-free environment. Outside it looks like a car in search of a starting grid. Inside it has all the luxury and refinement of the interior of a filing cabinet.

The steering wheel is so taut that you only have to think about going round a corner and the car twitches. It gets about as close to a racing car as a road car is allowed to. It doesn't actually come with a fire extinguisher bolted between the seats, but you could fit one in there and it would look just fine.

If you're interested in heated front headlamp-washers, electric windows and boot-mounted CD-changers, this may not be your next vehicle. If you're in terested in the way engines smell when under pressure on a hairpin bend (and this is a small but by no means negligible market), then welcome home. Lotus has restyled the Elise - which is the kind of news that leads petrol-heads nationwide into spasms of wincing and leg-crossing. That's not just a car that Lotus are tinkering with there; it's a way of life. You mess with an Elise, and people get upset in the way they do when telephone boxes change.

But there's no major damage done. Some of the soft, rounded aspects of the old model have been swapped for some sharp creases. The old body didn't exactly seem apologetic, but the new one is brash and outgoing, quite muscular at the back and a bit angry-looking. It is also, apparently, 10mm closer to the ground than the old Elise, which might seem negligible. But, given that in the old model you were already virtually flat on your back on the tarmac, the extra 10mm represents a considerable feat of engineering.

It also makes the car just that little bit more difficult to get into, which surely will go down as added value among the sports-car-owning hardcore. Unless a vehicle requires you to rupture at least one hamstring slotting yourself inside, it just isn't trying hard enough, and neither are you. Here, Lotus has come good: the new Elise is definitely a double- hamstring-twanger. And if the Elise is difficult to get into, it's nigh on impossible to get out of. Imagine trying to exit a deep sea diving outfit through the helmet. And with no hamstrings. Heaven knows how one would manage this while drunk. Even sober, the most sensible thing to do might be to take some tools and tunnel out at the back.

Up to now, the Lotus Elise has been out on its own, but these days it doesn't quite have the road to itself and, unusually, it's the company's own fault. When Lotus helped out Vauxhall in the creation of the Vauxhall VX220 (the surprising, angular roadster that Griff Rhys-Jones advertises in his underpants), it's clear they did more than simply pass on a couple of tips. From within, through half-closed eyes and while stationary, the two models could be mistaken for one another. True, the Vauxhall has an exciting, you-too-can-race-at-Le-Mans push-button starter on the dashboard, whereas the Lotus is boring old key-operated. But otherwise, the most noticeable difference is that where the Vauxhall's dashboard is plastic-clad, the dashboard on the Elise I drove was wrapped in black suede, for that authentic, scratch-n-sniff, 1970s student effect.

Inevitably, to elect to have an Elise in the British climate is to choose to be cold a lot of the time. Even with the roof on. But at least the fan keeps the windscreen clear. In the VX220, I spent a lot of time and energy swiping away at the glass with my forearm in a largely unsuccessful attempt to prevent it misting over completely every 10 seconds or so. The Elise has four slatted vents, like miniature Sydney Opera Houses, positioned neatly under the glass, with which you can wage effective war on the fug which predictably builds up when your nose is only three or so centimetres away from the windscreen and the temperature outside is close to freezing.

The disappointing thing about the VX220 is how inoffensive the engine sounds. By contrast, the engine in the Elise (a 1.8 litre K-series, as in the previous model, but retuned) throbs like a powerboat at a standstill and very rapidly reaches offensiveness under acceleration - which must be at least half the point of owning a car like this.

The two cars cost exactly the same, but one comes with a Lotus symbol on it and the other comes with a Vauxhall symbol - and, more than that, a Vauxhall nose, with its chrome V, as seen on Astras and Cavaliers. For some buyers, the choice will come down to which badge they prefer on their key-fob: the Lotus one, with its charismatic oily whiff of British motor sport history; or the Vauxhall one, with its charismatic oily whiff of sales rep. Which, on reflection, may prove to be no choice at all.

fields.headline: Armani outlines his curvy phase
fields.trailText: In the leopard print and diamante world that is Milan fashion, Giorgio Armani is an unlikely ruler. But his is an inescapable presence in this city.
fields.body:
In the leopard print and diamante world that is Milan fashion, Giorgio Armani is an unlikely ruler. But from the giant adverts that line the airports to the football stadium-sized Armani superstore, slap bang in the centre of the shopping district, his is an inescapable presence in this city.

Of course, it would hardly befit such a figure to present his collections in the city's municipal venues. Instead Armani has a private catwalk theatre, hidden in the basement of his elegant palazzo.

The look for the designer's upscale Giorgio Armani autumn/winter range yesterday was floor-length and dramatically full-skirted. Particularly striking were coats in velvet or tuxedo-style satin, slim at the shoulders and waist but structured to billow out at the hem.

There was lots of movement in this collection: giant sequins swung from a breezy double-layered camisole; trousers had ra-ra style layers, one finishing at the ankle, another mid-calf, another at the knee. In sheer tulle, these were much softer and more elegant than they sound.

Armani is famed for his softly tailored trousersuits, and there were plenty of good examples here. Soft knitted cardigan-jackets came in palest eau-de-nil wool, while crepe jackets featured curving, petal-shaped hems and loop-and-button fastenings.

Known for a somewhat androgynous style, Armani is nonetheless going through a curvy phase: after the glittery bras shown at the cheaper Emporio Armani show at the weekend, yesterday's show focused on waisted shapes.

Eveningwear had a balletic theme. Tulle was layered over sequinned petticoats, giving soft glimmer rather than flashbulb-popping shine. Dresses featured simple leotard-smooth scoop-necked torsos, but frothed outwards from the waist.

The bulk this creates around the hips is not the easiest silhouette to carry off, and the effect was sometimes more waddling cygnet than Odette/Odile. But knitted camisoles, similar to dancers' warm-up wraps, worn with flowing silk skirts, delivered Armani ease and glamour with aplomb.

fields.headline: Comeback Kidd
fields.standfirst: Two years ago she was underweight, jaded and rather full of herself. But a break from modelling has left Jodie Kidd two stone heavier and a great deal happier, finds Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.trailText: Two years ago she was underweight, jaded and rather full of herself. But a break from modelling has left Jodie Kidd two stone heavier and a great deal happier, finds Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.body:
Jodie Kidd is wearing a short platinum blonde wig, the fringe cut at a rakish angle. A make-up artist hovers with green eyeshadow and long, feathery false eyelashes. She looks a little overdone for noon. But then we are backstage at a fashion show and in half an hour Kidd will be stepping into a sequinned dress and high heels and taking her turn on the catwalk. She looks like something out of Bladerunner, she says.

Oddly, neither the hairdresser nor his assistant have seen Bladerunner or, indeed, even heard of it, so this line of conversation isn't going anywhere, but she is right.

Even without the wig and false eye lashes, Kidd has an almost sci-fi kind of beauty: with her preternaturally huge, almond-shaped, green-grey eyes; a wide, perfect mouth; and those extraordinary cheekbones.

Kidd became famous for being thin, which is, she agrees, an odd thing to become famous for. She also became famous for being posh - very posh: polo-playing, hanging-out-with-royalty, country-house posh - but it was mainly the thin thing. She is still thin but no longer gaunt. In fact, her body is quite different to the days when her knobbly knees and sunken cheeks made the front pages. At 22, she has put on two stones to fill a size 10, occasionally a 12. She is beautiful now: lanky, yes, but peachy too.

Meeting Kidd, it strikes you that the public furore over her weight was vicious. "I was never remotely anorexic: it's the stupidest thing I've ever heard. My family are all skinny. I was 14 when I started modelling, and I was 6ft 1in. People hated me for it, and that was scary."

She has often spoken of hearing the daytime television presenter Lorraine Kelly, whom she had never met, call her a "sick, anorexic giraffe" on air. It would be fairer to blame the designers, Kidd says. "By the end, I wasn't enjoying modelling, but designers were still ringing me up and persuading me."

Two years ago, she decided it was time to take a break. "I was too thin, but I was also getting really sour, really jaded. I was earning all this money and getting flown first-class and I thought I was the bees' knees." During her time out from the fashion world, her figure developed. "I didn't do it deliberately, I just grew up. I got boobs. My sister had always said to me that the second I hit 20 I would round out as she had. It's hard for me to put on weight but I was spending more time in the countryside, doing lots of riding, and I put on muscle."

Kidd returned to the catwalk last year with a new mindset. "I look much better now, and I know it. Before, I thought everyone hated me when they looked at me. I really enjoy the catwalk now. I've got that excitement back, the butterflies back."

As a catwalk model, Kidd has metamorphosed from a loping, bony teenager to one of the best in the business: while many models wander, zombie-like, along the runway with the enthusiasm of schoolgirls trudging to the bus stop on a Monday morning, Kidd loves to vamp it up for the cameras. "Of course it's just modelling, but I do think if you try a bit harder, give a bit more, it does show. There are girls who have beautiful faces but don't give."

Kidd has not managed to steer clear of controversy over body image since her return - she was recently quoted as saying that her fellow model, Anna Kournikova, was fat. But then, it is probably almost impossible to be a catwalk model and have a "normal" body image. At her biggest - size 12, although she looked much thinner because of her height - Kidd found that clothes samples didn't always fit and was rejected from some Paris shows for being too big. At that point, she declared herself "fat", but said: "I love being this size, I finally feel sexy." Her newfound womanly poise has led to an appointment as spokeswoman for the Rover British Fashion Awards. She is clearly anxious to confound the image of models as ditsy and rude. When caught unawares she can be rather offhand, in the way that beautiful 22-year-olds used to having people vying for their attention can be; but when she turns her full attention to a conversation she is exceedingly well-mannered. Perhaps she is right to say that the break from fashion deflated her ballooning ego.

"I'm the right age to model now, because I'm old enough to see that I'm incredibly lucky to have this opportunity. People shouldn't complain when they are being paid to wear incredible clothes and to travel. Modelling is very, very tough if you're slogging around and you don't quite make it, but if you get to a certain level it's fantastic." She spends as much time as possible at home in Wiltshire with her boyfriend, sleeping in her brother's spare room when she works in London. "There is obviously a fake side to the industry and in London you get swept up in it. I need to get back to the countryside, cook a big shepherd's pie, muck my horses out, go for a walk."

Kidd has her sights set on the country life: her goal is to make money to fund it. "I can probably get my head down, work really hard for the next five or 10 years, and then be able to have a family and enjoy it. I want to have a nice house with lots of animals, and ride my horses." As well as modelling, she is planning a sideline in corporate entertainment, "teaching people to play polo. You know, top model teaching you to ride sort of thing."

Not that she needs the money. As a great- granddaughter of Lord Beaverbrook, Kidd's childhood was divided between English boarding schools and her parents' home in Barbados, where she learned to love horses through her wealthy showjumping father, Johnny Kidd. The patrician self-confidence which comes with her background is probably an asset in negotiating the world of fashion, and Kidd is close both to her parents and to her make-up artist sister and polo-playing brother.

Her parents are watch proudly from the front row as Kidd returns to the catwalk for London Fashion Week. Backstage, her mother, Wendy, is perched quietly, trying not to get in the way. This is almost impossible with 40 rowdy people barging around a small room full of clothes rails and make-up kits, handbags and champagne glasses, and Wendy decides to head out for a walk before the show. Kidd asks her to bring back a chicken and sweetcorn sandwich. One sandwich and a swig of champagne later, she is up there in a red corselette worthy of a Las Vegas showgirl, and a white feather opera coat. Then it's home to feed the horses.

She looks a little overdone for noon. But then we are backstage at a fashion show and in half an hour Kidd will be stepping into a sequinned dress and high heels and taking her turn on the catwalk. She looks like something out of Bladerunner, she says. Oddly, neither the hairdresser nor his assistant have seen Bladerunner or, indeed, even heard of it, so this line of conversation isn't going anywhere, but she is right. Even without the wig and false eye lashes, Kidd has an almost sci-fi kind of beauty: with her preternaturally huge, almond-shaped, green-grey eyes; a wide, perfect mouth; and those extraordinary cheekbones. Kidd became famous for being thin, which is, she agrees, an odd thing to become famous for. She also became famous for being posh - very posh: polo-playing, hanging-out-with-royalty, country-house posh - but it was mainly the thin thing. She is still thin but no longer gaunt. In fact, her body is quite different to the days when her knobbly knees and sunken cheeks made the front pages. At 22, she has put on two stones to fill a size 10, occasionally a 12. She is beautiful now: lanky, yes, but peachy too. Meeting Kidd, it strikes you that the public furore over her weight was vicious. "I was never remotely anorexic: it's the stupidest thing I've ever heard. My family are all skinny. I was 14 when I started modelling, and I was 6ft 1in. People hated me for it, and that was scary." She has often spoken of hearing the daytime television presenter Lorraine Kelly, whom she had never met, call her a "sick, anorexic giraffe" on air. It would be fairer to blame the designers, Kidd says. "By the end, I wasn't enjoying modelling, but designers were still ringing me up and persuading me." Two years ago, she decided it was time to take a break. "I was too thin, but I was also getting really sour, really jaded. I was earning all this money and getting flown first-class and I thought I was the bees' knees." During her time out from the fashion world, her figure developed. "I didn't do it deliberately, I just grew up. I got boobs. My sister had always said to me that the second I hit 20 I would round out as she had. It's hard for me to put on weight but I was spending more time in the countryside, doing lots of riding, and I put on muscle." Kidd returned to the catwalk last year with a new mindset. "I look much better now, and I know it. Before, I thought everyone hated me when they looked at me. I really enjoy the catwalk now. I've got that excitement back, the butterflies back." "Of course it's just modelling, but I do think if you try a bit harder, give a bit more, it does show. There are girls who have beautiful faces but don't give." fields.trailText: March 5: Disney is considering accepting advertising on its TV channels for the first time.
fields.body:
Disney is considering accepting advertising on its TV channels for the first time.

Attic Futura has been put up for sale by its Australian parent company.

Penthouse is to return to UK newsstands as an adult title "with a celebrity and lifestyle twist". The veteran soft-porn magazine is being relaunched by XXX Publications.

The decline in sales for the regional press is continuing - morning, evening, Sunday and weekly titles have all lost readers.

Emap has poached Richard Hayes from Express Newspapers to be the commercial director for Heat.

webTitle: Media giants in sports merger talks

fields.headline: Media giants in sports merger talks
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 5 owner RTL and French rival Canal Plus are making a joint bid for domination of the European sports market. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Channel 5 owner RTL and French rival Canal Plus are making a joint bid for domination of the European sports market.

The powerful media groups are discussing the merger of their sports broadcasting rights and marketing units in a deal that would create a major player in the sports rights field.

Sources close to the negotiations said it was inevitable that both companies would start serious talks, following months of speculation.

"The catalogue of sports rights between the two is really impressive. The potential synergies are very obvious and have been discussed before," said one source.

RTL owns broadcast rights to more than 200 football teams through its Ufa Sports operation, and handles over 70% of the broadcasting franchise for the Uefa Champions League.

Canal Plus owns the international rights to the French Rugby League, the UK Premier League and the French first division football league through its Sports Plus subsidiary.

A Canal Plus spokesman denied that a successful merger would break a pact with the shareholders of sports channel Eurosport.

The French company recently sold its stake in the station, and promised not to establish a rival service within 12 months.

"What we are talking about here is sports rights. Eurosport broadcasts sports rights, but this is about sharing the management of sports rights and nothing else," said the spokesman.

The deal could also include French sports marketing firm JC Darmon, in which RTL holds a minority stake.

Analysts gave the thumbs-up to the talks, saying that a successful merger would create a genuine power in European sports broadcasting rights.

"It is all about critical mass and bargaining power, so the bigger the better and you cannot get much bigger than this," said Christophe Cherblanc, analyst at SG Securities.

Mr Cherblanc added that Canal Plus and RTL do not overlap geographically, and the deal would be a perfect combination of pay-TV and free-to-air services.

A successful deal would put both companies second in the market for European sports broadcasting rights, behind Kirch Group of Germany. Kirch owns the rights to the next two World Cups and Formula One, following a controversial arrangement with national rival EM.TV.

webTitle: Life imitates art as kidnappers target Crowe

fields.headline: Life imitates art as kidnappers target Crowe
fields.trailText: Russell Crowe, who plays a kidnap and ransom expert in Proof of Life, was apparently the target for kidnappers on his trip to London for the film's premiere
fields.body:
Hollywood beefcake Russell Crowe is declining to comment on weekend reports in the British press that the Gladiator star was targeted by kidnappers. The Sunday People carried a story describing how Scotland Yard stepped in to protect Crowe after receiving a tip-off from the FBI that kidnappers planned to grab the Oscar favourite at the London premiere of his new thriller Proof of Life - in which the actor plays a kidnap and ransom expert.

The Kiwi star, a renowned tough guy and hellraiser, is said to have been "genuinely scared" when informed of the danger. The newspaper quotes a police source as saying: "This threat was real and treated very seriously. The FBI were insistent we acted immediately Crowe took the threats extremely seriously. It's hard to imagine the man you see playing mighty Maximus in Gladiator being frightened, but he was genuinely scared." No information was given about the identity of the kidnappers, who were thought to be planning to make a huge ransom demand.

According to a source at the Dorchester Hotel, where Crowe was staying: "When he left for the airport, the security operation was like something out of the movies. He had five guards, all built like brick walls... Their eyes never left him for a moment. It was executed like a Secret Service operation."

Crowe also experienced the downside of fame last year, when an Aussie landlord reportedly tried to extort money from him over a fracas in an Australian pub.

fields.headline: Mogul who rules the World Cup
fields.standfirst: The secret life of Leo Kirch, who bestrides the TV world like a colossus.
fields.trailText: John Hooper delves into the life of Leo Kirch, who is holding British broadcasters to ransom over TV rights to the next two World Cups.
fields.body:
Some years ago there was a media congress in Munich. A party was thrown for the participants and Leo Kirch, as the city's biggest media tycoon, put up the lion's share of the money. "When he turned up, the security guards didn't recognise him and wouldn't let him in," recalls one who was present. "He was standing there saying: 'But I paid for everything here ...'"

Kirch may be one of Germany's most powerful men but, as that incident indicated, the vast majority of his own compatriots have no idea what he looks like. The wheeler-dealer at the centre of raging controversies over access to two of the world's premier sporting competitions, formula one and football's World Cup, is an odd paradox: a man who has devoted his life to controlling what other people can watch, yet who himself does not wish to be seen.

Already embroiled in rows in Britain and Germany over his ownership of the television rights to the 2002 and 2006 World Cups, Kirch has now run into another storm over the 75% stake in formula one which he and his partners took last week.

Though he has interests in free-to-air television, advertising and publishing, he is best known as Germany's pay-to-view TV czar. And though his group has denied it plans to make the public pay to watch formula one, the sport's major manufacturers are unconvinced and last week threatened to stage their own racing series if an attempt were made to limit coverage.

Similar concerns surround his involvement with the World Cup. Last month his company filed a complaint with the European Court of Justice challenging the British government's "Crown Jewels" policy of reserving key sporting events, including the World Cup, for free-to-air television.

Talks between the Kirch group and BBC and ITV broke down last November after the British broadcasters rejected the group's demand for a reported £171m. That compares with £4m for the British rights to the last World Cup.

Yesterday the BBC's director of sport Peter Salmon accused Kirch of holding Britain to ransom over World Cup rights.

"Kirch has put aside the interests of the British public in its quest for a payment for UK rights in the order of 40 times what was previously paid for the 1998 World Cup," Salmon told MPs from the all-party BBC group at the House of Commons. "BBC and ITV have made a very competitive bid. Kirch refuses even to discuss it with us."

Defending the "Crown Jewels" policy, Salmon suggested that last year's Olympic Games, for example, would never have been given the blanket coverage they received in Britain had they not been protected. "Commercial interests would snap up some events, like track and field, but who would bother with shooting and sailing?"

If the Kirch group's complaint is upheld, it will be free to accept the highest offer, even if that comes from a subscription channel such as Sky. If it is not upheld, there is the danger the company could withhold the rights from Britain altogether.

Much the same pattern is being followed in Germany. Last month Kirch's talks with ARD and ZDF broke down and are being resumed only at the urging of the German chancellor Gerhard Schröder.

Nothing about Kirch, from his obsessive secrecy to the way he built his fortune, suggests that concerns over his involvement in sport are misplaced.

He is the head of one of Germany's two biggest television empires. Yet he does not even have an entry in the German version of Who's Who. He has only ever given two press interviews and virtually the only chance to catch a glimpse of him comes at the annual general meeting of the Axel Springer publishing group, of which he is the second biggest shareholder.

When I began the preparation of this article, I naively rang the Kirch Gruppe press office to ask for some basic facts about him. I was referred to the company's website which purports to carry a biography of the chairman. It is nothing of the sort, merely a brief history of Kirch's business exploits.

I repeated my request. There was no reply for more than a week. So I sent a reminder and got back this email: "Unfortunately I have to tell you that we cannot give you any other information than published in the curriculum vitae [sic] at our website".

Kirch has also succeeded in persuading others to go along with his insistence on absolute privacy. Business acquaintances undertake to talk about him, then when you ring them at the agreed time they are occupied - and, according to their secretaries, certain to remain so for the indefinite future.

Kirch has no known interest in sport beyond the commercial possibilities it offers. In the days when he was slightly less jealous of his privacy, a business directory managed to publish an entry on him which listed his only recreation as listening to classical music.

That, though, may be more of a giveaway than it might appear for, paradoxically, this collector of viewing rights has for years been losing his sight.

It is said now to be so poor that he has to have newspaper articles and the like read to him by his aides. The condition from which he suffers has the effect of making this unquestionably brilliant man look simple, particularly in unposed photographs. That would seem to explain his reclusiveness.

But Lutz Meyer, the media editor of Financial Times Deutschland, is unconvinced. "Maybe it's one of the reasons," he says. "But I think he's a very traditional entrepreneur, and the film-rights business in which he rose to prominence is a naturally secretive one."

Kirch was born in 1926 in the historic Bavarian town of Würzburg. Like most Bavarians he is politically a conservative. When last year the former chancellor Helmut Kohl organised a whip-round to help pay a fine imposed on the Christian Democrats for illegally accepting anonymous contributions, the media tycoon was among those who stumped up.

Like Kohl, he grew to adulthood in the final years of the second world war. He obtained a doctorate in business administration and became an assistant professor in economics at Munich university. But in the 50s he opted for a career in business and began acquiring the film rights that were to provide him with the foundations for his media empire.

Kirch is the king of content. His first purchase was Fellini's La Strada. He later acquired many of Buster Keaton's films and, in 1969, the Howard Hughes/RKO library of films.

It was the ownership of so much content that smoothed his path into television, where he could show for free what others had to pay for. His empire now comprises no fewer than six channels, including the pay TV station Premiere.

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours have pulled out of Boyzone's summer tour, costing Mikey, Stephen, Keith and Shane a cool £3m
fields.trailText: Charlton may break their club transfer record to sign Primera Division leading scorer Javier Moreno. The Alaves striker, who has scored 17 goals this season, has a clause in his contract which allows him to join a foreign club for £5.8m, reports the Sun.
fields.body:
Charlton may break their club transfer record to sign Primera Division leading scorer Javier Moreno. The Alaves striker, who has scored 17 goals this season, has a clause in his contract which allows him to join a foreign club for £5.8m, reports the Sun.

Real Madrid are planning a £20m bid to take former Atletico Madrid striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink away from Stamford Bridge, reports the Daily Mail. They may succeed as well: Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri is said to be unhappy at the forward's work-rate.

Manchester United, Arsenal, Leeds and Spurs are all gearing up to battle for the signature of Everton striker Francis Jeffers, after the 20-year-old turned down a double-your-money £20,000-a-week wage offer from Walter Smith.

Rangers want Dundee's Argentinian striker Claudio Caniggia to spearhead their title challenge next season, according to Planet Football. Boss Dick Advocaat said: "Caniggia is a very good player, definitely. I don't know if he wants to move but I like him very much as a player with his pace and his all-round quality." Celtic are also monitoring the situation, but Dundee are digging their heels in. "Unless Celtic or Rangers came forward with crazy money it wouldn't be sensible to sell," said Dens Park co-ordinator Dario Magri.

Roma have signed long-term Manchester United target Antonio Cassano from Bari for £19m. The 18-year-old midfield prospect has signed a five-year deal with the Serie A leaders and will become, according to official bumph, "a symbol of the AS Roma brand".

fields.headline: Telewest sells home shopping channel
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Telewest has sold its TV home shopping operation Screenshop to interactive auction channel Sit-up.tv. By Wale Azeez.
Mar 5: Telewest in £15m bid for auction channel
fields.body:
Telewest has decided its TV home shopping operation Screenshop is surplus to requirements and has sold it to interactive auction channel Sit-up.tv for £10m.

Sit-up.tv was set up last year by former ONdigital directors John Egan and Ashley Faull.

Screenshop will be merged with the company's Bid-up.tv shopping channel.

The move will provide it with the funds and attention it was starved of under Telewest.

Telewest will retain a 38% stake in the enlarged shopping channel, which will be carried on the cable operator's Active Digital platform.

In addition, Telewest will invest £14.8m in Sit-up.tv

According to a Telewest spokesman, Screenshop had always been on the "slow burner".

"It was never a core channel, and so never given the development it needed, hence the consolidation with Bid-up.tv," he said.

Screenshop was launched in October 1997, but did not begin a 24-hour service until late last year, and is only carried on Sky Digital.

One analyst said Telewest has learned lessons from Sky's foray into TV shopping and had realised the only way forward was through partnerships.

Related story

fields.headline: BBC3: Mingers need not apply
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Only reporters who can combine 'poise and style with journalistic credibility' will be acceptable, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC is searching for presenters to front its news bulletins for the new youth and entertainment network BBC3.

But newspaper recruitment adverts fail to reveal one crucial quality for the job: good looks.

Only reporters who can combine "poise and style with journalistic credibility" will be deemed acceptable.

A BBC source put it more bluntly: "Mingers need not apply."

The policy takes a leaf out of ITV's book which for years have been filling the screens with good-looking women including Kirsty Young and Katie Derham.

If the government gives the go-ahead for the corporation to change its BBC Choice digital channel into the youth and entertainment network BBC3, it will feature snappy one-minute news bulletins throughout the evenings.

At least £1m is being invested in developing the format.

Recruitment advertisements, which began to appear this week, state applicants must be "equally at ease reporting on Eritrea, Eminem and Everton" for an "original, inventive and challenging" news programme.

The service will "reflect the channel's innovation and tone while maintaining the values and authority of BBC News".

There is a hint of what BBC bosses are looking for in another sentence: "Those in front of camera will be able to combine poise and style with journalistic authority and credibility."

In other words, applicants will have to pass a BBC beauty test.

A source at BBC Choice said the channel head, Stuart Murphy, wanted two or three presenters to become the main faces of the channel's news output when it becomes BBC3.

"Stuart is keen they reflect the attitude of the rest of the channel and don't scare the horses," the source said.

The BBC stressed the successful candidates would be "journalists first and presenters second".

However, the revelation of Mr Murhpy's aim will fuel the concerns of BBC news veterans who feel they are being sidelined.

A number of seasoned BBC journalists were upset at the end of last year, when they were told to concentrate only on radio.

webTitle: The transfer agreement: point by point

fields.headline: The transfer agreement: point by point
fields.trailText: *In the case of players aged under 23, a system of training compensation should be in place to encourage and reward the training effort of clubs, in particular small clubs.
fields.body:
*In the case of players aged under 23, a system of training compensation should be in place to encourage and reward the training effort of clubs, in particular small clubs.

*Creation of solidarity mechanisms that would redistribute a significant proportion of income to clubs involved in the training and education of a player, including amateur clubs.

*International transfer of players aged under 18 to be allowed subject to agreed conditions. The football authorities will establish and enforce a code of conduct to guarantee the sporting, training and academic education to be provided.

*Creation of one transfer period per season and a further limited mid-season window, with a limit of one transfer per player per season.

*Minimum and maximum duration of contracts of respectively one and five years.

*Contracts to be protected for a period of three years up to 28; two years thereafter.

*The system of sanctions to be introduced should preserve the regularity and proper functioning of sporting competition so that unilateral breaches of contract are possible only at the end of a season.

*Financial compensation can be paid if a contract is breached unilaterally, whether by the player or the club.

*Proportionate sporting sanctions to be applied to players, clubs or agents in the case of unilateral breaches of contract without just cause, in the protected period.

*Creation of an effective, quick and objective arbitration body with members chosen in equal numbers by players and clubs and with an independent chairman.

*Arbitration is voluntary and does not prevent recourse to national courts.

webTitle: Discord in court over Bond theme

fields.headline: Discord in court over Bond theme
fields.trailText: Monty Norman, the man credited with writing the James Bond theme tune, yesterday began a high court libel case against a newspaper for repeating claims that he was not the author of one of the best known pieces of film music.
fields.body:
It could be a case for superspy James Bond.

Monty Norman, the man credited with writing the James Bond theme tune, yesterday began a high court libel case against a newspaper for repeating claims that he was not the author of one of the best known pieces of film music.

Oscar-winning composer John Barry claims he wrote the theme to the first Bond movie, Dr No, and not Norman.

Yesterday Mr Justice Eady and a jury heard the twangy guitar score ringing out across the usually staid court number 13 at the high court in London.

Opening the case for Norman, 72, James Price QC told the jury that the claim against the Sunday Times turned on whether the tune for the 1962 movie was written by Norman or, as the newspaper claims, by Barry.

Mr Price said that the article damaged Norman's reputation not just by saying that he did not write the Bond theme but by suggesting that for 35 years he had been dishonestly taking the credit and the royalties for a piece he did not compose.

Mr Price added that the article hurtfully suggested Norman was a "nonentity" and said he started his career as "the singing barber of Hackney".

Apart from Dr No, Norman had written music for stage and film musicals, including Expresso Bongo, and had won Ivor Novello, Evening Standard and Laurence Olivier awards.

The newspaper, said Mr Price, claimed that the famous Bond tune owed nothing to Mr Norman except for a snatch of a much-altered melody line. Barry, whose film scores include Born Free, Zulu and Midnight Cowboy, was in court.

Opening the defence, Mark Warby, for Times Newspapers, said that the article was a classic example of a report and comment piece on a live dispute and was neutral and sensibly balanced, with the reader reaching no other conclusion than that Barry was claiming to have written the theme.

Mr Warby said: "The truth can hurt and Mr Norman has tried to falsify history to justify the claims he has made for recognition as composer of the theme."

Mr Warby said that Barry was brought in to write the theme six months into the project because Norman had run out of inspiration.

Barry was called in and offered £250 to sort out the problem. A deal was struck whereby Barry would write the theme for a flat fee and no royalties and Norman was to get the credit and the royalties.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Investment trust adverts face axe
fields.trailText: 10.30am: A campaign designed to make investment trusts sexy may be scrapped due to lack of support, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A multimillion-pound campaign designed to make investment trusts sexy is at risk of being scrapped because so few investment trust companies are willing to contribute to the cost.

The director-general of the Association of Investment Trust Companies, which runs the campaign, will today call on members to support it or risk having their membership revoked.

Daniel Godfrey is threatening to scrap the campaign altogether if it does not get more widespread support.

At the moment, only two-thirds of trust companies support the campaign, which was worth £7m last year - little more than half the launch budget.

The "ITS" campaign was launched in October 1999 to create a brand for investment trusts, which had suffered from a much lower profile than rival products such as ISAs and Peps.

But the original campaign failed to live up to expectations and some members decided not to renew their contributions.

The AITC last year hired HHCL & Partners to create its advertising.

The agency launched First Direct and now handles the account for the Prudential's online bank Egg.

fields.headline: Navy to advertise in lads' mag
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The Royal Navy is advertising in lads' mag FHM in a bid to encourage recruitment from ethnic minority groups, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Royal Navy is advertising in lads' mag FHM in a campaign to encourage recruits from ethnic minority groups to enlist.

The "Local Heroes" integrated marketing campaign has been devised by The Watch-Men Agency for the navy's Directorate of Naval Recruiting and the COI.

The adverts will run in magazines including FHM, The Face, Untold, Mix Mag, Touch, Fresh Directions and Pride.

A national six-sheet Adshel campaign will run in urban areas that with large ethnic minority communities and postcards will be placed in cinemas and community centres.

The campaign intends to promote the navy as a genuine career option full of opportunities.

It portrays the skills and achievements of real people from different ethnic minority communities who already serve in the Royal Navy and the Royal Marines.

The focus of the campaign is on the role of the individual within a team, reinforcing the mainstream navy campaign slogan "The team works".

Research conducted by The Watch-Men, the advertising agency that created the campaign, has shown that young people from ethnic minority communities do not believe that there are people like them in the navy.

Only around 2% of new recruits are currently drawn from the ethnic minorities and the navy wants to increase that figure to 5%. Nationally, about 6.5% of 16 to 24-year-olds come from ethnic minority backgrounds.

"The navy spends a lot on recruitment advertising every year and overall we are pretty successful at hitting our recruitment targets," said Captain Andrew Cameron, the navy's assistant director of ethnic minority recruiting.

"But we needed to bring in an organisation that understood more about advertising to this niche market.

"The confidence and commitment young people show in joining the navy is frequently rewarded by real pride in their achievements during their career. We wanted to portray this in our poster subjects," Captain Cameron added.

fields.headline: Radio 1 signs DJ Fergie
fields.trailText: Radio 1 has signed DJ Fergie as a new resident for its bi-monthly essential mixes, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Radio 1 has signed DJ Fergie as a new resident for its bi-monthly essential mixes.

Belfast-born Fergie is the biggest new signing for the station as it launches its new live events programme. He said it was "the ultimate thing" to be joining Radio 1.

Fergie was discovered by the late hard-house club DJ Tony de Vit at a Northern Ireland nightclub.

He beat Roger Sanchez in the International DJ awards in Melbourne in 1999 and has since gone on to be one of the biggest names in hard house.

Meanwhile, Radio 1 is increasing its live events coverage by 25%.

The season begins in April with the One Live in London tour at Easter.

fields.headline: Crossroads makes steamy comeback
fields.trailText: 10am: The return of Crossroads, with slick new sets and plenty of sex, did not win over all the critics, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The reincarnation of Crossroads Motel as Crossroads Hotel has not pleased all the critics. For Charlie Catchpole of the Mirror, it's a refit too far.

"It's a total travesty. An utter disgrace," claimed the affronted critic. "They've completely ruined one of TV's legendary landmark programmes."

The problem is, it's just too damn good to be Crossroads.

And the Sun's Garry Bushell agreed. "The set didn't even wobble once" shrieked the page six headline.

Both critics were taken with the speed it took the writers of the new-look Crossroads to introduce some sex as the lantern-jawed deputy manager Jake Booth (Colin Wells) absconded into a bedroom with a gorgeous young bridesmaid - in the middle of the wedding celebrations.

And Mr Bushell has already taken a liking to head porter Rocky Wesson with his "When I was at the Hilton" anecdotes.

Most of the critics - including former Coronation Street producer Brian Park writing in the Sun - thought the Carlton production team had expertly handled the introduction of 30 new characters in the first episode.

Gone are the drab 1970s soft-furnishings to make way for a slick new reception area, a water feature and - to the Independent's horror - Thai fishcakes. This is definitely a rebranded hotel for the 21st century.

And there was more sex in the first 30 minutes than in Crossroads' previous 24-year history, with all of the young, glamorous characters veritably pulsating with hormones.

As the Sun declared, "the old dump has improved since we saw it last in 1988. They've made it a palace fit, if not for a king, then certainly for Alan Partridge."

The Times described the programme as "altogether slicker" than in its previous incarnation while the Telegraph described it as "pretty sturdy".

The well-publicised gay handyman Bradley Clarke managed to imbue his tussle with a young petrol thief with enough lust to put Blake and Alexis to shame.

On the other hand, there is enough soap history to please the real trainspotters.

Crossroads veteran Jill Harvey has been dusted down and moved to an executive suite. Played by Jane Rossington, she had the closing line of Crossroads back in 1988 and appropriately cropped up in one of the closing scenes last night.

But, as Jaci Stephen of the Mail pointed out, such is the stress "it takes her only until episode two to hit the bottle".

Some of the new actors are household favourites, such as Kathy "Norah Batty" Staff as Doris Luke and former Corrie star Sherrie Hewson in a new, glamorous guise.

On the basis of first impressions, it's too good to be true. As Jaci Stephen observes: "Meg Richardson will doubtless be turning in her grave - not least because of the extra cash Carlton has thankfully ploughed into the remake."

And the Mirror's Mr Catchpole? "On the evidence of the first 30 minutes, this is a confident, pacey, funny, sexy little soap which could wash the BBC's Neighbours down the plughole."

fields.headline: Single parents targeted by £2.5m back-to-work adverts
fields.trailText: 9.15am: The government has launched a £2.5m advertising campaign aimed at encouraging single parents to return to work, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The government has launched a £2.5m advertising campaign aimed at encouraging single parents to return to work.

The national TV and press campaign promotes the government's new deal for lone parents, a scheme for those on income support with at least one child under 16.

The programme provides advice on childcare, training allowances and benefits to tide job starters over until pay day.

Britain has one of the highest levels of lone parents out of work in Europe and the government is hoping to put 70% of them back into jobs.

"The new deal is providing the practical help and support needed by lone parents who want to do the best for themselves and their families," said social security secretary Alistair Darling.

"Almost 200,000 lone parents have joined so far, more than 81,000 have found work and more than 22,500 have gone into training."

A TV advert, to be shown in tonight's edition of Hollyoaks, shows a lone parent who uses her new skills to create a birthday card for a work colleague by superimposing his head on a Chippendales body.

And four press adverts show single parents dealing with a potential barrier to work that the new deal could help them overcome.

The campaign was created by Publicis and is due to run until the end of this month.

webTitle: 'Take your life in your own hands, that's my philosophy'

fields.headline: 'Take your life in your own hands, that's my philosophy'
fields.standfirst: Petra Brockmöller is hoping to end her life with the help of her doctor - and the Dutch legislature, which is decriminalising euthanasia. Will other nations follow its lead, asks Clare Dyer
fields.trailText: Petra Brockmöller is hoping to end her life with the help of her doctor - and the Dutch legislature, which is decriminalising euthanasia. Will other nations follow its lead, asks Clare Dyer
fields.body:
The winter sunlight filters into the living room of Petra Brockmöller's Amsterdam maisonette. Like the room, which is full of books, plants, fresh flowers and family pictures, Brockmöller is cheerful and upbeat. She looks a healthy, fit 65. But she's suf fering from terminal cancer and knows the end is not far off. S

he still enjoys life, walking miles each day, going to concerts and joining the younger colleagues she worked with before she retired a year ago for a drink, a few jokes and a meal. Her three children are all doing well and have given her four grandchildren, with a fifth on the way. But she is already talking to her doctor about helping her end her life when the time comes. She is confident she will be allowed to choose the timing and manner of her death - not in pain or sedated, but fully conscious and able to make her goodbyes to her children and grandchildren. "Some people don't grow old; that's your fate. My philosophy is carpe diem . Take your life in your own hands as far as possible. I believe in reaching the age of 67 in freedom and not being dependent on anybody, rather than reaching 70 and not being able to do anything."

A bill now going through the Dutch legislature will decriminalise a practice that has been judicially recognised in the Netherlands for nearly 30 years. The lower house passed it last November by a majority of more than two-thirds. It is expected to be accepted by the upper house next month and to come into force later this year. Euthanasia and assisting suicide have always been, and will remain, a criminal offence in the Netherlands.

By agreement between the medical profession and the ministry of justice, doctors have not been prosecuted if they fulfilled certain conditions and reported the death to the coroner as an unnatural one. The patient must have asked to die and persisted in the request - taking a patient's life without a request still counts as murder. The doctor must be satisfied that the patient's suffering is unbearable and lasting and that there was no reasonable alternative, and must have consulted another independent doctor. These will remain the criteria. What the new act will do is to incorporate these grounds for immunity from prosecution into the criminal code. Doctors will not only escape prosecution if they follow the rules, but they will no longer be committing a criminal act.

Those who disregard the rules will still risk a prosecution and possible murder conviction. Two weeks ago an Amsterdam GP, Wilfred van Oijen, was convicted of murder for injecting an 84-year-old woman with an anaesthetic drug without her request or a second opinion. The woman was in the last stages of death in a nursing home but had not been given pain-killing drugs ordered by the GP. She was covered in bed ulcers and nurses feared that washing her would kill her. Her daughters had urged him to end her suffering. The court declined to punish him for ending her life, saying he had acted "honourably and according to his conscience", and imposed a suspended fine for reporting that the death was from natural causes.

Since 1990, 20 doctors have been charged with carrying out euthanasia outside the guidelines. In most cases the charges have been dropped. Some of those prosecuted have been acquitted, others convicted, but none has served a prison term. A murder conviction does not carry the automatic life sentence a British doctor could expect if convicted in similar circumstances, but Dutch doctors say the prosecution process is still harrowing.

The procedure set up by the act will remove the fear of prosecution from those who scrupulously follow the rules. Three-person regional review committees, each consisting of a doctor, a lawyer and an ethicist (usually a clergyman), now look at all euthanasia and assisted suicide cases to see if they come within the criteria. At present, all cases also go to the public prosecution service for possible investigation. Once the act comes into force, the review committee will refer only doubtful cases to the prosecution authorities, although prosecutors will still be able to initiate their own investigations into a suspicious death.

In the Dutch legislature, the leading opponent of euthanasia is Andre Rouvoet of the small Christian Union party. He asks: "Is there any other crime where the one who commits the crime can make a report and be found guilty or not guilty by a non-judicial committee just on the basis of his own report?"

The Dutch point out that euthanasia happens in other countries but it goes on clandes tinely. They would prefer to have it out in the open where it can be monitored to minimise abuses. Fully decriminalising it will, they hope, encourage more doctors to report it. Despite the transparency, only 50 to 60% of cases are thought to be reported, up from 18% in a 1990 survey. A number, like the van Oijen case, undoubtedly happen without the patient's request. Some cases don't fall easily within the guidelines; some doctors are confronted with a patient in intractable pain and act immediately; others believe the patient's family deserve privacy. But there is no evidence that doctors act from any other motive than to relieve the patient's suffering.

Euthanasia is not available on demand: two-thirds of requests are turned down. Doctors on the second opinion panel, who see the patients and produce their own report, are trained to help their colleagues resist the too importunate patient. Most patients have had the same GP for many years, and doctors are widely trusted. In 85% of cases, euthanasia is carried out not in nursing homes or hospitals, but by GPs in the patient's home.

Patients must persist in their requests, which the criteria stipulate must be "voluntary and well-considered". Nico Mensing, a GP who also acts as a second opinion doctor, recalls his most difficult case. "It was a young mother of 31 with three kids of five, three and six months. I had kids the same age. She had cancer over all her body. She suffered a lot for months and months. We talked for months about it." Even Rouvoet admits: "I do have faith in our doctors and our medical system. I do not suspect any doctor of choosing easily the route of euthanasia and I'm convinced most doctors do not offer euthanasia to their patients. But when it comes up, it's a legal option and that doesn't help in encouraging investment in palliative care."

The most controversial element of the bill, a provision allowing children of 12 and over to choose euthanasia without their parents' consent, was dropped. Children between 12 and 16 may opt for euthanasia but only with parental agreement. Those between 16 and 18 take their own decisions but parents must be involved.

For the first time, the bill will allow euthanasia for patients unable to request it, if they made an advance directive - a "living will" - asking for it while they were still in full possession of their faculties.

Most of the patients who choose euthanasia are in the final stages of cancer. But court cases over the years have established that euthanasia is not limited to cases of terminal illness, and that unbearable suffering may be psychological as well as physical. Advocates of the slippery slope argument point to the case in 1994, where a court refused to punish a psychiatrist who gave a 50-year-old former social worker suffering from pathological grief over the death of her two sons the means to kill herself. Some thought this was a case too far, though the rules stipulate that doctors must satisfy themselves that the patient's request does not stem from depression.

Many, including the Royal Dutch Medical Society and the justice minister, felt the line was crossed last year when a court exonerated the doctor who helped the former senator Edward Brongersma, who had no serious physical or psychological illnesses but felt that at the age of 86 he was living "a pointless and empty existence", to die. The prosecuting authorities are appealing, as they have the right to do in the Netherlands.

On the whole, though, more than 90% of the Dutch support euthanasia. They may wonder why so few other nations have followed their lead. One US state, Oregon, has allowed doctor-assisted suicide, but not euthanasia, for the last four years. In Australia, a law to legalise euthanasia was passed in the Northern Territory in 1995 but overturned by the Australian senate in 1997. The Netherlands' neighbour, Belgium, is only now considering a euthanasia bill.

Johan Legemaate, professor of health law at Erasmus University, Rotterdam, says the Dutch system works because patients have a long-lasting relationship with a single GP, nursing home care is free so there are no economic pressures to shorten life, and the general attitude in society is to be open, not to cover up. "If you have a country in which one or more of these elements is lacking, you should be very cautious."

fields.headline: Vivendi gives Napster hope
fields.standfirst:
Messier says he can work with any website that protects rights but will continue to pursue pirates

More net news
fields.trailText: Vivendi Universal has offered an olive branch to Napster, the online song swapping service struggling for survival. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Vivendi Universal, owner of the world's largest music publishing group, yesterday offered an olive branch to Napster, the online song swapping service struggling for survival.

Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's chief executive, said the company had no argument with Napster if the service became legitimate. Vivendi, he said, would be prepared to license its output to Napster if the site could prove it was able to protect copyrights.

"I don't intend to take a position where we say we won't license our material to Napster," Mr Messier said. "Neither are we in a position where we need to license our catalogue to Napster as a matter of urgency. I am neutral."

Mr Messier said he would license the company's catalogue under the same terms to any online platform as long as it fulfilled two criteria: full recognition of copyright and demonstration that encryption technology was secure.

"Why should we not be on Napster in a couple of months when it has demonstrated that it respects those two criteria, alongside MSN, Yahoo! or Wanadoo? I am not going to struggle against Napster. I just need to get my content out there to as many platforms as possible."

Mr Messier, who was speaking at the Financial Times New Media and Broadcasting conference, warned that Vivendi would aggressively pursue online companies breaching copyright. The group last month announced the formation of rival online music alliance - Duet - with Sony of Japan.

Napster promised in court last Friday to use a filter to prevent copyrighted music being downloaded from its site.

That was a last minute attempt to persuade US district judge Marilyn Hall Patel to allow the service to survive, albeit radically reshaped.

Judge Patel said on Friday that she would soon decide "not if, but what an injunction should look like".

There are is still a row between Napster and the music industry over which side should bear the cost of providing secure, copyrighted material. The software to be installed on Napster's servers will block access to 1m music files.

Leading record labels, including Sony, Warner and EMI, are suing Napster, claiming that it encourages copyright infringement.

Last month they won a victory when a US court of appeals ordered Napster to stop trading in copyrighted material ahead of the conclusion of the trial.

So far Bertelsmann, which owns BMG, has been the only of the five largest music publishers to take a stake in Napster, which has 65m users, and attempt to turn it into a legitimate membership business.

Napster has offered $150m a year to the big five music groups over the next five years. Under the model, Napster would take 40% of revenues from its fee paying members and the music industry 60%.

Mr Messier also disclosed plans to halve the number of staff at Uproar and Flipside, its two online gaming services, with the loss of 150 jobs. The aim is to reach profitability by the end of the year.

He also signalled that the collapse in internet-related shares had created opportunities for further acquisitions. "What are the consequences of the e-crack? The consequences are opportunities.

"Some of these businesses have become really cheap, and some of these businesses are really good," he said.

 Vivendi said yesterday it had agreed to sell its stake in AOL France back to AOL Time Warner, the US media and internet conglomerate formed by the merger of America Online and Time Warner, for about $700m.

fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The shares of number one net retailer Amazon.com surged yesterday after rumours the struggling company was in talks with Wal-Mart Stores.
fields.body:
The shares of number one net retailer Amazon.com surged yesterday after rumours to the effect that the struggling company was in talks with Wal-Mart Stores to form some kind of strategic e-commerce deal.

Amazon's shares, which have lost about 83% of their value over the past year, were up 23.75% on the Nasdaq stock market in early trading.

Wal-Mart shares were up less than 1% on the New York Stock Exchange.

This weekend, the Sunday Times newspaper in Britain, citing executives close to the talks, reported that Amazon founder Jeff Bezos had met with Wal-Mart's chief executive Lee Scott to work out a deal in which Amazon would handle Wal-Mart's online strategy, as well as develop a presence in the retailer's more than 4,500 stores.

Under the terms of the deal, Amazon would receive a cash injection and a percentage of the sales it made through Wal-Mart, the Sunday Times said, although an equity investment by Wal-Mart into Amazon would be unlikely.

Wal-Mart would not comment on speculation about their business plan. Amazon.com did not immediately return calls for comment.

A handful of Wall Street analysts admitted they thought the deal would be a perfect fit, given Wal-Mart's failed attempts at building a strong presence on the web and given recent rumours that Amazon, like many e-tailers, has been thwarting off bankruptcy as it struggles to turn a profit.

Wal-Mart is the largest retailer in the world, with fourth-quarter sales topping $56.5bn (£38bn), and the company, which did not catch the dot.com fever until recently, only ventured into the fray when it relaunched Walmart.com in November last year. Last month, however, Walmart.com laid off 10% of its staff in a move to conserve cash and focus its efforts on the site's technology.

Since Amazon started selling books online in 1995, it has expanded its product offerings to include everything from music CDs to kitchen appliances, a strategy that has raised concerns that it was expanding too fast.
Reuters

webTitle: Maxwell-led software firm accused of fraud

fields.headline: Maxwell-led software firm accused of fraud
fields.trailText: Nine lawsuits alleging securities fraud have been filed against an American software company run by Robert Maxwell's daughter, Isabel. By Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Nine lawsuits alleging securities fraud have been filed against an American software company run by Robert Maxwell's daughter, Isabel.

Lawyers for shareholders accuse Commtouch, of which Ms Maxwell is president, of violating US securities regulations when it overstated revenues by $4.4m during the first three quarters of 2000.

The accounting errors, which one lawyer called a "shocking revelation", were made public at the company's annual results last month, prompting a 29% drop in the share price.

At the time, Commtouch announced it would lay off 200 staff, blaming the slowdown in the hi-tech sector.

Commtouch shares are now trading at 75 cents, 95% off the 52-week high of $68.50.

Several of the company's directors are named individually in the suit, although Ms. Maxwell is not among them.

The troubles at Commtouch follow problems at two other companies which have associations with the Maxwell family.

Telemonde, a telecoms company based in the Bahamas and run by Kevin Maxwell, was forced to restate its earnings last year by the securities and exchange commission.

The company, which buys and resells telecoms services, owes millions to suppliers such as MCI WorldCom and Global Crossing.

Shares in the company are traded on the American equiv alent of Britain's lightly regulated Ofex, but were de-listed briefly last July after accounting irregularities raised the authorities' interest.

Email provider Critical Path, which is run by Ms Maxwell's former husband, David Hayden, has also hit hard times.

Critical Path announced last month that it had mis-stated its prospective earnings drastically, and ousted two top executives, leaving Mr Hayden in charge.

The chief executive, who was one of those sacked, had said only months earlier that the company would be profitable by the February earnings announcement.

Instead, massive losses caused Critical Path's shares to drop 70% in a single day before trading was halted. Critical Path's shareholders responded with a string of class-action lawsuits.

Ms Maxwell has worked for Commtouch for nearly four years and has spent the past 15 years in Silicon Valley.

She founded one of the earliest internet search engines, Magellan, with her sister Christine, and they sold it to Excite in 1996.

In a recent interview, she said she had learned a lot from the rise and fall of the internet industry.

"You need to be able to turn on a dime in this business or you'll die," she said.

"The baby really has been thrown out with the bathwater, but the tough babies will dry themselves off with a towel and get on with it."

webTitle: BSkyB target is extra £50 a viewer

fields.headline: BSkyB target is extra £50 a viewer
fields.trailText: BSkyB yesterday made an ambitious forecast for the additional revenues it hopes to generate from interactive services. By David Teather.
fields.body:
BSkyB yesterday made an ambitious forecast for the additional revenues it hopes to generate from the introduction of interactive services.

Richard Freudenstein, chief operating officer of the pay-TV group, said he was aiming to win an extra £50 per customer per year because of the advent of digital technology.

The broadcaster, which already offers some interactive services on its news and sports channels, is planning services including SMS messaging, email and interactive advertising for later this year.

BSkyB recently launched on online betting operation through Sky Sports after last year's acquisition of Sports Interactive. In its recent year-end results, BSkyB said £33m had come from betting - although most is still offline.

Three weeks after the service was launched, 15,000 accounts had been opened.

Mr Freudenstein, who was speaking at the Financial Times New Media and Broadcasting conference, said viewers' willingness to use interactive technologies had been demonstrated by the broadcaster's first on-screen poll over the weekend, which registered 28,000 votes.

Like other pay-TV operations, BSkyB is under pressure to increase revenue per household to begin paying back the cost of giving away set-top boxes. When the annual results were published, chief executive Tony Ball set a target of raising average revenue per subscriber to £400 a year by 2005.

webTitle: BBC warns staff of sensitivity on Europe

fields.headline: BBC warns staff of sensitivity on Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The BBC has warned reporters and programme-makers to be extra-sensitive over Europe during the run-up to the election. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC has warned its reporters and programme-makers to be extra-sensitive over the issue of Europe during the run-up to the general election.

In guidelines issued yesterday, the corporation said that issues such as Europe caused divisions within parties as well as between them, and all views should be fairly represented.

The BBC has come under fire from all sides of the debate over its coverage of Europe. The Today programme on Radio 4, which has attempted to cover the issue in depth, has taken much of the flak.

The guidelines take account for the first time of the problems posed by the internet. Since the last election, the BBC's online news service has undergone a huge expansion.

Online staff are warned to be aware of concerted email campaigns conducted by political activists, and talk forums must be monitored to ensure that they reflect a fair debate. Devolution also features strongly in the guidelines: network programmes must give time to Plaid Cymru and the SNP. Individual programmes do not have to be artificially balanced, but must give the different parties a fair hearing over the course of a week.

The guidelines highlight the sensitivity of certain issues. "Particular care should be taken over high-profile issues like Europe where there is a multi-faceted debate within and between the parties to ensure that a balance of views is maintained," the guidelines warn.

Producers and editors are also warned over the dangers of opinion polls. The results of an opinion poll should never lead a news bulletin on their own, and the interpretation given to the results by the publication or organisation that commissioned it should not be relied upon.

Great care must be taken with the language used to report political surveys: "Polls 'suggest' but never 'prove' or even 'show'," the guidelines say.

The BBC said that the guidelines, developed by the corporation's editorial policy department, would "help ensure balance and fairness during the campaign".

fields.headline: BBC series films paedophile unit
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC is filming Scotland Yard's paedophile unit for a major fly-on-the-wall documentary, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The work of Scotland Yard's paedophile unit, including its investigation into an internet child-porn ring, is to be turned into a fly-on-the-wall documentary series by the BBC.

Hundreds of hours of material have already been shot for the observational series but such is its sensitivity that all the tapes are under police guard.

Bob Long, executive producer and director of the BBC2 series, described the footage as a "remarkable" insight into the disturbing criminal world of child pornographers.

"People won't have seen anything like this on TV before, it's a very difficult and tough subject," he said.

Mr Long stressed that "all of the tapes are kept under lock and key at Scotland Yard because there's a lot of child porn on them".

BBC cameras are following an investigation into an internet child-porn ring "comparable" to the Wonderland website smashed by police in late 1998 following an international operation.

"I think people watching this will learn an awful lot about the subject and how to protect their own children," he said.

Mr Long, who works in the BBC documentaries and investigation group, spent two-and-a-half years negotiating access to the Scotland Yard paedophile unit.

The documentary has been in production for eight months and filming is to continue for another five.

The four-part series is expected to be delivered to BBC2 controller Jane Root next February.

Mr Long is also executive producing a BBC2 documentary series about the Brighton gay scene.

Brighton out of the Closet, which was described by Mr Long as an "unapologetic" look at the city's gay scene, is to be broadcast Monday to Thursday over two weeks in May.

webTitle: 'Political' fuel duty cut ignored environment, say MPs

fields.headline: 'Political' fuel duty cut ignored environment, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday received a sharp pre-budget rap on the knuckles when a committee of MPs accused him of a "politically motivated" cut in fuel duties after last autumn's protests, with scant regard for its environmental impact.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday received a sharp pre-budget rap on the knuckles when a committee of MPs accused him of a "politically motivated" cut in fuel duties after last autumn's protests, with scant regard for its environmental impact.

The chancellor cut the duty on ultra lowsulphur petrol (ULSP) in his November pre-budget report, just within the 60-day deadline for renewed disruption set by militant truckers. Though ministers said they were not giving in to blackmail, yesterday's report by the Commons committee set up in 1997 to provide an environmental audit was "unconvinced".

The MPs "can only conclude that this move was politically motivated to address the concerns of the hauliers", it says. Together with other changes to car and fuel taxes it amounted to a failure to make "a comprehensive appraisal of the trade-offs between social, economic and environmental objectives".

In other findings the MPs, chaired by Tory John Horam, complain that Mr Brown's Treasury team is not using VAT rules wisely to encourage energy efficiency in homes and offices or on home renovation. It does welcome Mr Brown's change on company car tax to curb unnecessary journeys.

Overall only four of the government's 21 departments are taking environmental legislation seriously, the MPs say. They demand much more serious and more regular analysis of what is being done and still needs to be done.

Though the financial secretary, Stephen Timms, told the MPs in evidence that the fuel duty escalator may be revived if crude oil prices drop, the report's timing is embarrassing.

Yesterday's report confirms the complaints of environmental campaigners that the government is sending out confused signals about the need to curb the number of vehicles and journeys to cut carbon emissions.

At a Westminster press conference Mr Horam also criticised the government's handling of the climate change levy on industry.

The public views it as "another stealth tax on industry for its own sake. It is being passed on to hoteliers and small businessmen which was not the original intention. It was meant to hit high energy users", he said.
