webTitle: Analysis: high petrol prices impacts road congestion

fields.headline: Hit the brakes
fields.standfirst:
Higher petrol prices last year hid a silver lining for motorists: the growth in traffic slowed, avoiding another leap in road congestion

Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Higher petrol prices last year hid a silver lining for motorists: the growth in traffic slowed, avoiding another leap in road congestion.
fields.body:
Today the prime minister makes a big environment speech - just as Gordon Brown puts the final touches to the Budget. It might have been useful if they had had a word about petrol. While there is clearly a case for higher fuel prices to reduce pollution, in the past we have underestimated their impact on levels of traffic and congestion.

Last year road traffic in the United Kingdom grew by only 0.3% - one of the lowest increases ever recorded in the modern age. What makes this volume all the more surprising is that it coincided with an economic boom: GDP was growing by 3%. There always used to be an inextricable link between economic prosperity and traffic growth; recently there have been signs of it uncoupling. Both the fuel shortages during last autumn's protests and, more importantly, an 8% hike in fuel prices last year were responsible for the change. Just as in any other area of consumer behaviour, increases in the cost of fuel gave rise to market resistance, with the consumer making other transport choices or not buying fuel at all.

If historical patterns had been followed we should have seen growth of 3.8% in traffic volumes last year - an extra 17bn vehicle-kilometres should have been travelled by cars and lorries on already busy roads. It did not happen. Instead growth nudged up by just this small amount, relieving us of around 16.3bn extra vehicle-kilometres.

We have been crawling over the figures, but only two things happened which seem to account for them: the fuel pump boycott in September, which left the country without fuel for several days, and higher fuel prices themselves.

Curiously, the rail chaos which followed the Hatfield crash last October had only a marginal impact on traffic. Commuters, it seems, had no choice but to use the train, and many of the more congested roads could not absorb much extra traffic. In the days immediately after the crash traffic volumes even went down, but that was probably a consequence of the flooding taking place at the same time.

After Hatfield, the airlines enjoyed a boom in passenger numbers on UK domestic flights, with increases of up to 50% in passengers on some routes. Many other people switched their work and travel plans. They either worked from home more or made greater use of the phone, email and remote conferencing facilities.

The fuel boycott certainly distorted 2000's figures as vehicles stayed parked at the kerb. None the less, if traffic had been flowing normally during the year growth would only have been 0.7% - way short of growth consistent with historical trends.

That leaves the fuel price hike. Last year petrol cost 8% more than in 1999 after allowing for inflation. Research suggests that, in the short term, for every 1% rise in fuel prices we see 0.18% knocked off traffic growth. A quick calculation shows that that should have led to more than a third (1.4%) off expected traffic growth of 3.8%.

Received wisdom says that higher petrol prices - or other direct charges - are just bad news for the motorist. But this cloud turns out to have a silver lining, for motorists themselves.

While it is comforting to have lower prices at the pumps, motorists have to balance that against worsening congestion. Last year petrol campaigners were calling for a 26p cut in the price of petrol. That could have resulted in an additional 6% traffic growth - or 22bn extra car-kilometres a year. To put that in perspective, the additional growth would have meant 4m extra average length car trips of 14 kilometres every single day of the year. That is the equivalent of 200,000 extra car journeys from London to Manchester a day. It just does not make sense.

With the government forecasting that motoring costs will fall by 20% over the next decade - mainly as a result of more fuel efficient vehicles - this will place greater pressure on other measures to reduce congestion.

We are already using our cars to take us a third further to work in the morning than 10 years ago and nearly doubling the proportion of children being driven to school - to the point where we now use our vehicles more than car owners in other major European Union countries.

There may be a good reason for that. Despite the claims of the motoring lobby, the cost of motoring taxation in the UK - including excise duties on petrol - is only middling in terms of the European league table illustrated in the chart. Even then, in real terms, the cost of motoring is 80% cheaper than it was 25 years ago when adjusted for rising disposable incomes.

There is one other major factor we have not discussed - congestion itself. Is worsening traffic congestion persuading us that there are better ways for us to go about our daily journeys? Logic would suggest it must be. Why, then, are we making more and shorter journeys by car?

Congestion is a very inefficient way to regulate traffic volumes - as any motorist stuck in a traffic jam recognises. If the political consensus is that we cannot increase the cost of motoring then it is imperative that we shift the burden of taxation away from vehicle excise duty towards car use.

Congestion charging will have a much greater impact on congestion levels than either fuel duty or vehicle excise duty. In the meantime we should take heart that traffic growth is slowing, even if the benefits of a more integrated transport system still have to kick in.

 David Begg is chair of the commission for integrated transport

webTitle: Striking a balance on taxing petrol

fields.headline: Striking a balance on tax
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The North sea fiscal regime is the main mechanism for capturing the benefit of Britain's oil and gas resources. The tax take is complex, and can vary between 30% and 70% depending on, among other variables, the age of the field. The government needs to balance extracting an appropriate share of profits against offering sound investment conditions for the oil industry.
fields.body:
The North sea fiscal regime is the main mechanism for capturing the benefit of Britain's oil and gas resources.

The tax take is complex, and can vary between 30% and 70% depending on, among other variables, the age of the field.

The government needs to balance extracting an appropriate share of profits against offering sound investment conditions for the oil industry.

The North sea is now a mature region and competes for investment against a dozen others.

Political risk and physical ease of extraction are two of a range of issues which influence oil companies.

The UK fiscal structure has developed piecemeal over 30 years. The main elements are:

 Royalty, which is paid at 12.5% of the landed value of the petroleum less an allowance for bringing petroleum onshore and treating it. Royalty is a condition of each oil production licence but not payable for any field approved after March 31 1982;

 Petroleum Revenue Tax, which was introduced by the Oil Taxation Act 1975. PRT is a tax on profits related to separate fields charged on the difference between income and expenditure. PRT was reduced from 75% to 50% with effect from July 1 in the 1993 Finance Act to encourage further investment. It was abolished for fields approved after March 15 1993;

 Corporation Tax, which is charged on the profits of oil and gas. It is the only tax applicable in the case of new fields. The main rate of CT is 30%. Both Royalty and PRT are deductible in calculating profits for CT purposes.

webTitle: Independent petrol retailers being driven out of business

fields.headline: Running on empty
fields.standfirst:
Independent retailer sees livelihood disappear

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Independent petrol retailer sees livelihood disappear.
fields.body:
Keith Mowbray owns the Kings Heath self-service petrol station near Birmingham

I have been here 23 years, but this could be the last. I made a small profit in 2000 but I am losing money now, and it looks like I will either go bust or have to sell up. The problem is there are so many service stations on the market that it is not easy to find buyers.

The oil majors are driving me out of business. There is a BP service station quarter of a mile down the road which is selling retail petrol 0.5p cheaper than the price they are charging me wholesale.

This two tier pricing is making things really bad for me. I am having to sell petrol at 75.9p for unleaded to compete, but I need 78.9p per litre to break even.

The oil companies are able to keep their prices low because they are making massive profits upstream. I am only keeping myself afloat through my car wash and selling other things. I have what is like a small convenience store attached to the petrol station where I sell sweets, cigarettes, frozen foods and snacks.

I would like to see the government take action against the oil companies in the Budget, but political interference so far has made things worse rather than better. There has been an OFT (office of fair trading) inquiry into the oil companies but it was a whitewash. Even that guy in Brussels, Mario Monti, told the British government it was not looking properly at what is happening in the industry.

I know the oil companies themselves are under pressure from government to keep petrol prices low, but that just encourages them make their money upstream. Over the last seven years, eight service stations in my immediate area have closed. I used to have 1,400 customers three years ago, but I am now down to half that number.

I have survived so far because I am single and have no family commitments. I am not sure what I would do if I sell up. I am 49 and have no academic qualifications. Who will employ someone like me?

 BP denies it is trying to drive out independents. It points out it is illegal for oil firms to cross-subsidise retail sites via upstream profits. It says its pricing policy is driven by competitive market conditions. A spokeswoman said: "I do not know Mr Mowbray's specific contractual arrangement with BP because all of them are very different, but they are entered into to provide mutual benefit and generally we have not changed terms or conditions."

webTitle: Brown to steer clear of 'big oil'

fields.headline: Brown to steer clear of 'big oil'
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor needs a pre-election fix for fuel protesters but dare not risk vital investment

Special report: the petrol war
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The chancellor needs a pre-election fix for fuel protesters but dare not risk vital investment.
fields.body:
When Gordon Brown stands up tomorrow to deliver the last Budget before the next election, one of the most obvious targets - the oil industry - is likely to escape his sharp tongue.

Last month the Treasury was also not pleased to see Shell raise pump prices just a day after the government announced a 2p cut in petrol.

The industry has done little to win over the motorist. Oil companies were partly blamed for last summer's fuel crisis. British drivers pay the highest pump prices in Europe, while the oil companies post record profits. And last week, "big oil" was charged with running out of town hundreds of small independent petrol retailers.

But there is unlikely to be any windfall tax in the Budget - or even tinkering with the North Sea tax regime - because Mr Brown knows his problems with fuel campaigners are much of his own making.

It was the Conservatives which introduced a link between higher petrol prices and higher taxation under the so-called fuel escalator. Mr Brown compounded the problem by raising the rate of tax from 5% to 6%. Hitting the oil companies is not as easy as it looks - even if Labour backbenchers, who have called for an end to oil company "rip-offs", think otherwise.

Many ask instead of imposing a tax on petrol on the forecourts, why not levy a charge on the exploration side of the oil business? This would mean that industry, not consumers, would bear the burden of taxation.

The chancellor is restrained by corporate logic. He is aware that big oil is highly mobile and will take its investment elsewhere if it deems the climate in Britain no longer attractive.

Shell might have made more than £1m an hour world-wide over the last 12 months, but little came from the petrol forecourt and 90% came from outside of Britain.

The oil industry is certainly awash with cash. ExxonMobil, the world's biggest oil group, last year made $17bn (£11.6bn), the biggest profits in corporate history, while BP gushed £9.8bn, the biggest annual earnings posted by a British company ever.

Paradoxically the oil industry itself has been struggling to decide what it should do with its record gains. Billions have been given back to shareholders but they have tried to escape the criticisms of the past when the good times led them to expand unprofitably into new areas in many cases long since abandoned. Shell diversified into nuclear power and forestry while Occidental Petroleum took up meat packing.

But under fire from financial analysts, big oil has become more conservative about spending its money. Companies remember two years ago that the industry was struggling with crude prices which had slumped from $34 per barrel to below $10 per barrel.

Over that time investment in the UK North Sea dropped from £5.8bn in 1998 to £3.6bn the following year and the same for 2000, but it should rise to $4bn this year.

Similarly, Mr Brown had to stand and watch the government tax grab fall from £3.3bn in 1998 to £2.5bn in 1999 and hobble along at the same level for 2000. Fiscal revenues are expected to rise to £5.3bn this year, while some of the 100,000 workers who left the industry between 1998 and 2000 are gradually coming back.

The government's careful balancing act was exposed by energy minister Peter Hain two weeks ago. "It is very difficult for the average motorist to understand that huge company profits are not passed on at the pump but, on the other hand, as any conversation or independent analyst will show, margins in the retail fuel markets, especially for petrol and diesel, are very tight and have been squeezed over the last few months," he told MPs.

What Mr Brown is likely to do tomorrow is to help motorists without attacking the oil industry by cutting duty on ultra low sulphur petrol.

The atmosphere surrounding the Budget preparations has been made more tense, however, by a warning last night that hundreds of more independent petrol stations could close this year.

This followed financial troubles at Save, the country's biggest independent petrol retailer, which was forced to appoint administrators last week.

Fuel retailers complain they are struggling with poor profit margins, intense competition from supermarkets and predatory pricing from oil majors, which is bolstered by their own upstream profits. CPL Petroleum, Britain's biggest franchise chain of independent fuel retailers, believed one-third of its network will pull out of the business within 12 months. The company's managing director, Phil Hall, said: "I can see quite a big fallout. Around about 30% of our [800] sites are at risk of closing." This could lead to the loss of 1,000 jobs.

Other independent retailers, which like CPL's chain of UK-branded sites are concentrated in loss-making rural areas, also fear the worst for their fuel businesses. "The situation for the independent fuel market is extremely grave, and the net result will be that many of the retail sites will close," said Peter Turner, director and general manager of Rix Petroleum.

The Institute of Petroleum says 800 filling stations of an estimated 13,000 could close this year.

Mr Turner said motorists would be forced to spend much more to reach the bigger petrol stations run by oil majors and supermarkets.

Oil companies deny claims of predatory pricing and argue they are struggling as much against heavy competition as the independents. They expressed confidence that the chancellor will not be delivering a one-off windfall tax or any tightening up of the UK North Sea fiscal regime.

The UK Offshore Operators Association has been working closely with government on a cost-reduction programme for the North Sea named Pilot. A spokeswoman said: "All the conversations we have had through Pilot suggests the government understands the economic realities of the need to be competitive with other oil and gas regions."

webTitle: Crucial drug case opens in Pretoria

fields.headline: Crucial drug case opens in Pretoria
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The world's largest pharmaceutical companies opened their lawsuit against the South African government's attempt to import cheaper anti-Aids drugs and other medicines yesterday by claiming that property rights were the the central issue of the case.
fields.body:
The world's largest pharmaceutical companies opened their lawsuit against the South African government's attempt to import cheaper anti-Aids drugs and other medicines yesterday by claiming that property rights were the the central issue of the case.

But demonstrators outside Pretoria high court and across the globe protested that what was really at stake was millions of lives.

Nearly 40 pharmaceutical companies claim that a new law which will permit the importation of generic drugs and patented medicines from suppliers at prices lower than those of the main drug giants breaches South Africa's constitution and international trade agreements.

"There can be no question that our rights are threatened," Fannie Cilliers, for the drug companies, told the court.

Representatives of Oxfam and Médecins sans Frontières attending the trial called the legal action an act of corporate inhumanity. Ellen 't Hoen of MSF said the case boiled down to the value of human life. "People no longer accept that profits are protected at any cost to human life. These companies now stand hopelessly isolated. No government supports their legal action any longer," she said.

Protesters rallied against the drug companies across South Africa and in countries including Australia, Canada, France, Germany and the US. In Britain, protesters picketed the Brentford headquarters of the world's largest drug company, GlaxoSmithKline.

A spokesman for the company, Phil Thomson,said: "The case is nothing to do with blocking access to medicines, or price fixing. It's about patents. Patents do not block medicines. They stimulate research and development."

The leadership of South Africa's powerful trade union confederation, Cosatu, headed a march of several thousand people to the US embassy in Pretoria. A verbal assault ensued after an American diplomat assigned to receive a memorandum calling on Washington to pressure the drug companies to drop their lawsuit refused to step outside the gate.

Cosatu's general secretary, Zwelinzima Vavi, scorned "the fat cats" in the embassy. "These bureaucrats from the US embassy are refusing to come here. They are treating people living with Aids, and all of us, with contempt," he told the crowd.

The drug companies have also been isolated by foreign governments. The United States, the European Union and the World Health Organisation say they do not oppose South Africa's right to implement the new legislation. The World Trade Organisation has said that the laws do not infringe international patent protections.

Inside the court, Mr Cilliers portrayed his clients as potential victims of wholesale theft, and the South African government as bandits riding roughshod over their patents.

But he might have fatally undermined his case when he conceded to the judge, Bernard Ngoepe, that the government already had the right to import cheaper drugs under South African common law.

The judge said that if that was the case then the new law was not breaking legal ground but simply setting out regulations. He questioned whether his court even had jurisdiction because the new legislation had yet to be signed into law by President Thabo Mbeki.

"As the acts stand now they affect your clients no more than cattle on a farm," he told Mr Cilliers. "If they are not in operation, how are your clients affected by an act that is not working?"

Mr Cilliers said the drug companies presumed that the laws would take effect.

The government has pointed out that drugs such as the anti-biotic Ciprofloxican, considered an "essential medicine", cost South Africa's public health sector 52p per pill and the country's private health care providers more than £3 a tablet. If the new law is implemented, a generic of the drug could be imported from India for just 4p a pill.

webTitle: Milosevic son hiding in hotel in Russia

fields.headline: Milosevic son hiding in hotel in Russia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The fugitive playboy son of the deposed Serbian leader and indicted war criminal Slobodan Milosevic was reported to be holed up in a Siberian hotel yesterday, under the protection of the Russian mafia.
fields.body:
The fugitive playboy son of the deposed Serbian leader and indicted war criminal Slobodan Milosevic was reported to be holed up in a Siberian hotel yesterday, under the protection of the Russian mafia.

The director of a Serbian company which owns the Sun hotel in Irkutsk denied the Serbian press reports of Marko Milosevic's presence and Russian counter-intelligence said that it had no knowledge of him being in the city.

But the Belgrade newspaper Glas Javnosti quoted "well-informed Russian sources" as saying that Marko had spent time in five or six Russian cities since fleeing Yugoslavia in October, when his father was toppled, and that he was now in Irkutsk.

Ksenija Micevic, the director of the Semitrade company which owns the Sun hotel in Irkutsk denied that Marko was in her hotel but said: "If someone called Milosevic knocks at the door of this hotel and asks for a room, we have to take that guest and his money."

Like scores of Serbian companies during Slobodan Milosevic's rule, Semitrade moved from Belgrade and registered in Cyprus in 1992 to beat the UN embargo against Yugoslavia. The hotel is to host President Vladimir Putin and the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, at a summit this month.

Glas Javnosti reported that Marko Milosevic was being protected by local Russian mafiosi who were being paid £14m to keep the playboy safe.

Under his father's rule, Marko became infamous for his lavish and thuggish lifestyle, running nightclubs and controlling cigarette-smuggling rackets in Serbia. He fled to Russia with his wife, Maria, and infant son just after the uprising against his father. They were helped out of the country by Rade Markovic, the secret police chief who has just been arrested in Belgrade.

From Moscow, Marko boarded a plane to Beijing, trying unsuccessfully to enter China. He returned to Russia and has been variously rumoured to be in several big cities.

Ms Micevic said she did not want Marko Milosevic in her hotel but, referring to reports of Russian mafia involvement, she said: "The problem is much worse .. He's not on any wanted list. This is a free country. And we're just a small hotel."

fields.headline: I sound like ripe cheese
fields.standfirst: Love her or hate her, Claron McFadden has one of music's most distinctive voices. The soprano talks to Warwick Thompson
fields.trailText: Love her or hate her, Claron McFadden has one of music's most distinctive voices. The soprano talks to Warwick Thompson.
fields.body:
When American soprano Claron McFadden sang in Tippett's The Mask of Time on the opening night of the 1999 Proms, one critic described her voice as "a sharpened arrow, clear and perfectly aimed". McFadden herself likens it to a "ripe French cheese". I would say that she has a voice so stratospherically pure and high that she ought to be able to microwave a potato just by singing a few phrases at it.

Apart from suggesting that McFadden's concert on London's South Bank tonight could be rather messy - these differences of opinion are indicative of conflicting attitudes toward the 39-year-old McFadden. In Britain, for example, her reputation rested for many years on her highly regarded early music performances and recordings. (Her very first CD, Acis and Galatea with the King's Consort, is still many a Handelian's number one choice.) But in the Netherlands, where she is now based, she has always been considered a specialist in contemporary music. And it was only when she took the title role in Berg's Lulu at Glyndebourne in 1996, and then returned to the company two years later to sing the Controller in Jonathan Dove's Flight, that British audiences began to recognise McFadden's full range as a performer.

Tonight she dons her new music hat for a concert with the Nash Ensemble, part of their annual New Music Series. She will sing Harrison Birtwistle's The Woman and the Hare, the world premiere of which she gave just over two years ago. Birtwistle has described her voice as "amazingly flexible and with a wide range of colours". Not that she wasn't anxious when she first sang it for him. "I was shaking ever so slightly, and wondering if what he had just heard was anywhere close to what he had been hearing in his own head," she says. "And his first reaction was to ask me if I wanted anything changed . . . Harry has an incredible understanding of the human voice, and though the piece makes a lot of demands vocally and dynamically, it feels good singing it."

The Woman and the Hare is about a woman (a notated speaking role for an actor, Julia Watson) who sees a hare being burnt in a field-fire on a moonlit night, and who comes to identify with the creature's suffering. The singer takes on the role of a Greek chorus, and elaborates the woman's emotions. McFadden talks about the need for the singer to "colour" the piece. What exactly does that mean? "For me, the voice is the link between one's emotions and the outside world," she says. "Babies express their needs directly through it, people's voices change when they're upset and, just as there are different gradations of emotion - of love, of anger, of desperate craving for a chocolate fix - I try to express this subtlety in the colours of my voice. I assume my audience come to a piece blank, and it's my job to communicate the emotions of a piece to them the best way I can."

McFadden was born in Rochester, New York state, into a family whose members all possessed a good set of lungs but little knowledge of "European" classical music. She discovered this for herself at grammar school, and received a grant to study in the Netherlands.

Her first opera job was as Zerbinetta in a Dutch production of Ariadne auf Naxos in 1989. "I've always loved acting," she says, "even from when I was a child. But when I got on stage I realised I couldn't act my way out of a paper bag. I was wild and full of unharnessed energy, but I was around all these seasoned performers like Rita Cullis. It was as if they were all in slow motion." So she spent a year taking acting lessons. "When you see a singer on stage who is 100% committed to the personality, character and temperament of the role being sung, it's truly awesome and very powerful." Which singers live up to this standard? "Sarah Vaughan is one of my greatest heroes. She personifies what an artist is all about, taking risks, daring to go beyond the boundaries of safety and convention. It takes courage to share your vulnerability." Does this mean there's a bluesy old jazzer inside McFadden, waiting to get out? "I listen to a lot of non-classical music at home, but I don't get many opportunities to sing it." She pauses wistfully. "But if I could scat like Sarah . . ."

McFadden herself likens it to a "ripe French cheese". webTitle: Internet site arranges marriage of old and new

fields.headline: Internet site arranges marriage of old and new
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: First there was online shopping, then came internet dating. Now to the burgeoning list of traditional activities going hi-tech, a British businessman has added another: arranged marriages.
fields.body:
First there was online shopping, then came internet dating. Now to the burgeoning list of traditional activities going hi-tech, a British businessman has added another: arranged marriages.

Sadiq Shah, from Luton, has launched a website aimed at Asian parents who are struggling against the tide of progress to find suitable spouses for their offspring.

Within a month, the site, www.kuchkuchhotahai.net - named after the Bollywood movie Something Something is Happening Now - has attracted 200 members.

Prospective brides and grooms, and their parents, can sift through a database which carries photographs of potential partners and personal details such as height, weight, likes and dislikes. Once a likely candidate has been selected, a fee of £19.99 buys further information and a supervised introduction.

Mr Shah, 33, a father of five who runs a fabric shop, is also planning a blind date service. The Cilla Black role will be left to the computer which will select two members it thinks are compatible. They will be contacted to see if they wish to meet.

The service would breathe new life into a traditional practice, Mr Shah said. "Ten years ago things were different, but the youngsters who have been brought up in this country are well educated and want a lot more out of prospective partner and they want a say in the decision.

"Parents are finding that they have nowhere to go. We are saying to parents if you are not computer literate get the kids to help you. Work together to find someone that everyone is happy with."

He added: "Traditions may change but arranged marriages are still going strong and research shows that arranged marriages are more successful than conventional love matches."

webTitle: Dock worker found 'sea of bodies' in lorry

fields.headline: Dock worker found 'sea of bodies' in lorry
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A dock worker found "a sea of bodies" when he searched a container lorry used to smuggle Chinese illegal immigrants, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A dock worker found "a sea of bodies" when he searched a container lorry used to smuggle Chinese illegal immigrants, a court heard yesterday.

Barry Betts, a freight supervisor, was called to assist in the unloading of cargo believed to be tomatoes, after the lorry, driven by Perry Wacker, 33, of Rotterdam, was stopped by customs officers in the early hours of June 20 last year after disembarking from the Zeebrugge ferry.

Inside, behind a screen of tomato boxes, Mr Betts found the bodies of 54 male and four female Chinese. There were two others still alive among them.

Mr Betts and his assistant, Darren Bailey, were asked to help unload the tomatoes so that customs and immigration officials could search the container properly. When the men arrived at the lorry, others had begun to remove the tomatoes, stacked in a specially constructed frame to stop their collapse on to the illegal immigrants. Mr Betts and Mr Bailey were the first people to climb inside the lorry.

"When I got to the area people were already unloading boxes. I could clearly see the body of a young Chinese man where the boxes had been, possibly a teenager," said Mr Betts in a statement read out at the fourth day of the trial at Maidstone crown court. "Myself and Darren Bailey got inside and I can remember it was very hot - when refrigerated containers carrying fruit are normally cold.

"We were clearing tomatoes from around this male's body, and as I shone my torch in and peered past the wooden structures holding up the boxes into the darkness, I was confronted by a sea of bodies which all appeared to be motionless.

"It was very hot in this part of the trailer and I shouted to colleagues to get ambulances. I could see a young boy who was tapping the side of the container to try to attract our attention. Darren was trying to coax him out but he appeared reluctant. After a few moments he started to come towards us. As I helped him out I had my hands and arms around his bare chest, as he wasn't wearing a shirt, and he was incredibly hot for a human.

"I remember seeing another young man moving and he began climbing over other bodies, we helped him out. It was clear there was no one else alive. I can remember a paramedic checking the first body in the container for a pulse and saying he was dead."

In his statement, Mr Bailey said that when he arrived it was clear "this was not the normal run-of-the-mill unloading job". His statement said: "There were tomatoes all over the floor and there was commotion. I immediately saw one male half buried, at the rear of the lorry. It appeared he had been trying to get under a gap in the pallets, and had collapsed."

Mr Bailey described how he helped the first survivor to safety after hearing him tapping on the side of the lorry.

"I could see a body moving so I called for quiet and a torch. I could see a person, which I believe was a teenage girl, she was lying still with her mouth open and eyes closed. I thought the floor was covered in fallen pallets. After taking a proper look I realised it was covered with bodies.

"I heard a noise, and looked left and saw a young boy eating a tomato. We gestured for him to come out. I told him he was okay and he came out."

Lisa Quigley, a customs dog handler at the scene, described Wacker's reaction on hearing that there could be bodies in the lorry. "He looked stunned," she said. "He looked at me and said 'What?'" Ms Quigley also said that Wacker had laughed when one of the officers dropped a box of the tomatoes. "I heard the driver chuckle ...and he was smiling," she said.

Andrew Smith, a customs and excise freight anti-smuggling officer, told the court that Wacker's lorry had been stopped because the company to which it was registered, Van Der Speck Transport, was not known to officials at Dover, and the driver had paid cash.

Mr Smith's first reaction on opening the rear doors was surprise, the court heard: "I expected it to be cold," he said. "Usually there is a blast of cold air but it was warm air."

The crown alleges that Wacker and his co-defendant, Ying Guo, an interpreter, were part of a Chinese snakehead trafficking gang and had conspired to organise the transport.

Wacker denies 58 counts of manslaughter and four counts of conspiracy to smuggle people into Britain. Guo, 29, of South Woodford, Essex, denies a count of conspiracy to smuggle immigrants into the UK.

The trial continues.

webTitle: BA crews to face spot checks for drink and drugs

fields.headline: BA crews to face spot checks for drink and drugs
fields.standfirst: Transport in the UK
fields.trailText: British Airways is to introduce spot checks for alcohol and drugs on pilots and cabin crew within months, the company announced yesterday.
fields.body:
British Airways is to introduce spot checks for alcohol and drugs on pilots and cabin crew within months, the company announced yesterday.

The procedure is likely to follow the pattern of the railway industry, where staff have to agree to random testing in circumstances where the company thinks a test is necessary.

BA's announcement was made after it revealed that eight of 11 pilots suspended after they had been exposed in a drinking scandal by Channel 4 television were back at work. They include two who were later sacked for gross misconduct but reinstated on appeal.

BA said last night that it was still negotiating with the airline pilots' union, Balpa, about the agreement on random testing. But it promised to make it wide ranging and comprehensive "to prevent a similar occurence".

BA said it had carried out an "exhaustive investigation" of the incidents, that had involved going through hundreds of hours of videotape. This involved those concerned as well as hotel and bar staff where the incidents took place.

BA said that safety was "absolutely paramount" and it would take action against flight crew who had beeen drinking.

BA said that of the other crew initially suspended, two were found to have no case to answer, and one still had a case pending which had been postponed because of ill health. Three others received written warnings and one a verbal warning.

BA said that in the case of the eight, insufficient evidence had been produced by the Channel 4 film that the crews had been breaking existing rules. These ban crew from drinking in the eight hours before take off. In the 16 hours before that, they are limited to two and a half pints of beer or its equivalent.

At least two of the staff have been fined more than £10,000 by the company and given a final warning about their conduct. The remainder have also been given stiff financial penalties.

The Air Transport Users' Council yesterday welcomed BA's decision to put in place safety measures to make sure that such incidents did not occur again.

It said that BA's decision to reinstate eight pilots was an internal matter.

The Department of Transport is planning to introduce an alcohol limit on pilots four times tougher than the drink driving limit, but the legislation has yet to go on the statute books.

The civil aviation authority said there was nothing to stop pilots flying again following disciplinary matters so long as they passed regular medicals.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: In a break from one's traditional weekend activities (executive paintballing with the cat not being available due to foot and mouth), Sidelines took the unwary step of attending a "gig".
fields.body:
In a break from one's traditional weekend activities (executive paintballing with the cat not being available due to foot and mouth), Sidelines took the unwary step of attending a "gig". Unused to such youthful enterprises, I had to be restrained from bringing my own rug and shooting stick, and was relieved to find it involved a large American man who looked like he'd be perfectly capable atop a John Deere, and a minimum of pale girls in need of thick soup. The "gig" passed without incident, but did lead Sidelines to ponder whether there ought to be a sheet of rules handed to people attending such functions, so they know how to behave. Take nodding. Very limited up and down nodding is acceptable. Woo-y, side to side, eyes closed nodding is not. Circling of the shoulders, meanwhile, is illegal.

Afterwards, Sidelines went home, too tired for sex, but in good company. According to the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development, more than half of those who work more than 48 hours a week don't feel like sex when they get home. Does this mean that all those unfortunate people who appear eager to have sex with you, often in bars, late in the day, are working less than 48 hours? Lucky, lucky, lucky bleeders. At least this offers up a further reason to reject them. But why has nobody told Jeffrey Archer that successful professionals no longer screw? It would save our brains from a lot of unnecessary information.

fields.headline: Robert Mugabe and me
fields.standfirst:
Two weeks ago, journalist Mercedes Sayagues was thrown out of Zimbabwe. Now she is living out of a suitcase. What next for this thorn in the president's side? Lesley Riddoch asks her

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago, journalist Mercedes Sayagues was thrown out of Zimbabwe. Now she is living out of a suitcase. What next for this thorn in the president's side?  Lesley Riddoch asks her.
fields.body:
Mercedes Sayagues, scathing freelance critic of Robert Mugabe's ZANU regime, takes over the reception phone of her temporary hotel home in Mozambique to keep the heat on her adversary till she drops.

"Typical!" she exclaims of his current trip to Europe. "The French will back any dictator if he has a big enough bank account. They should be ashamed."

The Zimbabwean president earned worldwide criticism for the arbitrary deportation of "foreign" journalists two weeks ago. One was BBC correspondent Joe Winter, the other Mercedes Sayagues, a 47-year-old Uruguayan national, single mother, freelance reporter for the South Africa-based weekly Mail and Guardian, and occasional Observer contributor. This week, Mugabe is guest of honour in Paris, welcomed as head of state by President Chirac. Sayagues, meanwhile, has nothing but a hotmail address.

She had worked for almost a decade in Zimbabwe and had been on a two-day trip to Johannesburg when immigration officers stopped her at Harare airport on February 17 and said her work permit had expired and would not be renewed. She was given 24 hours to leave the country. Had it not been for the fact that Esmerelda, her nine-year-old daughter, was still at school in Harare, she might never have seen Zimbabwe again.

Sayagues was allowed a further 24 hours to collect her child and leave, but she decided to tough it out and stay to fight the deportation through the courts. While the flight of the BBC correspondent with his wife and child grabbed the headlines, Sayagues and Esmerelda moved to a safe house. The international outcry initially provided a useful screen as friends came in and out to sell her car, to bring clothes, ornaments, books, cups and cutlery to share out among friends, and to deliver mail.

But soon the situation became more fraught. Sayagues' picture was on every TV station every hour. The government said her home had been abandoned and described her as a "prohibited immigrant" which meant that she could be grabbed from the street without explanation. Trips outside needed a bodyguard - "lent" by a female opposition MP. On the final trip to her lawyer, it started pouring with rain. "We had to use umbrellas for camouflage," she says. "I had a huge black one pulled down to cover my face; the only other one was Esmerelda's pink mermaid umbrella. I've a feeling the six-foot karate expert with a girl's pink brolly gave the game away."

Though the prospects of a Mugabe backdown didn't look good, Sayagues argued her case before she finally left the country on February 22. "They really get a kick out of it, seeing people running scared," she says. "You should stand up to bullies because sometimes they back down."

Sayagues learned her journalism and her activism at the same time. At the age of 17, she helped launch the magazine Opinar in opposition to the military dictatorship in her native Uruguay. "I know what it is to live without rights and how vigilant you have to be," she says. "When the rights are gone, you are in deep shit."

She left her homeland in 1984, just as the dictatorship was replaced in democratic elections, and studied for an MA in journalism in New York. From 1990 she worked for the UN world food programme as a senior information officer, moving to Zimbabwe in 1992. Two years later, she lost her impressive UN salary after being ordered to a new posting in Yugoslavia at the same time as apartheid was ending in South Africa. "It was financial suicide but how could I leave?"

She stayed on and began working as a journalist. Her main outlet outside Africa was the Worldwoman web paper which I edit. Founded in 1999, it's an online newspaper written by women around the world, which aims to give a northern voice to southern journalists in developing countries without liberty or profile in their own country.

Last year she wrote about the farcical election that kept Mugabe in power, describing one opposition rally and its bloody aftermath. She attacked "that nice man" former vice president Gore for supporting the big US pharmaceutical companies such as Glaxo as they tried to prevent poor governments developing generic versions of drugs to treat HIV. She also discussed a huge taboo - the fact that the male preference for dry sex has a significant impact on HIV transmission rates across Southern Africa. Women use herbal powders to prevent lubrication during intercourse, which can result in tearing and easier virus transmission.

It takes a remarkable doggedness to keep optimism and journalistic standards high in such a situation. When I first met Sayagues, two years ago, she brought to a halt my training seminar on editoral skills by demanding an apology. It seems a local Harare organiser had urged journalists to commit for the entire day's training or not to come. Impossible for a freelance, she said; impossible for a single mother. Of course she was right. But how many of her female colleagues would have dared mention any domestic obstacle to work?

She recounts the story of an 80-year-old illiterate peasant woman whose son was a supporter of the MDC opposition party. A gang of ZANU supporters turned up at her home and threatened to beat her. She said: "Beat me - it won't change me."

"She could withstand threats without options, without a CV, without connections, without cash," Sayagues says. "In that case, so can I."

Which helps explain why she decided to stay those extra dangerous days in Zimbabwe. Sayagues felt she was being judged, not just as a journalist but as a player. She played by the rules, Mugabe does not.

And now? "I can't plan," Sayagues says. "I want to take Esmerelda to Disneyworld. She deserves it. She keeps asking when she can go back to school. Will she have to miss her sports day. It breaks my heart but I have to be strong."

She has seven days' work left with Unesco in Mozambique, then the hope of a job offer in South Africa with a British-based charity. But in the long term, she says, there can be only one destination. Mr Mugabe, you have been warned.

 Lesley Riddoch is Worldwoman editor - www.worldwoman.net.
To contact Mercedes Sayagues, email lesley.riddoch@virgin.net

While the flight of the BBC correspondent with his wife and child grabbed the headlines, Sayagues and Esmerelda moved to a safe house. The international outcry initially provided a useful screen as friends came in and out to sell her car, to bring clothes, ornaments, books, cups and cutlery to share out among friends, and to deliver mail. But soon the situation became more fraught. Sayagues' picture was on every TV station every hour. The government said her home had been abandoned and described her as a "prohibited immigrant" which meant that she could be grabbed from the street without explanation. Trips outside needed a bodyguard - "lent" by a female opposition MP. On the final trip to her lawyer, it started pouring with rain. "We had to use umbrellas for camouflage," she says. "I had a huge black one pulled down to cover my face; the only other one was Esmerelda's pink mermaid umbrella. I've a feeling the six-foot karate expert with a girl's pink brolly gave the game away." Though the prospects of a Mugabe backdown didn't look good, Sayagues argued her case before she finally left the country on February 22. "They really get a kick out of it, seeing people running scared," she says. "You should stand up to bullies because sometimes they back down." Sayagues learned her journalism and her activism at the same time. At the age of 17, she helped launch the magazine Opinar in opposition to the military dictatorship in her native Uruguay. "I know what it is to live without rights and how vigilant you have to be," she says. "When the rights are gone, you are in deep shit." She left her homeland in 1984, just as the dictatorship was replaced in democratic elections, and studied for an MA in journalism in New York. From 1990 she worked for the UN world food programme as a senior information officer, moving to Zimbabwe in 1992. Two years later, she lost her impressive UN salary after being ordered to a new posting in Yugoslavia at the same time as apartheid was ending in South Africa. "It was financial suicide but how could I leave?" She stayed on and began working as a journalist. Her main outlet outside Africa was the Worldwoman web paper which I edit. Founded in 1999, it's an online newspaper written by women around the world, which aims to give a northern voice to southern journalists in developing countries without liberty or profile in their own country. Last year she wrote about the farcical election that kept Mugabe in power, describing one opposition rally and its bloody aftermath. She attacked "that nice man" former vice president Gore for supporting the big US pharmaceutical companies such as Glaxo as they tried to prevent poor governments developing generic versions of drugs to treat HIV. She also discussed a huge taboo - the fact that the male preference for dry sex has a significant impact on HIV transmission rates across Southern Africa. Women use herbal powders to prevent lubrication during intercourse, which can result in tearing and easier virus transmission. It takes a remarkable doggedness to keep optimism and journalistic standards high in such a situation. When I first met Sayagues, two years ago, she brought to a halt my training seminar on editoral skills by demanding an apology. It seems a local Harare organiser had urged journalists to commit for the entire day's training or not to come. Impossible for a freelance, she said; impossible for a single mother. Of course she was right. But how many of her female colleagues would have dared mention any domestic obstacle to work? She recounts the story of an 80-year-old illiterate peasant woman whose son was a supporter of the MDC opposition party. A gang of ZANU supporters turned up at her home and threatened to beat her. She said: "Beat me - it won't change me." "She could withstand threats without options, without a CV, without connections, without cash," Sayagues says. "In that case, so can I." Which helps explain why she decided to stay those extra dangerous days in Zimbabwe. Sayagues felt she was being judged, not just as a journalist but as a player. She played by the rules, Mugabe does not. And now? "I can't plan," Sayagues says. "I want to take Esmerelda to Disneyworld. She deserves it. She keeps asking when she can go back to school. Will she have to miss her sports day. It breaks my heart but I have to be strong." She has seven days' work left with Unesco in Mozambique, then the hope of a job offer in South Africa with a British-based charity. But in the long term, she says, there can be only one destination. Mr Mugabe, you have been warned.  Lesley Riddoch is Worldwoman editor - www.worldwoman.net. To contact Mercedes Sayagues, email lesley.riddoch@virgin.net

fields.headline: An unlikely hero
fields.standfirst: A tiny village in Germany is on the verge of being wiped out by a huge mining conglomerate. So how come the man most likely to save it is a Brit?
fields.trailText: A tiny village in Germany is on the verge of being wiped out by a huge mining conglomerate. So how come the man most likely to save it is a Brit?
fields.body:
Geil auf Horno! " the sticker on the door to Michael Gromm's Berlin flat announces to visitors. The slogan translates into "Horny for Horno!" Though lacking in subtlety, it succinctly sums up the passion that the Englishman feels for the tiny east German village. He has been fighting to save Horno (population: 330) from total destruction by mining for more than eight years.

Gromm, a postman's son, grew up in London, near Hampstead Heath. But he has lived in Germany since 1974. He feels more comfortable speaking German than his native tongue. But Gromm is also a Sorb - the only Sorb in the world, he claims, to hold a British passport. The Sorbs are a little-known 60,000-strong Slavic minority that has lived in what is now the eastern edge of Germany for at least 13 centuries. Gromm discovered that he had Sorb blood while researching a novel in the early 1990s. He traced his roots to a Sorb village 15km across the border in Poland called Chlebowa in Polish or Niemasch Kleba - Sorbian for "Haven't got any bread". While spending time in the area, he became interested and, finally, deeply involved in the story of Horno.

Gromm becomes impassioned and animated when discussing the plight of the village. He has written two books in German on Horno and is planning a third entitled Black Raven, Black Robe. The raven refers to the harbinger of death in Krabat, an old Sorb saga. The black robe stands for those he blames for Horno's woes, Germany's judicial system.

He calls lignite (brown coal) mining the "messenger of death for Sorb culture". Opencast mines wiped out about 100 Sorb villages in the 20th century - 73 during communist rule in East Germany. More than 20,000 people lost their homes. After consuming everything in their path, the coal-extracting machines leave behind a bleak and barren moonscape.

A two-hour drive away from Berlin, the 650-year-old village lies in fields of grain just 500m from the river Neisse and the Polish border. About 1.5km to the south, where there was once a forest, the "Horno Mountain", the highest hill for miles, is being chewed away by a herd of bulldozers and digging machines. Beyond the rise is a view of Horno's possible fate: an 80m- to 90m-deep man-made valley of brown and black layers. A 650m-long steel leviathan straddles the valley. The mining company that operates it, Laubag, calls it "the world's largest movable technical device". While coal is dug out from the bottom of the valley by other machines and transported to the massive Jänschwalde power plant up the road, this "conveyor bridge" travels back and forth, shaving away virgin land. It dumps it on to the other side of the pit, filling it up again as it moves north, towards Horno, at a rate of 10m a week.

"The edge [of the mine] is just one-and-a-half kilometres away. Some of the older people, they just can't cope," says the mayor, Bernd Siegert. As he sips a beer in his cosy living room, Siegert's forehead is creased with worry. "A lot of the people here are being forced to move for the second time in their lives," he adds, referring to the massive influx of German - many of whom were ethnic Sorb - refugees from what is now Poland after the second world war.

After German reunification in 1990, the Hornoers were given new hope when the country's then chancellor, Helmut Kohl, announced in an election campaign speech in nearby Cottbus that lignite mining - which has long been the economic lifeblood of the region - would be kept alive, but that no more Sorb villages would be destroyed.

The villagers quickly learned not to trust campaign promises, and were soon embroiled in a battle against both Laubag and the state government of Brandenburg. Despite a clause in the state's post-reunification constitution explicitly protecting Sorb villages, politicians began to toe the line of the energy and mining industries, as well as the miners' union. Each of these vested interests shouted: "But we have to save the jobs."

Laubag was formed in 1992 by the privatisation of the former East German state mining firm, on the promise that jobs would be saved. They weren't: in 1989 more than 100,000 people were employed in East Germany's lignite-mining industry; less than 10,000 jobs remain. "It's an economic disaster," Gromm says. "The jobs are gone. And when the mining comes to an end in the next few years, the whole region will go will down the drain."

For years, Laubag has been trying to buy up land in Horno, from the kindergarten to the churchyard to farmland, to ensure that the mine can continue to supply the power plant. Those villagers who don't sell their land voluntarily will probably be forced to sell and move out by next year. The Brandenburg state mining office, which oversees the industry, will file "property transfer proceedings" against each homeowner who refuses to budge, on the grounds that the common economic good takes precedence over the Hornoers' rights.

Gromm, 57, became interested in Horno in 1992 and has launched or aided several legal battles to save the village. He has fought for his rights as a member of the Sorb minority and as a Horno property owner: the village council gave him a three square metre triangular traffic island. Gromm - throwing in a little Dadaist humour to keep up morale - christened this the Horno Golf Course. Even if the rest of the village residents give in, Gromm has vowed that he will never sell his land to Laubag.

Gromm and the Hornoers have had bad luck in the courts. Having suffered several legal defeats in Germany, in 1999 they took their case to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg. They argued that the destruction of the village went against the right of the Sorbs to maintain their way of life and culture as guaranteed by the Brandenburg constitution.

Last June, the court refused even to hear Horno's case against the German government, calling the destruction of the village a "serious but, relatively speaking, permissible encroachment of human rights". Gromm says German courts are far too easily influenced by politics and operate at a snail's pace.

The writer's latest target is the state-owned Swedish utility Vattenfall. The firm owns the majority stake in HEW, an electricity provider in Hamburg that is expected to buy Laubag and Veag, the firm that runs east Germany's lignite-fired power plants. Gromm sees this as a chance to bring Horno's cause to the international stage.

Domowina, the local Sorb cultural association, has asked him to organise an appeal to convince Vattenfall to halt the mining. Once the sale of Laubag to Vattenfall has been finalised, he plans to stage a "spectacular action" in Sweden and launch a worldwide appeal to minority organisations to put pressure on Vattenfall and the Swedish government. "What interest does the Swedish people have in the destruction of Sorb villages in Germany?" asks Gromm.

Meanwhile, the earth-churning monster creeps towards Horno. At the yet-to-be-built New Horno, Laubag is supposed to provide housing of "equal worth" for the displaced inhabitants. "If they have golden taps in the old house, we have to replace them," says Roger Kohlmann, a spokesman for the company. "In fact, they will probably end up making a profit." But for the many Horno residents who hang on to the very German concept of Heimat , a home rooted in land and community, such promises don't offer much comfort. Paul Noack, a former bricklayer who has lived there since 1948, says: "We'll have to start everything again: our gardens, our fruit trees. That's no village life."

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
The snow melts, but tempers continue to rise in the country

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The snow melts, but tempers continue to rise in the country
fields.body:
The temperature outside has risen considerably in the past few hours, inducing a partial thaw. But the livestock farmers grow steadily more angry at the time taken to cull and burn the infected cases; and as the suspected cases edge nearer to us all the stomach-churning fear bites even harder. Our friends are still waiting to hear whether they are a confirmed, rather than a suspected case, and this is driving them insane - and they have a calf with a big blister. They are angry that the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) has not even rung to see if things are worse. The tests were taken on February 27 and still they wait . . .

Keeping track of the known cases is becoming increasingly hard. I have a map marked with crosses and this helps me to plan routes if and when we need to leave the farm. My daughter Victoria's dental brace has broken which means a special trip to the dental hospital in Newcastle to get it fixed. I've mapped out a special route to Newcastle, avoiding all the farms that are officially confirmed to have foot and mouth, but this will add 20 minutes to our expected journey time. It's normally 28 miles, but I think it will be far more.

Peter is very anxious, as am I, yet we are so busy sorting out day-to-day problems that somehow we keep going. Sleeping is easier as the numbing worry induces exhaustion and this eventually knocks us out, although not every night.

Just now, Peter is welding a gate and post back together from the cattle shed; the electricity supply flickers as he welds. Overnight the yearling cattle (last year's calves) broke down the solid metal gate-posts and mixed with the cows and new calves. No lasting damage was done to any of the animals, but it all takes time to sort out and this is time that should be spent in getting ready for lambing at the end of the month.

The task of the day is to move straw and hay bales from one shed to another so that we can begin to build 120 individual sheep pens from wooden hurdles, tied together with the "farmer's friend" - baler twine. Once the ewes have lambed they spend one or two days inside, so the lambs can gain in strength.

Education in the area is still severely disrupted, as anyone with any contact with animals is told to stay away - and this affects both the teachers and the children. Our children have been stuck at home since half-term. Julie and Nick Howard farm near Allendale, 25 miles away: Julie is the science teacher at Allendale middle school. Since last week she has been barred from school and the strain is beginning to tell. She does not want to leave either her husband to fend for himself, or her pupils to remain untaught especially since the key stage-two science tests are due soon. And on top of that her two eldest daughters, Laura and Vicky, are studying for A and AS levels and GCSEs respectively.

Plans are being made today to try to send Laura to stay with friends as she has been offered an RAF scholarship to study medicine at Edinburgh on condition of three A grades. And Haydon Bridge high school is believed to be taking advice from the examination board on changing GSCE course work dates for its affected pupils.

As for the cyclist who literally barged through our cows last week, one of our neighbours did see and challenge him, as it turns out. They weren't sure whether to send him back or let him go, however. Eventually they let him pass, but he said he was local, which we all think is much worse. Since the snow drifts were so high everyone is wondering why he was even out.

Another neighbouring farmer, John Browell, is trying to get a movement order from Maff to bring back 130 ewes to their main farm from another field three miles away - his sheep are due to start lambing any day. These movement restrictions, however necessary, could not come at a worse time for many sheep farmers, especially flocks farther south, since March and April is peak lambing season. The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She is writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

fields.headline: Weeping for the country
fields.standfirst: The Tory leader tried to raise the spectre of a 'foreign' Britain in his pre-election speech
fields.trailText: The Tory leader tried to raise the spectre of a 'foreign' Britain in his pre-election speech
fields.body:
Let me take you on a journey to a foreign party. The party is called the Conservative party. It used to belong to Britain as much as Britain belonged to it. For 70 years of the 20th century it owned the politics and government of its country. The voters saw it as the party of the nation. But now it is a foreign party. It has become something altogether other. This means that anyone who votes for it next time may be doing so for the last time. People should understand this. Unless they do so very soon, an independent and sovereign Conservative party will become nothing more than an offshore pimple on the British body politic.

Its transformation has been extraordinarily sudden. So much history was sacrificed so fast, burned on the pyres of zealotry and desperation. The philistines, who remember nothing, are now in charge. Insofar as they know history, they despise its compromises. Like the Taliban, they seem bent on smashing every memorable idol, above all the claim they once had to be the party of the British people.

This claim goes back longer than 70 years. Throughout the 19th century, Conservatives adapted to the society around them. That's why they enjoyed a longer continuous history than any other European party. From Peel to Disraeli, they became the party of one English nation. From Baldwin to Macmillan, they rode the tides of peacetime Britain, banishing ideology, speaking for the people, sucking up the votes. From Edward Heath to Margaret Thatcher, they remained at the centre of the centre ground, wherever that came to be defined. They were, in fact, its definers. Mrs Thatcher became an ideologue, but she was not foreign. She knew what the British people wanted. From this position she won three elections.

Now, something important has changed. The state of society is no longer the Conservatives' guide to political survival. For society, they say, is mistaken. Instead of listening to the people, the Tories want to fight them. The people have made some big mistakes. They gave Labour a landslide victory in 1997. From there the people have gone downhill all the way. After four years, they continue to reward Mr Blair with a 15-point lead in the opinion polls. Something must be wrong. It isn't, of course, the Conservative party. The party is in denial about all that.

The people, for example, have watched their country being parcelled up and given away. Scottish devolution was agreed by the Scots and accepted by the English, and is working in conformity with a promise made at the last election. But the Conservatives cannot credit that. By raving against its iniquities, they announce their distance from the people. They are stepping away from being fully British. This is only the beginning of a hallucination that Disraeli and Macmillan and even the pre-retirement Thatcher strove always to discourage: the belief that the people cannot be right.

That judgment reaches into every cranny of what Labour has done. The government's persistent popularity is simply, we learn, an error. The British people are prepared to pay their taxes, they want better public services, and support the chancellor and prime minister who have been in charge of the modest social democratic progress of the last four years. But in Tory eyes, this is an aberration. The government's anti-progressive side, also popular, is another fraud. Having been even more reactionary than the Tories on issues of liberty and law, asylum and immigration, Blair and Straw may have gained votes, but this is all part of a package designed to take the country from the "decent, plain-speaking people", as the Tory leader called them this weekend.

Only a party that has become foreign - alien - could seriously believe that. Conservatism, we discover from William Hague and Michael Ancram, is alienated from reality. It doesn't merely believe that Blair, the people's choice by a mile, is wrong. It says that he is not, at a deeper level, entitled to be prime minister. That was the message from Harrogate, with its references to the "stench" of Blairism, as compared with the simon-pure days of John Major. It has become the seigneurial presumption of Mr Ancram, a mild man now evincing apocalyptic rage at the presence of these filthy upstarts in the seats of power, stealing the very birthright of the British - the same British people who are about to cast the Tories once again into electoral darkness.

There are those who believe the latest Conservative synthesis is a pose, and that the party is not really accelerating towards the fringe. Forgive them their madness, they have nothing else to say. Wait until they get back to power, we are assured. They'll sober up, regain their balance. In particular, wait for this moment to see the return of realism on the issue where, at present, they are most obsessed with the image of the theft of a nation: Europe.

The chances of this happening seem slight. For a start, until they remake contact with the centre ground, they will never get back. But leave that small point aside, and observe the depth of their unrepentance. Call them extreme, and they reach further towards xenophobia, sneering at foreign doctors. Call them racist, and they plumb the richer subtexts of political incorrectness, vowing to lock up all asylum seekers, implying that foreigners are not welcome, suggesting that Britain will soon no longer be Britain because of them.

Call Hague reactionary, and he plunges deeper into promises of more prison than Mr Straw. Call him a nationalist, and he exposes hostility for the European Union of a breadth he's never shown before. He promises to march into the EU demanding a new agriculture policy, a new fishing policy and a torn-up treaty of Nice. These statements do not connect with reality. Far from pointing to the broad uplands, he plunges deeper into the fetid cave that offers very temporary security. Fearful and disgusted, Michael Heseltine even contemplates not voting Conservative. Habit called him back, but he thought about it publicly. Disraeli would have seen such a danger coming. Macmillan would have learned the lesson. Thatcher spent a decade keeping the broad church together. But modern Conservatism neither understands nor respects the people. Let me take you on a journey to the party that is leaving its country behind.

fields.headline: No 1832 Daniel Hannan
fields.trailText: Age: 29, going on 89.
fields.body:
Age: 29, going on 89.

Appearance: Even the Daily Telegraph calls him "tweedy".

Why are you bothering me with this inconsequential young fogey? Because Dan is an MEP for the Euro-province of south-east England and therefore very important. He is also credited with writing William Hague's "Britain will be a foreign land" speech.

Gosh, I didn't realise William was so depressed about his prospects that he's going to emigrate. Alas, he's not. He was warning us against those wily Europeans plotting to melt down our pounds and steal our national identity.

Not again. I'm afraid William is a moderate on the subject of Europe compared to Dan, who could bore for England on the subject, though for no other country. He does so regularly in the Daily Telegraph.

Come again? Though barely old enough to remember the Spice Girls, he has written books with titles like Britain in a Multi-Speed Europe and A Guide to the Amsterdam Treaty.

Let me guess, he's against them. Well spotted. He writes sentences such as, "Danes have an attachment to freedom that we seem to have lost", and, "When truly vital matters are at stake, the blood of the English-speaking peoples is thicker than the water of the Channel". His hobby is "English poetry".

But surely Dan keeps reminding readers that he was raised in South America. He does. He also reminds them that General Pinochet's arrest was "the most shameful episode in Britain's history" since we declared war on Finland in 1941.

Not many people know that. Who won? Long-term, the Finns. So did their mobile phones. Pinochet lost.

Is it true Dan commissioned his own EU Christmas card, depicting himself in defiant pose in front of the All-White Cliffs of Dover ? "The printers in my own constituency needed the business," he claimed.

Sad or what? I'm beginning to feel sorry for the little creep. Don't!

webTitle: America's eco-arsonists put heat on the FBI

fields.headline: America's eco-arsonists put heat on the FBI
fields.standfirst: Underground activists in US-wide arson attacks on 'pillagers of planet'
fields.trailText: Their message is explicit: "You build it, we burn it." They have caused more than $45m (£31m) of damage in attacks across the United States. They say they were inspired by British environmental campaigners and are regarded by the FBI as belonging to one of the fastest-growing terrorist groupings in the US.
fields.body:
Their message is explicit: "You build it, we burn it." They have caused more than $45m (£31m) of damage in attacks across the United States. They say they were inspired by British environmental campaigners and are regarded by the FBI as belonging to one of the fastest-growing terrorist groupings in the US. This week they claimed responsibility for an attack in California.

They are members of the Earth Liberation Front (ELF) and a previously unknown group called the Coalition to Save the Preserves (CSP), which has carried out arson attacks in Arizona. The two groups describe each other as "kindred spirits" and both use variations on the "build it, burn it" slogan.

As the authorities seek information on the ELF and CSP, journalists and environmental campaigners who have been contacted by the groups have been followed, had their homes raided and served with injunctions and subpoenas.

In the three years since its foundation, the ELF has become probably the most active underground group in the US, attracting the attention of the authorities from coast to coast. Its members' success in avoiding capture and carrying out spectacular attacks on property has increased the pressure on the FBI to make arrests.

This week the ELF claimed responsibility for a warehouse fire in Visalia, California in February. Its communique said the target was chosen because it "contained massive quantities of transgenic cotton seed in storage. But now, this seed will no longer exist to contaminate the environment, enrich a sick corporation, or contribute to its warped research programmes."

In January the group said that it smashed the windows of two buildings nearing completion in Louisville, Kentucky, and warned that "the once beautiful farmlands of eastern Jefferson county, Kentucky are being destroyed by earth rapers .. This was the first, be it minor, direct action. It will be a long fought battle and more actions are planned in the future."

The CSP has claimed responsibility for 11 arson attacks on homes on the edge of a desert preserve outside Phoenix, Arizona, causing around $5m of damage and leaving a note which read: "U Build It We Burn It - Again."

In Long Island the message, this time from the ELF, is the same. After the torching of a housing development, a statement read: "The actions of those who orchestrated the construction are absolutely intolerable, so we are now declaring an unbounded war on urban sprawl."

Last month the ELF said it burned down a lumber company's offices in Glendale, Oregon. It has recently made clear its intention to escalate the battle and widen its targets to "capitalism and industry".

The increasing frequency of the attacks and the fact that they are being carried out across the country has alarmed the FBI, not least because the organisation, which operates with small independent cells, has been difficult to penetrate.

However, some arrests have been made. Frank Ambrose, an environmentalist in Bloomington, Indiana, is due to be appear in court in April in connection with "timber spiking" - sticking nails in trees to damage loggers' chain saws. He denies the charges.

Three teenagers have been arrested in connection with the Long Island attacks.

In Portland, Oregon, environmentalists have been served with subpoenas to testify about the work of the ELF and the Animal Liberation Front.

Craig Rosebraugh, a spokesman for the North American Earth Liberation Front press office, explained yesterday why he believed that the organisation was able to carry out its attacks. "I think the individuals involved have a certain level of intelligence. There is no physical membership, no physical base, no hierarchy. It's an anonymous group that operates in underground cells and that makes it very difficult for the FBI to infiltrate," he said.

He said the group owed its origins to the direct action taken by environmentalists in Britain. US activists have been particularly impressed by the struggle against the Newbury bypass, which delayed the road building while gaining public support.

Mr Rosebraugh, who writes about the group in Earth First magazine, said his home had been raided and property seized. He also said he had been followed and called on to testify before a federal grand jury about the group's activities. He said the ELF was acting "out of self-defence - to preserve our air, our water and our soil .. As people see the destruction of our environment, they see what ELF is doing as a positive reaction."

James Hibberd, who has covered the arson attacks for the weekly Phoenix New Times in Arizona, has been put under pressure to assist the police after being contacted by the man who described himself as a member of a CSP cell. The county attorney went to court to make Mr Hibberd produce a tape recording supposedly made of the man's voice during his telephone call, so that police could try to match it with voice prints of a suspect. Mr Hibberd refused, citing state laws which allow a journalist to protect a source.

The man told Mr Hibberd that he was a management professional and family man with a "healthy income". He said he had no previous convictions and that the idea of the arson attacks came to him as he was mountain biking.

'Terrorist threat'

The FBI in Phoenix confirmed this week that they were investigating at least 10 separate arson attacks. An FBI spokeswoman in Portland said that the ELF had now claimed responsibility for more than 20 attacks. She said the group had been declared a "terrorist threat" by the FBI and department of justice.

The ELF keeps in touch with its supporters via its earthliberationfront.com website, which currently shows a photo of a burning building on its home page. It also includes advice on what to do "if an [FBI] agent knocks".

In the latest Earth First, a member of the ELF denies that the activists are terrorists. "We condemn all forms of terrorism. We are trying to cost the rich sprawl corporations enough money so they stop destroying the planet and the health, well-being and existence of humankind."
