webTitle: Record storm menaces millions in the US

fields.headline: Record storm menaces millions in the US
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Millions of inhabitants of the north-eastern US were bracing last night for a blizzard which was forecast to bring record amounts of snowfall and paralyse cities from Washington to Boston and beyond.
fields.body:
Millions of inhabitants of the north-eastern US were bracing last night for a blizzard which was forecast to bring record amounts of snowfall and paralyse cities from Washington to Boston and beyond.

Offices closed, schoolchildren were told to stay at home and transport and emergency services prepared for a shutdown lasting for at least 48 hours across much of the region. In Washington, many supermarkets have been out of supplies such as bread, milk, bottled water and batteries since Saturday morning.

The storm was taking shape as a cold weather system from Canada and damp air from the Gulf of Mexico combined in a blizzard which threatened to deposit as much as 3ft of snow in some inland areas.

"This storm will rank in the top 10 of March storms," a weather service meteorologist, Greg DeVoir, said.

"This is the one that the kids are going to look back on in years to come," another forecaster said, as weather experts predicted that it would snow for much of today and could continue into tomorrow.

Hundreds of flights into and out of the north-eastern US were cancelled. At New York's La Guardia airport, one airline, Delta, suspended all flights until further notice even before the storm arrived.

New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, told all non-essential workers to stay at home to avoid creating extra hazards on the roads. Articulated lorries were ordered to stay off main routes in Connecticut.

A state of emergency was declared across the state of New Jersey, which was expected to be hit particularly hard.

According to early reports, the snow was particularly heavy in north-eastern Pennsylvania, with more than a foot falling in the Allentown area by midday. But forecasters said the worst was yet to come, with 50mph winds whipping up blizzard conditions in parts of New England.

North-easterly winds drove tides 7-9ft above their normal limits in parts of New Jersey, where residents in some areas were told to evacuate.

fields.body:
Good day

The environment. Tony Blair will today announce a £100m boost for wind, solar and wave power, claiming that the UK can reap environmental and commercial advantage by investing in the new technologies.Mr Blair accepts that climate change means a real crisis facing the planet. The prime minister will predict a population crisis - up to 9bn by 2050 from 5.9bn in 1998 - and a crisis of flood and drought.

Bad day

The Bar, accused of "ageism" by a former director-general of Age Concern England, Lady Greengross, who told fellow peers that people of 35 were often regarded as too old to train as barristers.

Today

Commons: Scottish questions. International development bill, third reading. Lords: Capital allowances bill, third reading. Vehicles (crime) bill, committee stage.

webTitle: 'Bundle of joy' leaves you tied up in debt

fields.headline: 'Bundle of joy' leaves you tied up in debt
fields.trailText: It is supposed to be the best thing that ever happens to you, but from that first £9 on a pregnancy testing kit to £200 on toys, having a baby costs parents £20,315 for the first five years alone, research out today reveals.
fields.body:
It is supposed to be the best thing that ever happens to you, but from that first £9 on a pregnancy testing kit to £200 on toys, having a baby costs parents £20,315 for the first five years alone, research out today reveals.

And that is only accounts for a frugal upbringing, where a mother breastfeeds, buys high street clothes and spends moderate amounts on toys.

For parents who opt for something a little more ostentatious, from private hospital treatment to organic food for the baby, their bank balances will be dented to the tune of £35,956, says Pregnancy and Birth magazine.

For parents who both work, childcare adds another £7,000 a year. Cots, prams, buggies, baby seats and a highchair can cost between £700 and £2,000, depending on whether you opt for Mothercare or designer accessories.

Meanwhile, parents can expect to spend an extra £177 on household fuel and more than £800 more on motoring costs, with car seats, extra petrol and possibly an upgrade to accommodate the new baby.

But parents have to begin raiding their piggy banks long before that first sleepless night. The cheapest maternity wardrobe adds up to £176.

As Valery McConnell, the editor, said: "Having a baby is the best thing that will ever happen to you - and you can't put a price on that."

For parents who opt for something a little more ostentatious, from private hospital treatment to organic food for the baby, their bank balances will be dented to the tune of £35,956, says Pregnancy and Birth magazine. For parents who both work, childcare adds another £7,000 a year. Cots, prams, buggies, baby seats and a highchair can cost between £700 and £2,000, depending on whether you opt for Mothercare or designer accessories. Meanwhile, parents can expect to spend an extra £177 on household fuel and more than £800 more on motoring costs, with car seats, extra petrol and possibly an upgrade to accommodate the new baby. But parents have to begin raiding their piggy banks long before that first sleepless night. The cheapest maternity wardrobe adds up to £176. As Valery McConnell, the editor, said: "Having a baby is the best thing that will ever happen to you - and you can't put a price on that."

fields.headline: Colin Webster
fields.standfirst: He helped Manchester United recover from the Munich disaster
fields.trailText: Colin Webster, who has died of lung cancer at the age of 68, could well have been a victim of the Munich air crash of February 1958.
fields.body:
Colin Webster, who has died of lung cancer at the age of 68, could well have been a victim of the Munich air crash of February 1958. The Manchester United footballer, a Welsh international forward who could fill any role across the attack, would certainly have been on the trip - if only as a reserve - but had 'flu and did not go. A few weeks later, he figured at outside-right in the reconstituted United team, which beat Sheffield Wednesday 3-0 before a huge and emotional crowd at Old Trafford.

Born in Cardiff, Webster began his career with Cardiff City, before leaving for Manchester. Though he could never claim a regular place in the first team, he won a league championship medal in the 1955/56 season, making 15 appearances and scoring four goals. He was no giant, standing 5ft 9in and weighing just over 11 stone, but he could be an abrasive opponent. A somewhat languid gait concealed the fact that he had substantial pace.

He scored a respectable total of 31 goals in 79 games for United, and got one of their three European Cup goals at Old Trafford when they beat Dukla Prague 3-0 in 1957. Perhaps his most important goal came in United's post-Munich run in the FA Cup. A few minutes from time, in the team's home replay against West Bromwich Albion - largely dominated by the away side - Bobby Charlton controlled a long clearance, set off on a run past three opponents, and finally presented Webster with an open goal at the far post.

For Wales, Webster won only four caps, three of them in the World Cup finals of 1958 in Sweden. "Every time you knocked one of them down," he complained, after playing in a 1-1 draw against the Mexicans in Stockholm, "he cried, he cried!"

In sharp contrast to an over-regimented England team, the Welsh, who had reached the quarterfinals, had a happy and relaxed World Cup. Webster, John Charles, and the goalkeeper Jack Kelsey, strolling along the quayside in Saltsjobaden, where they were based, hired a boat for 10 kroner an hour, Webster assuring its owner that he was quite capable of handling it.

He duly took charge, and almost at once missed a yacht by a matter of inches. Then the engine failed and, while the horrified owner semaphored from the shore, the three Welsh footballers struggled to get the boat back. Webster declined to row, and it was Kelsey who slowly and laboriously brought the boat to shore.

In the quarterfinal at Gothenburg, an injury to John Charles, a mighty presence in the Welsh attack, enabled Webster to replace him. By an irony, an early cross from the Welsh rightwing created a chance which Charles, so powerful in the air, might well have put away, but it was too high for Webster. Eventually, Wales lost only 1-0 against Brazil, the eventual winners. The decider was a scrambled goal by Pele.

At the end of the 1958 season, Manchester United transferred Webster to Swansea Town, where he played for four seasons, scoring another 65 goals in 159 games. His last league club was Newport County, whom he joined during the 1962/63 season, playing for them until the end of 1963/64, with just three goals in 31 games.

 Colin Webster, footballer, born July 17 1932; died March 2 2001

fields.headline: Jack McVea
fields.standfirst: Innovative jazz musician whose big hit failed to save him from changing styles of music
fields.trailText: The career of Jack McVea, who has died aged 86, could serve as a template for the kinds of stylistic adjustments required of African-American jazz musicians of his generation.
fields.body:
The career of Jack McVea, who has died aged 86, could serve as a template for the kinds of stylistic adjustments required of African-American jazz musicians of his generation. Having started out as a sideman in big bands, where he built a reputation as a fine tenor-saxophone soloist, he achieved chart success in the 1940s with the r&b nonsense song, Open The Door, Richard. Its fame enabled him to tour successfully for months on end with his small combo until fashions changed.

McVea's father had been a musical pioneer in Los Angeles whose advertisements in the Yellow Pages, under his band name of Satchel McVea and his Howdy Entertainers, brought work playing at parties given by movie stars, or providing entertainment on set during the silent film era. His son was soon caught up in this heady activity, playing banjo from the age of 12 before moving on to saxophone when a member of the band died.

After leaving school in 1932, McVea was proficient enough on alto and tenor saxophones to work with all the best groups on Central Avenue, the main thoroughfare of black Los Angeles, including those of now-forgotten leaders like Dootsie Williams, Lorenzo Flemioy, and Cee Pee Johnson. 0ne highlight was a shortlived unit, led by the former Cab Calloway soloist Eddie Barefield, that also included tenor star Don Byas, whose muscular solo style proved a major influence on McVea.

Another key encounter came when he played alongside the young Art Pepper in Lee Young's band at the Club Alabarn. "Art couldn't play the arrangements; I taught him to read," McVea remembered.

His first major break came in 1940 when Lionel Hampton, fresh from his success with Benny Goodman, formed his own big band. McVea was persuaded to play baritone saxophone, looking on as the teenage Illionis Jacquet grabbed the limelight with Flying Home. In 1943, McVea returned to Los Angeles exhausted and ill, opting to concentrate on his studio calls, jam sessions for Norman Granz - including the first-ever Jazz at the Philharmonic concert, where he battled persuasively with Jacquet - and recording. He also formed the first of many small groups, inspired by the success of Louis Jordan, developing a brand of swingy, blues-orientated music best described as "jump jazz".

Something of an innovator in this, McVea seemed to have hit a happiness nerve for the burgeoning numbers of African-Americans attracted to Los Angeles by war work. His success accelerated with the recording of Open the Door, Richard, based on a routine popular in black vaudeville. With McVea listed as co-composer, this piece of flim-flam was covered by everyone from Count Basie to Louis Jordan, setting off a series of "response" numbers - and, people thought, surely earning McVea a fortune. Not so. In an overly-familiar scenario, he was denied his royalties, due to record company chicanery, only obtaining partial restitution later.

Now fronting the Door Openers, McVea recorded and toured non-stop, with his wife Louise Beatty as vocalist, threading his way up and down the west coast until the early 1960s, when pop edged out r&b. Forced to collect scrap-metal for a living, he was relieved when Disneyland asked him to beguile visiters as a strolling clarinettist on their site in Orange County, with the Royal Street Bachelors. He put in 25 years of service, and was grateful to live out his retirement bolstered by a Disney pension.

Always affable and happy to answer researchers' questions, McVea was predeceased by his wife. He is survived by three daughters and a son.

 Jack McVea, jazz musician and bandleader, born November 5 1914; died December 27 2000

fields.headline: John Diamond's legacy
fields.trailText: I have been greatly moved by reports about John Diamond (Love and pain in Diamond's last words, March 5).
fields.body:
I have been greatly moved by reports about John Diamond (Love and pain in Diamond's last words, March 5). Just as the death of the Princess of Wales gave many people an opportunity to express their feelings of loss, John Diamond's decision to make his experience available to millions allowed people to feel the intense and conflicting emotions evoked by a life-threatening illness. Descriptions of his love for his family and how much he was loved are uplifting. What I don't understand, however, is why we need the names of various celebrities who attended the funeral - was I wrong to think that I was being offered a window into human experience by a talented writer? Were his words only valid because of who came to his dinner parties?
Emily Mumford
Wymondham, Norfolk

 John Diamond was wrong to say that "the cancerous cells left in my body couldn't give a damn whether I'm determined to live forever or not". They could. It has been shown clinically that, in simple terms, the immune system is profoundly affected by one's mental state. People with serious illnesses should not think that having a positive attitude would not have a beneficial impact on their illnesses or their lifespan.
Patricia Purbrick
Aylesbury, Bucks

 Many of us were saddened by John Diamond's attacks on complementary approaches to cancer. I hope that his criticisms will not have deterred people from trying the many forms of help which are available, using, of course, their own common sense.
Isla Bourke
London

fields.headline: Harold Stassen
fields.standfirst: Reforming US Republican who stood nine times for his party's presidential nomination and played a vital role in establishing the UN
fields.trailText: Reforming US Republican who stood nine times for his party's presidential nomination and played a vital role in establishing the UN.
fields.body:
American presidential elections will never seem the same again; the candidacy of Harold Stassen, who has died at the age of 93, will no longer figure as the last certainty in the increasingly confused quadrennial battles.

Stassen's nine forlorn bids for the Republican presidential nomination made him the butt of every wit in the country. Yet his career between these eccentric diversions was long, distinguished and influential. At home, he was a political white hope who turned into a renowned and prosperous international lawyer. He played a critical role in creating the United Nations - he was the last surviving American signatory - and fought valiantly for arms reductions.

His tenacity and energy were astonishing. At 89, he was prepared to make yet another run at the governorship of Minnesota, the state which had put him in the record books as - at 31 - the youngest governor in US history. The reforms he had then introduced to his local Republican party and the state government first drew him to national attention, and later to major positions under Democratic and Republican administrations.

Stassen was the fourth of five children born to immigrant Norwegian farmers in West St Paul, Minnesota. Emerging with flying colours from high school, he was still too young to go to university, and busied himself on the family farm. He then worked his way through the University of Minnesota, emerging in 1929 with an excellent law degree to start his own practice in St Paul. He did so well that he soon took on five legal partners, and, in 1930, ran successfully for county attorney.

His victory came partly through his efforts to galvanise the state's young Republicans into overthrowing the party's notoriously right-wing leadership. Years later, Stassen recalled how his decision to liberalise the party had been made while he was still a student, and had been pursued throughout his life.

As part of this strategy, he fought and won Minnesota's 1938 gubernatorial election, and immediately signalled the changed nature of the regime by appointing a Democrat as his chief of staff. He vastly improved the state's industrial relations, and worked hard to introduce what he called "enlightened capitalism". It sounds marginal now but verged on revolutionary at the time. Incredibly for the period, he appointed a black officer to the national guard.

He dismantled the corrupt patronage system established by the ousted Farmer-Labor party, and cleared 7,000 political appointees from the state payroll in his first term. The tax cuts he was then able to introduce ensured his re-election for two more terms, though the third was interrupted by wartime service in the US navy, during which he won three decorations.

On Stassen's return in 1945, President Truman appointed him to the American delegation at the San Francisco conference convened to establish the United Nations. He was regarded as one of the most influential voices in the preparation of the UN charter, his most significant battle being over the use of the veto in the security council. Though he lost that, he did succeed in forcing through the provision that member states could act collectively against an aggressor, even where such action has been vetoed.

International peacekeeping was one of the pre-eminent themes of Stassen's political life. In 1955, President Eisenhower chose him as his special assistant for disarmament, and he became the chief American negotiator at the London arms control talks in 1957.

Back home, the 1952 campaign that brought Eisenhower to the White House had, in fact, been Stassen's best hope of the presidency. He had already put up a respectable show in 1948, when he fought for the nomination against the arch-conservative Senator Robert Taft and Governor Thomas Dewey of New York. Stassen won the first four primaries, and seemed the likeliest winner until he was rejected in Oregon. Dewey's narrow defeat by President Truman left Stassen as a favoured contender for the 1952 race - until Eisenhower announced his candidacy and Stassen withdrew in the interests of party unity.

He did not, however, lose his appetite for the fray. In 1958, he started a law practice in Pennsylvania, and immediately launched a bid for the state governorship. When he lost that he tried to become mayor of Philadelphia, and then tried again for the governorship. Getting the feeling that he was not wanted by the Pennsylvanians, Stassen returned to Minnesota, where he ran unsuccessfully for the US senate, for the house of representatives, and again for the governorship.

With the Republican party increasingly turning to right-wing presidential candidates, Stassen resumed his campaign for liberalisation. He was on the ballot against Barry Goldwater in 1964, Richard Nixon - whom he loathed - in 1968, Gerald Ford in 1976, Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984, and George Bush in 1988 and 1992.

In spite of his repeated rejection by the electorate, he never lost his sense of humour. When the Republicans chose Bob Dole in 1996, Stassen half-acknowledged that his long presidential battle was over. At 89, he offered to become the party's vice-presidential candidate. It would, he said, be a way to help the 72-year-old Dole look young.

Stassen's wife Esther, to whom he was married for 70 years, died last October. He is survived by a son and a daughter.

 Harold Edward Stassen, lawyer and politician, born April 13 1907; died March 4 2001

fields.headline: Arlene Mundle
fields.standfirst: Brixton leader building bridges betweeen blacks and the police
fields.trailText: Arlene Mundle, who has died of cancer aged 47, was a campaigner for social justice and a fearsome adversary to anyone who stood in her way.
fields.body:
Arlene Mundle, who has died of cancer aged 47, was a campaigner for social justice and a fearsome adversary to anyone who stood in her way. She was a crucial figure in reshaping relations between the black community and the police in south London, but her influence stretched far wider, touching the very heart of national policing policy.

Born in Portland, Jamaica, Arlene was the granddaughter of a prosperous businessman and the daughter of an RAF warrant officer. When she was two, her family moved to Hong Kong, where her earliest memories were of life on the military base as the only black family. She recalled no overt racism, just a sense of being different and special - qualities which continued to set her apart.

In the late 1950s, her grandfather brought the family to Brixton, south London, where she and her sisters went to the Dick Sheppard school. At the age of 16, she began work as a secretary and switchboard operator. In her early 20s, she married Lascelves Mundle and had two children, Rascelles and Acqua, though the marriage broke up shortly afterwards. Later, she met Cecil "Junior" Williams, with whom she had a daughter, Cassandra. Attracted by his sense of life's possibilities, she recalled this as her happiest period.

By the mid-1980s, Arlene was enjoying the showy affluence of the times, earning good money as an escort in West End clubs. It was also the period in which crack- cocaine started appearing in Britain, and Arlene's life took a downward turn as she became sucked into the world of drugs and crime. In the mid-90s, Junior and Arlene separated. Arlene knew it was time to turn her life around.

There was another blow when her friend Brian Douglas died in police custody in 1995. His family mounted a campaign to press for justice, and Arlene threw herself into this activity with a passion and fury. This was her first encounter with the community police consultative group in Lambeth, which was to become the platform from which she launched her public career.

Arlene's temper was legendary, and, at first, her anger at the racism and injustice she perceived as endemic in police relations with black people boiled at an almost uncontrollable pitch. But she harnessed that energy, in particular working with Lee Jasper's 1990 Trust, motivating others and engaging her organisational skills to huge effect. She met Stephen Lawrence's parents and, through various campaigns, started to understand more about police work.

Arlene saw how black victims of crime were being poorly served by the police, but, more controversially, believed change would only come if the black community engaged with the authorities to push for it. No one pushed harder than she did.

Her direct approach and unorthox methods - telephone calls in the early hours, even to senior officers, were her trademark - came as a culture shock to the Metropolitan police. But at a time when the police needed to listen, she had plenty to say, so she was employed to provide a much-needed community perspective for senior officers on training exercises, and to advise an operation tackling drug-related gun crime, codenamed Trident.

At times, Arlene jeopardised her own safety, but she was never afraid to speak out against the villains on her doorstep, and took the lead in promoting a highly successful firarms amnesty in Lambeth. During the tension that followed the Brixton nailbombing in 1999, she was a conduit of understanding between grassroots black feeling and the police investigation.

When her cancer was diagnosed just before Christmas last year, messages of support came in from chief constables and from public figures such as Neville Lawrence, the home secretary Jack Straw, and the former football star Ian Wright. Two months ago, she received a Metropolitan police commissioner's commendation.

Everything Arlene achieved was done through her own efforts. Tragically, her illness struck just as she was to embark on a law degree at Southampton University. Her life was about transformation and she would have become a fine lawyer. She is survived by her three children and her mother.

Penny Wrout

Lee Jasper writes: Arlene Mundle was the kind of person whom you felt you had known for years. In that sense she was an "old soul". I first met her through my association with the Brian Douglas Family Campaign in 1995.

Working for me at the 1990 Trust, she had convinced me of the need to speak publicly about how the black community could work with the police to tackle crack-cocaine gun violence. It was a difficult position to take. Nevertheless, she worked hard to ensure I spoke about these issues publicly. Make no mistake, Arlene gave me the confidence to speak out. Her enthusiasm was infectious.

Over the years, she developed leadership skills and became a figure in her own right. To me, she was my sister and confidant. In Jamaican terms, she was my key spar. Her work will remain a shining testimony to her selfless dedication.

Arlene Mundle, community leader and police adviser, born August 17 1953; died March 2 2001

She was a crucial figure in reshaping relations between the black community and the police in south London, but her influence stretched far wider, touching the very heart of national policing policy. Born in Portland, Jamaica, Arlene was the granddaughter of a prosperous businessman and the daughter of an RAF warrant officer. When she was two, her family moved to Hong Kong, where her earliest memories were of life on the military base as the only black family. She recalled no overt racism, just a sense of being different and special - qualities which continued to set her apart. In the late 1950s, her grandfather brought the family to Brixton, south London, where she and her sisters went to the Dick Sheppard school. At the age of 16, she began work as a secretary and switchboard operator. In her early 20s, she married Lascelves Mundle and had two children, Rascelles and Acqua, though the marriage broke up shortly afterwards. Later, she met Cecil "Junior" Williams, with whom she had a daughter, Cassandra. Attracted by his sense of life's possibilities, she recalled this as her happiest period. By the mid-1980s, Arlene was enjoying the showy affluence of the times, earning good money as an escort in West End clubs. It was also the period in which crack- cocaine started appearing in Britain, and Arlene's life took a downward turn as she became sucked into the world of drugs and crime. In the mid-90s, Junior and Arlene separated. Arlene knew it was time to turn her life around. There was another blow when her friend Brian Douglas died in police custody in 1995. His family mounted a campaign to press for justice, and Arlene threw herself into this activity with a passion and fury. This was her first encounter with the community police consultative group in Lambeth, which was to become the platform from which she launched her public career. Arlene's temper was legendary, and, at first, her anger at the racism and injustice she perceived as endemic in police relations with black people boiled at an almost uncontrollable pitch. But she harnessed that energy, in particular working with Lee Jasper's 1990 Trust, motivating others and engaging her organisational skills to huge effect. She met Stephen Lawrence's parents and, through various campaigns, started to understand more about police work. Arlene saw how black victims of crime were being poorly served by the police, but, more controversially, believed change would only come if the black community engaged with the authorities to push for it. No one pushed harder than she did. Her direct approach and unorthox methods - telephone calls in the early hours, even to senior officers, were her trademark - came as a culture shock to the Metropolitan police. But at a time when the police needed to listen, she had plenty to say, so she was employed to provide a much-needed community perspective for senior officers on training exercises, and to advise an operation tackling drug-related gun crime, codenamed Trident. At times, Arlene jeopardised her own safety, but she was never afraid to speak out against the villains on her doorstep, and took the lead in promoting a highly successful firarms amnesty in Lambeth. During the tension that followed the Brixton nailbombing in 1999, she was a conduit of understanding between grassroots black feeling and the police investigation. When her cancer was diagnosed just before Christmas last year, messages of support came in from chief constables and from public figures such as Neville Lawrence, the home secretary Jack Straw, and the former football star Ian Wright. Two months ago, she received a Metropolitan police commissioner's commendation. Everything Arlene achieved was done through her own efforts. Tragically, her illness struck just as she was to embark on a law degree at Southampton University. Her life was about transformation and she would have become a fine lawyer. She is survived by her three children and her mother. Penny Wrout Lee Jasper writes: Arlene Mundle was the kind of person whom you felt you had known for years. In that sense she was an "old soul". I first met her through my association with the Brian Douglas Family Campaign in 1995. Working for me at the 1990 Trust, she had convinced me of the need to speak publicly about how the black community could work with the police to tackle crack-cocaine gun violence. It was a difficult position to take. Nevertheless, she worked hard to ensure I spoke about these issues publicly. Make no mistake, Arlene gave me the confidence to speak out. Her enthusiasm was infectious. Over the years, she developed leadership skills and became a figure in her own right. To me, she was my sister and confidant. In Jamaican terms, she was my key spar. Her work will remain a shining testimony to her selfless dedication. Arlene Mundle, community leader and police adviser, born August 17 1953; died March 2 2001

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A letter to the editor, page 21, March 3, attributed to the Press Complaints Commission an adjudication that the term "bitch" was acceptable street slang for a woman. In fact the complaint which led to an adjudication on this issue was dealt with not by the PCC but by the Broadcasting Standards Commission, the BSC. It arose from the application of the term to the Queen in the television programme Have I Got News For You.
fields.body:
A letter to the editor, page 21, March 3, attributed to the Press Complaints Commission an adjudication that the term "bitch" was acceptable street slang for a woman. In fact the complaint which led to an adjudication on this issue was dealt with not by the PCC but by the Broadcasting Standards Commission, the BSC. It arose from the application of the term to the Queen in the television programme Have I Got News For You.

In a report headed QC beefs up Equitable fight, page 24 (Finance), February 24, we said Vanni Treves, the new chairman of Equitable Life "had hired a top QC to overturn the court ruling which forced the world's oldest mutual insurer to put itself up for sale". In fact the QC was appointed before Mr Treves took the post.

We confused two similar words in a review of David Lodge's new book, Think... , page 8 (Books), Saturday Review, March 3, when we referred to: "That tired old antimony between the arts and the sciences." Antimony: a toxic metallic element; Antinomy: a conflict between two laws or authorities (Collins and Oxford).

Gypsies, mentioned in our review of Hugh Thomas's book SS-1: The Unlikely Death of Heinrich Himmler, page 10 (Books), Saturday Review, March 3, should always have a capital G in the Guardian, as a reference to the style guide would show.

fields.headline: Woodhead: my part in his downfall
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead is inconsistent in his recollections and supremely insensitive about other people (Woodhead attacks Labour betrayal, March 1).
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead is inconsistent in his recollections and supremely insensitive about other people (Woodhead attacks Labour betrayal, March 1).

I have known previous chief inspectors during my 20 years of wardenship at Impington Village College, Cambridgeshire, and after. They valued people - children, teachers, heads and administrators - and were respected. Woodhead is deficient, being unable to extend any warmth or regard to people, particularly teachers.

His career is unimpressive; he is not a good leader; he does not inspire; and is tucked up with conservatism. That is not an array which gave confidence to teachers. They were glad to see him go, not because of what he had done, but because he had no thought for them as persons. Such regard is essential to leadership; lack of it in people with power tends to corrupt.
John Brackenbury
Ashford, Kent

 It is no use, I can't go on living with this guilty secret. I taught C Woodhead at Wallington Grammar School for Boys in the 60s. In mitigation I offer the fact that I was young, inexperienced and an art teacher. Perhaps I could, nay should, have done more. Introduced him to some extra curricular crocodile wrestling maybe. Alas it is all too late. I cannot even remember if he was good enough to pass O-level art.
John Hunter
Fulbourn, Cambs

 Many thanks for your articles by Ted Wragg and Nick Davies (You'd really need a heart of stone not to laugh at this man; Two enemies: both wrong, March 2). As always, Professor Wragg is splendidly on target in opposing Woodhead's egocentric nonsense and the laugh was deeply satisfying.

I reread Nick Davies's article several times and still wonder whom he considers to be the liar and the fool. Twenty years of arrant foolishness will take much more time than Blunkett has had to put right, so calling him a liar is unfair. Or perhaps Blunkett was a fool for not sacking a man often caught out telling porkies. Whatever Davies thinks, it is good to see Woodhead now encamped where he belongs.
Frank Howard
Chipping Sodbury, Bristol
cahaba.fhow@cableinet.co.uk

fields.headline: The elusive third way
fields.trailText: I should thank Andy Beckett for his profile of me (Dulling down, G2, March 5). So selective was he in quoting my least complimentary comments about the government's thinking that several friends I haven't seen since being a leftwing firebrand in the 1980s emailed me with congratulations.
fields.body:
I should thank Andy Beckett for his profile of me (Dulling down, G2, March 5). So selective was he in quoting my least complimentary comments about the government's thinking that several friends I haven't seen since being a leftwing firebrand in the 1980s emailed me with congratulations.

At the risk of disappointing them, I should put my words back in context. It is true that I found the prime minister's recently published article on the third way disappointing. But this was primarily because I think it is a pity to ascribe Labour's progress in government to the elusive third way rather than seeing it for what it is - modern social democracy in action.

At its best, New Labour's approach combines traditional social democratic policies, such as increased investment in public services and redistribution to the poorest, with a new emphasis on opportunity through education and employment and the need for "joined-up" policy on deeply entrenched social exclusion. The task for progressives is to understand the strengths and limitations of this approach.

We need to recognise that dilemmas such as those between promoting social equality and civic engagement, or between successfully managing consumer capitalism while mitigating some of its worst effects, are ones that progressives in Britain and across the world have been dealing with for a century. New Labour is developing some innovative ways of addressing these issues but it should be proud of renewing the social democratic tradition rather than claiming to have discovered a new politics.
Mathew Taylor
IPPR

 Andy Beckett writes that the government has reduced the number of targets for improving services. Yet local government is still required to adopt hundreds of meaningless targets. I know one council that has set up 1,000 of them in vain. I remind officers that Arnie Weinstock ran GEC using seven indicators.
John Garrett
Norfolk county council

 You report "some Labour strategists" as thinking that the Budget is excessively targeted at helping the poor, "many of whom do not bother to vote" (Budget to give public jobs boost, March 5). Many people do not help the poor in order to get votes for the Labour party, but help the party in order to get money for the poor. If the Budget fulfils the party's purpose, Labour will have keener, more active workers. If people become less poor and better integrated into society, they may have a chance to think about voting.
Robert Dimmick
Reading
robert@dimmick33.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Price of a bacon butty

fields.headline: Price of a bacon butty
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's comments (Blair sparks stores row, March 3) correlating the plight of farmers and cheap food in supermarkets simplified serious concerns. There is clear evidence that families living in poverty in Britain are suffering higher rates of major health problems.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's comments (Blair sparks stores row, March 3) correlating the plight of farmers and cheap food in supermarkets simplified serious concerns. There is clear evidence that families living in poverty in Britain are suffering higher rates of major health problems. Diet is a key factor in preventing cancer and coronary heart disease (second only to quitting smoking), and is also fundamental to many subtler health issues, such as performance at school and work, the maintenance of adequate energy and activity levels and the ability to cope with stress.

Although most people are aware of the benefits of good nutrition, families living on low incomes face many barriers to meeting their basic food needs because healthier food options are often too expensive, especially when weighed against the more concrete expenses of rent and utility bills.

A simple equation between cheap food and the plight of farmers cannot be made when there are so many other players in the food chain who add to the cost of food production: seed companies, fertiliser and chemical producers, farm equipment manufacturers, storage and distribution companies, transportation networks, marketing boards and retailers. Simply raising the price of food would increase the disadvantages of the many low-income consumers across the country.

Perhaps we should consider supporting locally diverse and sustainable food production. But we should remember that access to food - as stated by the Rome declaration on world food security - is a basic human right.
Erika O'Hara
Durham
erikaohara@canada.com

 We have just returned from a round the world trip. Everywhere we stopped, food in markets, supermarkets and restaurants was either cheaper or much cheaper than in the UK. For the last few years all the overseas visitors in our B&B have told us how expensive everything - including food - is in the UK. So why is cheap food given as the excuse for the farming cri sis? Politicians may find it convenient to hide behind this outdated smokescreen, but the people on low incomes, will readily confirm that we don't have cheap food.
IJ Gibson
Ullapool, Ross-shire
ijgibson@globalnet.co.uk

 That the recent concern shown by adjacent farmers, district councillors and environmental agency officials towards the farm suspected of starting the foot and mouth outbreak was left unheeded by Maff inspectors and country council trading standards officers is of little surprise to those of us who live in the countryside (MP hits at safety on outbreak farm, March 5). From my observations around the Peak District, where I live, I can think of farms which are in an appalling state of disrepair, with stock clearly in a poor and dirty condition, rotting machinery, and tottering and filthy farm buildings.

In my view we desperately need a "name and shame" whistleblowers policy for farms suspected of employing short-cut methods and poor husbandry, and an independent force to close down such cowboy operators.
Dr David Baker
University of Warwick
D.L.Baker@warwick.ac.uk

 Ponies and other wild animals on Dartmoor could now be slaughtered, all due to a disease which is non-fatal to animals or humans and clears up within weeks, but makes the animals "not economically viable". It's time you flesh eaters took responsibility for the suffering and destruction you cause. Every one of you who says "I could not give up my bacon butty" shares the responsibility for what is happening now.
Diane Manning
London

fields.headline: A case of fuzzy logic
fields.standfirst: Stop giving bacteria such a bad name
fields.trailText: If only the judiciary knew a little more science. An employment tribunal has just upheld the right of the Waitrose supermarket chain to refuse employment to a former chef as a catering assistant in one of its coffee shops, because of his beard.
fields.body:
If only the judiciary knew a little more science. An employment tribunal has just upheld the right of the Waitrose supermarket chain to refuse employment to a former chef as a catering assistant in one of its coffee shops, because of his beard.

The tribunal ruled the discrimination as lawful because "hair both from the head and face poses a significant food safety risk ... since it hosts bacteria ..."

All true. The applicant's beard was bushy enough to play host to all manner of cake and biscuit crumbs, not to mention beer dribbles. But where is the sense of perspective? We are all walking sacks of bacteria. The average man comprises one hundred million million cells. Multiply that by 10 to obtain the number of bacteria. We shed millions a day. Most bacteria are not bad for you. We live in harmony with them. The air we breathe, water we drink and food we consume arrive courtesy of bacteria and recycling, cleansing and other processes.

Does the tribunal chairman not eat yoghurt? True, some bacteria are a risk. True, in this risk-averse society, we require staff handling food to wear hairnets. Surely, then, the right ruling would have been a compromise: insisting on a beardnet.

fields.headline: Buffeted in the Balkans
fields.standfirst:
A more robust approach is required
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Sporadic fighting along the Macedonia-Kosovo border has reawakened fear of a new Balkan conflagration and increased concern that Nato is losing its grip.
fields.body:
Sporadic fighting along the Macedonia-Kosovo border has reawakened fear of a new Balkan conflagration and increased concern that Nato is losing its grip.

Macedonia criticised the alliance last week for opposing its use of force against armed ethnic Albanian separatists in Tanusevci, north of Skopje. After three of its soldiers died on Sunday, the Macedonian army went ahead anyway, forcing some of the gunmen to flee back into Kosovo.

Macedonia believes Nato is not doing enough to curb infiltration from majority Albanian Kosovo into both its territory and Serbia's adjacent Presevo valley. Greece warns that an "explosive situation" is developing and demands that Nato take a tougher line with the successors to the Kosovo Liberation Army. Another neighbour, Bulgaria, has offered to send troops - a perhaps well-meant gesture but a worrying one, too. Tanusevci had been seized by a group calling itself the Albanian National Liberation Army.

A similarly motivated outfit has caused such mayhem in Presevo that Nato agreed last week to hand back parts of the border buffer zone to Yugoslav military control. In other words, the violent advocates of a greater Albania have become such a threat to regional stability that the west is now being forced into alliance with forces that not so long ago were campaigning for a greater Serbia.

That is a remarkable turnabout less than two years after Nato went to war with Serbia on behalf of Kosovo's Albanians. It comes despite Yugoslav President Vojislav's Kostunica's continued, unacceptable foot-dragging over the extradition of his deposed predecessor, Slobodan Milosevic, to the Hague interna tional war crimes tribunal. It is consistent with K-For's failure to halt Kosovo Albanian attacks on those few, isolated Serbs who still live in the province.

But the broader context remains the lack of a clear consensus among Nato's political masters and the UN about the shape of any final Kosovo settlement. Kosovo remains Yugoslav sovereign territory. Yet most of its inhabitants want substantial autonomy, if not independence from Belgrade. Plans for all-inclusive elections in the province, promoted by the OSCE for this October, look optimistic if not totally unrealistic. In the meantime, opponents of the west's 1999 war, such as Russia's Vladimir Putin, highlight Nato's difficulties, saying they demonstrate that intervention in a state's sovereign affairs is wrong in principle and brings only greater grief in practice.

Disproving Mr Putin's contention is as important in the long term as is halting this rekindling ethnic conflict now, before its spreads. That means more robust, cooperative action by Nato forces, particularly the US contingent, against violent Albanian nationalists inside Kosovo and along its borders with Macedonia, Serbia and Albania proper.

It means an end to the political games of the French, who appear, on the pretext of protecting EU observers in Presevo, to be trying to create a de facto first mission for Europe's proposed Rapid Reaction Force.

It means no more talk from Bush administration hawks about a Balkans withdrawal, Colin Powell's recent assurances notwithstanding. And it means increased, friendly pressure on Belgrade's new government to ensure it lives up to the democratic ideals that gave it birth.

fields.headline: Prove that politics works
fields.standfirst:
That is the best task for Northern Ireland

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: When it comes to the grisly world of organised terrorism, it is probably a vain task to distinguish between degrees of evil. And yet dissident republicanism - whether in the form of the so-called Real IRA or Continuity IRA, two separate organisations now said to be collaborating - seems bent on plumbing new depths.
fields.body:
When it comes to the grisly world of organised terrorism, it is probably a vain task to distinguish between degrees of evil. And yet dissident republicanism - whether in the form of the so-called Real IRA or Continuity IRA, two separate organisations now said to be collaborating - seems bent on plumbing new depths.

Not content with staging the deadliest atrocity in 30 years of the troubles, killing 29 civilians in the bombing of Omagh town centre in August 1998, the rejectionists of republicanism have now declared war on the truth itself.

They will doubtless claim that BBC Television Centre is a citadel of the British state and therefore a "legitimate target". But more plausible is the notion that the hardmen were angered by Panorama's recent expose of the Omagh bombers and that Sunday's planned "spectacular" was payback. This says much about the fascistic impulses of the Real IRA and its ilk: they regard journalists courageous enough to tell the truth as targets for murder and maiming. Dissident republicanism's American backers should take note. Before they next dip in their pocket to make a sentimental donation for the boys' struggle back home, they should remember their own hallowed First Amendment guaranteeing freedom of speech - and recall the terrorists' contempt for it.

Confronted with such malice, it is no wonder that people revert to their default positions - with the perennial Unionist demand for decommissioning the most instant reaction. Witness David Trimble's declaration that dissidents were using "material and expertise" leaked from the mainstream IRA and so extra pressure had to be brought to bear on the latter to hand over its guns.

And yet this logic, while superficially appealing, is not sound. First, it ignores what was always the most stubborn fact about disarmament, best stated by the nationalist leader John Hume: "You can hand over a gun on Monday, only to buy another one on Tuesday." In other words, even if the Provisional IRA handed in every last one of its weapons, it would not prevent the likes of the Real IRA from striking again. They can get hold of explosives easily - whether of the homemade, fertiliser-based variety or byimporting them: latest reports suggest the Balkans has become a source. Moreover, if the Real IRA have got hold of some Provisional arms, then clearly the latter cannot hand them over, even if they wanted to. As always, the key point about weapons is the intent to use them. The Real IRA have that intent, and no amount of Provo decommissioning will prevent them acting on it.

In fact, the reverse is true. It is the issue of disarmament which, more than any other, acts as a recruiting sergeant for dissident republicanism. When Gerry Adams or Martin McGuinness is seen even to be negotiating the issue, hardliners are able to brand the Sinn Fein leaders as sellouts on the brink of symbolic surrender.

By continuing to push the question, Unionists inadvertently confirm the hardliners' core argument: that the peace process is just a ruse to disarm republicans. When there have already been more than 50 pipebomb attacks on Catholic homes this year, hardliners strike a chord when they ask why republicans alone are pressed so hard to give up their weapons.

Unionists should follow the wise counsel of the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid. The best way to marginalise the dissidents is to prove that "politics works". When Sinn Fein can boast of progress, there will be no constituency to nourish the Real IRA or its murderous collaborators.

webTitle: Royal control of strife-hit abbey could end

fields.headline: Royal control of strife-hit abbey could end
fields.standfirst:
Inquiry calls for commission to modernise independent churches

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: One of the Queen's more arcane prerogatives - her control over churches such as Westminster Abbey, quaintly known as Royal Peculiars - was placed under notice yesterday with the publication of a report suggesting that their management should be dragged into the 21st century.
fields.body:
One of the Queen's more arcane prerogatives - her control over churches such as Westminster Abbey, quaintly known as Royal Peculiars - was placed under notice yesterday with the publication of a report suggesting that their management should be dragged into the 21st century.

An official inquiry called for the appointment of a standing commission, including lay members, tacitly to curtail the independence of the peculiars and their governing deans and chapters, who have retained almost medieval powers over how they are run.

Such a move - if accepted by the Queen and the government - would have the effect of distancing her from what has been a series of acrimonious disputes over the running of the abbey.

The inquiry team's 116-page report stated: "The key question is whether the Royal Peculiars should continue to be treated as unique institutions or whether, in the light of modern developments in both church and public life, they should accept more of the character of cathedrals ... in organisation and outside links."

Westminster Abbey, the site of coronations and other state occasions, which last year had an income of £8.7m, with more than 200 staff and 1.25m tourists, is still governed by statutes settled in the reign of Queen Elizabeth I, in 1560.

The other peculiars - so called because they are under the authority of the Queen rather than the Archbishop of Canterbury or a diocesan bishop - are St George's Chapel, Windsor, and the chapels Royal at St James's Palace, the Tower of London and Hampton Court.

The statutes of St George's are even older than those at the abbey, having been granted by King Edward III with the aid of a Papal Bull securing its independence in the 14th century.

The inquiry, under Professor Averil Cameron, warden of Keble College, Oxford, was set up two years ago, partly in the wake of the sacking of Martin Neary, the abbey's organist, by the dean, Wesley Carr - an event described in the report as "a difficult episode".

More recently, the dean has been criticised for his handling of parental criticisms over the running of the abbey's choir school, whose headmaster was forced out last week.

Professor Cameron and one of the other members of the inquiry team, the Dean of York, Raymond Furnell, said their proposals would introduce "useful checks and balances" into how the peculiars are run.

Asked whether the reforms would prevent capricious behaviour by a dean and chapter, Prof Cameron said: "It would be a very useful safeguard."

The report says the standing commission should consist of no less than three and no more than five persons, all appointed by the crown, including a senior bishop as chairman, a judge and someone with financial expertise.

The commission would oversee the annual accounts of each peculiar, receive an an nual report and "where possible exercise a mediating role in the settlement of disputes".

It suggests the controversy over the sacking of Dr Neary would not have occurred if such procedures had been in place. Employees with a grievance would still have the right to appeal to the Queen, though their cases would be dealt with by ad-hoc committees of the commission.

The report claims that the abbey has been subjected to a "sustained campaign of criticism ... some of it extremely unpleasant in character. Although this criticism is often ill-informed, it has undoubtedly had a damaging effect."

The abbey's critics claimed last night that the report was a whitewash, which would have little effect on the daily running of the Royal Peculiars. Judge Christopher Compston said: "The dean continues to be haunted and taunted by the effects of the Neary dispute."

Dr Carr said: "[We] have been working hard to improve the way the abbey is run ... so we are encouraged by the commission's recognition of very considerable achievement in this direction and their commendation of our success."

webTitle: Killing of Zimbabwean widow was political

fields.headline: Killer's motive 'not robbery'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The truck stolen by the killers of Gloria Olds, a 68-year-old white Zimbabwean widow who was gunned down as she opened the gates to her farm on the weekend, was recovered yesterday in the nearby southern city of Bulawayo.
fields.body:
The truck stolen by the killers of Gloria Olds, a 68-year-old white Zimbabwean widow who was gunned down as she opened the gates to her farm on the weekend, was recovered yesterday in the nearby southern city of Bulawayo.

Nothing had been taken from the vehicle, not even her handbag or the radio and tape player, convincing many in the white community that she was a victim of Zimbabwe's rising political violence.

Her killers remained at large last night.

"The truck was simply used as a getaway vehicle," a neighbouring farmer who tracked the vehicle said.

"These people were not robbers," he said. "This was a politically motivated killing, plain and simple."

Mrs Olds had remained on the family farm despite the murder of her son, Martin, a year ago. Her murder is seen as part of another surge in violence and threats against white farmers in the Matabeleland countryside, near where the truck was found.

"We are experiencing a definite escalation of pressure and violence," Mac Crawford, an official of the Commercial Farmers' Union, said. "The tempo of trouble has stepped up. It appears to be intended to demoralise the farming community and to get people to abandon their farms. But it has hardened our resolve to stay put and to see this through."

Farmers in Matabeleland, however, now worry about what will happen next.

"Things are very bad. We've got 1,000 war veterans and others on our farm. They are killing our game, poaching, cutting down trees and planting their crops," one farmer said. "And we know it is orchestrated from the top. Last year was very tough. This year looks tougher."

webTitle: Two killed by student gunman in US

fields.headline: Two killed by smiling student gunman
fields.standfirst:
Boy, 15, told friends of plan for 'another Columbine'

Special report: Gun violence in America
fields.trailText: A smiling high school student opened fire on fellow students at a school in the suburbs of San Diego, California, yesterday morning killing two and wounding at least 13 others.
fields.body:
A smiling high school student opened fire on fellow students at a school in the suburbs of San Diego, California, yesterday morning killing two and wounding at least 13 others. According to friends, the student had bragged at the weekend about his plans for "another Columbine" and asked if they wanted to join him. They had thought he was joking and had not reported his plans.

The shooting awakened memories of the Columbine high school tragedy in Colorado in 1999 when two students opened fire on fellow students and teachers.

President Bush yesterday extended his sympathies to the students and families and said: "All of us must be mindful of the fact that some people act out their aggressions.

"Our hearts go out and our prayers go out to the parents and the teachers and the children whose lives have been completely turned upside down right now."

He described the shooting as a "disgraceful act of cowardice" and called on adults to teach their children that "life is precious."

The shooting took place at the Santana high school in Santee, a suburb of San Diego, shortly after school had started for the day. It apparently started in one of the male bathrooms at the school when a ninth grade student, aged 15, described by fellow students as a "known troublemaker" pulled out a handgun and opened fire.

Over the weekend, the student had complained to friends about being bullied and said he was "going to start in the bathroom and work his way out." His friends had not thought he was serious and said that, although he had on occasions complained about being bullied, he was someone with many friends.

One friend of the alleged gunman said: "He was talking about it at the weekend ... His dad had a bunch of guns." He said that he and other fellow students did not take him seriously and did not report the conversation because "I didn't want to get him into trouble."

One student even patted the student down before school in a semi-serious attempt to see if he was going to fulfill his threat. The gun had been hidden in the gunman's backpack.

Fellow students said that the youth was smiling as he opened fire with a long-handled handgun in the bathroom, eventually hitting 15 people, including a security guard who worked at the school and a campus supervisor. Student John Schardt, 17, said: "I looked at the kid. He was smiling and shooting his weapon."

Two of those hit, both students, have died of their wounds. One of those killed was 15 and died at the scene and the other in hospital. One of the wounded was said to be in a critical but not life-threatening condition.

Panic ensued as students fled the area and the gunman re-entered the bathroom to reload, came out and opened fire again.

Police Swat teams were on the scene within two minutes of an emergency call and the student, who was still in the bathroom, was taken into custody. A sheriff's department spokesman said only that "a lone gunman" was believed to be responsible although an investigation was under way to see if any friends had agreed to join him in the shooting. The police bomb squad also swept the school in case, as has been the case in other school shootings, home-made bombs had been planted.

There was puzzlement on the 2,000-student campus as to why the student should open fire. One girl student said: "I don't know why he did it. Everyone has friends here. No one is usually left out or made fun of."

webTitle: Comment: The grim message of the BBC bomb

fields.headline: The bombers have blown a hole in more than the BBC
fields.standfirst:
The blast is a rallying cry to all those disillusioned with the peace process

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: It was probably no coincidence that the Real IRA bombed the BBC Television Centre when it did. Twenty years ago on March 1, the IRA icon Bobby Sands began his 66-day hunger strike to the death in the Maze prison, guaranteeing his primacy in contemporary republican history as the prisoner who refused to bend the knee to the British.
fields.body:
It was probably no coincidence that the Real IRA bombed the BBC Television Centre when it did. Twenty years ago on March 1, the IRA icon Bobby Sands began his 66-day hunger strike to the death in the Maze prison, guaranteeing his primacy in contemporary republican history as the prisoner who refused to bend the knee to the British.

Nine other republican prisoners followed Sands to their graves in the hunger strike which proved to be the great watershed in the evolution of the republican movement - the IRA and Sinn Fein.

Nor was it any coincidence that, in the anniversary- obsessed IRA calendar, Sands began his fast on March 1 1981. It was the fifth anniversary of the Labour government's abolition of special category status which recognised that republican (and loyalist) inmates were political prisoners in everything but name.

Sands's sister, Bernadette Sands-McKevitt, was a founder member of the 32-County Sovereignty Committee, which is to the Real IRA what Sinn Fein is to the Provisional IRA. "Bobby clearly stated what he believed he was dying for, and that was the sovereign independence of his country," she told me shortly after Sinn Fein entered the all-party talks that finally led to the Good Friday agreement of 1998.

To the Real IRA and its followers, the Provisionals led by Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness have usurped Bobby Sands's name and betrayed the principle for which he died by putting away their guns and signing up to a partitionist solution that leaves the "Brits" as entrenched as ever in the north. The dissidents believe, as the provos once believed, that Irish unity will be achieved only with gun and bomb and not by getting into bed with the enemy. Hence the explosion at the BBC.

Bernadette Sands-McKevitt said her brother did not die for the peace process embraced by Adams and McGuinness. "It's not what most of the volunteers in the Irish Republican Army would have gone out and given their lives for - the freedom of their country." Her words still strike the rawest of nerves in grassroots Provisionals and their families who have lost fathers and sons in the "war" and yet still give their support to the leadership, however apprehensive they may be.

The dramatic image of a great orange ball of fire rising outside the main studios of the British Broadcasting Corporation in the Brits' capital city is a reminder of where they all came from. The Provisionals used to say that a bomb in London is worth 10 in Belfast. The bomb at the BBC was probably worth double in terms of global exposure, telling the world, and especially the paymasters in America and elsewhere, that at least one IRA was still in business.

The repeated warnings by MI5 and special branch that more mainland attacks were to be expected after the Real IRA's rocket attack on the M16 headquarters (which damaged the paintwork but little more), were well founded. The Real IRA is believed to have been well penetrated north and south of the border - witness the number of arrests made and the number of operations thwarted. But however good the intelligence cover, it can never be 100% complete. Canary Wharf proved that.

Yet the Real IRA might never have got off the ground. It was founded late in 1997 after an extraordinary IRA army convention in the tiny village of Falcarragh in north-west Donegal. The convention was called at the instigation of the IRA's then quartermaster general - a powerful figure in his own right - and his supporters, who were bent on engineering a coup in opposition to the "peace" strategy of the IRA leadership.

They advocated an end to the IRA's ceasefire and a renunciation of senator George Mitchell's "principles" of non-violence. Adams and McGuinness spoke against them and won the day. The quartermaster general resigned, along with a handful of associates who held key positions in his department and the IRA's "engineering" division. What they lacked in numbers, they made up in experience and expertise.

Soon afterwards, a member of the IRA's army council is believed to have advocated a "night of the long knives" to finish off the dissidents before they could pose a serious threat to the Provisionals. Wiser counsels prevailed - after all, the IRA was on ceasefire. Nevertheless the quartermaster general and other prominent defectors were visited by senior IRA men and left in no doubt as to their fate should they touch the IRA's dumps.

No action was taken, presumably because the dumps were not touched. There was no need to. The Real IRA soon established its own sources of money and guns and attracted a new generation of young recruits, many of whom were "clean skins" without security force traces on either side of the border.

Many thought that the Real IRA was finished after the horror of Omagh in August 1998 when 29 people died. Reports of its demise were premature, as the BBC bomb and the growing series of attacks in Northern Ireland were to prove. It is too simplistic to say that the television centre was targeted purely in revenge for Panorama's award-winning expose of those alleged to be responsible for Omagh - although the connection would hardly have escaped the bombers' minds.

Sunday's explosion not only shook the BBC but rocked the peace process it was designed to sabotage. The guiding principle of Adams and McGuinness in steering the IRA and Sinn Fein along the precarious path to peace, overturning many of the cardinal tenets of republicanism in the process, was to keep the republican movement together. To date that has been their great and largely unsung achievement.

The BBC bomb is bound to cause them concern, not because they suddenly fear mass defections, but because it gives the Real IRA a critical credibility and makes it a powerful rallying point for dissidents at a time when the peace process appears to be delivering little to republicans. The dramatic simplicity of the bomb may be more appealing to those who have fought the "war" than the achingly slow process of negotiating peace. The Real IRA is looking over Sinn Fein's shoulder as Ian Paisley and the DUP are looking over David Trimble's.

Despite what Sinn Fein says, the real obstacle to breaking the current impasse in the peace process is not policing but decommissioning. Although the IRA has pledged not to hand over a single bullet, it has taken the unprecedented step of opening up a couple of its bunkers to independent inspection. Much more was expected of it, but any further concessions, if any, the IRA was prepared to make have probably been blown away by the Real IRA's bomb. That is Sunday's grim message.

Peter Taylor's BBC Irish trilogy, Provos, Loyalists and Brits, won the Royal Television Society's judges award last week.

To the Real IRA and its followers, the Provisionals led by Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness have usurped Bobby Sands's name and betrayed the principle for which he died by putting away their guns and signing up to a partitionist solution that leaves the "Brits" as entrenched as ever in the north. The dissidents believe, as the provos once believed, that Irish unity will be achieved only with gun and bomb and not by getting into bed with the enemy. Hence the explosion at the BBC. Bernadette Sands-McKevitt said her brother did not die for the peace process embraced by Adams and McGuinness. "It's not what most of the volunteers in the Irish Republican Army would have gone out and given their lives for - the freedom of their country." Her words still strike the rawest of nerves in grassroots Provisionals and their families who have lost fathers and sons in the "war" and yet still give their support to the leadership, however apprehensive they may be. The dramatic image of a great orange ball of fire rising outside the main studios of the British Broadcasting Corporation in the Brits' capital city is a reminder of where they all came from. The Provisionals used to say that a bomb in London is worth 10 in Belfast. The bomb at the BBC was probably worth double in terms of global exposure, telling the world, and especially the paymasters in America and elsewhere, that at least one IRA was still in business. The repeated warnings by MI5 and special branch that more mainland attacks were to be expected after the Real IRA's rocket attack on the M16 headquarters (which damaged the paintwork but little more), were well founded. The Real IRA is believed to have been well penetrated north and south of the border - witness the number of arrests made and the number of operations thwarted. But however good the intelligence cover, it can never be 100% complete. Canary Wharf proved that. Yet the Real IRA might never have got off the ground. It was founded late in 1997 after an extraordinary IRA army convention in the tiny village of Falcarragh in north-west Donegal. The convention was called at the instigation of the IRA's then quartermaster general - a powerful figure in his own right - and his supporters, who were bent on engineering a coup in opposition to the "peace" strategy of the IRA leadership. They advocated an end to the IRA's ceasefire and a renunciation of senator George Mitchell's "principles" of non-violence. Adams and McGuinness spoke against them and won the day. The quartermaster general resigned, along with a handful of associates who held key positions in his department and the IRA's "engineering" division. What they lacked in numbers, they made up in experience and expertise. Soon afterwards, a member of the IRA's army council is believed to have advocated a "night of the long knives" to finish off the dissidents before they could pose a serious threat to the Provisionals. Wiser counsels prevailed - after all, the IRA was on ceasefire. Nevertheless the quartermaster general and other prominent defectors were visited by senior IRA men and left in no doubt as to their fate should they touch the IRA's dumps. No action was taken, presumably because the dumps were not touched. There was no need to. The Real IRA soon established its own sources of money and guns and attracted a new generation of young recruits, many of whom were "clean skins" without security force traces on either side of the border. Many thought that the Real IRA was finished after the horror of Omagh in August 1998 when 29 people died. Reports of its demise were premature, as the BBC bomb and the growing series of attacks in Northern Ireland were to prove. It is too simplistic to say that the television centre was targeted purely in revenge for Panorama's award-winning expose of those alleged to be responsible for Omagh - although the connection would hardly have escaped the bombers' minds. Sunday's explosion not only shook the BBC but rocked the peace process it was designed to sabotage. The guiding principle of Adams and McGuinness in steering the IRA and Sinn Fein along the precarious path to peace, overturning many of the cardinal tenets of republicanism in the process, was to keep the republican movement together. To date that has been their great and largely unsung achievement. The BBC bomb is bound to cause them concern, not because they suddenly fear mass defections, but because it gives the Real IRA a critical credibility and makes it a powerful rallying point for dissidents at a time when the peace process appears to be delivering little to republicans. The dramatic simplicity of the bomb may be more appealing to those who have fought the "war" than the achingly slow process of negotiating peace. The Real IRA is looking over Sinn Fein's shoulder as Ian Paisley and the DUP are looking over David Trimble's. Despite what Sinn Fein says, the real obstacle to breaking the current impasse in the peace process is not policing but decommissioning. Although the IRA has pledged not to hand over a single bullet, it has taken the unprecedented step of opening up a couple of its bunkers to independent inspection. Much more was expected of it, but any further concessions, if any, the IRA was prepared to make have probably been blown away by the Real IRA's bomb. That is Sunday's grim message.
