fields.headline: Fantasy that became 17 year nightmare
fields.standfirst: Cloud over police as court quashes conviction of attention seeker jailed for killing two women out walking dogs
fields.trailText: Peter Fell was drunk, depressed and alone when he made a phone call that he would regret for the rest of his life. A fantasist and inveterate attention seeker, he dialled 999 and "confessed" to murdering two women who were walking their dogs on Hungry Hill, just outside Aldershot, Hampshire.
fields.body:
Peter Fell was drunk, depressed and alone when he made a phone call that he would regret for the rest of his life. A fantasist and inveterate attention seeker, he dialled 999 and "confessed" to murdering two women who were walking their dogs on Hungry Hill, just outside Aldershot, Hampshire.

He gave the wrong date for the killings, burped and was mostly incoherent during a conversation that was hard for the police operator to take seriously.

Yet despite repeatedly insisting to detectives that he made up the whole story because he wanted "to be somebody", it was only yesterday - after 17 years in jail for double murder - that Mr Fell proved he was innocent .

He was freed by Lord Justice Waller at the court of appeal, who quashed his conviction, saying it was unsafe.

The decision left Mr Fell, now 40, relieved that his nightmare was finally over and Hampshire police stung by allegations that officers had put pressure on him to confess.

It also meant that the mystery of who stabbed Ann Lee and Margaret "Peggy" Johnson in mid-afternoon on May 10, 1982, has yet to be solved.

Their deaths horrified the country and led to a huge police investigation involving 100 officers.

Mrs Lee, 44, left her home in Highfield Gardens, Aldershot, with her labrador, Monty, to meet Mrs Johnson, 66, who lived in a nearby bungalow and owned a red setter called Tara.

The two women were about halfway round their regular walk on the common when they were attacked and stabbed repeatedly with a double-edged knife.

Blood

Mrs Lee, a mother of two, was discovered lying on the path at the top of a small hillock. Monty was pining by her side.

Mrs Johnson, a grandmother who had been married for 47 years, was 20 yards away slumped by a five-bar gate where she had run to escape. The lower rungs were covered in blood.

Although the murders had been committed in daylight and the bodies found close to an army base, there were no witnesses. Robbery and rape were ruled out as potential motives and no weapon was found.

There were two suspicious sightings on the day; a man wearing a camouflage jacket and a lorry driver - crying, with his head in his hands - seen close to the murder scene. The police dismissed both.

Mr Fell, however, had already tried to implicate himself. On the evening of the murder, he staggered out of a pub in Aldershot and called the police.

He told an officer he had met a man who had told him he was the killer. Mr Fell said the man lived at 10 York Road - his own address.

The police did nothing, so Mr Fell rang again the next day and offered the same information.

It was another two weeks before he was questioned and then he was ruled out as a suspect. Detectives concluded he could not have been on the common at the time of the murder, and in any event, there was no motive.

A year later, the police were no nearer to catching the killer and Mr Fell, a hospital porter, had moved to Bournemouth.

After another night of heavy drinking, he called the local police and said: "I know who did Bournemouth ... Aldershot double, double murderer on May 10, '78."

He gave his own name.

Several days later he was interviewed by the police for nearly 10 hours in seven sessions without a solicitor. To begin with, Mr Fell denied involvement.

"I have not murdered anyone," he told them. "Never have and never will, there's not a lot else I can say ... I know the phone calls and all that ... that's only because I wanted to be someone. I'm nobody."

During subsequent interviews, Mr Fell made a partial confession which he immediately retracted.

He'd said he'd met the two women and had struck one of them with a stick because she looked like his mother.

In the book Trial and Error, author David Jessell describes how officers were taped saying to Mr Fell "the sooner you see clear, my sunshine, the better", and "from the day you started to walk you lied."

Still protesting his innocence, Mr Fell was convicted of both murders in August, 1984, at the end of a 19-day trial at Winchester crown court.

Mr Fell's tendency to make things up was well-known to the police.

During a spell in the army as a cook, he twice lied about being attacked by civilians. He also claimed he was an army boxing champion - another fantasy.

He even tried to incriminate himself in the Yorkshire Ripper murders by phoning the police and giving them his name.

His disturbed childhood also made him prone to attention seeking. His parents split up when he was three, and two sets of foster parents had given him up, leaving him in the care of a children's home.

After considering his background and details of the confession, the criminal cases review commission referred the case back to the court of appeal in September, 1999.

Vulnerable

During the hearing, Patrick O'Connor, QC, accused the police of putting Mr Fell under pressure when he was in a particularly vulnerable state.

He also pointed to psychiatric evidence that showed Mr Fell was emotionally vulnerable and had a "suggestible" personality.

A psychologist, Gisli Gudjonsson, testified that he had had doubts about the reliability of Mr Fell's confession since 1988.

Following the quashing of the conviction, Mr Fell said he wanted to start afresh.

"If I dwell on it, it will just do me more harm, so I don't want to dwell on it. I'll just take one day at a time. I have always believed that one day I would be proved innocent," he said.

Asked why he confessed to the murders, he replied: "I used to say a lot of silly things but did not realise they would be used against me at the trial."

Mr Fell will probably be due a substantial sum in compensation. Hampshire police said yesterday it would review the murder case.

"We never give up on murders," said Detective Superintendent Des Thomas. "If any further evidence is forthcoming, we will take the appropriate action. The families of the victims will be informed of developments."

Jim Nicholl, Mr Fell's lawyer, said of his client: "He might be a crackpot, he might be crazy, he might be all those things, or probably was in 1982. But a murderer he was not and never has been. He is completely and totally innocent."

Stephen Downing Spent 27 years in jail for the murder of Wendy Sewell in Bakewell, Derbyshire, in 1973. He was refused parole because he would not admit a part in the killing. Released last month.

Iain Gordon Cleared last December of murder of judge's daughter Patricia Curran, 19, in 1952. Found guilty but insane. Spent more than seven years in Holywell mental hospital in Antrim before being freed and returned to Glasgow under a false name.

Cardiff Three In December 1999, Darren Hall, Michael O'Brien and Ellis Sherwood, jailed for life for battering newsagent Philip Saunders to death during a robbery 11 years earlier, had their convictions quashed.

Bridgewater Four Served 17 years. Sentenced in 1979 to life (Michael and Vincent Hickey, James Robinson) and 12 years (Patrick Molloy) for the murder of Carl Bridgewater. Convictions quashed in 1997.

Stefan Kiszko Served 17 years. Sentenced to life in 1976 for murder of Lesley Molseed, 11. Conviction quashed in 1992. Kiszko suffered a fatal heart attack in the following year.

webTitle: Judges to hear appeal in Guinness fraud case

fields.headline: Judges to hear appeal in Guinness fraud case
fields.trailText: Three men found guiilty in the Guinness fraud trial have had their convictions referred to the court of appeal, it was announced last night. The cases of Ernest Saunders, Gerald Ronson and Anthony Parnes will now be heard by three appeal judges later this year.
fields.body:
Three men found guiilty in the Guinness fraud trial have had their convictions referred to the court of appeal, it was announced last night. The cases of Ernest Saunders, Gerald Ronson and Anthony Parnes will now be heard by three appeal judges later this year.

The criminal cases review commission has already sent the conviction of the fourth defendant, Jack Lyons, to the court of appeal.

The men were convicted in 1990 of involvement in a conspiracy to drive up the price of Guinness shares during a takeover battle.

The European court of human rights has ruled they had an unfair trial because they were compelled to give information then used against them.

The four cases will be heard together after a judge asked for the legal process to be speeded up.

Saunders was convicted of eight counts of false accounting, two counts of theft, and conspiracy to contravene the Prevention of Fraud Act 1958. He was jailed for five years, halved on appeal.

Ronson was sentenced to 12 months and fined £5m for false accounting, theft, and conspiracy; Parnes was jailed for 30 months, reduced to 21 on appeal.

Press Association

fields.headline: Psion 'undervalued'
fields.trailText: Although Psion has abandoned plans to create a next generation wireless device, analysts at Nomura and Merrill Lynch reckon it is undervalued.
fields.body:
Although Psion has abandoned plans to create a next generation wireless device, analysts at Nomura and Merrill Lynch reckon it is undervalued.

The heart of Psion is now Teklogix, which develops mobile computing products for businesses, and its 28.8% stake in Symbian, the consortium developing the Epoc operating system for wireless devices.

Assuming that Teklogix makes its profits forecasts this year, on a conservative multiple of 20 times earnings it should be worth £240m, Nomura says.

As Psion's market capitalisation was £546m last night, this means investors are giving Symbian a value £306m, which seems harsh.

Although Symbian's valuation has been affected by the problems with the development of 3G technology, Merrill Lynch values Psion's stake at 140p, or about £550m.

Psion shares closed at 138p last night.

fields.headline: Bears maul Baltimore
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Confusion reigned yesterday, with stock market bears giving Baltimore Technologies a mauling as rumours of a massive share placing swept through the City.
fields.body:
Confusion reigned yesterday, with stock market bears giving Baltimore Technologies a mauling as rumours of a massive share placing swept through the City.

The internet security firm shed more than 6%, or 14.5p to 219.5p, amid speculation that the former shareholders of a company named Content Technology were preparing to dump 27m Baltimore shares - some 6% of the company - on to the market.

The speculation was traced to a note published by Jonathan Crozier, a security software analyst at German broker WestLB Panmure.

In the note, Mr Crozier lowered his rating on Baltimore to "market underperform" and said that 27m shares belonging to the former Content shareholders were being released from a lock-up next Thursday.

He went on to say that Balti more's chief executive, Fran Rooney, stated at a recent analysts' meeting that he was having discussions with the company's brokers - Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch - about placing the shares in the market.

While Mr Rooney may or may not be talking to his brokers about placing the shares, sources close to Baltimore insist that Mr Crozier - who has just taken up coverage of Baltimore - has got his figures wrong. They say the number of shares eligible for sale next week is 7.25m - with a further 11m due to be unlocked on April 25.

Baltimore acquired Content, an email security company, last year for £691m in shares, making millionaires of its founders. In October, Content shareholders decided to cash in some of their Baltimore shares in a placing arranged by Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch.

The session's other juicy story also derived from a placing. Dealers could not understand why Pearson fell 64p to £14.97p. After all, the media company - which owns the Financial Times - had posted better than expected figures.

Towards the end of the session the reason emerged. Ac cording to traders, Goldman Sachs was contacting the City's biggest institutions to see if they would be interested in buying Telefonica of Spain's 4% stake in Pearson.

In the interim, leading shares bounced back from Friday's two-year low, with the FTSE 100 closing 72.7 points higher at 5,931.3, after a rally in the telecoms sector.

Vodafone and BT contributed the bulk of the gains - with the former rising 7.75p to 189.75p ahead of tomorrow's annual investors' day, and the latter adding 27.5p to 559.5p on renewed speculation that its chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, is to retire early.

Marconi , up 38p to 485p, and Colt Telecom , 87p highger at £12.29, also chipped in with useful gains.

Elsewhere, the FTSE Techmark 100 closed 53.43 points higher at 2,301.86, led by ARM Holdings , 24.5p better at 334.5p, and Logica , 113p stronger at £14.84. Yet traders remained unconvinced by the market's performance.

Turnover was light, suggesting that the majority of the buying was related to short sellers closing their positions.

Senior traders said institutional money was being held back until the Budget, on Wednesday, and the meeting of the monetary policy committee, on Thursday, were out of the way.

Moreover, the lead from New York simply could not be trusted. Although the Nasdaq was higher by the time London closed, volumes were also light as much of Wall Street was staying at home because of a severe storm.

The flipside of the move back into the technology and telecoms sectors was underperformance from old economy favourites such as Dixons and Marks & Spencer .

Dixons ended 6.25p lower at 243.5p on reports that Merrill Lynch had lowered its recommendation to "neutral" ahead of the publication of the latest British Retail Consortium data. Apparently, electricals had another tough month in February.

Marks & Spencer lost 10.25p to 226.75p on concerns about trading.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Letsbuyit.com, the co-operative shopping website with the annoying animated ants TV ads, spluttered back to life last week - having been rescued from bankruptcy by a consortium with more money than, er, most people.
fields.body:
 Letsbuyit.com, the co-operative shopping website with the annoying animated ants TV ads, spluttered back to life last week - having been rescued from bankruptcy by a consortium with more money than, er, most people. Let's hope this latest incarnation of Letsbuyit is kinder to customers than the last one, which had one or two very minor technical hitches, such as not delivering goods that had been paid for. That was the experience of Patrick Davies, who ordered a camera from the site and had his credit card debited for the sale on December 2 last year, without ever receiving the camera. Or Meg Arnold, who was billed for a Palm Pilot personal organiser and, having not received it, cancelled the order more than a month later - only to get a reply saying (purely by chance) that Letsbuyit had shipped the goods that day. The Register website lit upon a nine-year-old boy who was enterprising enough to gather up the rubble that fell off the Starbucks HQ during last week's Seattle earthquake, and sell it on eBay, the online auction website. fields.headline: At this price? Celltech
fields.trailText: Peter Fellner, the chief executive of Celltech, may not look like the thrusting biotech entrepreneur, with his pinstripe suits and retiring manner, but he is proving to be very effective.
fields.body:
Peter Fellner, the chief executive of Celltech, may not look like the thrusting biotech entrepreneur, with his pinstripe suits and retiring manner, but he is proving to be very effective.

In typically low key fashion, Celltech, Britain's biggest biotech, yesterday revealed it had chosen Pharmacia as its world-wide partner for the "co-development and co-promotion" of its anti-arthritis compound, CDP 870.

The dry wording of yesterday's news does not suggest this is a very important deal. In fact, it is probably not going too far to say it a groundbreaking alliance. It is possibly the biggest deal a European biotech has made.

Under the terms of the agreement Pharmacia, the world leader in arthritis drugs, will sell injectable CDP 870 - which is designed to alleviate severe and moderate arthritis - alongside its blockbuster Celebrex, which treats milder forms of the disease.

Given the size of Pharmacia's trained sales force and franchise with rheumatologists, analysts predict peak annual sales for CDP 870 of $500m to $1.2bn (£820m).

In return for a slice of the action, Pharmacia is making an up-front payment of $50m to Celltech and payments of up to $230m based on the achievement of development and sales milestones.

Celltech will receive an undeclared share of profits in big markets and the rights to co-promote one of Pharmcia's, Arthrotec, a $250m-selling arthritis drug.

Of course there are risks. CDP 870 is in trials and will not reach the market until late 2003, by which time rival products such as Enbrel, made by US firm Immunex, may have cornered the market.

But CDP 870 has greater dosing flexibility and lower price in its favour. So far, trial patients are receiving a dose once a month. This compares with Enbrel, which is taken twice a week.

After yesterday's rise of 82p to £14.17, the question is how much of this is in the price? The shares reached £18 last March, which suggests there is upside from here. Buy.

webTitle: Labour plans purge of top rail jobs

fields.headline: Labour plans purge of top rail jobs
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Sir Alastair Morton, the chairman of the strategic rail authority, and a number of senior rail officials will be replaced if Labour wins the general election, government sources revealed last night.
fields.body:
Sir Alastair Morton, the chairman of the strategic rail authority, and a number of senior rail officials will be replaced if Labour wins the general election, government sources revealed last night.

The clear-out at the top of the industry has been threatened for some time by ministers, who have become increasingly disenchanted by the way in which the railways are run.

No action will be taken until after the election - although John Prescott, deputy prime minister, would like to see a reshuffle at Railtrack, which has been unsuccessfully seeking a chairman to succeed Sir Philip Beck.

Sir Alastair and his lieutenant at the SRA, Mike Grant, have been criticised by ministers for making little impression on the industry since the organisation was set up as a shadow authority, almost two years ago.

The SRA has failed to come up with a strategy for the industry and made little progress on letting new franchises. Sir Alastair particularly has irked ministers for failing to resolve a dispute between the Great North Eastern Railway and Stagecoach-Virgin Trains over operating the east coast main line. This could involve the building of a new high speed line between Scotland and London.

A replacement for Sir Alastair is already being discussed in the industry. Government sources said last night that Sir Alastair could stand down without losing face after issuing the SRA's long-awaited strategy for the industry in the summer.

By then, he and Mr Grant would have less than a year of their three-year contracts to run, and a new broom could be brought in to start sweeping almost immediately.

The most likely candidate is Richard Bowker, a senior executive with Virgin Trains. Mr Bowker is considered by the government to be young and energetic with a wide practical experience of the industry.

Mr Bowker worked for London Underground before joining Virgin. He has been generally credited with drawing up plans for a fast, 120-mile rail route through eastern England. The route would take 10 years to build and cut the Edinburgh-London journey to little more than three hours.

Government sources said that to win Mr Bowker from the private sector it might be possible to merge Sir Alastair's part-time job with that of Mr Grant. Sir Alastair receives a salary of about £160,000 and works a two and a half day week, suggesting that ministers would offer £300,000 to his successor.

 Belgian-Dutch financial group Fortis said yesterday the claims resulting from the train accident in Britain last week would have a "negligible" effect on its results. Fortis said that its British business, Fortis Insurance, insured the driver of the Land Rover that careered off a motorway on to a railway line but the risk was covered by reinsurance.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Ford completes deal for Hertz
Ford Motor said yesterday it had completed its tender offer for the remaining publicly held shares of car rental company Hertz.
fields.body:
Ford completes deal for Hertz
Ford Motor said yesterday it had completed its tender offer for the remaining publicly held shares of car rental company Hertz.

Ford said it received and accepted about 19.4m of the 20.3m class A Hertz common shares it did not already own in the $35.50 (£24) per share tender, which expired on March 2. Remaining Hertz shares will be acquired in a merger at the same price in about a week.

Refinancing of TWA proposed
An investor group headed by investment banker Brian Freeman said it had submitted a plan to reorganise bankrupt Trans World Airlines with $650m (£442m) in financing from financier Carl Icahn. The offer is intended as an alternative to the sale of TWA to American Airlines parent AMR - planned by TWA and AMR.

Other groups, including Jet Acquisitions Group and Global Airlines, have also submitted buyout offers as alternatives to AMR's plan. Those bids are being considered as part of an auction of TWA's assets. TWA met with bidders yesterday as part of the court-ordered auction process. The Freeman group's offer would not be part of the auction but proposes a reorganisation outside of that process.

Biotech firm plans listing
British biotech firm Oxford Biomedica aims to raise £20m-£30m this month ahead of its move to a full London Stock Exchange listing, a company spokesman said yesterday.

Oxford Biomedica, which is working on gene therapy treatment for cancer and other diseases, has already secured interest from institutional shareholders, and a share offering is expected to be completed in two or three weeks.

Equitable offers bonus hope
Troubled insurer Equitable Life said yesterday it will consider recommencing the payment of guaranteed bonuses to policyholders later this year as it issued its payout figures for 2000.

It announced rates of return for the year of 3.3% for most pension policies and 2.8% for products such as endowments. Policyholders had to forgo seven months' investment growth to cover liabilities.

fields.headline: Chez Gérard beefs up profits
fields.trailText: Upmarket restaurant chain Groupe Chez Gérard has hoarded two months' supply of Scottish beef in order to ensure steak-frites stays on its menu despite the ravages of foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Upmarket restaurant chain Groupe Chez Gérard has hoarded two months' supply of Scottish beef in order to ensure steak-frites stays on its menu despite the ravages of foot and mouth disease.

The company, which claims to serve "the best steak-frites this side of Paris", has also helped its suppliers in Aberdeenshire to secure one of the first four licences to transport livestock since the outbreak of the disease last month.

Chez Gérard yesterday announced a 3.9% increase in half-year pre-tax profits to £2.1m.

Its chief executive, David Williams, said he was confident of riding out the crisis.

"Our view is, first of all, one of great sympathy for the farming industry, which has been hit very hard. But we've always used British suppliers and we're as well positioned as we possibly could be in the current circumstances."

The group recently took its Chez Gérard and Livebait chains to Manchester, its first openings outside London, and has earmarked sites in Nottingham, Bath, Leeds, Edinburgh and Brighton.

Analysts pointed out that other upmarket chains such as Fish! and Gaucho Grill were expanding into the provinces. Greg Feehley, of Old Mutual Securities, said: "They're not really getting much growth out of their existing portfolio so it all depends on openings outside London. The problem is that the world and its wife is doing the same."

Like for like sales were up 2.5%. But the group's one-off "signature" restaurants, which include Bertorelli's, Scotts and Soho Soho, had a tough year.

The company is on track to open 20 restaurants over two years. Its shares yesterday edged up 0.5p to 153p.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Homeless get banking service
fields.body:
Homeless get banking service

Britain's first banking service for the homeless was today launched by the Bank of Scotland and the Big Issue yesterday. The scheme, based at the Big Issue's Scottish HQ in Glasgow, offers homeless people a way of depositing and withdrawing sums from as little as a pound at a time.

Girl savaged by bull terrier

A man was arrested under the Dangerous Dogs Act after seven-year-old Kathryn Ambrose was mauled by a bull terrier while playing in her grandmother's garden in Norris Green, Liverpool, police said yesterday. She was undergoing plastic surgery at Alder Hey Children's hospital last night.

Open verdict on prison death

A jury at the City of London coroners court yesterday returned an open verdict on Cheryl Hartman, 20, of Park Royal, north London, who hanged herself in her cell in Holloway prison last June just 10 days after being transferred from the psychiatric wing to the young offenders' unit, where she had been bullied. The deputy coroner for the City of London, Paul Matthews, said he would be writing to the governor of Holloway to express his concern at the number of deaths at the prison.

Green fuel giveaway

Drivers were yesterday queuing up for free diesel at a temporary service station in Edinburgh's Ferry Road, as Greenpeace offered 7,000 litres of bio-diesel, a plant-based fuel not commercially available in the UK. Greenpeace is planning to repeat the exercise in Glasgow today.

Beatles school reports for sale

Sir Paul McCartney had a higher IQ than George Harrison when they were 11, according to the former Beatles' secondary school entrance exam cards. In 1953, aged 11.2, Sir Paul had a rating of 137, while in 1954, aged 11.6, Harrison had one of 117. The cards will be auctioned at Phillips on March 30.

Marr to head book prize panel

The BBC's political editor, Andrew Marr, is to chair the judges for this year's £30,000 Samuel Johnson non-fiction prize.

fields.headline: Dozens killed in pilgrims' stampede
fields.trailText: The stoning of Satan, the most perilous of duties performed annually by millions of Muslims, yesterday consumed the lives of 35 pilgrims in a stampede, which has become almost as much of a regular event as the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia itself.
fields.body:
The stoning of Satan, the most perilous of duties performed annually by millions of Muslims, yesterday consumed the lives of 35 pilgrims in a stampede, which has become almost as much of a regular event as the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia itself.

The official Saudi Press Agency said that 23 women and 12 men were killed, and unknown numbers injured as a wave of pilgrims surged in front of one of three giant pillars in the Mina valley which symbolise the devil.

It was the third time in seven years that pilgrims have died in stampedes at the stoning point on Jamarat bridge, crushes which Saudi religious authorities attribute to the huge numbers involved.

Witnesses blamed the stampede on overzealous pilgrims: "It was very crowded and a lot of pushing was going on," said a Turkish pilgrim named Fateeh. "I knew something was wrong when I saw ambulances, but I had no idea that so many people were killed and hurt."

The Jamarat bridge was the scene of two similar stampedes: in 1998, when at least 118 people were killed, and 1994 when 270 pilgrims died.

Hours after the crush yesterday, helicopters flew overhead and police urged people to move on. Scores of ambulances were parked nearby.

The pillars symbolising the devil are at the centre of giant ramps built to accommodate the pilgrims who must complete the stoning ritual by dusk. Muslim tradition says it was here that the devil tried to tempt the prophet Abraham to disobey God by refusing to sacrifice his son. Abraham, his wife Hagar and their son are said to have thrown seven stones each at the devil. It is the duty of each of the Hajj's 1.8m pilgrims to cast 21 pebbles at the pillars.

webTitle: Pro-Putin party calls for vote of no confidence in government

fields.headline: Pro-Putin party calls for vote of no confidence in government
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russian politics were in flux last night when President Vladimir Putin's loyal disciples in parliament called for a vote of no confidence in the government.
fields.body:
Russian politics were in flux last night when President Vladimir Putin's loyal disciples in parliament called for a vote of no confidence in the government. The move, by the Unity party, the second biggest caucus in the duma, follows similar calls by the communists a fortnight ago.

The surprise move could bring down the government of the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, trigger the dissolution of parliament and herald fresh elections only 15 months into the life of the current duma.

Although the Kremlin enjoys broad support from a comparatively docile parliament, new elections could see Unity, a Putin instrument, supplant the communists as the biggest party in the duma and guarantee Mr Putin even greater uncritical backing.

Rumours have been circulating in Moscow since the start of the year about Mr Putin wanting to be rid of the prime minister and undertake a cabinet reshuffle, but it was not clear if the Kremlin was behind last night's move.

Frants Klintsevich, deputy head of Unity in parliament, said a final decision would be taken today on whether a vote of no confidence would be taken.

"We don't think the government is working badly. We want to dissolve the duma and have new parliamentary elections," he said.

Between them, Unity and the communists can comfortably muster the 226 votes needed for the no confidence motion to succeed. The Kremlin could ignore the result, but would have to respond to a second no confidence vote by either replacing the government or dissolving parliament.

Mr Klintsevich said a first vote of no confidence could take place next week and new elections could happen in September.

Boris Gryzlov, the Unity leader in parliament, predicted that his party would take up to 40% of seats in new elections, about double the tally it won in December 1999.

It was clear that Unity would base its campaign on a simple single issue of support for President Putin, hoping to capitalise on his huge approval ratings of around 70%. Mr Putin is due to hold a one-hour internet conference later today, during which he will answer the questions of journalists from Russian online sites.

Gennady Zyuganov, the lacklustre leader of the communists who challenged Mr Putin for the presidency a year ago, said he was surprised at the Unity move and speculated that Mr Putin would dismiss the government rather than dissolve parliament.

"If the president backs a government whose policies do not suit the entire nation, this will mean he has decided to sink with this government. I don't think he will make such a choice."

Sergei Ivanenko,the deputy leader in parliament of the small liberal Yabloko party, said that yesterday's Unity move was not engineered by the Kremlin but a result of political intrigues within the party. He added that his party, too, was dissatisfied with the performance of the government and could support the no confidence vote.

His party colleague, Vladimir Lukin, a former Russian ambassador to Washington, was mystified by the possibility of Mr Putin welcoming new elections: "It's impossible to elect an even more obedient duma."

Former president Boris Yeltsin was locked in unproductive power struggles with parliament for years, and repeatedly sacked his prime ministers. But Mr Putin has been determined to consolidate power while maintaining stability and the parliamentary shock may provide him with an opportunity to shake up the cabinet and emerge with an even more loyal legislature.

Unity was created from nothing at breakneck speed in 1999 as a vehicle for mobilising support behind a Putin presidency. It stunned analysts by polling almost a quarter of the vote in elections.
fields.bodyText: Russian politics were in flux last night when President Vladimir Putin's loyal disciples in parliament called for a vote of no confidence in the government. The move, by the Unity party, the second biggest caucus in the duma, follows similar calls by the communists a fortnight ago. The surprise move could bring down the government of the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, trigger the dissolution of parliament and herald fresh elections only 15 months into the life of the current duma. Although the Kremlin enjoys broad support from a comparatively docile parliament, new elections could see Unity, a Putin instrument, supplant the communists as the biggest party in the duma and guarantee Mr Putin even greater uncritical backing. Rumours have been circulating in Moscow since the start of the year about Mr Putin wanting to be rid of the prime minister and undertake a cabinet reshuffle, but it was not clear if the Kremlin was behind last night's move. Frants Klintsevich, deputy head of Unity in parliament, said a final decision would be taken today on whether a vote of no confidence would be taken. "We don't think the government is working badly. We want to dissolve the duma and have new parliamentary elections," he said. Between them, Unity and the communists can comfortably muster the 226 votes needed for the no confidence motion to succeed. The Kremlin could ignore the result, but would have to respond to a second no confidence vote by either replacing the government or dissolving parliament. Mr Klintsevich said a first vote of no confidence could take place next week and new elections could happen in September. Boris Gryzlov, the Unity leader in parliament, predicted that his party would take up to 40% of seats in new elections, about double the tally it won in December 1999. fields.headline: Nursery teacher broke two-year-old's arm
fields.trailText: A nursery teacher was yesterday found guilty of grievous bodily harm after breaking a two-year-old's arm when he fidgeted during a nap.
fields.body:
A nursery teacher was yesterday found guilty of grievous bodily harm after breaking a two-year-old's arm when he fidgeted during a nap.

Helen Lamb, 27, from Cheadle Hulme, Greater Manchester, denied harming the boy. A jury at Manchester crown court was told how the teacher at the private Greenbank nursery school must have twisted the boy's arm until he howled. She then made him sit on his own with his arm dangling from its socket.

On January 6 last year, Lamb's class of nine, aged 18 months to two years, were settled on to mattresses for an afternoon nap, though the boy was settled onto a beanbag because he did not care too much for a nap. Lamb's co-teacher, Lisa Dare, 20, left Lamb in charge while she went for lunch.

Susan Klonin, prosecuting, said it was impossible to determine what happened when the boy was alone with Lamb. But it was likely that the child had wanted to leave his beanbag, and was yanked back because Lamb did not want to be disturbed. She said the fracture could not have been taken for an accident or gone unnoticed. "It would have caused him to cry out in pain for a significant time."

After the verdict, Kevin Phillips, headteacher of Greenbank, said he had undertaken an extensive review of procedure.

Judge Stuart Fish adjourned sentencing for three weeks.

fields.headline: Chechen corpses 'show signs of torture'
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: The number of Chechen corpses discovered in an abandoned holiday village outside Grozny has risen to more than 50, with investigators reporting signs of torture.
fields.body:
The number of Chechen corpses discovered in an abandoned holiday village outside Grozny has risen to more than 50, with investigators reporting signs of torture.

Several of the corpses had their ears missing, most had their arms bound behind their backs and many had been blindfolded.

The identities of several of the dead men and women were revealed yesterday with the publication of an investigation by a Russian human rights organisation, Memorial.

Several of the dead had disappeared shortly after being detained by the Russians at the end of last year, the report said. Their corpses were found during the past week hidden in basements or partially buried in ditches in Zdorovye.

Russian officials claimed initially that the dead were rebel fighters killed up to a year ago, when fighting was active in the region, but said later they were rebels killed during internal guerrilla disputes.

The village is in a heavily guarded area near Khankala, Russia's main military headquarters, where many detained Chechens are held.

Oleg Orlov, the president of Memorial, inspected 23 of the bodies at an impromptu morgue in Grozny. He said he was convinced they were the victims of illegal punishments meted out by the Russian army, and represented "incontrovertible proof of war crimes by the Russian forces".

fields.headline: Ex-paramilitary warns of terrorism deaths
fields.standfirst:
Real IRA could have carried out 28 Ulster attacks in year

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Real IRA will almost certainly murder people in mainland Britain as it continues its terrorist campaign for a united Ireland, a former republican paramilitary, now   totally opposed to violence, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Real IRA will almost certainly murder people in mainland Britain as it continues its terrorist campaign for a united Ireland, a former republican paramilitary, now totally opposed to violence, said yesterday.

Ex-Provisional IRA man, Anthony McIntyre, said he did not believe the dissidents who bombed the BBC headquarters in London had the ability to sustain a campaign on the level of past Provo activity, but he did not underestimate them.

"Omagh should never have happened and when it did, those should have been the last deaths, but we won't change these people's [dissidents'] minds," he said. "The Real IRA will probably kill more people in the pursuit of their goals."

The renegade group's worst outrage, the 1998 Omagh bomb, which killed 29 people and injured hundreds, caused a worldwide backlash, forcing them to call a temporary ceasefire.

But they have been stepping up their activities again in Northern Ireland, where security sources believe it could have been behind as many as 28 attempted attacks in the past year, and in London, where operations included a rocket launch on the MI6 building last September, and bombs at Hammersmith and Acton, west London.

Mr McIntyre, who served 18 years for murdering a loyalist, says a Panorama documentary naming four men suspected of the Omagh bombing made the BBC an "acceptable" target, but the primary objective was maximum publicity.

The televised explosion would be regarded as a major propaganda coup, he said. But "republicans should have found out by now, armed strategy is the road to disaster. You can't tweak a few bolts in Frankenstein's neck and hope no one gets hurt".

He is certain the Real IRA has an eye on projecting an exciting image to young potential recruits with no previous record.

"I know what made me join the Provisional IRA at 16," he said. "There is a romance and glamour in operations like that, and the Real IRA will have noted the effect that televised reconstructions of the MI6 hit had."

Major carnage has been avoided in several attacks in Northern Ireland through RUC intelligence and sheer good luck.

In January, a dozen soldiers narrowly avoided death when a mortar bomb partially exploded just a few feet from where they lay asleep at Ebrington barracks in Derry, while security information foiled a 1,100lb bomb beside a road, near Armagh, used by army vehicles.

One security source feels that the dissidents may have turned their attention toward the mainland, and softer, non-military targets, because they were being thwarted at home.

"I don't expect there will be attacks every week, it will be more sporadic. The fear factor, with the public not knowing when or where they will strike next, is what terrorism thrives on," he said.

The weekend explosion has put new pressure on the stumbling political process.

Tony Blair is determined to move the situation on, or at very least avoid the appearance that things are irretrievably deadlocked, by getting all sides back round the negotiating table on Thursday to thrash out the problems regarding policing, decommissioning and demilitarisation.

But the Real IRA bomb, and ominous portent of more to come, could hamper an early deal in several ways.

Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble is convinced the Real IRA's weaponry and expertise have come from the Provisionals and will press all the harder for paramilitary disarmament, while insisting the security scaledown demanded by republicans is foolhardy in light of the current dissident threat.

Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams will point to the dissidents as an example of the extreme dangers of further splits in the republican movement should the government try to force his hand on decommissioning.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Some see journalism as a cold-blooded trade, but in fact nothing pleases us more than helping out an old friend. Take the Home Office minister Barbara Roche, as Max Miller must have put it. Turncoat candidate Babs revealed recently that the expelled asylum seekers target rises from 12,000 this financial year to 30,000 next. Large ones all round at the Mail, then?
fields.body:
 Some see journalism as a cold-blooded trade, but in fact nothing pleases us more than helping out an old friend. Take the Home Office minister Barbara Roche, as Max Miller must have put it. Turncoat candidate Babs revealed recently that the expelled asylum seekers target rises from 12,000 this financial year to 30,000 next. Large ones all round at the Mail, then?

No, not quite. Unwittingly, Babs has confused an issue we are thrilled to clarify for her now. In the excitement she forgot a vital change in the method of calculating removals. Dependants are not counted now but will be next year: two parents with three children count as one removal today, to illustrate, but will be numbered as five next year. In other words, by way of a classic case of New Labour accounting, the removal figure could leap to 30,000 with fewer people leaving the country.

Didn't Babs gloss over this when trumpeting the policy, we ask the Home Office's Gemma Smith once she has confirmed the facts. "Not at all. It seems fairly obvious to me." So obvious that you've chosen not to spell it out? "I think the gap between the two figures speaks for itself," says Gemma firmly, and is gone.

 Meanwhile, the 12th Turncoat has been selected. Well done to you Kim Howells for edging out Jim Fitzpatrick for the final slot. Diary pundit Steptoe gives Kim, a full account of whose spectacular turncoatery will appear soon, an opening price of 18-1. Favourite Peter Hain is on the slide, however, out to 2-1, with Robin Cook looking the main danger and in to 4-1.

 How long now before it's mitres off to Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke? Next Sunday's The God List on Channel 4 will unveil "the 50 individuals whose personal beliefs have the most impact on the way we live", and Steve is in at 29, three places above chief rabbi Jonathan Sachs, with the Queen ambling in further down at 37.

Then again, no one has a clue what, if any, her personal beliefs are, so she's lucky to be there at all - luckier than the Archbishop of York who fails to make the cut. We will talk to Rev Steve about this, and ask him to gauge what part his career as Diary vicar played in his elevation, very soon.

 I am worried by Janet Street-Porter's column in the Rambler. "Talking of ageing, I have just returned from a short holiday in Hawaii with extremely swollen knee joints, the result of a series of exciting ridge walks on the island of Oahu," writes Janet of a recurrent injury. "I hate to admit any kind of physical impairment, so when my knees swelled up to twice their size I resorted to sleeping with ice packs around the offending areas."

Poor old girl, how far from yoof those ballooning knees have taken her. Meanwhile, the blurb at the end reads: "Janet Street-Porter is a TV personality, Rambler's vice president, and editor of the Independent on Sunday." Ah, priorities, priorities...

 Faint signs of life are noted in the Melton Times, one of the four local papers whose petrified indulgence of MP Little Alan Duncan (not a word about his work for Marc Rich and as consultant to a Yemeni arms dealer in any of them) featured here last week. The Melton Times not only mentions references here but asks him about Mr Rich itself, Little A insisting he hasn't spoken to him in years. And asked after Diary coverage, meanwhile, he replies: "it does become tiresome, but one does have to have broad shoulders... A free press is also entitled to be a poisonous press." Impudent little squit.

 We await confirmation, but the word in the gay community is that the hottest new icon is my friend Richard Littlejohn, columnist for the Sun. It sounds crazy, but who in advance could have made up a duet between Elton John and Eminem? Anyone who knows more about this phenomenon, and which gay mag is planning to feature Richard as pin-up of the month, should contact us at once in confidence.

fields.headline: Portuguese anger at bridge deaths
fields.standfirst:
Government minister resigns after river sweeps away part of cracked, rusting structure, killing 70

Audio: Giles Tremlett in Madrid (1min 35)
fields.trailText: Portugal faced a political crisis yesterday as popular outrage grew over the worst national tragedy for decades when a rusting roadbridge collapsed and killed 70 people.
fields.byline: Giles Tremlett in Castelo da Paiva
fields.body:
Portugal faced a political crisis yesterday as popular outrage grew over the worst national tragedy for decades when a rusting roadbridge collapsed and killed 70 people.

A busload of 64 day trippers, including many children, and the occupants of two cars met their deaths in the murky, swollen waters of the northern river Douro.

The river swept away a 76-metre stretch of iron bridge and a 30-metre high stone pillar. The narrow, rusty structure now reaches just half way across the river. Jagged points of torn metal mark the spot where the iron was wrenched apart.

Yesterday it emerged that cracks had earlier been spotted in the bridge's structure and the town hall had been campaigning for a new bridge for more than a decade.

Distraught and angry families huddled in the mist above the river waiting for news. "There were complete families on that bus," said Rui Cesar, a town councillor. "There must have been many, many children in there."

He said the tragedy would leave deep scars in Castelo da Paiva, a market town of 17,000 people. "I know at least one friend of mine was in there. Everybody has lost someone they know or someone from their family," he said.

A senior government minister, Jorge Coelho, whose public works ministry is responsible for rail and road transport, yesterday announced his "irrevocable" resignation from the government.

The prime minister, Antonio Guterres, was jeered when he arrived in Castelo de Paiva to witness the recovery operation. He pledged a full investigation.

"What if it had been your son?" one man shouted at him.

The government declared two days of national mourning from today, with flags on public buildings to fly at half-mast.

Eduardo Moreira, a local man who was the only eyewitness to the accident, said he saw the lights of the bus under the water as it sank and was pulled downstream by the current.

"They suddenly disappeared, I couldn't believe it," he said. "The current is massive."

Rescue workers admitted that strong winds and a fierce current were hampering the search for bodies. By late afternoon only three bodies had been pulled from the river. Two of them were found about two miles downstream - a sign of the strength of the Douro's current.

A temporary morgue set up at a local sports centre remained empty.

Mr Coelho said that 70 people were thought to have been travelling in the three vehicles that plummeted into the river, while the local mayor, Paulo Teixeira, said he believed 77 people had died. "Whole families have been lost," he said.

National fire service divers suspended operations shortly before dark because of the risks posed by the fast-flowing water, although teams in boats continued to probe the banks for bodies.

"If conditions in the water do not change, we run a tremendous risk of seeing a further tragedy," a senior diver, Vitor Hugo, said.

Mr Teixeira said he had repeatedly warned the government of the parlous state of the 116-year-old bridge, which was built for horse-drawn carts rather than motor vehicles.

"I warned a long time ago about the state of that bridge and I have fought as hard as I can to get it replaced," Mr Teixeira said.

There were already restrictions on vehicles with heavy loads crossing the bridge.

"We have even held press conferences on that bridge to warn how dangerous it is," Mr Cesar added.

Convoys of troops continued to arrive late into the day to assist with the search, but could do little more than join the onlookers.

Police officers were posted along the dam at Lever, 12 miles downstream. "We are waiting for the bodies to appear here, but we have not seen a thing," admitted one officer.

In Castelo da Paiva, locals blamed political ineptitude and a company that extracts sand from a stretch of river beside the bridge. The sand, known locally as white gold, is used for the construction industry.

"They take three boatloads a day from the river," said Lucia Serreira, who lives beside the bridge.

Locals said engineers from the University of Oporto had claimed three years ago that the bridge's pillars were shaking.

Lots of people gathered on the roadsides of villages near the bridge yesterday asking those who drove past for information about friends and relatives.

These were the villages which had waved whole families off on a twin-decked bus for a day's outing on Sunday. They had gone to see the almond trees blossoming further up the Douro valley.

Yesterday their families were demanding that they at least be given bodies to mourn.

Portuguese politicians, unable to explain how the bridge was allowed to disintegrate, were unable to promise that the bodies would be retrieved soon.

"I warned a long time ago about the state of that bridge and I have fought as hard as I can to get it replaced," Mr Teixeira said. There were already restrictions on vehicles with heavy loads crossing the bridge. "We have even held press conferences on that bridge to warn how dangerous it is," Mr Cesar added. Convoys of troops continued to arrive late into the day to assist with the search, but could do little more than join the onlookers. Police officers were posted along the dam at Lever, 12 miles downstream. "We are waiting for the bodies to appear here, but we have not seen a thing," admitted one officer. In Castelo da Paiva, locals blamed political ineptitude and a company that extracts sand from a stretch of river beside the bridge. The sand, known locally as white gold, is used for the construction industry. "They take three boatloads a day from the river," said Lucia Serreira, who lives beside the bridge. Locals said engineers from the University of Oporto had claimed three years ago that the bridge's pillars were shaking. Lots of people gathered on the roadsides of villages near the bridge yesterday asking those who drove past for information about friends and relatives. These were the villages which had waved whole families off on a twin-decked bus for a day's outing on Sunday. They had gone to see the almond trees blossoming further up the Douro valley. Yesterday their families were demanding that they at least be given bodies to mourn. Portuguese politicians, unable to explain how the bridge was allowed to disintegrate, were unable to promise that the bodies would be retrieved soon. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Swiss still want to be part of EU | Rwanda returns to the polls | Rwanda returns to the polls | Monica agrees to tell all on film
fields.body:
Swiss still want to be part of EU

Switzerland yesterday reaffirmed its commitment to joining the EU despite a resounding "no" vote in a weekend referendum on seeking closer EU ties now.

The government said the vote was a sign the Swiss want a "slowly, slowly" approach to joining the EU. "The goal [of membership] remains," said the foreign ministry spokesman, Rüdi Christen.
Reuters, Zurich

Rwanda returns to the polls

Rwanda holds its first district council elections in 35 years today; a major step to returning to normal political life after the genocide of 1m people in 1994.

The international community is paying half the £3.4m costs of the polls. Parliamentary and presidential elections will be held in three years, after a new constitution is drafted and ratified in a referendum.
Victoria Brittain

Rwanda returns to the polls

The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, survived a second no-confidence motion yesterday and called the result a victory.

The lower house of parliament, where his Liberal Democrats hold a majority, voted 274-192 against the motion but Mr Mori's support ratings are below 10%, and there is still speculation that he could leave office this week.
AP, Tokyo

Monica agrees to tell all on film

Monica Lewinsky has agreed to take part in a TV film for the Home Box Office channel about her affair with Bill Clinton and its impact on the US.

The former White House intern told the New York Times this week that time has given her a new perspective on her affair with the president.
AP, New York

fields.headline: An overnight success
fields.trailText: Crossroads | Coronation Street | Jumpers For Goalposts
fields.body:
The only time anyone canvassed my views on anything was when a woman with a clipboard and pinned-on smile asked if I would care to answer a few questions about television. I was elated and said so. She seemed surprised, then nervous. What were my favourite programmes? I said Crossroads and Scooby Doo, for I was very truthful in my youth. And my profession? If any? TV critic of the Guardian. "Oh well," she said, "if we're going to be silly...." And flounced off.

I loved Crossroads. When it was axed in 1988, I went to a sale of the effects. Beside the tear-stained chintz sofa on which Meg Richardson ("Sit down, dear") sorted out so many fraught lives was a filing cabinet full of viewers' letters, all eagerly enquiring about the rates and availability of a chalet. And who would not have happily spent a surreal week at Crossroads, where you might easily see Amy Turtle being levitated, or Benny, the bobble-hatted handyman, returning from his six-month search for a spanner.

Bright new producers improved it out of all recognition. Noele Gordon, who behaved like Queen Marie of Romania, was axed and waved away on the QE2. It certainly killed her. Benny, whose impact was out of all proportion to his part, was sent up a Christmas tree and never came down again. Amy Turtle, a natural card, who took to show business like a duck, was wonderful at opening shops but written out when copped shoplifting. Miss Diane died suddenly of a brain haemorrhage after a sharp difference of opinion with the producer about salary. Oh, Miss Diane!

Trading on the brand name and our undying devotion, Carlton have revived Crossroads . If it weren't for Tony Hatch's theme tune (ding, dingally dong ) you wouldn't know the old place. It is now a four-star hotel with a dozen youngsters in the galley and experienced actors on the bridge.

Drifting through all this is the ghost of Crossroads past. Jill (Jane Rossington), Meg Richardson's wayward daughter, has appeared in a puff of smoke to irritate the new management. She has, she says, just buried her husband and is hoovering up booze at the bar. As Doris Luke (Kathy Staff), another substantial ghost from the old days, said with more truth than tact , "You 'aven't 'ad much luck with men, 'ave you?" In the old Crossroads, Jill was married three times, once bigamously, and had a child by her step-brother. She also astounded medical science with an 11-month pregnancy, and this child, Sarah-Jane, is scheduled to appear shortly.

Kathy Staff did not apply for her old job in Crossroads. She says she was told she was in it and accepted. You perfectly recognise the feeling of oh-well-why-not. As daytime soaps go, it is polished, promising and prettily packaged. And not a syllable of that sounds like Crossroads.

Meanwhile, back in Coronation Street (Granada), Deirdre has left Ken again. He told her they are moving to Scotland and might as well have said Sri Lanka. Outside a soap bubble, everything is Indian country. "Scotland! What would we do there!", cried Deirdre, her throat a-throb, and exited stage right in a marked manner. Leaving her mother behind with Ken. You could study marital strategy for months and not come up with a neater trick than that.

Jumpers For Goalposts (Sky 1) is an anarchic panel game spun off a Fast Show sketch. The team captains Ron Manager (Paul Whitehouse) and Tommy Stein (Mark Williams) have been adversely affected in youth by heading mud encrusted leather balls. Ron sees only a rosy glow while Tommy sees a red mist. Of the bemused players, Noel Gallagher seemed to communicate with one middle finger. The chairman (Simon Day) confirms what one has often suspected, that this is a job for a very sad man indeed. "I'm a single man at the moment. I eat out most nights at the local pizzeria. I sit by the window and watch the traffic go by. All the cars, the lights and the faces. They seem to form a sort of sea. I find it strangely comforting. OK! Let's move on!"

There are also useful half-time scores from other quizzes. Watch it, you will have the added benefit of missing the news.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: A sight for sore eyes
fields.trailText: A sight for sore eyes
fields.body:
Wiltshire

Horningsham Church stands on the rim of a valley shaped like a shallow bowl. From beside the church, you look out as if from the back row of an amphitheatre at what Pevsner called "a singularly loose village ... with no visual cohesion". It struck us as a particularly happy arrangement of farms and cottages strung across gentle slopes. One can see why the powerful 16th-century Seymours and Thynnes valued this part of Wiltshire, with the generous curves of its downs and complementary hollows. They make for splendid views. A Seymour was granted lands here when the King married his sister, and a Thynne who was comptroller of the Princess Elizabeth's household built magnifi cently nearby. It was a mile or so for us, past the flock of geese on the millpond and up into the woods, to the spot where a track leads through a fir plantation and opens out onto one of the classic scenes of English landscape.

The sweep of the natural contours, generations of aristocratic wealth and flair, and the artifice of Capability Brown combine to provide the prospect you see from Heaven's Gate. To the left, the stream runs down the gentle slope, through a series of dammed ponds, some with islands, and under My Lady's Bridge to Half-Mile Pond, beside the sumptuous, symmetrical mass of Longleat House. Further across to the right, we could just make out some grazing animals. We thought at first they were deer, but as we walked along the path just below the beechwood, they began to look more like bison, or maybe wildebeest. The Wiltshire scene accommodates the exotic beasts of the safari park without a sense of incongruity.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: A Summer's Tale | Live football
fields.body:
Films

A Summer's Tale (Eric Rohmer, 1996) 6pm, FilmFour One of Rohmer's Tales Of The Four Seasons, a typically delicate chamber piece that seems quite frivolous, until you find yourself on the edge of your seat wondering how it will be resolved. This midsummer comedy has Melvil Poupard as Gaspard, a student holidaying in Brittany, awaiting the arrival of his girlfriend (Aurelia Nolin). There he strikes up a strictly platonic relationship with another student (Amanda Langlet) and a more physical one with her friend (Gwenaëlle Simon). So there's the choice: will he plump for the affair romantic, intellectual, or sexual? A very funny, perceptive little masterpiece.

Wild Wild West (Barry Sonnenfeld, 1999) 8pm, Sky Premier Sonnenfeld's disappointing follow-up to the smash-hit Men In Black is a western spoof that forgot to stir in the jokes. And despite a fusillade of special effects, a predictable plot and flat script leave it mainly dull. Will Smith and Kevin Kline, though, employ their idiosyncratic brands of charm as odd-couple federal agents. They are matched against Kenneth Branagh's criminal mastermind Dr Arliss Loveless, who with his giant mechanical spider looks like a baddy out of Jules Verne. Salma Hayek helps liven it up a little, too.

Malcolm X (Spike Lee, 1992) 10pm, FilmFour This lengthy biopic of the 60s black militant leader finds Lee in curiously subdued mood - perhaps he felt the weight of history too heavily on his shoulders. It's an intelligent and thorough job, following Malcolm from his days as a street hustler through to his leadership of the Nation of Islam, but it badly needs some of the fizz of Lee's earlier work. Still, Denzel Washington is a suitably charismatic presence as Malcolm, oozing commitment and delivering the speeches with real fire.

What Ever Happened To Baby Jane? (Robert Aldrich, 1962) 12midnight, Sky Cinema In all their years as screen goddesses, Joan Crawford (at MGM) and Bette Davis (at Warners) had never appeared together until Aldrich pulled them in for this glorious piece of grand guignol. It's a real heavyweight title fight, with, apparently, plenty of spitting and snarling behind the scenes. The pair play sisters whose illustrious careers in the movies and vaudeville are now behind them: Crawford's poor Blanche is locked in the decrepit house without the use of her legs and horribly persecuted by Davis's deranged Jane. It looks almost comically excessive now, but as a document of old Hollywood it's fascinating.

Sport

Live football 7pm ONsport2; 7.30pm ONsport1 Leeds United have already qualified from Group D of the Champions' League, along with tonight's opponents, the Spanish league leaders Real Madrid. So it might be a slightly low-key encounter, particularly with Real having played Barcelona at the weekend. Can England beat Spain for the second week running? Don't bet on it. Arsenal, meanwhile, must beat Spartak Moscow at Highbury over on ONsport1.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Wood For The Trees | File On 4| It'll Never Last...
fields.body:
There has been controversy about the Forestry Commission's vast acreages of conifers since they were originally planted in the 1920s. Conceived almost entirely in economic terms, they were condemned as a thoroughly undesirable alternative to Britain's native broad-leaved trees. Now, as Jeremy Cherfas discloses in Wood For The Trees (11.0am, Radio 4), even the economic case has vanished. He reports from the 230-square-mile Kielder Forest how imports of cheap timber and pulp have killed the market. Now what?

A year ago an RAF Tornado bomber came within 100ft of a passenger plane on its final approach to Newcastle airport - the 87th near-collision of a military and civilian aircraft since 1990. With the partial pri vatisation of air traffic control still on the agenda, File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4) discovers that breaches of aircraft separation rules have doubled in a decade.

Alan Whicker's survey of 70 years of British television recalls two decisive moments. Incredible though it now seems, various palace flunkies tried to stop the BBC televising the 1953 coronation. It'll Never Last... (9.0pm, Radio 2) shows how that single day's broadcast generated a boom in TV sets that entrenched the medium in millions of British parlours. The emergence of this huge new audience immediately brought pressures on the Churchill government, whose supporters saw television advertising as an unparalleled licence to print money. Enter commercial television.

fields.headline: 'Take your life in your own hands, that's my philosophy'
fields.standfirst: Petra Brockmöller is hoping to end her life with the help of her doctor - and the Dutch legislature, which is decriminalising euthanasia. Will other nations follow its lead, asks Clare Dyer
fields.trailText: Petra Brockmöller is hoping to end her life with the help of her doctor - and the Dutch legislature, which is decriminalising euthanasia. Will other nations follow its lead, asks Clare Dyer
fields.body:
The winter sunlight filters into the living room of Petra Brockmöller's Amsterdam maisonette. Like the room, which is full of books, plants, fresh flowers and family pictures, Brockmöller is cheerful and upbeat. She looks a healthy, fit 65. But she's suf fering from terminal cancer and knows the end is not far off. She still enjoys life, walking miles each day, going to concerts, and joining the younger colleagues she worked with before she retired a year ago for a drink, a few jokes and a meal. Her three children are all doing well and have given her four grandchildren, with a fifth on the way. But she is already talking to her doctor about helping her end her life when the time comes. She is confident she will be allowed to choose the timing and manner of her death - not in pain or sedated, but fully conscious and able to make her goodbyes to her children and grandchildren. "Some people don't grow old; that's your fate. My philosophy is carpe diem . Take your life in your own hands as far as possible. I believe in reaching the age of 67 in freedom and not being dependent on anybody, rather than reaching 70 and not being able to do anything."

A bill now going through the Dutch legislature will decriminalise a practice that has been judicially recognised in the Netherlands for nearly 30 years. The lower house passed it last November by a majority of more than two-thirds. It is expected to be accepted by the upper house next month and to come into force later this year. Euthanasia and assisting suicide have always been, and will remain, a criminal offence in the Netherlands. By agreement between the medical profession and the ministry of justice, doctors have not been prosecuted if they fulfilled certain conditions and reported the death to the coroner as an unnatural one. The patient must have asked to die and persisted in the request - taking a patient's life without a request still counts as murder. The doctor must be satisfied that the patient's suffering is unbearable and lasting and that there was no reasonable alternative, and must have consulted another independent doctor. These will remain the criteria. What the new act will do is to incorporate these grounds for immunity from prosecution into the criminal code. Doctors will not only escape prosecution if they follow the rules, but they will no longer be committing a criminal act.

Those who disregard the rules will still risk a prosecution and possible murder conviction. Two weeks ago an Amsterdam GP, Wilfred van Oijen, was convicted of murder for injecting an 84-year-old woman with an anaesthetic drug without her request or a second opinion. The woman was in the last stages of death in a nursing home but had not been given pain-killing drugs ordered by the GP. She was covered in bed ulcers and nurses feared that washing her would kill her. Her daughters had urged him to end her suffering. The court declined to punish him for ending her life, saying he had acted "honourably and according to his conscience", and imposed a suspended fine for reporting that the death was from natural causes.

Since 1990, 20 doctors have been charged with carrying out euthanasia outside the guidelines. In most cases the charges have been dropped. Some of those prosecuted have been acquitted, others convicted, but none has served a prison term. A murder conviction does not carry the automatic life sentence a British doctor could expect if convicted in similar circumstances, but Dutch doctors say the prosecution process is still harrowing.

The procedure set up by the act will remove the fear of prosecution from those who scrupulously follow the rules. Once the act comes into force, the review committee will refer only doubtful cases to the prosecution authorities, although prosecutors will still be able to initiate their own investigations into a suspicious death.

He asks: "Is there any other crime where the one who commits the crime can make a report and be found guilty or not guilty by a non-judicial committee just on the basis of his own report?"

The Dutch point out that euthanasia happens in other countries but it goes on clandes tinely. They would prefer to have it out in the open where it can be monitored to minimise abuses. Fully decriminalising it will, they hope, encourage more doctors to report it. Despite the transparency, only 50 to 60% of cases are thought to be reported, up from 18% in a 1990 survey. A number, like the van Oijen case, undoubtedly happen without the patient's request. Some cases don't fall easily within the guidelines; some doctors are confronted with a patient in intractable pain and act immediately; others believe the patient's family deserve privacy. But there is no evidence that doctors act from any other motive than to relieve the patient's suffering.

Euthanasia is not available on demand: two-thirds of requests are turned down. Doctors on the second opinion panel, who see the patients and produce their own report, are trained to help their colleagues resist the too importunate patient. Most patients have had the same GP for many years, and doctors are widely trusted. In 85% of cases, euthanasia is carried out not in nursing homes or hospitals, but by GPs in the patient's home.

Patients must persist in their requests, which the criteria stipulate must be "voluntary and well-considered". But court cases over the years have established that euthanasia is not limited to cases of terminal illness, and that unbearable suffering may be psychological as well as physical. Advocates of the slippery slope argument point to the case in 1994, where a court refused to punish a psychiatrist who gave a 50-year-old former social worker suffering from pathological grief over the death of her two sons the means to kill herself. Some thought this was a case too far, though the rules stipulate that doctors must satisfy themselves that the patient's request does not stem from depression.

Many, including the Royal Dutch Medical Society and the justice minister, felt the line was crossed last year when a court exonerated the doctor who helped the former senator Edward Brongersma, who had no serious physical or psychological illnesses but felt that at the age of 86 he was living "a pointless and empty existence", to die. The prosecuting authorities are appealing, as they have the right to do in the Netherlands.

The Netherlands' neighbour, Belgium, is only now considering a euthanasia bill.

webTitle: Marcel Berlins: Keeping up with criminal justice

fields.headline: Keeping up with criminal justice
fields.standfirst: There's been a lot of government policy on criminal justice. If only it were coherent and workable
fields.trailText: There's been a lot of government policy on criminal justice. If only it were coherent and workable
fields.body:
I've occasionally won money by betting suckers that I could name all 50 American states. I'm usually quite good at such lists. But the other day I was asked to list the Labour government's policies on the criminal justice system. I gasped. "What, all 1,376 of them?" Never in the history of government has so much been said, and so difficult to understand, by so few (the few usually being Jack Straw). I've tried to keep up, I really have. But the sheer speed, volume and variety of the stuff coming out on paper, in speeches and in off-the-cuff remarks are enough to send anyone to bed with a sick headache.

Lord Justice Auld has more than a headache; he has been supremely shafted. He spends more than a year working himself silly preparing his proposals to reform the legal bits of the criminal justice system, as asked for by the lord chancellor, and lets the government have a peek at some of his interim thoughts, making it clear that he hasn't finally made up his mind. The government carefully cherry-picks some of Auld's thinking and turns it into electioneering tough-on-crime propaganda. No wonder he felt obliged to issue an angry press release - unprecedented for a judge in his position.

All this frenetic activity might be vaguely acceptable if there seemed to be any coherent and workable structure behind the myriad of sound-bites emerging.

 There was much smiling at George Carman's choice of The Lord Chancellor's Song, from Gilbert and Sullivan's Iolanthe, to be sung at his rather jolly, celebrity-studded memorial service last week. Was it, we wondered, some posthumous joke, a sly dig at Lord Irvine? I was in a position to watch the lord chancellor's reaction to the performance. He sustained throughout a mixture of beam, benign smile and distant amusement. If there was a special message from George to Derry, I didn't spot it.

Random thought: the service for Carman was at St Clement Danes - the RAF church in the Strand - where the memorial to Sir David Napley was held a few years ago. Napley was the solicitor who brought Carman to national fame by hiring him to defend (successfully) Jeremy Thorpe. Napley, too, had many celebrity clients and, in his heyday, was the most famous lawyer in the country, just as Carman later became. End of coincidence.

 In his oration, Lord Alexander mentioned, as had many of the obituaries, Carman's sobriquet, Gorgeous George, but I wonder how many in the assembly understood the reference. I suspect I was alone in actually having seen the original Gorgeous George in professional action, when I was a boy.

He was an American wrestler who would enter the ring in glittering trunks, swathed in a golden cape, his hair perfectly coiffed in dyed golden locks, and reeking of perfume. He paraded haughtily as the audience booed and jeered, and then got down to the business of wrestling, at which he was very good. He was one of the first sportsmen to suss out that antagonising people by flamboyant behaviour brought media attention and paying customers. Muhammad Ali revealed that George had been his inspiration when he started his outrageous and provocative performances.

Why, though, the nickname attached itself to Carman I don't know. Wrestler and advocate had little in common except excellence at their job. I assume it was a tabloid invention, by someone who liked the sound of it, without knowing the background.

 Last year, there were 27 American jury awards of more than $100m, and hundreds of more than $1m. On the surface that's a lot. What the statistics don't reveal is how often the absurd sums that get a lot of publicity are fantasy (like the award against Radovan Karadzic for $4.5bn) or are drastically reduced on appeal.

In fact, the debate in America is over the decline and erosion of the role of civil juries. They're being used in a dramatically shrinking proportion of trials. And when they do come up with large awards, the chances of their assessment being the last word is becoming rarer.

One survey shows nearly 40% of jury decisions in federal civil trials being overturned. Jurors interviewed by the New York Times expressed bitterness when their carefully considered amounts - often including punitive damages against large corporations or hospitals - were disregarded. The compensation culture run rampant - which commentators wrongly claim has arrived here - is clearly on the decrease in the US.
