fields.headline: Murder trial law to change
fields.standfirst:
Cleared defendants could be tried again
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Defendants cleared of murder could face a second trial under proposals from the Law Commission today which are expected to become law if Labour is re-elected.
fields.body:
Defendants cleared of murder could face a second trial under proposals from the Law Commission today which are expected to become law if Labour is re-elected.

The change could theoretically open the way for a new trial for the men suspected of killing the black teenager Stephen Lawrence, but the adverse publicity they received would probably bar any fresh attempt to prosecute them.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, asked the commission, the official law reform body for England and Wales, to look at possible changes to the ancient law of double jeopardy, which states that no one who has been convicted or acquitted of an offence can be tried a second time on the same facts.

The inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's death, headed by Sir William Macpherson, recommended a review of the law, adding: "Perhaps in modern times such absolute protection may sometimes lead to injustice."

The commission recommends that, in murder cases only, a fresh trial should be possible if "compelling" new evidence of guilt emerges after the defendant is found not guilty.

The change would be retrospective, applying to acquittals, such as those of three of the Lawrence suspects, which have already happened.

Under current law, Neil Acourt, Luke Knight and Gary Dobson, three of the five suspects, cannot be retried because they were formally acquitted after a private prosecution launched by the Lawrence family following the crown prosecution service's decision that there was insufficient reliable evidence to prosecute.

The collapse of the family's prosecution in 1996 sparked outrage when the three suspects were cleared after a judge ruled that identification evidence was unreliable.

The Home Office's national crime faculty has calculated that there are currently 35 murder cases where defendants who were acquitted could be reinvestigated and new charges brought if the law is changed retrospectively.

Lawyers yesterday argued that it would be unfair and oppressive to remove the ancient protection of the double jeopardy rule.

Roy Amlot QC, chairman of the bar council, said: "In principle, it cannot be right for somebody who has been acquitted to be tried again, albeit for murder. It has to be unfair to put someone through the stress of a trial without finality. It tempts sloppy investigation by the police if they think that, should things go wrong, they may be able to have another crack at some time in the future."

John Wadham, director of the civil rights organisation, Liberty, said: "The protection of double jeopardy is a fundamental part of our criminal justice system, and we increase the chances of innocent people being convicted if we remove it. People who have been arrested and prosecuted and who would have been locked up for months before trial should be free once they have been acquitted by a jury."

The leading defence barrister Geoffrey Robertson QC said a retrospective change in the law would almost certainly be a breach of human rights. He welcomed the recommendation to allow second trials in technical acquittals, but said it was "irrational" to confine the change in the double jeopardy rule to murder trials and exclude "repetitive, professional" crime such as armed robbery.

"Abolishing the rule of double jeopardy after a full trial and jury acquittal is unprincipled and impractical," he added.

"The police will never look for anyone else after a defendant is acquitted of murder. They will just keep on after him, trying to trap him and to dig up 'fresh' evidence to justify their original decision to prosecute."

In a second proposal, also likely to be enacted, the commission recommends that the prosecution should be given a new right to appeal against acquittals which result from judges' rulings.

These include cases where the judge decides the prosecution should not go ahead because of adverse publicity, or where the judge rules crucial evidence inadmissible, making it impossible for the crown to go ahead.

That issue was referred to the commission last May by the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, who said he thought there was an imbalance in the system. If the judge's decision could not be tested on appeal, he asked in a lecture last November, "are we not allowing a system in which judges are unaccountable to the appeal courts as to a crucial aspect of their responsibilities, at the very time that we are providing them with greater powers through the implementation of the Human Rights Act?"

Judge Alan Wilkie QC, who headed the commission's inquiry, said: "We believe these new recommendations recognise the need to enhance public confidence in the criminal justice system by enabling manifestly questionable acquittals in serious cases to be called into question, whilst paying proper regard to the fundamental principle that it is not legitimate for the state to continue to pursue a person who has been found not guilty after due process."

webTitle: Cries for help up by 400% as outbreaks take toll

fields.headline: Cries for help up by 400% as outbreaks take toll
fields.standfirst:
Farmers Anguish of many isolated by the crisis

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Michael Bradshaw and his brother Howard of the aptly named Bleak House farm in, Staffordshire were yesterday desolate. On Saturday night, police and Ministry of Agriculture officials surrounded their farm. On Sunday foot and mouth was confirmed and yesterday the family which has farmed for four generations watched their 51 cattle and 1,000 sheep being slaughtered.
fields.body:
Michael Bradshaw and his brother Howard of the aptly named Bleak House farm in, Staffordshire were yesterday desolate. On Saturday night, police and Ministry of Agriculture officials surrounded their farm. On Sunday foot and mouth was confirmed and yesterday the family which has farmed for four generations watched their 51 cattle and 1,000 sheep being slaughtered.

Or rather they could not bear to. The carcasses will be piled high and burnt today and some time in the future the brothers will restock their silent acres.

"This has come at a terrible time, but we will not give up," said Michael.

The Bradshaws have been through foot and mouth before when Bleak House farm was infected in 1967. Then their father saw his life work destroyed in a few hours. But for most farmers the present ordeal is new and, say professional counsellors, it will take years to recover from.

Yesterday 129 farmers were effectively modern day lepers, forbidden to leave their farms, isolated from their communities and peers.

A further 117 who have had confirmed cases or whose animals have had "dangerous contact" with confirmed cases are preparing to have animals slaughtered.

The Rural Stress Network, a Christian organisation staffed largely by volunteers from within the farming industry, yesterday reported a 400% increase in distress calls since the first outbreak two weeks ago.

"People are breaking down in tears, saying it is the last straw," said director Caroline Davies.

"I'm in total anguish. My family and I just sit here waiting. I don't know whether this is the end or not", said one farmer in Cumbria, next door to an infected farm. His neighbour is "terrified" because he may have unwittingly have brought the disease to the valley.

"I watched as a child my father break down in 1967," said Gwyn Jones, a 45-year-old farmer in the Welsh borders. "He was never the same again. Now we can feel it closing in on us. I know animals are sent to slaughter every week, but this is different. It makes you wonder why you're farming at all."

A survey of British tenant farmers last year suggested that one in 10 are being prescribed anti-depressants, 70% said their business concerns kept them awake at night, and nearly a quarter had marital problems. More that 70 farmers and farm workers committed suicide in 1998, more than one a week.

Yet some farmers "may be praying for the disease to hit them", said one former National Farmers Union official, who watched the 1967 crisis unfold. "The compensation was quite good and it was seen as a nice a way out of farming."

fields.bodyText: Michael Bradshaw and his brother Howard of the aptly named Bleak House farm in, Staffordshire were yesterday desolate. On Saturday night, police and Ministry of Agriculture officials surrounded their farm. On Sunday foot and mouth was confirmed and yesterday the family which has farmed for four generations watched their 51 cattle and 1,000 sheep being slaughtered. Or rather they could not bear to. The carcasses will be piled high and burnt today and some time in the future the brothers will restock their silent acres. "This has come at a terrible time, but we will not give up," said Michael. The Bradshaws have been through foot and mouth before when Bleak House farm was infected in 1967. Then their father saw his life work destroyed in a few hours. But for most farmers the present ordeal is new and, say professional counsellors, it will take years to recover from. Yesterday 129 farmers were effectively modern day lepers, forbidden to leave their farms, isolated from their communities and peers. A further 117 who have had confirmed cases or whose animals have had "dangerous contact" with confirmed cases are preparing to have animals slaughtered. The Rural Stress Network, a Christian organisation staffed largely by volunteers from within the farming industry, yesterday reported a 400% increase in distress calls since the first outbreak two weeks ago. "People are breaking down in tears, saying it is the last straw," said director Caroline Davies. "I'm in total anguish. My family and I just sit here waiting. I don't know whether this is the end or not", said one farmer in Cumbria, next door to an infected farm. His neighbour is "terrified" because he may have unwittingly have brought the disease to the valley. "I watched as a child my father break down in 1967," said Gwyn Jones, a 45-year-old farmer in the Welsh borders. "He was never the same again. Now we can feel it closing in on us. I know animals are sent to slaughter every week, but this is different. It makes you wonder why you're farming at all." A survey of British tenant farmers last year suggested that one in 10 are being prescribed anti-depressants, 70% said their business concerns kept them awake at night, and nearly a quarter had marital problems. More that 70 farmers and farm workers committed suicide in 1998, more than one a week. Yet some farmers "may be praying for the disease to hit them", said one former National Farmers Union official, who watched the 1967 crisis unfold. "The compensation was quite good and it was seen as a nice a way out of farming." What's going on? webTitle: Share sales dampen Guardian iT results

fields.headline: Share sales dampen Guardian iT results
fields.trailText: Computer services group Guardian iT yesterday saw its upbeat results announcement overshadowed by news that key directors planned to sell 1m shares in the company.
fields.body:
Computer services group Guardian iT yesterday saw its upbeat results announcement overshadowed by news that key directors planned to sell 1m shares in the company.

The group, which focuses on disaster management, storage and web hosting, saw £87m wiped off its market capitalisation as its shares dropped 15% to 690p.

Peter MacLean, Guardian iT's chief executive, said the three directors - himself, Peter Jakob, the finance director, and Richard Raworth, the chairman - were exercising options over shares held by the venture capital backers of the company's management buy-out, in 1995.

After selling enough shares to cover their tax costs, the directors plan to dispose of 50% of the rest of these options, a total of 1.1m shares.

This will leave the directors holding a stake of 1.5%in the company.

Mr MacLean insisted: "There is certainly no lack of confidence in the company." Guardian iT, which offers companies disaster management services such as off-site backup for computer systems or emergency office space, posted a pre-tax and pre-exceptional profit of £13.2m, compared to £8.3m in 1999.

The pre-tax, post-exceptional profit was £3.8m, down from £7m.

Turnover, including growth from acquisitions, was £86.4m, compared to £49.2m for the previous year.

The company admitted that it was constantly looking for acquisitions.

Mr MacLean said: "We believe there will be more opportunity for acquisitions than there has been."

Guardian iT, which employs 420 people and is due to expand into the US, was bullish about its entrance into web hosting at the end of last year. The group now has two web hosting sites in Britain.

Analysts were yesterday positive about Guardian's prospects for 2001.

The board posted a full year dividend of 1.78p, an increase of 10% from last year.

webTitle: Vet says Foot and Mouth virus still under control

fields.headline: Vet says virus still under control
fields.standfirst:
Ministry says all outbreaks can be traced back to first

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Agriculture's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, yesterday said he was confident the foot and mouth outbreak was not out of control despite its continued spread. Every confirmed case had been traced back to the original outbreak at Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Agriculture's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, yesterday said he was confident the foot and mouth outbreak was not out of control despite its continued spread.

Every confirmed case had been traced back to the original outbreak at Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland, Mr Scudamore said, although 100,000 sheep which had been in contact with the disease still had to be traced to make sure they were not infected.

"If we were getting outbreaks in new areas unrelated to markets, farms, or vehicles we already know may have been contaminated I would be far more concerned," he said.

"As it is, we believe we are containing the disease to the known contacts before we stopped all farm animal movement on February 23. When the two-week incubation period for the disease ends we expect the number of outbreaks start to fall."

Six new cases were confirmed yesterday, compared with 13 the day before, all in areas where there had been previous outbreaks. Two were confirmed in Devon, at Hatherleigh and Highampton, two at St Weonards in Herefordshire, one at Beattock in Dumfries, and one at Bishop Auckland, Co Durham. They brought the total of confirmed cases to 74.

"I expect the figures to average about eight, nine or 10 [new cases] a day about now and then start to drop later in the week," Mr Scudamore said. There are more than 120 farms still being investigated.

The outbreak discovered at Dunna Bridge farm on Dartmoor on Sunday, on land owned by the Prince of Wales's Duchy of Cornwall estate, was linked to other cases in Devon, the chief vet said.

Investigations were still continuing to see if any of the 46,000 animals on common land had been infected but no decision had been made on whether any of the cattle and sheep which roam free would have to be destroyed. The ponies, which do not contract the disease, would not be killed.

The chairman of the Devon branch of the National Farmers' Union, David Hill, suggested a ring of troops should be posted on a one-mile radius around the farm to prevent wildlife getting in and livestock getting out.

Yesterday Prince Charles confirmed he had spoken to his tenants: "I rang them this morning. It is an absolute nightmare .. particularly as they have spent much of their lives building up a pedigree herd." There are a number of suspect cases in Europe, Italy, France, the Netherlands and Germany, but none has been confirmed and some ruled out as negative. A large number of animals have been slaughtered as a precaution.

The number of animals which have to be destroyed in Britain is still rising, creating logistical problems is getting rid of the carcasses. So far only 14,092 animals have been slaughtered out of a total of 77,614 which will be destroyed because they are infected or have dangerous contacts. The totals are 64,804 sheep, 10,894 cattle, 2,003 pigs and 13 goats.

Mr Scudamore said contractors were being employed to build the pyres and hundreds of tons of straw, wood and coal had to be moved. Some corpses were being buried and some taken to rendering plants in sealed containers but for the majority burning in the farmers' fields was the best course. "Fire kills the virus," he said.

On Sunday in Banff, Aberdeenshire, pigs were slaughtered to supply shops for the first time since the ban on live stock movements was imposed. Licences to slaughter were issued to 170 abattoirs in England yesterday. Lorries carrying the stock have to be disinfected before loading and after delivery.

The only other livestock being moved were in danger of drowning because of flooding but plans are being drawn up to move sheep ready for lambing down from the hills.

The government is also reinspecting all pig farms that use swill - only about l.5% of the total. Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, said one of the matters to be considered after the outbreak was over was whether swill feeding should be stopped altogether. Swill remains the chief suspect for how the outbreak began. To cope with the crisis the Ministry of Agriculture's 220 field vets have been augmented by 240 volunteers.

More are coming from overseas including two from Australia, eight from the US, 10 from New Zealand, 10 from Canada and four from Ireland.

Work has started on disinfecting abattoirs and farms affected by the disease where the animals have been destroyed. Farms can restock after 30 days, after which time the virus will have been eliminated.

In Hereford three farmers accused of contravening foot and mouth movement restrictions by moving stock had their cases adjourned until March 22.

 The government made no attempt to prepare for the devastating outbreak of swine fever in the pig industry last year, after a major outbreak in the Netherlands, the agriculture select committee will reveal today, writes Patrick Wintour .

The MPs also attack the Ministry of Agriculture over a £66m rescue package for the industry, announced last year, which has still not reached farmers.

webTitle: French export ban on 'at risk' animals

fields.headline: French export ban on 'at risk' animals
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: France yesterday banned the export of all animals at risk from foot and mouth disease as well as most livestock movements amid mounting concern that the epidemic has reached the continent.
fields.body:
France yesterday banned the export of all animals at risk from foot and mouth disease as well as most livestock movements amid mounting concern that the epidemic has reached the continent.

The agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, announced the strict new security measures after tests found traces of the disease in slaughtered British sheep that had passed through nine farms in five different departments of France.

Two cattle that had come into contact with some of the British sheep at a farm in Cher in central France had also shown initial symptoms of the disease and been destroyed immediately, the ministry said.

The health minister, Bernard Kouchner, said "every conceivable measure" was being taken to ensure the disease did not gain a foothold in France, but that it would be "a veritable miracle" if the country was spared.

Mr Glavany said it was too soon to confirm that France had been hit, noting that the initial tests on the nine potentially infected herds showed only that some animals had developed antibodies of the virus.

All the animals concerned had already been slaughtered under a government decision announced last week to kill 20,000 British sheep that had been imported into France and another 30,000 French animals that had come into contact with them.

All exports of animals at risk from foot and mouth disase - principally sheep, cattle, pigs and goats - have been banned for 15 days, along with the movement of susceptible live animals other than to abattoirs. Horses are also affected by the restrictions and most racing events are likely to be cancelled today.

The nine French farms affected, in the departments of Cher, Mayenne, Oise, Vienne and Seine-Saint-Denis, have been placed under quarantine and six-mile exclusion zones set up around them.

webTitle: US vice-president hospitalized with heart pains

fields.headline: Ailing Cheney returns to hospital
fields.standfirst: Vice-president with history of heart attacks hit by chest pains
fields.trailText: Vice-President Dick Cheney underwent surgery yesterday to reopen a partially blocked artery after complaining about renewed cardiac problems less than four months after suffering his fourth heart attack.
fields.body:
Vice-President Dick Cheney underwent surgery yesterday to reopen a partially blocked artery after complaining about renewed cardiac problems less than four months after suffering his fourth heart attack.

Mr Cheney checked himself into the George Washington University hospital yesterday afternoon after feeling what aides described as mild chest pains on two occasions in recent days, including once while he was exercising on Saturday.

The White House sought to play down the gravity of the news, but Mr Cheney's latest health scare is a major personal and political blow to the new Republican administra tion. He is an unusually influential vice-president; he led George Bush's transition team, played a major role in cabinet and top personnel selections and has helped the president to forge his foreign policy.

He was expected to spend the night in hospital and to be discharged today.

The artery, which had been opened in late November, had partially reclosed, his cardiologist, Jonathan Reiner, told reporters. He said there was no evidence that Mr Cheney had suffered another heart attack, and he had not suffered any additional heart damage.

He said the episodes were "much milder and very brief; when compared with the chest pains Mr Cheney had suffered in November. "The symptoms were subtle this time," Dr Reiner said.

"There is a very high likelihood he can finish out his term in his fully vigorous capacity."

Mr Bush telephoned Mr Cheney to wish him well, the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said. Mr Cheney had replied "that he was feeling fine and looked forward to returning to work", he said.

In hospital, Mr Cheney underwent two procedures; a "cardiac catheterisation" to investigate the source of the pain and an angioplasty to remove the blockage in the blood vessel.

The catheter examination was a repeat of the probe which was inserted into his ar teries in November after he experienced what doctors described as a mild heart attack. On that occasion, doctors discovered that one of his cardiac arteries was 90% blocked. Following that discovery, a wire device called a stent was inserted into the artery to push open the blockage and keep the artery walls apart.

After his last heart attack, Mr Cheney's doctors said the accumulation of disease had left his heart "moderately damaged". Other heart experts said that Mr Cheney was at higher risk of further heart attacks than the average person of his age, and that he needed to take protective steps such as losing weight.

However Dr Reiner said that Mr Cheney had been "exceedingly diligent in following both dietary and exercise recommendations, including essentially eliminating red meat from his diet.

"He has very nicely adhered to what we wanted him to do," Dr Reiner said, adding that the vice-president could fully re turn to his work "later in the week".

The hospital where Mr Cheney is being treated is the same one in which he had his operation last year. He phoned his medical advisers there after the weekend pains and was advised to come in for immediate examination.

Mr Cheney has a long history of heart trouble, though he was given a clean bill of health by doctors when Mr Bush picked him to be his running mate last August.

He suffered his first heart attack at the age of 37 in 1978. This was followed by a second attack in 1984 and by a third in 1988. All three were described at the time as mild. In August 1988 he had quadruple heart bypass surgery.

webTitle: France pulls horses out of Festival

fields.headline: France pulls horses out of Festival
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The French government dealt another blow to the Cheltenham Festival yesterday when it ruled out any runners from France travelling to the three-day meeting next week. This follows Ireland's decision, made last week because of the foot and mouth epidemic, not to send their powerful team to the Festival, which is due to start on Tuesday.
fields.body:
The French government dealt another blow to the Cheltenham Festival yesterday when it ruled out any runners from France travelling to the three-day meeting next week. This follows Ireland's decision, made last week because of the foot and mouth epidemic, not to send their powerful team to the Festival, which is due to start on Tuesday.

The absence of the French is especially damaging as they are responsible for three of the ante-post favourites in the big races: First Gold (Gold Cup), Jair du Cochet (Triumph Hurdle) and Baracouda (Royal & SunAlliance Novice Hurdle). The Irish withdrawal denied Istabraq, the odds-on favourite, the chance to win the Champion Hurdle for a record fourth successive time.

It is a blow, too, to the gambler JP McManus, who recently paid more than £m for First Gold and Baracouda. He also owns Istabraq.

Cheltenham remained bullish last night on going ahead with the Festival despite the widespread feelings of racegoers that the meeting has been depleted too much and would better be postponed to next month. fields.headline: Retailers resort to panic buying
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Retailers have been frantically buying meat in an effort to keep up with a 40-50% surge in demand from customers over the past few days following the foot and mouth outbreak.
fields.body:
Retailers have been frantically buying meat in an effort to keep up with a 40-50% surge in demand from customers over the past few days following the foot and mouth outbreak.

The big retail chains last week were buying pork in Denmark, according to an industry insider. There was also, he said, some "argy bargy" over New Zealand lamb, with buyers competing to secure stocks from abroad. Prices had risen because of this.

Supermarket buyers, already criticised by the prime minister for having farmers in a "armlock" to produce cheap food, were attacked in the industry bible, the Grocer magazine, for pushing farmers and producers to deliver "unreasonable" quantities of meat.

Manufacturers also warned that the price of processed foods would rise, as they would be forced to source more ingredients from abroad.

But others were predicting a glut. Slaughtering and processing began again on Sunday as some livestock moved under licence. Exports are still banned, and it is thought surpluses may therefore build up. Clare Cheney, of the Provision Trade Federation, said there was already a surplus of dairy products.

Yet shoppers were stockpiling food. Safeway said sales of fresh pork, lamb and beef were up by 70% and sales of chicken breast were 80% higher. Much of the extra meat would go into household freezers, Tesco said, "so presumably it will come out again soon and demand will level off". Sales of other goods, including cereals and pasta, were up "significantly", said Safeway.

By Sunday evening, 170 abattoirs had approval to start slaughter again but farmers complained they were being offered less for livestock than before the crisis. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said the government would not intervene.

fields.headline: History of haj tragedy
fields.trailText: 1998 Stampede in the plain of Mina killed 118 as large crowds assembled near a bridge on their way to the devil-stoning ritual.
fields.body:
1998 Stampede in the plain of Mina killed 118 as large crowds assembled near a bridge on their way to the devil-stoning ritual.

1997 Fire swept through a tent camp in Mina killing 343 pilgrims. Officials said the blaze was caused by a pilgrim cooking on a gas stove in his tent.

1994 A stampede at Jamarat killed 270 pilgrims to Mecca.

1991 Airliner carrying pilgrims home to Nigeria crashed after the haj, killing 261.

1991 Plane crash in northern Saudi Arabia killed 91 Senegalese soldiers returning from a pilgrimage to Mecca. The trip had been a reward for their service in the US-led coalition that drove Iraqi forces from Kuwait in the Gulf war.

1990 1,426 pilgrims were crushed in a stampede in a tunnel. Most were from Indonesia and Turkey.

1989 Bombs exploded near the grand mosque in Mecca, killing a pilgrim and wounding 16. Saudi Arabia beheaded 16 Kuwaiti Shi'ites after finding them guilty of planting the bombs.

1987 Some 400 people, mainly Iranian Shi'ite pilgrims, died in clashes with Saudi security forces during anti-western protests in Mecca.

1979 About 250 armed Sunni Muslims took over the grand mosque. More than 100 of them and 127 Saudi troops were killed in a two-week siege, which did not take place during the main pilgrimage season.

fields.headline: James saved by the whistle
fields.trailText: A hapless David James provided the final touch from a Stefan Schwarz free-kick as Sunderland cancelled out Julian Joachim's earlier strike to scrape a late point.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
A chilled and nervous crowd watched, sighed in relief and ultimately cursed the officials last night as two of the Premiership's more out-of-sorts sides grappled their way to a nail-biting stalemate.

Trailing to Julian Joachim's second-half goal, Sunderland rallied late on as Stefan Schwarz's 25-yard free-kick was deflected off Alan Wright and parried by the hapless David James.

Daniele Dichio's follow-up succeeded only in finding Gavin McCann, who gleefully tapped the equaliser into the empty net.

Then came the furore. In the dying seconds James made amends by deflecting Dichio's point-blank effort wide. From the subsequent corner the goalkeeper fell in a heap and the Sunderland substitute blasted into the empty net, only for an assistant referee's flag to cut short the celebrations. "Someone, somewhere obstructed me," claimed James. In fact it was his teammate Ian Taylor.

"I think we were slightly unfortunate," said the home manager Peter Reid, celebrating his 250th league match in charge spanning almost six years on Wearside. At least Villa did not become only the 16th team to leave victorious.

"It looked like a really good goal. I don't want to criticise anyone because I'll sound like a moaner, but it may have cost us two points. They say that luck evens itself out, so we're in for some interesting decisions in the last few weeks of the season."

In truth, the draw did little for either side's prospects. Villa continue to hover precariously over the relegation scrap with only two league wins in 15 since they climbed to fourth in November. Sunderland go fifth but remain without a top-flight victory for two months, rekindling nightmarish memories of last season's three-month slump - an 11-match winless streak that derailed their challenge and left them in seventh place.

Oddly, a similar finish this season could earn them a Uefa Cup berth given the migraine-inducing intricacies of European qualification. It would require Liverpool finishing in the top three and winning the FA Cup and the Uefa Cup, with the FA Cup runners-up finishing in the top four.

Sunderland should have given their fans more to think about by edging ahead after only four minutes. James shanked his clearance straight to Niall Quinn - soon to depart with a recurrence of a back injury - who advanced into the area to shoot across the England goalkeeper and wide of the far post with Don Hutchison unmarked and livid in the middle.

The Scot, forced into a striker's role in the absence of Kevin Phillips, might have had a penalty midway through the half after tripping over Alpay Ozalan off the ball.

The frenzied opening soon blew itself out, but James did his best to rekindle the whirlwind by spilling McCann's innocuous shot. In nipped Julio Arca to chip over the goalkeeper, who was sprawled sheepishly at his feet, but he then scuffed his shot desperately across goal; Hutchison added to the comedy by skewing his effort back across the gaping goal the other way.

The visitors threatened only sporadically with Paul Merson their creative inspiration, class oozing with every graceful twist. On one rare foray Dion Dublin sent Joachim clear five minutes before the interval only for Thomas Sorensen to blockthe vicious shot.

The former Leicester striker had better luck seven minutes into the second period.

James's long clearance bounced towards the home area with Emerson Thome in a muddle and, after Lee Hendrie nodded back skywards, Joachim gath ered, turned and crashed his shot low beyond the exposed Sorensen's dive.

The home side deserved better but must have feared the worst when Hutchison blasted a free-kick on to the bar. Then came McCann's tap-in and a madcap finish. "Three points would have been a major turning point but we let them slip away," said John Gregory. "We should have used the ball better at 1-0 but we were sucked into the way Sunderland were playing.

"We needed a bit more composure, but I look at it as one defeat in four. My head's always on the block and it will be while I am manager of Aston Villa. That's just the way it is."

webTitle: Europe reaches deal on football transfers

fields.headline: Europe reaches deal on football transfers
fields.trailText: Months of uncertainty are at an end after Fifa and Uefa, with the support of the European players union, reached agreement with the European Commission on a new system for player transfers.
fields.body:
The saga over the future of the European transfer system, which has threatened to tear football apart, was finally resolved last night after the game's world and European governing bodies, Fifa and Uefa, reached agreement with the European Commission on a new system more in line with community labour laws.

The landmark agreement, which will have major implications for the future of football, was reached after a five-hour meeting in Brussels and ends six months of arduous negotiations which have caused widespread uncertainity within the game.

Significantly, last night's deal on the shape of the new transfer system was reached with the support of Fifpro, the European players' union which was initially against Fifa and Uefa attempts to tie players to long contracts and punish those who unilaterally broke them.

Under the new transfer system, which is expected to be in place by the start of the next football season, all contracts will be for a minimum of one year and a maximum of five. There will be one transfer window, but there will be a limited mid-season window. There will be a limit of one transfer per player per season.

Players aged up to 28 will have to honour five-year contracts for a minimum of three years, and two years thereafter. Any player breaking his contract within the first two years of a three-year "protected" period can be barred from playing for his new club for four months in the next season and for six months should he repeat the offence.

Sanctions can also be applied against agents where it is proved a contract has been broken "without just cause".

The question of penalties surrounding a breach of contract had been one of the main sticking points going into yesterday's meeting. Another was the level of compensation small clubs should receive for developing young players. The joint Fifa and Uefa taskforce had stated that unless the EC compromised on the two issues, no solution would be possible.

Though full details were not available last night, all sides expressed satisfaction.

The Fifa president Sepp Blatter said last night: "We are looking forward very positively to the realisation of all the amendments of the Fifa transfer recommendations, and it will be for the benefit of football. It will be for the protection of the young players, for the protection of the training clubs and it will be for the protection of the fans.

"They will have footballers who are protected by contract but they will also have clubs who will have at their disposal footballers for a certain time."

An adequate compensation system for smaller clubs nurturing young players is expected to provide a financial lifeline for less glamorous teams who rely on the selling of players for their existence.

Clubs will receive compensation for players aged under 23 who are transferred, to reward them for time spent on their development and training. Money will also trickle down to smaller clubs, professional and amateur, who have discovered players who then eventually end up at a big clubs.

The entire transfer system will be overseen by an arbitration panel which will settle compensation levels and other disputes that may arise from players breaking contracts.

The six months of negotiations with the EC almost led to a split in world football as Fifa and Uefa disagreed over the shape of the new transfer system. The EC initially intervened more than two years ago when it ruled that players faced too many restrictions on movement and that clubs had too much power, contravening the Treaty of Rome.

The EC has accepted the unique nature of football and that it cannot be treated like any other business but insisted that modifications needed to be made to make the system more flexible and more in line with European labour laws.

Key changes

 Small clubs to be compensated for training young players.
 Code of conduct covering international transfers for players aged under 18.
 One transfer period per season, one transfer per player per season.
 Minimum/maximum contract one/five years.
 Financial compensation to be paid if a contract is breached unilaterally by a player or club. Offending player may face suspension.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Hallé/Jac van Steen
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
A wag from California once asserted that all classical music is played nowadays as though it were late Stravinsky: fast speeds, hard edges and an emphasis on bright colours. In fact, very few performances are like this, because it is normally a recipe for disaster. But Jac van Steen is a conductor who does take this approach. With his speed established, he seems determined not to slow down until instructed to. Beethoven rarely gives these instructions, so, in Van Steen's hands, the 2nd Symphony never wavers.

It is most unlikely to be what Beethoven expected, but it worked with the Hallé Orchestra, partly because the musicians plainly loved it and mainly because Van Steen managed to generate an exceptional range of colours and articulations.

Even more surprisingly, he did the same with Ravel's second Daphnis and Chloé suite. One of the most self-indulgent and impressionistic of all scores was treated with absolute rigour: every crystal-clear beat from Van Steen coming exactly when it was expected.

Rarely can the Hallé strings have sounded so velvety; Ravel's wonderful climaxes positively glowed, aided by the radiant Hallé Choir. Nobody wants to hear Ravel done like this every day; but on this occasion the effect was terrific.

These works were framed by middle-period Stravinsky. In the Symphonies of Wind Instruments every edge was in place. But Van Steen left his most surprising gesture to the end. For the Symphony of Psalms he darkened the stage and used constantly changing lighting to emphasise changes in the music. So the final chord of the first movement was underlined with a sudden brightness, and the work ended in complete darkness. Some would regard this as an extremely tacky approach, but it did stress the special nature of the work, perhaps the most subversive and perplexing of all Stravinsky's compositions.

fields.headline: Terris go back to the drawing board
fields.standfirst:
Terris
Rocket
Leeds
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Terris
Rocket
Leeds
Rating: **
fields.body:
Welsh band Terris provide an intriguing example of the increasingly competitive, fame-at-all-costs nature of today's pop industry. A year or so ago they arrived in a blaze of hyperbole as the "first new stars of 2000", winning the NME's Best New Band award after releasing just one low-key single. Singer Gavin Goodwin seemed to believe that in order to be heard you just had to shout loudly. Welsh icons, from Shirley Bassey to Tom Jones, were dismissed with expletives, while the Manic Street Preachers were derided for peddling "stolen rhetoric".

Having set themselves up as the saviours of a "rotten" music scene, Terris surely knew they would have to deliver. But it has all gone badly wrong. Following another EP, which made little impression, the band have been ensconced in the studio for a suspiciously long time. The resulting album, Learning To Let Go, is released in two weeks. In the meantime, the band are virtually starting again, with a tour of tiny venues.

Judging by this performance, they don't deserve much better. The band's earnest rock sound seems even more dated than before, while a presumably chastened Woodward says barely a word to the crowd. As a whole, the group just flail and bluster.

Questions must be asked of the supposedly experienced industry figures who convinced these impressionable lads that they could fly before they could even crawl. Terris are a tight, competent indie rock band. Nothing less; certainly nothing more.

Woodward may have been a potent spokesman for the band, but musically he is the weakest link. His marionette dancing seems to have been copied from videos of Joy Division, his strangled vocals from a horrifying coupling of Axl Rose and a bison. He has some good lines - "I am a bomb, and I've been searching for the switches to turn myself on" - but doesn't back them up with tunes.

It's probably too late for Terris, but lessons are being learnt. Support band Mull Historical Society have had no hype whatsoever, but leave having won over Terris's own audience. Someone should have told the headliners about the tortoise and the hare.

 Terris play Dingwalls, London NW1 (020-7267 1577), tomorrow, the Roadhouse, Manchester (0161-237 9789) on Thursday, then tour.

webTitle: The professionals who specialise in catastrophe

fields.headline: Picking up the pieces
fields.standfirst:
The emergency services weren't the only ones to rush to the scene of last week's train crash. Anita Chaudhuri meets the professionals who specialise in catastrophe

Special report: Selby train crash
Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: The emergency services weren't the only ones to rush to the scene of last week's train crash. Anita Chaudhuri meets the professionals who specialise in catastrophe
fields.body:
The first thing Brian Cronie did when he arrived at the site was to sit his team down together. He has 12 staff working on the job, and his colleagues needed to be briefed on what to expect as the situation progressed. The team are used to working together - Cronie likes to use the same workers, as they know the drill and are familiar with each other's habits. But on this occasion he was conscious that some might not want to take part. "Any person who feels they don't want to be involved is given the option to go off on another job."

Cronie is safety and training director at Baldwin's, a crane operating firm. It is one of only two companies in the country with equipment large enough to lift train carriages. Last Wednesday, he was called in to the site of the Selby rail disaster. Yesterday they were lifting the last of the carriages from the mangled wreckage of the two derailed trains.

Following last week's fatal collision, survivors, relatives and visitors to the site paid tribute to the emergency services struggling to free trapped survivors, recover bodies and secure the site. Yet fire and ambulance services are not the only ones called in to work round the clock following a major disaster. Dozens of other specialist professionals are drafted in to provide physical, emotional and psychological backup. Among the fluorescent, hard-hatted figures swarming around the site were scores of unlikely professionals whose job it is to clear up after catastrophes.

Inspector Richard Allison of the British Transport Police says few members of the public are aware of the scale of the operation. He attempts to list every specialist currently working at the Selby site. "Socos [scene of crime officers dealing with the pathology]; body retrieval specialists, some drafted in from the Metropolitan police; property specialists charged with gathering up every last personal effect left by passengers on the train. All those laptops, briefcases, mobile phones have to be logged, bagged and owners traced. Then there's the CID; they have to take a statement from everyone who was on that train."

In addition, he cites crash in vestigators from the Health and Safety Executive, Railtrack and GNER, local council traffic controllers, family liaison officers to deal with enquiries and information from relatives, coroners liaison officers, undertakers and specialists to operate the mobile mortuaries, not to mention all the medics, firefighters and other hospital personnel. It is an enormous operation, one that requires its own support network: caterers, computer specialists manning the police Holmes system, an office manager and staff for the incident room at the site.

"You tend to meet the same people at every crash," says Cronie. "The pathologists, the trauma people, the counsellors, some of the police specialists. That makes everybody's life easier." Selby is Cronie's 12th crash in the five years he has been working with Baldwin's. He says it is the worst he has seen. "You can't help but see bodies being carried away. I'm ex-army, though, so it doesn't affect me so much - and a lot of our team have similar backgrounds."

Apart from the psychological pressures, there are physical risks involved in manning the cranes. "In the construction industry, crane operation is classified high risk and the reason for that is that cranes can turn over. We're building the big 1,000-tonne ones on site. It's like building a giant Meccano set and they require very firm, level ground to sit on. Of course, at most crash sites you don't have that, and you also don't have easy access. At Selby we have had to build before we could even get access to the track. We've got riggers out preparing the ground, and it's them that are really at risk of seeing the gory stuff."

In addition, there's the problem of coordinating all the specialist beams, chains and crane parts to arrive at the site at the right time - preferably not all at once. "It's a big job, and there are also minor things to sort out. The other afternoon I had to find a photocopy shop in Selby that could run me up a couple of colour signs that said 'No Entry: Lifting in Progress'. They gave me them for free when I told them what it was for."

What runs through his mind when he hears about another crash on the news? "You just get on with it, as I imagine the police or the fire service get on with their jobs. It is like being part of an emergency service."

Hacher Tekari is the forensic officer for British Transport Police and is in charge of its laboratory. All the photographic and fingerprint evidence taken from the site will be processed by her team. "Yes, sometimes there are distressing images coming through the lab, or you're dispatched to a site for forensic retrieval and so you're faced with certain things. We're very well trained to deal with all that though: it's part of the job."

Tekari says that although forensic science sounds high-tech, the key to the job is more mundane. "More than anything, you need to be meticulous, and have common sense, particularly with British Transport Police. When you're collecting evidence, you're not just dealing with one small area of the country. The force is nationwide."

While the workers charged with clearing up after a major incident will have been trained to deal with distressing situations, on-site counselling is imperative for those who have not. CareFirst, a private counselling firm, is paid a retainer by Railtrack to be on standby to send in teams of professionals following an incident like Selby. Their teams were in place at Hatfield and Paddington, and the firm currently has 25 people working at the Selby site. "We call it psychological first aid," says Jane Neal, who works for CareFirst. Before that, she did a similar job at British Airways, which took her to the Lockerbie crash site among other disaster zones.

"We use a treatment called diffusion technique - it's used by the American Red Cross in worldwide disaster scenarios. What we do is allow people to talk in the aftermath of trauma, let them release all the emotion they're feeling and help them to normalise the experience. Most importantly we point them in the direction of where to go for help at the next stage, and provide ongoing support, maybe for weeks afterwards."

Although the service was primarily put in place to help Railtrack's employees cope in the aftermath of accidents, when there is a major incident, the counsellors are briefed to provide assistance to everyone who needs it, be they passengers, relatives, local residents or other professionals working on the clear-up operation.

Anyone imagining that traumatised passengers receive a cosy one-to-one session would be mistaken, though. "It works on the hoof," says Neal. "There's no waiting room, unless the crash site has a longer-term incident room, like at Paddington. Generally, we walk around and just go up to people and ask them if they're OK. It might involve sitting down and having a cup of coffee. It's important to circulate, to talk to as many people as possible. Allowing someone to talk about their feelings for five minutes in these situations can be as effective as an hour's session."

How do she and her colleagues cope with the stress of being on standby for major incidents themselves? "Well, obviously we're all trained to cope, and CareFirst is very mindful of the welfare of its own employees. It isn't all major crashes either - we also work with isolated incidents, for example a train driver who has witnessed a suicide. We're also contracted by various branches of the emergency services to assist their workers."

Neal is keen to stress, however, that what they are providing is not therapy. "That wouldn't be appropriate until some time later, for those who are still not coping after a few months. We find that many people develop their own coping strategies. For our teams, going into these situations can be difficult because every major incident is different: we can't prepare a set of dos and don'ts. We work with whatever we're presented with."

Until the physical and mental wounds heal, the services of healthcare professionals, counsellors and psychiatrists will continue to be in demand. The crash site, meanwhile, almost a week after the collision, is finally beginning to return to normal. Police and accident investigations will continue away from the site, and soon the track will be repaired and trains running again. And Cronie and his colleagues, and the scores of other backup personnel, will return to base and await the next call.

fields.headline: Bohemia comes to Britain
fields.standfirst:
LSO/Jiri Belohlavek
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
LSO/Jiri Belohlavek
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
This was the opening concert of the Bohemian Spring festival, a celebration of Czech music and Czech culture at the Barbican. Over the next six weeks the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by its music director, Sir Colin Davis, and the leading Czech conductor, Jiri Belohlavek, will be exploring a wide range of Czech music, while the Czech Philharmonic, under Vladimir Ashkenazy, will crown the series with two concerts, curiously not of Czech music but of German and Russian.

It seems odd too that Bohemian Spring had to start with Dvorak's Stabat Mater, the opposite of a celebration, written by Dvorak in agony over the deaths of three of his young children. Not only that, the Stabat Mater, though deeply felt, has precious little of Dvorak's Czech flavours in it.

When it came to setting religious texts, Dvorak, a dedicated Catholic, seemed to feel that an earthy, folk-based manner such as you find in his orchestral music was inappropriate, like whistling in church. The Victorians loved it, seeing Dvorak as a successor to Mendelssohn, encouraging a series of choral commissions from Britain. Yet the stylistic safeness hardly gives an idea of the true, colourful Dvorak, and it was to the credit of Belohlavek that in a sharply focused performance he made the Stabat Mater sound so fresh.

It greatly helped too that he kept things moving. One problem of this Stabat Mater, as indeed of so much religious music beloved by the Victorians, is that allegros are generally avoided, with one only here, briefly, in the final coda. Every one of Dvorak's 10 movements has a slow tempo marking, whether andante or largo, with the opening movement longer than any. Yet Belohlavek terraced his forces, large chorus and four soloists, to bring clarity not just to textures but to the structure too.

The LSO Chorus sang with characteristic freshness and fervour, with clear, polished playing from the orchestra, and the soloists, three of them Czech, made a strong team. True, the tenor, Valentin Prolat, seemed nervous of the high tessitura of his big solo in the sixth movement, Fac me vere, but a few minutes later, in the eighth movement, Fac ut portem, he was back in light, heady form for his duet with soprano Janice Watson.

Watson was a last-minute substitute for the Czech Eva Urbanova, but the challenge made her the star of the show. She sang ravishingly throughout, placing her voice unerringly on the most exposed top notes, producing the gentlest pianissimos. The mezzo, Dagmar Peckova and the bass, Peter Mikulas, were first-rate too.

 Bohemian Spring continues until April 24. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: Time takes its toll on Dame Kiri
fields.standfirst:
Kiri Te Kanawa
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Kiri Te Kanawa
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It was 30 years ago that Kiri Te Kanawa became famous overnight when, in what was apparently an astonishing debut, she sang the Countess in Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro at Covent Garden. Since then she has become arguably the most popular of all sopranos, though she still divides opinion. More than a few have been sniffy about her "crossover" work (though she has always done it better than most). Others have criticised her for a lack of drama, which in many respects is unfair. Her approach has always been non-interventionist, based on security of technique and sumptuousness of voice, rather than rampant histrionics - and we should always remember that when Te Kanawa was at her peak, her voice was, quite simply, among the most beautiful in the world.

Her Covent Garden recital revealed a decline, perhaps inevitable, in vocal quality, though not in technical assurance. She chose a programme that mingled Mozart and Strauss (she could be wonderful in both) with composers with whom she's not usually associated - Weber and Liszt, together with some wistful, nostalgic songs by the Argentinian Carlos Guastavino. Mozart's concert aria Chi Sa, Chi Sa, Qual Sia revealed coloratura that still flows with immaculate ease. Her ability to float high notes, then slowly crescendo and diminuendo through them, remains astonishing as Agathe's act two aria from Der Freischütz and Liszt's Lorelei proved. The long, difficult lines of Strauss's Befreit were perfectly judged, with not a hint of the sagging pitch that plagues some singers in this music.

The once glorious sound, however, could only be heard sporadically. The creamy, rich tone of her voice was well in evidence in the Guastavino's folksy numbers and in the Liszt songs (the high point of the evening), though elsewhere, you were conscious of breathiness in the lower registers, and hardness above the stave. Rachmaninov's Vocalise brought with it a couple of moments of effort. Throughout, she seemed unwilling to let rip, preferring to sing softly most of the time. Strauss's Cäcilie was muted, when it should surge with passion and sheer dynamic volume. Her pianist, the American Warren Jones, seemed to support her reticence, playing with a quiet limpidity throughout.

The Opera House, predictably, was packed, and every song was spontaneously applauded. "You've been such a responsive audience," she remarked, when it was over, before launching into her only encore, the aria Io Son L'Umile Ancella from Cilea's Adriana Lecouvreur, a vision of the performing artist as "the handmaiden of the creative genius". Though she lacked sheer weight of voice for it, she sang the aria with moving simplicity and a sincerity that genuinely touched the heart.

fields.headline: Miranda July
fields.standfirst:
Pandaemonium festival
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Pandaemonium festival
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
How to explain Miranda July? Hailing from Portland, Oregon, the woman is a multi-media polymath: a film-maker, a performance artist and a distributor of "lady-made" movies via her mail-order company Joanie 4 Jackie. Friday night found her performing her "live movie" The Swan Tool at the ICA. On Sunday, she was in Hoxton to introduce Getting Stronger Every Day, a short film commissioned by the Lux as part of its Pandaemonium 2001 festival. "To be honest, I don't think it's absolutely done yet," July apologises.

Getting Stronger Every Day runs six minutes top to toe; its narration is provided by a man who recounts the plot of a true-life TV movie (I Know My First Name is Steven) about a boy who spends seven years held hostage by a paedophile. The accompanying images offer a vintage brew of trash-pop avant-gardism. Ensconced in a cluttered home, July's players (a man, a little girl, the family cat) find themselves haunted by abstract pink and yellow shapes that hover above their heads. At one stage the girl lies on the bathroom floor and matches one of these shapes to the floppy-eared outline of her toy rabbit. The soundtrack (by Zac Love) provides a roar of celestial synthesiser.

"Any questions?" wonders July when the credits roll. When pressed, she explains that she borrowed the idea of the abstract shapes from a children's book about a myopic girl who viewed objects without her glasses. But she seems wary of explaining the film any further.

Getting Stronger Every Day is a critic's nightmare. It's whatever the hell you want it to be. So I could say it's a film about recovery and you could say that it's about a little girl who loves her woolly rabbit, or a man who watches too much TV, or a cat who digs sitting on unmade beds. Hailing from Portland, Oregon, the woman is a multi-media polymath: a film-maker, a performance artist and a distributor of "lady-made" movies via her mail-order company Joanie 4 Jackie. Friday night found her performing her "live movie" The Swan Tool at the ICA. On Sunday, she was in Hoxton to introduce Getting Stronger Every Day, a short film commissioned by the Lux as part of its Pandaemonium 2001 festival. Ensconced in a cluttered home, July's players (a man, a little girl, the family cat) find themselves haunted by abstract pink and yellow shapes that hover above their heads. At one stage the girl lies on the bathroom floor and matches one of these shapes to the floppy-eared outline of her toy rabbit. The soundtrack (by Zac Love) provides a roar of celestial synthesiser. webTitle: Disability rights to cover millions more workers

fields.headline: Disability rights to cover millions more workers
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: The government yesterday promised the biggest extension of disability rights for 30 years, including legislation to protect people diagnosed with cancer and HIV from victimisation by their employers.
fields.body:
The government yesterday promised the biggest extension of disability rights for 30 years, including legislation to protect people diagnosed with cancer and HIV from victimisation by their employers.

Margaret Hodge, the employment minister, said she would amend the Disability Discrimination Act to strengthen protection for 600,000 already in work and cover nearly 7m jobs previously excluded from the legislation.

They include police officers, firefighters and prison officers, but not the armed services, which are to remain exempt following a rearguard action by senior officers.

By 2004, small businesses will be obliged to make "reasonable adjustments" to their premises for the benefit of disabled employees and job applicants.

All firms will have to remove unreasonable obstacles for disabled customers. And the government will place a legal duty on public bodies to provide equal opportunities for disabled people.

Bert Massie, chairman of the disability rights commission, said it was "the most significant programme of reforms since disability rights legislation was first introduced 30 years ago ... Under these proposals, millions more disabled people will be protected against discrimination."

Ms Hodge said the changes - recommended by a taskforce in 1999 - would give disabled people "comprehensive and enforceable civil rights".

Enhanced protection for cancer sufferers was triggered by evidence that women were sacked, or selected for redundancy, while the disease was in remission and unlikely to recur. In one case, a woman who had recovered from a mastectomy was told to quit when she needed reconstructive surgery.

Ms Hodge said: "This is shameful. The taskforce found some employers discriminate against people diagnosed with cancer even though the cancer had no present effects, or was in remission."

Under the new law, people's employment rights would be protected from the moment they were diagnosed as likely to require substantial treatment for cancer or HIV. They would have the same rights as those available for those diagnosed with diabetes, epilepsy or arthritis.

Nick Partridge, chief executive of Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse, said: "The announcement sends a clear message to employers that it is not acceptable to practise discrimination against people just because they have HIV."

There will also be more protection for people who are blind or partially sighted, but have had difficulty qualifying as disabled.

Ms Hodge said she made no compromises to win business support for the changes. "We have persuaded employers that nobody will be asked to do anything unaffordable or beyond common sense."

The average cost for smaller firms making their premises suitable for disabled employees would be £78 per person.

The CBI said the 2004 deadline for small firms was "appropriate and realistic".

Paul Whitehouse, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officers, welcomed the extension of the act. "It will require us to establish clearly what the requirements are to be an effective police officer."

webTitle: Abbey undercuts Halifax with new home loan rate

fields.headline: Abbey undercuts Halifax with new home loan rate
fields.trailText: Abbey National waded into the home loans war yesterday by in effect cutting its key standard variable rate by up to 0.84%, taking it just below the Halifax's latest variable rate.
fields.body:
Abbey National waded into the home loans war yesterday by in effect cutting its key standard variable rate by up to 0.84%, taking it just below the Halifax's latest variable rate.

It puts rival lenders such as Cheltenham & Gloucester under increasing pressure to respond, said Ray Boulger of the mortgage brokerage, John Charcol.

The move by the second largest mortgage lender comes two weeks after Nationwide and Halifax announced core loan rates of 6.49% and 6.75% respectively - saving borrowers with larger loans £1,000 or more a year.

Like Nationwide and Halifax, Abbey National is phasing out its standard variable rate. This is at 7.49%, and is paid by more than 600,000 of its 2m borrowers.

They will be able to switch to one of two new rates tracking the Bank of England base rate, either a "no-frills" 6.65% or a flexible 6.75% - 0.9% or 1% above base rate respectively.

Borrowers will not be moved automatically to the new lower rates. Abbey said it will be contacting existing borrowers over the next year to offer a "homeowner's review".

They will be asked if they wish to switch.

The new rates will not be available to the 1.3m borrowers with discounts and fixed rates, or to those locked in to the standard variable rate for a period after having been on such a deal.

The new rates will be available from April 30.

"Today's announcement stamps a definitive sell-by date on our present standard variable rate," said Andrew Pople, Abbey's retail banking managing director.

He made clear the shake-up was aimed at making it less tempting for borrowers to remortgage away from Abbey, so that those who take out its special offer deals "do not want or need to slip quietly out of the back door".

Cheltenham & Gloucester, Barclays and Alliance & Leicester said they have no plans to drop their standard variable rates.

 Halifax has rebuffed an attack from Brian Davis, the chief executive of Nationwide, over allegedly "misleading" comments about offering better deals than the building society. Responding to a critical two-page letter from Mr Davis, his Halifax counterpart, James Crosby, issued a three-sentence reply. It said: "We will continue to make our case directly to customers and to the media."

webTitle: What's wrong with men working in childcare?

fields.headline: The way we work
fields.standfirst:
There are women serving on warships - so what's wrong with men working in childcare?

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: There are women serving on warships - so what's wrong with men working in childcare?
fields.body:
In the film Meet the Parents, much is made (by the parents) of the fact that Greg, played by Ben Stiller, is a male nurse. He faces the usual jokes and innuendo. But what is most striking is that the term "male nurse" is still in use at all. True, there are very few men in nursing. But I can't recall someone being described as a female doctor, lawyer, engineer - or even "female soldier". It's a sign of how men in caring professions continue to be viewed as slightly weird. They are lucky if people simply assume they are gay; if unlucky, that they have darker motives for choosing a caring role.

Men who choose a career caring for children are the ones who face the highest obstacles. At a nursery attended by my oldest son, the good news was that there was a male member of staff. The bad news was that many parents were put off by this. Many insisted that their children's nappies were not changed by him. Think that through just for a moment, and imagine how it made him feel. He has moved on to other things now.

Just one in a hundred nursery nurses are male. Early schooling is also - increasingly - a female- dominated zone: just 3% of nursery teachers and 17% of primary school teachers are men, with the lower years even more skewed along gender lines.

The only two men on an infant school course at a central London college say they have been openly accused of being gay ("even by my mum's friends," says one), "perverts" and/or not up to a "proper" job.

Does it matter? Isn't childcare women's work anyway? Yes and no. The gender gap in care matters hugely. It blocks men from a growing part of the labour market. And it almost certainly holds wages down in the caring professions. But the real price will be paid in years to come, because the apartheid of the childcare professions is based on outdated, self-fulfilling assumptions about gender roles. It risks condemning another generation to a life of gender inequality. We lament the fact that men do not do their fair share of unpaid work, then put our sons into institutions which, being female-staffed, ram home the message that caring is women's work.

Why is an 18-year-old woman with no children seen, intrinsically, as a better carer than a man who has raised three? We have progressively and successfully abolished the myths that barred women from certain professions, including the military. Women are now on warships and in the cockpits of fighter planes. It is time to drop the similarly short-sighted prejudices about men's ability to care, to cuddle, to teach, to play. We've had GI Jane; it's time for Barbie Bill.

What, then, is to be done? The national childcare commission, which produced its excellent report recently, records gender disparities but has little to offer in terms of remedies. A few symbolic gestures from the government would help (how about a Male Carer of the Year award?). The training bodies for caring professions need to adopt a more proactive approach to attracting men - or at the very least, to not repelling them. And individual institutions need to put in place strict non-discrimination policies.

But it may be that, given the size of the mountain, more drastic action is required. We know that men are put off by the low salaries and that many are unable to take the time to undergo training courses, because they are more likely to be the primary breadwinner in their household. Perhaps we should offer men who want to train as childcarers an additional financial incentive. We offer science and maths teacher trainees £1,000 bursaries. Why not male childcare trainees? Of course, it should not be necessary. But in the real world, right now, it might be the key to kick-starting the process of getting more men in the nursery, in the same way that women-only shortlists kick-started the process of getting more women into parliament.

Above all, though, a broader shift in attitudes is required if men are to feel comfortable choosing a caring job. One of the infant school trainees, after recounting endless tales of stereotyping and innuendo, said: "It is incredibly upsetting. You just try not to think about it and get on with the job. Because I think it is the most important job in the world."

fields.headline: Dennis Oppenheim
fields.standfirst:
Irish Museum of Modern Art
Dublin
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Irish Museum of Modern Art
Dublin
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Thanks to foot and mouth disease, you have to walk over antiseptic-drenched matting to enter IMMA, but, once inside, there's fun for all the family in this well-attended event Land & Body, the show from the veteran US conceptualist Dennis Oppenheim.

All the work goes back to the 1960s and early 1970s, when Oppenheim, Smithson, De Maria and others marched out of the galleries and onto big landscapes.

Two VCRs, side by side, riffle through early "documentations" with some hypnotic forces-of-nature stuff (Landslide, 1968), or obscurer polemics such as his female assistant drawing on his back the Pollock satire he is drawing on the wall.

But Attempt to Raise Hell (1974) gets everyone going: a small aluminium man-puppet who, every 100 seconds, headbutts a bell, causing people to jump out of their skins and then laugh in nervous relief.

Theme For A Major Hit (1974) is a room populated by marionettes, each wearing the mask of their creator, and grooving foolishly to some rangy R'n'B from the artist and friends. Weirdly entertaining and deliciously sinister, this is the show's highlight.

Another noisy installation is the provocative Two Right Feet for Sebastian (1970-4), in which two miked-up motorised boots kick the walls, while two metal tubes droop asymmetrically from the ceiling like barometer rods.

Originally, this was a performance in which an amputee swapped his prosthetic leg for a piece of lead tubing, which Oppenheim's bunsen burner slowly melted from under him.

Disappointingly, this retrospective only includes Oppenheim's influential early work, with himself looking svelte in his bum-hugging bell-bottoms. What on earth has he been doing since 1975?

 Until April 22. Details: 00 353 1 6129900.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Man Who Was Thursday

fields.headline: The Man Who Was Thursday
fields.standfirst:
Bridewell
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Bridewell
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
This is a great little piece of theatre. Adapted from GK Chesterton's novel, it tells the story of poet Gabriel Syme, who finds revolution revolting and, after becoming an undercover detective, infiltrates a Europe-wide secret organisation dedicated to the overthrow of society. The seven-strong ruling council take their names from the days of the week; Syme is elected to the group as Thursday.

Attempting to foil their dastardly plans, Syme sets out on a journey during which it becomes apparent that, like him, his fellow anarchists are not always what they appear. But the question that looms largest is the identity of the elusive, terrifying Sunday.

This surreal scenario is, in Ben Harrison's clever production, cunningly played both as tragedy and farce, with the actors called to switch between the two with stunning dexterity. One minute they are donning silly beards and disguises, the next their masks are revealed as something more sinister.

As the story spirals to its conclusion the boundaries between dreams and reality become blurred. Sometimes this energetic production, with its cutout trains, hot air balloons and escaping elephants, is a tad wearing, but the inventiveness of the evening is beyond doubt.

And there is always something more serious going on behind the romp. The way in which the protagonists project their fears so vividly that they become a reality is as pertinent today as it was then. The suggestion is that it is not the anarchists who are the real threat, but our own paranoia.

Neil Irish's atmospheric design, with its host of shadowy, sinister cutout figures, sets the tone for 90 frenzied minutes during which the audience, like Syme, has every expectation shaken up. This is small-scale theatre to be sure, but it has big ambitions.

 At Aberystwyth Arts Centre tonight (01970 622882), Miskin Theatre, Darlington (01322 629472) March 14 and touring until March 24. Details: 020-7378 9787.
